HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
$576 Million Reserve Is Set For Cutting Pacific Bell Jobs

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The Pacific Telesis Group said today that it would set aside $576 million and take an additional charge of $89 million to cover the costs of a revamping at Pacific Bell that will eliminate 10,000 positions by the end of 1997.
The cuts at Pacific Bell, its regional telephone operating subsidiary, are in line with earlier projections by the company. The plan calls for 3,000 of the job reductions to come this year. 
 The revamping, analysts said, follows similar moves by other regional Bell companies aimed at becoming more competitive and taking advantage of technologies that have reduced work force requirements.
"All the phone companies have been letting people go to become more competitive," Daniel P. Rheingold, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
The $576 million reserve will cover future expenses associated with the revamping and will reduce fourth-quarter earnings by $1.58 a share, Pacific Telesis said. In the third quarter, the company had earnings of $323 million, or 77 cents a share, so the charge is expected to result in a loss for the fourth quarter.
Pacific Telesis previously announced that it would have a loss for the year as a result of the adoption of various new accounting standards.
Investors were not concerned by the one-time charges against fourth-quarter earnings, analysts said, adding that the cuts had been expected. Shares of Pacific Telesis rose 62.5 cents today, to $54.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Customers tell us we need to lower prices and move more quickly to meet their needs," Philip J. Quigley, Pacific Bell's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "With tough new competition, the continuing slow state economy and our customers telling us where we need to be, we are making dramatic and necessary changes now."
Mr. Quigley noted that the company announced in January 1990 that it would reduce its work force of 61,500 employees by 11,000 by the end of 1994. The work force "is now down about 9,500, so we're on track," he said.
The company is also reducing management jobs, deferring management salary increases and requiring managers to contribute to their health plans beginning in 1995.
Mr. Quigley said the revamping of Pacific Bell's business began after a group of managers were asked to design a telephone company. The managers came up with Infotel, a unit in Newhall, Calif., which now serves about 35,000 customers.
"Using only existing systems and transmission and switching facilities, they created the fastest, most effective and least expensive ways of serving customers because they weren't encumbered with old processes," he said. "Infotel demonstrated to us what was possible if we implemented the process changes they pioneered."
 Mr. Rheingold of Merrill Lynch said: "The new equipment doesn't require as many people to operate. They've got room for efficiency gains, and they're acting on that." He noted that GTE recently announced it would cut 514 jobs in California.
But local consumer advocates criticized the job cuts.
"There's been a whole lot of hoopla lately from Pacific Telesis and the other phone companies about the information superhighway and all the wonderful high-paying jobs it's going to bring to California," said Audrie Krause, executive director of Toward Utility Rate Normalization. "Laying off 10,000 people will just contribute further to the economic problems in California and probably result in service a little bit worse than it is now."
Pacific Telesis said the $89 million charge was a result of one-time factors, including $29 million in a refund to customers of cellular research and development costs and an additional $24 million related to the pending spinoff of the Pacific Telesis wireless companies.

HEADLINE: Ex-G.O.P. Leader Sentenced For Taking Bribe to Aid a Bill

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Richard Foley, the former chairman of the state's Republican Party, was sentenced today to 40 months in prison and fined $25,000 for taking a bribe to influence votes in the state legislature on a banking bill in 1989.
He was ordered to begin serving his sentence on Jan. 31.
Judge T. F. Gilroy Daly of Federal District Court said he would recommend that Mr. Foley be sent to a Federal prison camp at Fort Dix, N.J. 
 Mr. Foley, a former state representative, cried as he apologized to family and friends, saying: "The pain is my pain. Sadness my sadness."
Outside the courtroom, he said: "There are a lot of hurt buckaroos out there, including me."
 
Help for a Banking Bill
 In October, Mr. Foley was convicted of accepting a $25,000 bribe in return for a promise to help get a banking bill through the General Assembly. He was also found guilty of helping conceal the money as consulting fees to help two developers cheat on their taxes.
His lawyer said he would appeal.
There was no testimony that Mr. Foley did anything for the money, only that he promised to.
"This case is not just about $25,000 moving from some corrupt bankers to a corrupt politician," said Assistant United States Attorney Amy Lederer. "Essentially, he sold out the legislature."
In asking for an alternative sentence of community service, Mr. Foley's lawyer, W. Paul Flynn, said the conviction had "destroyed his objective in life forever and that perhaps for him is the ultimate punishment."
"It has ended forever Mr. Foley's political career," Mr. Flynn said.
 
5 Terms in the House
 Mr. Foley served five terms in the House of Representatives and left office last January after deciding not to seek re-election. He is now unemployed.
With his conviction, Mr. Foley joined a long list of Waterbury city officials and their associates, including former Mayor Joseph Santopietro, caught up in corrupt dealings with the former top officers of the failed Security Savings and Loan.
The banking bill saved Fleet Bank, based in Providence, R.I., from having to divest itself of a Connecticut bank, United Bank and Trust.
Fleet faced a divestiture order after merging with New York-based Norstar Bancorp Inc. State law at the time barred non-New England banks from owning a Connecticut bank.
Fleet sought the help of Richard Barbieri, then a top officer of Security Savings and Loan, because he was known to be influential in Republican circles. He had also borrowed money from Fleet and had a $12.5 million loan application pending in April 1989.
When Mr. Barbieri turned to Mr. Foley for help, the lawmaker demanded a $25,000 bribe, Mr. Barbieri testified. He said it was paid without Fleet's knowledge.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Three years ago today, the United States was a week from war with Iraq and still debating whether such a war was morally justified. At the center of that debate was the question of whether economic sanctions were the more humane way to the desired end.
A United Nations resolution authorized the use of force if Saddam Hussein had not withdrawn Iraqi forces from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Give the sanctions more time, was the cry of those opposed to military action. 
 Even today the chief argument by those who considered the Persian Gulf war unjust is that military force was not a "last resort," undertaken only after all alternatives had proved unavailing.
Throughout the 20th century, economic sanctions have been the hope of many who sought an escape from the moral impasse of warfare. "Apply this economic, peaceful, silent, deadly remedy and there will be no need for force," President Woodrow Wilson declared in his ill-fated campaign on behalf of the League of Nations after World War I.
Yet even in Wilson's day, John Foster Dulles opposed broad embargoes, spelling out his opposition in a report by the United States Committee on Economic Sanctions. Mr. Dulles, who became the Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, said sanctions harmed the innocent. His argument haunts discussions of economic sanctions in the case of Iraq and Haiti.
"Although sanctions have surely contributed to malnutrition in Iraq," wrote Mike Moore, the editor of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, in introducing a special November issue on sanctions, "one supposes that Saddam Hussein has never involuntarily missed a meal." The magazine, a monthly, was founded by some of the scientiests who helped develop the atomic bomb and is devoted to preventing nuclear war.
Three years ago many people, including many religious leaders, conveyed a kind of moral innocence about sanctions. Their faith in economic pressure rested less on the historical record or economic and political facts than on their opposition to the alternative, military force. Even with hindsight, only a few have granted that maybe they underestimated Mr. Hussein's indifference to his people's suffering.
But most of the same observers soon realized that sanctions did exactly what they had considered most morally reprehensible about military action: wreak injury on civilians. Sanctions, it turned out, struck more directly at civilians than did smart bombs. Sanctions even seemed to strike at precisely those civilians -- infants, children, women, the elderly -- who were most vulnerable and least responsible for the regime's political or war-making strength.
Most studies of sanctions, of which there are few, focus on their effectiveness, not their morality. One recent study of 104 cases since World War II shows that sanctions succeeded about a third of the time when the goals were modest -- to obtain the release of captives, for example, or to demand respect for human rights.
The study, undertaken by the Institute for International Economics in Washington, shows that the success rate was much lower when the goal of sanctions was a major reversal of another nation's policy, or even the removal of its government. Success in the latter cases was usually linked to covert American action or local rebellions to undermine the government.
After reviewing these findings in The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, two staff members of the Roman Catholic Bishops' Office on International Peace and Justice, Drew Christiansen and Gerard F. Powers, concluded, "We cannot presume that sanctions are an effective alternative to military force."
To mix and modify phrases from the psychologist William James and the military strategist Karl von Clausewitz, sanctions are not so much the moral equivalent of war as they are the continuation of war by other means. So is there need for a theory of just sanctions like the historical theory of a "just war." The country's Roman Catholic bishops tried to sketch something like that in one section of a major document on peacemaking they issued last November.
Referring to the suffering of "innocent people in Serbia, Haiti, Iraq, Cuba and elsewhere, the bishops said that sweeping economic sanctions are justified "only in response to aggression or grave and ongoing injustice" and only with "clear and reasonable conditions set for their removal." Embargoes should always "make provision for the fundamental needs of the civilian populations," the bishops said.
Echoing the language of the "just-war" theory, the bishops said that "the harm caused by sanctions should be proportionate to the good likely to be achieved." Sanctions should "avoid grave and irreversible harm" to civilians and therefore "should be targeted as much as possible against those directly responsible for the injustice."
"The consent to sanctions by substantial portions of the affected population is morally relevant," the bishops advised. In other words, be guided, at least in part, by what black South Africans or poor Haitians are themselves willing to undergo.
These criteria provide little more than a checklist of things to think about. The bishops admit their criteria are "tentative" and urged "much more study, reflection and public debate over the moral dimension of comprehensive sanctions."
None of this is very encouraging for those who dream of a new world order. They might, however, find one glimmer of hope in special issue of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists. That is the impression that so far very little inventiveness and less willpower have gone into devising the kind of "selective sanctions" the bishops prefer, those directed against ruthless leaders and oppressive elites.

CUOMO SEEKING FOURTH TERM
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will seek a fourth term, saying he wants the chance to help New York rebound from a recession that has sapped both the state's economic vitality and the Governor's political popularity. Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine will again be his running mate. Page 1. 

REPUBLICANS SEEK UNITY
New York State Republican leaders say they are confident they can unseat Mr. Cuomo, but their party remains disunited. At last county, 12 men were vying for the party's nomination. Page 29.

DRUG CENTER KILLING CALLED A PAID JOB
The fee was $150 and for that, the police said, two teen-agers agreed to gun down an accountant who had uncovered discrepancies in the books of the Promesa Drug Center in the Bronx. The two have been arrested. Police officials say someone higher up at the drug agency did the hiring. Page 1.

Conceding to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Thomas J. Schwarz resigned as chairman of the Campaign Finance Board, saying he had been heartened by the Mayor's pledge to establish a nonpartisan method for board appointments. Mr. Schwarz's appointment had been one of David N. Dinkins's last acts as Mayor. Page 26.
 
ISRAELI COMMENTS CONDEMNED
Former Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was embroiled in a dispute over remarks he made that seemed to many in Jerusalem to condone an attempted terrorist act by right-wing Jewish extremists in New York City. Page 3.
 
HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES AGAIN AT ISSUE
The newest dispute over horse-drawn carriages: humane society officers are ticketing drivers for charging rates set by an expired law, and the drivers are outraged. Page 27.
 
FELONIES DOWN DURING GUNS EXCHANGE
During the 16-day guns-for-gifts exchange that collected 1,502 firearms in a Washington Heights police precinct, armed felonies there dropped substantially, the police said. Page 27.

HEADLINE: Fred Scribner Jr., 86, Treasury Aide to Eisenhower

 BODY:
Fred C. Scribner Jr., an Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration who held positions in the Republican Party and in his home state of Maine and in Washington, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Portland, Me. He was 86 and lived in Falmouth, a town near Portland.
The cause was a heart attack, said Robert N. Barnes, a funeral director. 
 Mr. Scribner's political and legal career spanned more than six decades. After rising to national committeeman from Maine, he went to Washington in 1955 to become general counsel to the Treasury Department. He stayed in the department through Dwight D. Eisenhower's second term and was appointed Under Secretary in 1957.
 
Work on Political Matters
 In the Treasury, Mr. Scribner supervised the Internal Revenue Service and United States Coast Guard, but his responsibilities went beyond his official duties. He became involved in policy matters, working on problems like the recession, the handling of the national debt and rising Government and military costs.
Mr. Scribner was also a member of the National Security Council from 1959 to 1961. In February 1961, he criticized John F. Kennedy's foreign policy, accusing the newly elected President of playing on fears of a missile gap that would leave the United States behind the Soviet Union.
"It could conceivably lead an emboldened aggressor to touch off a world holocaust through miscalculation of our retaliatory strength," he said. "Somehow the world must win the time it needs to achieve a just and lasting peace, even though this may require half a century or more."
Mr. Scribner was born in Bath, Me., in 1908. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1930 and from Harvard Law School in 1933.
He began to practice law after Harvard and, except for his years in Washington, was a partner in Pierce, Atwood, Scribner, Allen, Smith & Lancaster in Portland until his death, his family said.
Mr. Scribner's interest in politics originated in 1936 when even Franklin D. Roosevelt was unable to take Maine away from the Republicans. In Maine, Mr. Scribner was associated with "Old Guard" Republicanism, rather than with the more liberal elements in the party.
 
A Nixon Strategist in '60
 In 1960, he was a top strategist in Richard M. Nixon's campaign against Kennedy and helped to arrange the first-ever televised Presidential debates.
Mr. Scribner's wife of 58 years, Barbara, died a few days before him. Her funeral was held Wednesday afternoon, just hours after her husband's death.
Mr. Scribner is survived by a sister, Frances, of St. Davids, Pa.; three sons, Fred C. 3d, of Cambridge, Mass., Curtis M., of Yarmouth, Me., and Charles D., of Portland, and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: New York Area Jobless Rate Higher

 BODY:
Even as the rest of the country reported the lowest jobless rate in three years, Government figures released yesterday showed that the number of unemployed in New Jersey went up by nearly 1 percent in December while the unemployment rates in New York and New York City rose slightly.
The monthly jobless rate continued to fluctuate more widely in New Jersey, rising to 7.1 percent of the work force last month, from 6.2 percent, according to seasonally adjusted figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 Unemployment figures in New York State and New York City remained almost unchanged. The state's seasonally adjusted jobless rate rose to 7.6 percent last month from the 7.5 percent recorded in November.
The city, meanwhile, continued to be much worse off, with 10.5 percent unemployed in December, up from 10.3 in November.
By comparison, the country's December jobless rate was 6.4 percent, the lowest since January 1991.
The Goverment reports monthly figures for Connecticut at another time
Despite increases in December, annual jobless rates for 1993 seemed to signal a slow -- and often fitful -- recovery for the New York region, which was among the first in the nation to slide into a recession.
New Jersey's unemployment rate for 1993 averaged 7.4 percent, down from 8.4 percent in the previous year. What is more, though its jobless rate swung greatly in 1993, the fourth quarter averaged 6.6 percent.
"New Jersey has been really, really volatile," said Susan Shank, a senior economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington. "It started the year at 9 percent. But there's been clearly a downward trend during 1993."
New York State showed a similar annual improvement as its jobless rate went down to 7.7 percent in 1993 from 8.5 percent in 1992. New York City reported a dip to 10.2 percent in 1993 from 10.8 percent in 1992.
For December, as the region lagged behind the rest of the country moving into economic recovery, New York was second to California with a jobless rate of 8.7 percent. Out of 11 major industrialized states, Michigan was third with 7.5, followed by New Jersey.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Mark Trading From Its Five-Month Peak

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower yesterday, tumbling from a five-month high against the German mark as modest December employment figures sent interest rates in Wall Street's credit markets sharply lower.
The dollar also lost ground in its recent rise against the Japanese yen. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.7278 marks, from 1.7453 marks on Thursday. It also slipped to 111.90 yen from 112.60 yen.
Traders attributed the dollar's losses to a lukewarm report about the American labor market.
The report, issued by the Labor Department, showed the nation's unemployment rate fell to 6.4 percent in December from the previous 6.5 percent, but it also said nonfarm payrolls grew by 183,000 in the month. Economists had predicted brisker jobs growth. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose by one and a half points in reaction to the report, sending its yield sharply lower.
 
Yen Slide a Factor
 In addition to the jobs report, the dollar was weighed down by reports this week that the United States was worried over its rise against the yen and by stubbornly high German interest rates.
"It's been a fairly bad week for the dollar in terms of news," said John Rothfield, international economist at First National Bank of Chicago.
He cited a series of statements by Treasury officials voicing concern about the dollar's rise against the yen. The market interpreted comment by Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and others to mean that the Government may act to stop the dollar from climbing too high.
A decision Thursday by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, to leave key interest rates steady also put pressure on the dollar, Mr. Rothfield said. The market is awaiting cuts in currently high German interest rates, which attract investors to certain mark-based investments at the expense of the dollar.
The Treasury comments and the Bundesbank decision did not cause large dollar sales when they were reported. However, by the end of the week, they encouraged caution among some dealers who had bet the dollar would rise quickly.
Meanwhile, the British pound closed in New York at $1.4935, up from $1.4815 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4669 Swiss francs, down from 1.4815; $1.3193 (Canadian), down from $1.3213 (Canadian); 5.8828 French francs, down from 5.9250, and 1,690 Italian lire, up from 1,685.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Are Down In Reaction to Job Figures

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Prices of inflation-sensitive precious metals fell yesterday in reaction to the smaller-than-expected pace of job creation in December, an indication that the economy is not overheating.
"I think a lot of cages were rattled by that employment report," said Bernard Savaiko, a metals analyst at Paine Webber. 
 The 183,000 new jobs created in December was anemic relative to most analysts' expectations. Prices for silver, copper and platinum -- all metals used by industry -- were down because a weaker economy is likely to mean less industrial demand.
The rebounding bond market also stole investor interest from the precious metals market, with gold for February delivery falling $2.90, to $387.20 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Mr. Savaiko said gold prices might breach a key level of support at $384 an ounce on Monday when the market reopened; another analyst agreed that a slip below $384 raised questions about gold's long-term prospects but said that "gold tends to look real bad when it's about to make a bottom."
 
Silver Down 11.2 Cents
 Also at the Comex, March silver dropped 11.2 cents, to $5.025 an ounce, and March copper sank 1.25 cents, to 78.60 cents a pound. April platinum lost $2.50, to $389 an ounce, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The cold weather gripping the northern tier of the country pushed up prices of natural gas and heating oil, as well as orange juice prices.
While February heating oil advanced 0.52 cent, to 48.17 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for February delivery sank 10 cents, to $15.32 a barrel, ending a four-day rally.
Oil prices have bounced back from five-year lows in the last two weeks, edging up $1.50 a barrel. But analysts said ample supplies and no sure signs that pumping would be curtailed might limit any further advances.
February unleaded gasoline edged up 0.17 cent, to 43.82 cents a gallon, and February natural gas rose 6.2 cents, to $2.156 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Consumers Again Increase Credit Buying

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Consumers increased their buying on credit for a sixth straight month in November, although not quite as robustly as in October, the Federal Reserve Board said today,
Consumer credit outstanding increased by a seasonally adjusted $6.88 billion in November at a 10.6 percent annual rate, compared with a rise of $7.66 billion at a 12 percent annual rate in October.
So far during the first 11 months of 1993, the only month in which consumer credit contracted was in May, when it declined by $752 million. Increases in each of the other 10 months underline the rebound in spending last year after a period of restraint after the 1990-91 recession.
In November, consumers took out another $2.98 billion of loans to buy new cars. That was down from October's increase of $3.95 billion in auto credit but still reflected healthy demand for new cars.
Credit-card buying in November increased by $2.15 billion, also down from October's increase of $3.42 billion but still a healthy rate of increase.
The steady pickup in consumer credit use is significant for the economy's expansion because two-thirds of national economic activity is fueled by consumer purchases of goods and services.
Many economists expect national output to expand at a 5 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1993 before easing back to about a 3 percent growth rate in the first half of this year.
Other credit, which includes consumer bank loans like those for boats or trailers but not real estate mortgages, jumped by $1.76 billion in November.

HEADLINE: New Year Tune-Up for Retirement Funds

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
The new year compels many people to re-evaluate their investments, and this month may be a good time to make some adjustments.
Among the five mutual fund experts who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times in July, most have decided to rejigger their portfolios after sitting tight for six months. 
 Their reasons are varied -- shedding laggards, taking profits, responding to research, assessing opportunities abroad and betting on an economic surge at home. While far from providing a consensus, they offer some insight to investors wondering what to do in 1994. Generally speaking, investing abroad continues to be a priority, and cyclical stocks that rise and fall with the economy look attractive. But opinion is split on small stocks.
Realigning portfolios yearly is a good idea, finance professionals say, because a strong performance in one area could quickly lead to an ill-advised concentration. Sheldon Jacobs, the editor of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y., saw that happen last year to his investment in emerging markets, which soared. Because of that runup, he is shedding some assets there.
 Foreign funds remain appealing, however. Mr. Jacobs recommends reinvesting part of the proceeds from the emerging markets in another foreign fund, albeit a European one, trimming his foreign exposure slightly, to about 23 percent. A second fund picker, Harold Evensky, who is an investment adviser with Evensky, Brown & Katz, in Coral Gables, Fla., is increasing his allotment for foreign equities to 20 percent from 15 percent. (He also has 5 percent in Sogen International, which invests globally, and 5 percent in foreign bonds.) Factoring in growth in recent months, the three other advisers have more than 20 percent invested in global or foreign funds as well.
 In performance, Mr. Jacobs continues to lead the five fund experts, sailing on several red-hot international funds. His portfolio has gained 18.32 percent since its inception, and surged 10.33 percent in the fourth quarter. All but one of the experts have beaten the market. Since tracking began on July 7, their portfolios have risen an average of 10.22 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index has gained 6.7 percent in the period.
 The portfolio performance, tracked quarterly by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in Summit, N.J., does not include taxes, transaction charges or sales charges. The latter charges, also called loads, would especially crimp the returns of the one portfolio that has lagged behind the S.& P. 500, returning 6.4 percent. That portfolio, designed for socially responsible investors, was compiled by Jack A. Brill, an investment adviser in San Diego, and almost all those funds have loads.
The 5 experts can choose up to 10 funds that are open to new investors, and can shift money quarterly, although the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.
 Mr. Jacobs describes his strategy as "taking money out of the winners, on the theory that their performance would be difficult to repeat, and putting it into market sectors that haven't been so strong."
He recommends selling enough of Fidelity Emerging Markets, which returned an extraordinary 81.8 percent in 1993, and T. Rowe Price New Asia, which gained 78.8 percent, to reduce their weighting to 5 percent each.
Half the proceeds go to Invesco European. "Europe is a little behind on the economic curve and hasn't had the run-up the emerging markets have had," Mr. Jacobs said. The balance goes to Neuberger & Berman Guardian, a growth-and-income fund, an average performer in 1993.
 The possibility of a correction concerns Eric Kobren, president of Insight Management and the editor of Fidelity Insight, in Wellesley, Mass. He is dumping the Fidelity Small Cap Stock Fund from his all-Fidelity portfolio. "If the market corrects itself, small-company funds are more likely to bear the brunt of the decline than larger-cap stocks and certainly industrials, which are our focus now," he explained.
 His main goal? "Inflation-proofing the portfolio in the face of an improving economy, particularly in the industrial sector," he said.
Therefore, he is plowing the proceeds from the small stock fund into Fidelity Capital Appreciation, which should benefit from strengthening commodity prices and its deep cyclical stocks. As the economy expands this year, cyclicals are expected to continue their strong performance of 1993.
Fidelity Value, Mr. Kobren's largest holding, already focuses on economically sensitive areas like basic industries, durable goods and industrial equipment manufacturers. That fund should do well as the economy strengthens, he said, even though its year-end performance was dampened by a slide in its energy stocks.
A more fundamental strategy shift comes from Mr. Evensky, who took an opportunity to adjust all his fund allocations. Although not dissatisfied with any of his original choices, Mr. Evensky is leaning toward smaller stocks now.
He attributed this change of heart to the growing currency placed on research by two University of Chicago professors, Eugene Fama and Kenneth French. They have concluded that stocks of small companies with low ratios of book value to market value are better performers over time than stocks that are extremely volatile, traditionally believed to be the best bets.
Mr. Evensky is adding to his stake in the Meridian Fund, a small-company fund with a median market capitalization of $580 million, by reducing positions in two large-cap stock funds: Vanguard Index 500 Portfolio and Windsor II. For more international flavor, he made small investments in two emerging markets funds, the Newport Tiger Fund, which carries a 5 percent load, and Pfamco Emerging Markets Portfolio. He also increased T. Rowe Price International's allocation to 15 percent.
Reflecting another change in thinking, Mr. Evensky replaced the Vanguard Limited Term Municipal Bond Fund with the Pimco Foreign Bond Fund, which can hedge against currency risk. While academic research is inconclusive, Mr. Evensky believes that hedging currency risk has a negligible impact when overseas bonds account for only a small part of the portfolio.
 A big disappointment for Mr. Brill has been Pax World, hammered by its position in large-capitalization consumer stocks. He is substituting the Calvert Social Investment: Managed Growth Portfolio, another balanced fund, which lagged in 1993 but has earned about 11 percent annually since its 1982 inception. Calvert holds up well in down markets, he said, and has not lost money in any year.
The two funds from Working Assets have done even worse, but Mr. Brill is hanging on to them. The new manager there has been repositioning the portfolios, he said, adding stocks with earnings momentum.
For the quarter, John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, trailed the group, with a 2 percent gain, mostly because of Vanguard's energy fund, which proved to be an unneeded hedge. "These 'hedge' funds make one look like geniuses or idiots; I'll answer to the latter," he said -- so far.
Still, the portfolio built by Mr. Rekenthaler, who has made no changes in his original picks, has risen a total of 8.12 percent since its inception.

HEADLINE: BANKING;
Assumable Mortgage Is Trying a Comeback

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo

 BODY:
THE assumable fixed-rate mortgage, a relic from the halcyon days before the high inflation of the 1970's and 1980's, is being unearthed and repackaged for home buyers in the low-inflation 1990's.
Such loans -- which allow qualified buyers to take over an owner's mortgage at the same interest rate -- remain uncommon, but are being offered by about 20 lenders across the country. Among the largest is the Barclays American Mortgage Company, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., and has 13 branches. 
 David W. Beal, the president of Barclays Mortgage, said the loans were attractive when interest rates were expected to rise because they could make homes easier to resell. Young home buyers, however, have not really grasped the loans' value, he said, probably because they have only seen interest rates decline.
"Our customers so far have been people in their 40's who had homes in the early 80's and remember what it was like not to be able to sell because interest rates were 15, 16 percent," he said. "They also remember that homes with assumable fixed-rate mortgages had no trouble selling."
Though most adjustable-rate mortgages are assumable, the fixed-rate version virtually disappeared in the early 1980's, when interest rates rose sharply and low-rate loans became unprofitable for banks and investors.
With inflation now low, some lenders again see a market for assumable fixed-rate loans. "It's just getting started," said Mr. Beal, whose company added the product last month.
Lenders generally charge a quarter-point to a half-point more in interest on assumable loans than on standard fixed-rate loans. If interest rates rise above the fixed level, the owner can offer future buyers a mortgage at less than the market rate with no points. A point is a fee by the lender that is equal to 1 percent of the loan.
The loan "is like interest rate insurance," said Joseph J. Mahoney, president of the Abbot Mortgage Company of McLean, Va., which began offering the loans last month. "If interest rates go up, you have made a good play and a tax-deductible play."
Assumable fixed-rate loans are usually for 30 years. Shorter-term ones build equity faster and require large down payments when assumed.
There are several caveats for buyers considering a fixed-rate assumable or anyone who might assume one. Some of today's loans, unlike those of the past, can be assumed only once. People who assume an existing loan should expect to pay a 1 percent assumption fee, the equivalent of an origination fee. They must also meet income and credit standards set by the lender.
Some mortgage analysts doubt that fixed-rate assumables will enjoy a resurgence. They cite a test program in the Detroit area that ended after six months because of a lack of interest.
Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates, a mortgage research firm in Butler, N.J., said that the higher interest rate would probably turn off many home buyers.
"Many of the buyers out there are first-time buyers," he said. "They can only afford the lowest rate they can find."
Mr. Gumbinger added that assumable fixed-rate mortgages might aid sales of homes only if the houses were not moving because of prevailing interest rates, not because of other difficulties, like inflated prices.
"If you have a condo and no one will buy it because it's a condo, no one is going to buy it -- assumable mortgage or not," he said.

HEADLINE: A New Opening in North Korea

 BODY:
Encouraging signs emerged this week that the Clinton Administration's diplomacy is having the desired effect on North Korea. The North has agreed to allow the resumption of regular international inspections of all seven of its declared nuclear sites. And it has reportedly canceled the sale of its Rodong missile to Iran. That is a relief to Israel, which would be within range of such a missile.
True, North Korea has not yet agreed to admit inspectors to two suspected but undeclared nuclear sites. But this initial agreement, if carried out, will go a long way toward easing immediate fears about the North's nuclear program. And it has set the stage for a package deal that could put more lasting curbs on proliferation on the Korean Peninsula. 
 Critics demean the importance of the new agreement, saying that North Korea has just stalled since March, when it announced it was suspending its participation in the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. But the North did nothing to divert more spent nuclear fuel into bomb-making in the interim. To remove such material, it would have had to shut down its reactors. It has not done so, according to U.S. intelligence.
An inspection can verify that, and much more. Inspectors will be on the scene when the fuel rods in one of North Korea's reactors are replaced in the coming months. Their presence would deter any diversion of nuclear material for use in weapons. Inspection of the reactor's core could also help determine whether or not such a diversion took place in 1989, before international inspections were instituted. The possibility of such diversion led some intelligence analysts to conclude that the North may have enough nuclear material for as many as two bombs.
Inspections that go beyond these regular visits will be a major subject for future high-level negotiations. Special inspections of the North's two suspected nuclear waste sites and other steps may be needed, for example, to ascertain how much nuclear material, if any, was diverted in 1989.
Those negotiations will take place once North Korea finishes working out the details of regular inspections with the International Atomic Energy Agency and reopens talks with South Korea on establishing a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula.
In preparation for those talks, President Clinton needs to prepare a package of incentives, including diplomatic recognition, military assurances and economic ties, to coax North Korea into opening up still more, in order to assure the world that it is not making nuclear arms.
Nuclear diplomacy is making real headway. It needs a package of incentives, and patience, to give it a chance to succeed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Loud Silence on Racism

BYLINE: By Roger Wilkins; Roger Wilkins is professor of history at George Mason University.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Khalid Abdul Muhammad of the Nation of Islam, speaking at Kean College in Union, N.J., on Nov. 29, talked of "Columbia Jew-niversity" and "Jew York City" and suggested that German Jews brought the Holocaust upon themselves. He also took aim at whites generally, the Pope, homosexuals and the blind and disabled.
No blacks on the faculty and staff condemned the contents of the speech, according to news reports. One faculty member sidestepped issues raised by the talk and lashed out at racism on the campus, to which he believed Jewish faculty members had contributed. 
 In avoiding swift and forceful condemnation of Mr. Muhammad's bilious diatribe, the black faculty members failed their students, failed their obligations as members of a civilized community and failed to uphold the best traditions of the black struggle.
While I have never been to Kean College, I have no reason to doubt allegations that black adults on the campus have encountered racial problems. Despite splendid efforts on many campuses to change behavior, populations and curriculums, racism remains alive and extremely hurtful in academia. But this is exactly why black staff and faculty members must display exemplary moral behavior. It is not just the black adults on campus who are harmed by racism; it is, primarily and most distressingly, the students -- students of all colors and backgrounds. The black adults have important lessons to teach all students, in the classrooms and outside.
Most white, Hispanic, Asian and American Indian students get their first sustained exposure to a black adult when they come into our classroom. No matter what subject we teach, our personas can be powerful countervailing lessons to the racist notions that nonblack students bring from their neighborhoods and homes.
Black students have come already hurt by a disdainful culture into an academic atmosphere of profound ambivalence. Despite the strongest efforts of the best-intentioned institutions, the atmosphere at predominantly white colleges and universities shrieks, "This is a white space that you occupy only at our sufferance!" Not too long ago, a black student in Oklahoma told me, "White people give me looks that say, 'What are you doing here?' " I asked him when that happened. "Every time I walk into a room," he replied.
One of our most important jobs as black staff and faculty is to help these young people, whose sense of themselves is precarious, learn that though it will be psychically and often economically difficult, they can become strong, effective and fulfilled citizens as so many of the most honorable African-Americans have been over the centuries.
Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth, Mary McLeod Bethune, W. E. B. DuBois, Fannie Lou Hamer, Martin Luther King Jr. and Thurgood Marshall were among those who created our best traditions. Their lives teach us that we blacks are much more than simply the sum of our injuries and grievances.
One of the first tasks black faculty members have in passing on those lessons is to separate, to the greatest degree possible, our teaching from the anger and pain our own institutional struggles have inflicted on us. We have to be able to manage our anger and pain and to use them constructively in order to teach our students how to do it after we are gone.
Our heroes did that. Though some of them worked during slavery and others during deepest segregation, they were not whiners or scapegoaters. Some of the most courageous and effective allies many had were Jews. They had other white allies as well -- some of them Catholic, blind, lesbian or gay. Our great leaders were not immune to pain or anger, but they were not racists.
It is not weakness to control your justifiable rage, to resist scapegoating, to deal with people as individuals and to use humane values to advance our cause. On the contrary, it is weak to be vile and stupid and anti-Semitic and homophobic and racist. Sometimes it takes strength for teachers to say such things to students when a truly wicked and destructive message has just pandered to their deepest injuries and insecurities.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

HEADLINE: U.S. and France Resolve Dispute on NATO Talks

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Three days before the NATO summit meeting, the United States and France have agreed to paper over their differences over Western military involvement in Bosnia and Herzegovina in a last-ditch effort to avoid an embarrassing rift at the meeting in Brussels.
In recent days, senior French officials have insisted that the war in Bosnia be at the top of the agenda when the 16 NATO heads of state come together next week, and have publicly announced that France would call on the United States to join Europe in a more direct military intervention in Bosnia. 
 The Clinton Administration, by contrast, is distressed that the fighting in Bosnia, particularly the intensification of Serbian shelling of civilian targets in the capital of Sarajevo in recent days, could dominate the summit and overshadow the effort to redefine NATO's mission for the post-Cold War era.
 
A Danger to Credibility
 In preparatory meetings in Washington and at NATO headquarters in recent days, senior Administration officials said that a focus on Bosnia would rob the summit meeting of any credibility by highlighting the inability of the West to deal with a nearly two-year-old war in the heart of Europe that has claimed 200,000 lives and left two million people homeless.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters today that although the Bosnian war will be discussed at the meeting, its main focus will be on the American proposal to extend some NATO privileges -- although not membership -- to the countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
The purpose of the meeting is "to discuss the future of NATO, to discuss how NATO would reach out to the east, to the newly emerging democracies," Mr. Christopher said. He called the American proposal, known as "Partnership for Peace," the "centerpiece" of the summit.
Bosnia, Mr. Christopher added, "will come up."
But the degree of Washington's concern was in evidence on Thursday when the United States, stunned by published remarks by French Cabinet officials earlier this week, warned France not to turn the NATO meeting into a showcase for Western policy on Bosnia.
Mr. Christopher, Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, and Stephen Oxman, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, all telephoned French officials to protest French comments that appeared to criticize the United States for not helping more to relieve Serbian pressure on besieged Muslim enclaves, senior Administration and French officials said today.
"At the last moment the French tried to pre-empt the summit, and we wanted to know what they were trying to achieve," a senior State Department official said. "Did they want better language in a summit declaration? Did they want a separate declaration? Or did they want Bosnia to overshadow other issues?"
A senior French official, reached by telephone in Paris, said, "The United States feared we were going to shift the focus of the summit to Bosnia and ruin the summit and ask them in front of all the allies to send troops to Bosnia to help protect the Muslim safe areas. What we said is that we cannot avoid the real world and that we had to issue a strong statement about Bosnia, but that we had no intention of sabotaging the American proposal on NATO."
Mr. Christopher did not confirm the report of a split with France, except to say that he had spoken with Defense Minister Alain Juppe by telephone and that he expected NATO to come up with "a coordinated position."
By this afternoon, both Washington and Paris reported that for the sake of NATO unity, they had agreed on a draft text of the NATO communique on Bosnia. The text was not made public.
Mr. Juppe sent a letter on Thursday to other members of the alliance requesting that the NATO meeting make it clear that the United States firmly backs the latest European peace effort in the Balkans, a senior French Foreign Ministry official said today.
The United States has declined to do so, in part because the plan includes a pledge to the Serbs to work to suspend United Nations economic sanctions if a peace agreement is reached.
The letter also requested a renewed commitment from the United States that it would be prepared to send troops to Bosnia to police and support a peace settlement if one is reached.
The United States has agreed to send troops to help implement an eventual accord, but only if strict -- perhaps impossible -- criteria are met, including a clearly stated time when the policy would be reviewed, a clearly stated "right to terminate" the operation if it went badly and a clear expression of support from the United States Congress.
The effort by the United States to play down the importance of the war in Bosnia is part of the Administration's strategy, announced by Mr. Christopher in November, to focus on big issues such as Russian reform and Middle East peacemaking and to treat crises in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti as bothersome regional issues with little or no importance for America's national interests.
In the face of European opposition, the United States has abandoned its proposals to arm the Bosnian Muslims and turn the war into what Mr. Clinton had called "a fair fight." Mr. Clinton acknowledged in an interview with editorial writers on Tuesday that this initiative was "a dead letter."
But in the letter, Mr. Juppe urged the allies to declare at the summit meeting that NATO is prepared to intervene to back United Nations peacekeepers where necessary. French officials said that he was referring to the situations in the six Bosnian cities and towns that were supposed to become security zones protected by the United Nations under a Security Council resolution approved last June. Only two of them, Zepa and Srebrenica, have received effective protection.
 
Backing for U.N. Measures
 "The countries of the Atlantic alliance must declare themselves ready to apply U.N. resolutions, which means reinforcing ground troops and extending real protection to security zones," Mr. Juppe said today.
Mr. Juppe also wants the potential threat of NATO air strikes reiterated at the summit. The United Nations has voted to allow air strikes if United Nations peacekeepers are attacked or if a no-flights zone over Bosnia is not respected, and last August NATO vowed to prevent the "strangulation" of Sarajevo with air strikes if necessary.
France's initiative reflects growing concern over its 6,000 soldiers in Bosnia and Croatia, the largest single contingent in the 30,000-strong United Nations peacekeeping force. Five French soldiers were wounded in the Sarajevo area during intense fighting Thursday.
The head of NATO said today that he expected that Mr. Clinton and other leaders would reiterate the alliance's willingness to bomb Serbian military targets in Bosnia and Herzegovina if they did not stop the siege of Sarajevo.
But in a telephone interview with American correspondents, the official, Manfred Worner, said that there had been no recent discussions between the United Nations and the alliance about actually launching air strikes.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an agreement between the United States and France on Western involvement in Bosnia and Herzegovina misidentified Alain Juppe. He is France's Foreign Minister, not the Defense Minister.

HEADLINE: New Pressures on the University

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Clark Kerr, who presided over the University of California during a period of rapid growth a generation ago, once wisecracked that a university is "a series of individual faculty entrepreneurs held together by a common grievance over parking." The major universities, he went on to say, had grown so rapidly and penetrated so many areas of American life that they should be called "multiversities." His own institution had more employees than I.B.M. (this was in 1963), conducted its business in more than 100 separate locations and had become, among other things, the world's leading supplier of laboratory mice.
One could chortle approvingly then because there seemed no reason to limit the growth of the modern university. The money was there. The frequent flutter of Nobel Prizes certified the importance of what was being done. And the students -- overwhelmingly white, middle-class and young -- were well suited to apprentice themselves to the masters, who were generally white, middle-class and middle-aged. 
 Today, an after-dinner line like Mr. Kerr's would inspire only a rueful smile. The perception is widespread now that the American university, and perhaps higher education as a whole, has not just grown but that it is overgrown, indeed become so bloated and muddled that it has all but lost its way.
The question is no longer whether to retract, consolidate, restructure and adapt in order to bear down on the basic mission of higher education -- preparing students to take part in their civilization -- but is whether these reforms can be accomplished from within or must be imposed from without. The answer to the question will be determined in large part by the outcome of a struggle -- some call it a shootout -- now in progress around the country between administrations and faculties.
 
Tight Money Drives the Struggle
 The pressures for change begin with tight money. Last year Yale University, with its traditional revenue streams choked by the poor economy, ran a deficit of $15.5 million and still needs about $1 billion in additional money for vital repairs to its crumbling physical plant. Since 1991 the California State Legislature has cut the budget of the University of California at Berkeley by $70 million, or 18.8 percent. Over the last four years the City University of New York, known as CUNY, the nation's largest urban university, has been slashed $200 million, or 20 percent.
On top of these strictures comes the rise of the New Student who is much more often nonwhite, relatively old, frequently part time, possibly a parent and determinedly job-oriented. These students cost more to educate than their predecessors because they frequently require remedial work, special language courses and financial aid to help with soaring tuition bills.
Forty percent of the current entering students at CUNY are black or Hispanic and trace their ancestry to the Caribbean. Nationwide, 43 percent of today's students are over 25, and 300,000 of them are over 50. At Portland State University, a state-assisted urban school in Oregon, the average age is 28 and only 1 percent of the student body lives in dorms. In addition, enrollment is expected to swell enormously with no prospect of increased revenue in the years ahead. CUNY, for example, anticipates a rise in its student population from 208,000 at present to a quarter-million by the end of the century.
Finally, critics of today's institutions of higher learning charge that their tuitions have risen out of sight, that new technologies are not being utilized and that colleges and universities are often engaged in research that is of marginal importance and is being done at the expense of teaching.
College and university administrators are generally much more focused than are faculty members on these institutional problems and pressures, not only because that is their field of specialization but because, unlike tenured professors, they can lose their jobs if they don't fix what's broken.
Last fall George E. Rupp, the new president of Columbia University, spoke with alarm of his discovery that Columbia had 123 separate centers and laboratories. "There simply must be a great deal of overlap," he said, promising to consolidate certain functions of the Business School with the Economics Department, and of the School of Public Health with Arts and Sciences. Like many leaders of major research universities, President Rupp also believes that educational emphasis must be shifted away from postgraduate to undergraduate education -- a hot issue around the country.
The new president of Yale University, Richard C. Levin, takes another approach to consolidating. "You can't be good at everything," he said in an interview. "We don't have to deal with every subspecialty in every field. Instead, we can create centers of excellence." And Harvard's president, Neil Rudenstine, directly contradicting Clark Kerr's memorable remark, said recently: "We need more emphasis on the university and less on the multiversity."
While today's college and university leaders have a clear understanding of their problems and needs, they actually lack the power to effect much change. Unlike the chiefs of General Motors and I.B.M., they cannot pare down and consolidate by handing out pink slips. About 70 percent of most college and university faculties are protected by tenure. And it is this entrenched professoriate, and not the administrators, that holds the power.
Some university presidents have been either bold or foolhardy enough in recent months to act as if they were running General Motors or I.B.M., and have paid dearly for the presumption. In 1992 Benno C. Schmidt Jr., then president of Yale, announced his intention to close a huge budget gap by eliminating nearly 11 percent of the faculty of arts and sciences and by cutting programs and departments. That ignited a faculty revolt that soon led to his departure.
Last year Thomas Day, the president of San Diego State University, announced a plan to offset a severe cut in revenue from the state by closing nine academic departments and terminating more than 100 tenured professors. A faculty rebellion immediately erupted, but Mr. Day was spared a bitter, last-ditch struggle when the State Legislature authorized an increase in student fees and a buyout for senior faculty members that attracted more than 100 takers. These unsystematic departures have created dislocations, but the budget is now in balance. The lesson, president Day said, is: "It's not your university; it's the faculty's university."
 
No-Confidence Votes by Faculty
 W. Ann Reynolds, the chancellor of CUNY, proposed to eliminate about 200 baccalaureate and associate-degree programs, saying they were duplicative or had small enrollments. A university-wide faculty committee condemned her for a "pattern of duplicity," and later six campus faculties, including those of Brooklyn College and Queens College, slapped her with votes of no confidence. By vigorous backpedaling, Chancellor Reynolds appears to have mollified many of her critics, but the outcome of her efforts is still in doubt.
Gerhard Casper, president of Stanford University, explains the politics of academia this way: "Many people think of universities as hierarchical because they have a president with a fancy title, and three or four levels of professors, but they are not hierarchical. Power comes from the bottom up. The most important decisions to be made are those concerning admissions, curriculum and faculty appointments, and these are areas where the university president has almost no power. In most circumstances, I'm the man with the pail and the broom."
University presidents are not totally without clout, of course. "I have the power of the pulpit," said President Casper. And President Rupp of Columbia believes that administrative finesse helps. There will be faculty resistance to the shift of emphasis to undergraduate education if it is considered "a devaluation of research and scholarship," he said. "If it is perceived as restoration of a balance, it will be welcomed."
He may be right. But last summer, when the Illinois Board of Higher Education urged a shift of emphasis from research to teaching, faculty members throughout the state were hostile. Mitchell Vogel, president of the University Professionals of Illinois, dismissed the recommendation and snapped that the board would have been better advised to study "administrative bloat."
Linda Ray Pratt, president of the American Association of University Professors, observed that, "Naturally, faculties are not very eager to participate in losing their jobs." Ernst Benjamin, general secretary of the A.A.U.P., commented that faculty members were "indeed conservative when asked to approve a consolidation that they see as a threat to academic integrity." Mr. Benjamin said that in the 15 years between 1975 and 1990, full-time faculty increased by only 6 percent whereas administrative positions went up by 45 percent. "That's why many faculty members would like to see the administration reduced in size before academic programs are cut," he said.
Thomas Day, the San Diego State president who went through a bruising fight with his faculty last year, contends that accusations of administrative bloat are frequently irresponsible. "Some people argue," he said, "if you want to cut 25 percent of the faculty then cut 25 percent of the administration. But you can't do that. In the administration, you have one president, four vice presidents and eight deans. Do you want to cut the dean of arts and sciences? The director of student health? Or the director of security? When you stop and think about it, you realize it isn't that simple."
Other administrators suggest that faculty members are also too often unreasonably rigid when asked to take fresh approaches to benefit new students in the courses they teach. Last spring, Paul Sherwin, then dean of humanities at the City College of New York, which has a large number of Haitian-American students, proposed that a special introductory course in French be offered for Creole-speaking Haitian-Americans, which would build on their knowledge of a closely related language. "The idea was not picked up, although you would think the French faculty would see this as a way of serving students and reducing costs," said Dean Sherwin, who was recently appointed a vice president for development.
Presidents are generally reluctant to characterize faculty unwillingness to cooperate on the issue of consolidation and restructuring. But some do speak out. Frederick Starr, who has announced his intention to leave Oberlin College in Ohio in June after 11 years, said in an interview: "Faculty, staff and trustees are deeply conservative and resistant to change."
 President Casper of Stanford came close to saying as much: "Accomplishing selective excellence is immensely difficult. You try to close down a library school, for example, and there's resistance. The people who oppose you don't have to make the trade-offs. They can simply say, 'It's a good thing, so why are you trying to get rid of it?' "
Robert Zemsky, a professor of education at the University of Pennsylvania and director of the Institute for Research on Higher Education, sides with presidents on the question of administration bloat. He argues that administrations grew so much because they "have had to hire people to do things --like being student advisers and teaching undergraduates -- that the faculties were no longer interested in doing." Professor Zemsky said, too, that many researchers were hired as professional staff appointments and consequently are listed as administrative personnel.
 
No Financial Incentive for Change
 The reason faculties tend to resist change, he said, is that midcareer and senior professors lack any financial incentive to support it. "They ask themselves, why bother to teach those Philistines in the business school, or adult learners, or people not as well prepared for our courses as in the past?" Professor Zemsky said. "And, they ask, why cooperate with someone who's going to cut the size of my department by 25 percent? I'm outta here in 10 or 11 years, they say, so why should I bother?"
If the faculty community proves unwilling to accept change, said Professor Zemsky, it is sure to be imposed from without. "The without," he said, "are the brute economic realities for private institutions and further cutbacks by city, state and Federal legislatures for the public institutions."
Doubtless there is a need for a cease-fire and give-and-take on both sides. But fundamentally what it comes down to is whether the faculties that actually run higher education can and will adapt to the new realities.
The struggle need not be a fight to the finish. Despite feeling relatively powerless, Gerhard Casper of Stanford is hopeful. "So many different institutions in our society must change that universities cannot consider themselves exempt from reviewing all of their activities," he said. "Selective excellence and other necessary changes will happen because they must happen."
Robert E. Pollack, a professor of biological sciences and former dean at Columbia University, says change is possible given the necessary sensitivity to faculty prerogatives. "The colleges and universities that will do well and improve themselves at a time of contraction and retrenchment," he said, "are those where the faculty is invited to participate in hard decisions rather than being told what those decisions are."
President Starr of Oberlin also looks on the bright side. "The crisis is forcing us to focus again on the core mission of higher education," he said. "That's 100 percent healthy. This is a golden time, painful yes, but golden because serious questions are being raised."

HEADLINE: Back to School for GATT and Nafta

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
AS THE acronyms GATT and Nafta fade from the nation's front pages, they are beginning to appear in university catalogues around the country, describing new courses aimed at helping business and professional people prepare for a new era of intensive international trade. Most of the demand is from continuing-education departments whose students will be forced, in their professional roles, to work under rapidly changing conditions and with sets of dizzying new rules.
For instructors, the task at hand now is to wade through the 550 pages of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, as well as the more than 3,000 pages of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and prepare courses that are useful and do not bore the often restive students to tears. 
 "We're trying to be as practical as possible for our participants who are trying to do business," said Robert W. Jerome, director of one such course being developed at the University of Maryland. "It may be more appropriate, for example, to knock on the door of the appropriate bureaucrat in Brussels rather than set up a focus group in Lyons."
Making the task even more complex is that the historic liberalization of trade continues and expands at a breathtaking pace. The European Community, having ratified the Maastricht treaty, must now institute the treaty's myriad rules on everything from potatoes to high-speed data transmission; talks on Asia-Pacific economic cooperation are proceeding briskly; America's bilateral negotiations with Japan, which cover many areas that are only lightly touched by GATT, resume this month.
 
3 Types of Courses
 At least three kinds of courses are being developed, and more permutations will arise. All three try to make cross-references to GATT, Nafta and other broad trade developments but try to focus on one geographic area. In Maryland, the emphasis is on Europe and GATT; in California, on Mexico and Nafta; and in Georgia, on China's coming entry into GATT as well as its investment opportunities.
Perhaps the most striking example of the trend is at the University of Maryland's University College. For years the university has been offering a series of non-credit and credit courses on international commerce that would take part-time students as long as seven years to complete. But in August the college expects to offer a one-year for-credit course in Germany that repackages much of the course material.
As now designed, it resembles Insead, or Institut Europeen d'Administration des Affaires, the elite French business school, which also has a one-year degree program. The difference is that the Maryland course has few of the daunting admissions standards that Insead requires. For example, the minimum grade point average is 2.75 and the minimum GMAT score is 500, lower standards that would allow students with weak academic credentials but rich practical experience to participate.
The Maryland course is known as the Master of International Management program at Schwabisch Gmund, a small town a half-hour from Stuttgart. The town contains a campus of the University of Maryland, rather than borrowed facilities from an indigenous university. There will also be field trips to Brussels, headquarters of the European Community.
A maximum of 35 early-to-mid-career executives and professionals, picked from a variety of nations and industries, would all take the same courses with the same goal -- "how to get things done," said Nicholas H. Allen, dean of the graduate school of management and technology. The course would emphasize global theory and practice. "We would, of course, teach the intricacies of GATT and the E.C.," Mr. Allen said. "But we would also say that in Germany it would be inappropriate to offer a small gift, as in Japan, but it would be entirely appropriate to celebrate with a good meal at a restaurant at the completion of negotiations."
 
A Cultural Context
 More importantly, because the course will be conducted in Germany, the geographic and financial center of Europe, the cultural context will become more evident, said Mr. Jerome, director of the Maryland program in Germany.
At the University of California at Los Angeles later this month, U.C.L.A. Extension will offer "Doing Business in Mexico." It will be taught by Duane Zobrist and Carlos Valderrama. Mr. Zobrist is a senior partner and Mr. Valderrama is a non-lawyer and research director for Latin American operations at Carlsmith, Ball, Wichman, Murray, Case and Ichiki, one of the first United States law firms to open a full branch office in Mexico. The three-month course will emphasize developing a marketing plan for a product or service to be sold in Mexico, with opportunities and pitfalls contained in the Nafta treaty.
Perhaps the most intriguing program is in Marietta, Ga., at Kennesaw State College's business training program for Chinese managers. It is an outgrowth of an exchange program eight years ago with China in which Chinese managers learned the rudiments of capitalism by field trips to nearby Atlanta and Savannah. Now, says Violet A. Towne, dean of continuing education, instructors are rethinking the program to reflect GATT and China's pending application to join the organization in a few years.
"We live in very interesting times," Ms. Towne said, recalling the ambiguous Chinese expression.

HEADLINE: Cramming for Kindergarten

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
I STARED intently at the white-and-red fowl in the picture, wanting desperately to get the answer right. "What's wrong with this picture?" the tester ordered, and that terrible angst of not having the right answer in class went through me like a knife. It's a hen. No, a turkey. What was that thing?
Then suddenly I relaxed: This isn't your test, you knucklehead, I said to myself. Matt has to answer the question. 
 "Nothing's wrong with the picture," the high-pitched 4-year-old voice answered -- another demerit on the I.Q. test. My city boy didn't have a clue: It was a turkey's head on a hen's body. Getting a teen-ager into Harvard is nothing compared with the madness of getting a child into a Manhattan kindergarten. It's not just New York, of course. A full year before their tykes will set foot in the schoolyard, parents across America enter whirlwinds of frenzy vying for space in "the best" kindergarten.
Gina Ginsberg Riggs, executive director of The Gifted Child Society in Glen Rock, N.J., says parental angst over finding the best possible school for gifted kids rears its head in virtually every region of the country from Connecticut to California. "The crazy parents you hear educators talk about aren't crazy," she says. "Educators aren't prepared with programs for these children, so they handle it by saying 'go away.' "
The handicapped kid who can't walk has needs that are obvious, Ms. Riggs explained, but the bored child who passes the hours staring out the window "has no crisis proportion," she said. Thus, far more gifted kids exist than do classroom seats t for them, she said.
The drill, no matter the city or town, is much the same. It moves from Round One, the rush to meet application deadlines before Thanksgiving and a whirlwind of school tours; to Round Two, parent interviews; to Round Three, "group" sessions in which the child interacts with others. The latter is the point at which junior inevitably repeats all the bathroom words he or she has ever heard.
Through it all, a handful of serene parents persevere with grace. But weaklings inevitably lose it, working themselves into a tizzy. They fret. They stay up nights. They grovel before administrators.
This is the confession of a groveler.
At the Hunter College Elementary School gifted program, one of four we applied for, 800 kids vie for 32 spaces, and the I.Q. cutoff point is at the 98th percentile. But even if your child can show in an I.Q. test that he or she can run a maze faster than 98 percent of his or her sandbox-playing peers, it still isn't enough. Make the cut and then your 4-year-old goes into the pressure cooker of a second testing session, custom-made for Hunter. Remember when preparation for kindergarten was a new lunchbox and a pencil case?
 
The Effect of Crime
 A sad fact of life is that city crime has many clamoring either to "out-district" their kids into the handful of area schools deemed safe by local lore, or push them into coveted enriched programs, where the Board of Education has allowed little "schools within a school." Then there is always the expensive but hard-to-get-into private school.
We took the two-pronged attack on the getting-into-kindergarten project: applications to several of the city's gifted programs, and two applications to private schools. The latter prospect, at $10,000 a year before books, transportation, class trips and baby-sitter fees to cover interminable school holidays, was rendered moot when the recession stole one of our two jobs. ("You're sending him to a New York City public school?" an astonished in-law recently quizzed my husband. "Ten thousand bucks for kindergarten," he retorted.)
Heaven forbid we should have thought about letting Matt try his hand at being one of the smarter kids in a regular public-school classroom. The crusade for the gifted program had a grip on us.
First stop in our process was the dreaded Stanford-Binet IV, a 45-minute I.Q. test. We found out late the night before that Matt was to be tested at 8 the next morning. Thus one sleepy, grumpy child asleep on his mother's lap on the subway.
Another mother was already in the waiting room quizzing her daughter on a few last-minute pointers when a groggy Matt and I arrived. No! I said to myself: These kids are supposed to study for this? Later a friend chastised me for my naivete. Didn't I realize there were cram courses for the admissions test?
Arthur Pober, who was principal of Hunter from 1987 to 1990, acknowledged that the stress can drive parents wacky. He tells of a dentist who wanted his son to get into a gifted pre-kindergarten program, and offered what Mr. Pober regarded as a bribe of unlimited free dental work.
He also mentioned the mother who showed up to meet him at Hunter to be sure she was doing what she should to prepare her son to get in. "She said she was taking him to museums and playing Mozart for him," Mr. Pober recalled. "So I asked her how old the child was, and she told me he wasn't born yet."
I didn't dare tell him about the time I cheated a bit on the application and called my sister-in-law, a teacher, to get a list of the qualities she saw in Matt that would sound best.
Some of the parental anxiety may be self-generated, but much of it is the rotten result of urban living, concluded Mr. Pober, currently director of the Children's Advertising Review Unit of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. "We see the admissions process with much more urgency because we want our kids in a safe situation," he said.
But the excessive aggression and protectiveness, he said, can be harmful. "A parent can wind up pushing a child who is a good little orange into a fruit salad of only apples and peaches," Mr. Pober warned. "It becomes a competition among parents."
And then what? For one thing, kids pick up on the mom-and-pop madness. Like the little fellow who made friends with Matt at a pizza party for 4-year-olds who'd made the cut into P.S. 9's Anderson Program, a gifted program that Matt began this fall. Excited to be meeting a new school friend, Matt nudged up next to the little boy and asked, "Are you going to P.S. 9, too?"
"Oh no," the tyke said with disdain. "I'm going to the Anderson Program." Can Harvard be far behind?
