HEADLINE: Industry's New Schoolhouse

BYLINE: By 

 BODY:
THEY PARK beneath the gray Toledo sky and slog toward the Chrysler Assembly Plant and the droning production line, as their fathers and grandfathers did when the factory was the Willys Overland plant. But as these workers approach the looming walls and smokestacks they are greeted by something new. It is a Harley-Davidson motorcycle, resplendent in glistening chrome. Beside the bike is a young woman, warmly suggesting something few real men could refuse: Sign up here, she says -- for a class in motorcycle mechanics.
The class is presented after work, free, in one of the company classrooms. If you don't like motorcycles, how about a real estate license or learning WordPerfect? And if the worker lacks the basic reading or math skills to master the course -- no problem. Tutors are waiting to help. "If we just offered reading and math, no one would participate," said Jerry Huber, the plant manager. The company had to de-stigmatize remedial training, making it "non-threatening." 
 Welcome to the 90's, where almost anything goes to bring the work force up to world-class standards. To stay competitive, United States industries know they must have a highly skilled force, but believe that America's education system is not adequately producing one. "The cliche is of the American whose VCR keeps flashing 12:00 because they don't know how to program it," said Margot Brown, manager of media relations for Motorola Corporation.
 
Tough Competition
 American companies say they have a difficult time competing with countries like Germany and Japan with an undereducated work force, because a higher level of education is required to communicate in the teams now used in manufacturing, as well as higher math and reading skills to understand instructions and operate equipment. Yet despite a greater proportion of gross domestic product spent on education here than by either of these rivals, Americans' test scores are only moderately higher than the industrialized nations' average in reading, and below their average in math.
In 1988, the latest year for which comparable figures are available, the United States spent 5.7 percent of G.D.P. through government expenditures (exclusive of gifts, grants, tuition and endowment) on education, compared with 4.7 percent for the Japanese and 4.2 percent for the Germans, according to Vance Grant, a specialist in education statistics for the Federal Department of Education's Office of Education Research. By the time total spending on education is calculated, including expenditures on private schools, which he said were higher in the United States than in many other places, the amount was 7.8 percent of G.D.P. in 1992-93. "In spending, we're competitive," Mr. Grant concluded. But he indicated that for what the United States spends, its results should be better.
So, some businesses are taking things into their own hands. Half the small companies and nearly three-quarters of the large ones in the United States now have some sort of skills upgrade program, according to Phyllis Eisen, an official of the National Association of Manufacturers. Industry is spending $40 billion a year educating and training employees, much of it in remedial education.
Harry Featherstone, president of the Will-Burt Company, which manufactures auto parts in Orrville, Ohio, is a leading advocate of educating employees. The company brings in professors from the University of Akron to teach "core competencies," which are basic math and reading skills, on company time. The basics last six months to a year, four to five hours a week. So far, all 250 of his employees have taken a core curriculum that includes math, geometry, blueprint reading and statistical process. Of those, 163 have taken a "mini-M.B.A." program for two more years on their own time. It is the equivalent of the first two years of college, at company expense.
 
Teaching Teamwork
 Part of what is taught is how to work together as a team, with rotating responsibility for safety, costing, production control, materials and personnel. Mr. Featherstone insists that this teamwork, an outgrowth of education, has made his company more competitive. He says he can beat other countries in efficiency and costs and has been able to take work back from Mexico and Japan. Last January, for example, the company captured a contract to manufacture sorters for printing equipment from a Mexican business, even though he pays his workers $11 per hour and the Mexican company pays $2.
Margo Brown of Motorola says that as a result of her company's education program, production per employee doubled over the last six years, while the work force went up by slightly less than 9 percent. In the same period, the number of defects fell from 6,000 per million units produced to 30, and the company is shooting for 3.4 defects per million. The improvement saved the company $3.9 billion in five years.
Motorola had wanted to teach workers new production methods in the mid-80's, but found they were unable to grasp them. "We were disappointed; they weren't getting it," Ms. Brown said. The company gave employees a reading test, and many failed. Those who did were trained in basic reading skills. Motorola officials work with school systems to teach teachers what industry needs.
To do their part in that direction, Motorola offered students communications workshops. Since the workers come from 40 different countries, the company also offered English as a Second Language classes. Ms. Brown credits the education program for the productivity increase.
There are other benefits. Mr. Featherstone's Will-Burt Company has found that a better-educated work force leads to reduced medical costs. He also credits improved education with cutting his workers' compensation bill from over $100,000 in 1985 to $662 last year.
Another solution for companies dissatisfied with the products of public schools is to start their own for the children of their employees. That's what is happening at Minco Technology Labs Inc., a resaler of value-added semiconductors in Austin, Tex. The company's president, Liz Coker, who had not gone beyond the ninth grade herself, launched her school for the children of employees last fall, with 13 children in classes from preschool through fourth grade. After three years the school is eligible to become accredited, which means the students will be tested to see if they have learned enough to transfer into other schools.
Ultimately, Minco is aiming for a school with grades K through 12. "We have to take the responsibility of educating our children ourselves," Ms. Coker said.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Women on the Edge, of Madness, of Life

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
"MUSIC FROM DOWN THE Hill," at the WPA Theater, is the title of John Ford Noonan's new, unexpectedly sweet, two-character play set in Heavenly Hills, a mental hospital in upstate New York. Though it's not an easy play to like initially, it grows on you. You have to give it time. By intention I suspect, it is all attitude at first: the voice too loud and vulgar, the manner borrowed hip, like that of a middle-class, middle-aged man who wears his baseball cap back to front and dirty white Reeboks with their laces untied.
Yet beneath that disguise you can recognize a delicacy of feeling that is rare in most theater pieces today. "Music From Down the Hill," directed by Terence Lamude, is a cannily constructed melange of alienation, nostalgia and shock effects, diluted only near the end by the kind of upbeat sentiments that are the bread and butter of television. 
 The play's single set is a big, comfortable double room at Heavenly Hills, which is clearly not a snake pit. The room is clinically impersonal, but it appears to be in the class of private institution that costs a mint, or certainly more than most of today's health-care plans will allow.
When the lights come up at the start, the audience is greeted by a long, aggressively lunatic monologue spoken by Claire (Welker White), a woman in her early 20's with the face of a waif who'd like to blow up the world.
"Every time I love someone's music," Claire begins, "I end up hearing these awful stories about their empty lives." In language meant to intimidate by its crudeness, Claire goes on to recall the bloody fight she had the night before, when Marsue De Santos bad-mouthed Bruce Springsteen. She grabbed a pair of shears, stolen from her sewing class, and, beginning with the pinky, cut off the tips of the fingers on one of Marsue's hands. Claire, who has a chip on her shoulder the size of Kilimanjaro, is staking out her territory for the benefit of Margot (Alma Cuervo), her new roommate.
Margot, an older, rather pretty woman, has just arrived at Heavenly Hills accompanied by several boxes of books and a large teddy bear. Short and broad-beamed in her jeans, she sits impassively on her own bed and listens. She is a self-described perfect listener. She has total recall.
To be fully appreciated, Mr. Noonan's play should be listened to with some of Margot's acuity. He can write lines that pierce. Says Claire as she explains why she is so unpopular with the other patients, "They're only jealous 'cause I'm rich and from Greenwich and believe in something powerful."
"Music From Down the Hill" superficially recalls "A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking," the playwright's best-known work. Though the new play also is about two women who sit around talking, it embraces feminism and then goes beyond. "Music From Down the Hill" is about two people, who happen to be women, both long out of touch with what's taken to be reality, who help each other to re-establish connections. Music is their bond -- music the ineffable comforter and consciousness-raiser.
Claire's obsession is Bruce Springsteen, especially his "Born to Run." Margot's passion is Steppenwolf (and the other musicians associated with the 1969 Woodstock music festival) and with the Fillmore East, New York's rock mecca in the late 60's. As it turns out, Heavenly Hills may overlook the Woodstock field where nearly 500,000 people communed for three days of peace, love, harmony and chemically induced trips, good and bad. Whether Heavenly Hills really does overlook that sacred site remains vague. The promise of Woodstock, its flower-power spirit, haunts Claire as well as Margot, and, it's assumed, Mr. Noonan.
The play unfolds in a series of short scenes, separated by blackouts in which the audience hears ghostly reminders of the Woodstock weekend: announcements over the festival's P.A. system. "Elliot," goes one, "the hitchhikers you picked up need the pills from your car."
Though Mr. Noonan supplies Claire with a detailed biography, he skimps on Margot who, maybe because of the lack of details, becomes a mysterious, compelling character. All that is known is that she was a Latin teacher at a private school on Long Island when, in 1969, she discovered rock through one of her students. It was the revelation she had been waiting for. Steppenwolf, Cream, Jimi Hendrix and the others spoke to her without words. Their music unlocked her, so that she could express herself for the first time.
She quickly progressed from passive listener to active groupie, someone who was a mild-mannered, buttoned-up teacher five days a week and, on weekends, a manic participant in the Fillmore East scene. Her specialty: dancing as the spirit moved her. Each side of her double life increased the exhilaration of the other. In the classroom she dazzled her students. At the Fillmore she was Queen of the Boogie.
When her double life was exposed and she was fired from her teaching job, Margot became a full-time groupie, and fell apart. She landed in the bin less than two years later and has been incarcerated every day since, including, she tells Claire proudly, the 972 days when she refused to talk.
THOUGH MR. NOONAN'S language is often rough, it is also precise, evoking the inexpressible effect of the music of one's choice. The scene in which the self-absorbed Claire effectively exorcises Margot's demons is a stunner, played by Ms. Cuervo and Ms. White with a beautifully controlled intensity that gives dramatic weight to the entire play. It is here that genuine tenderness is allowed to surface over bogus attitude.
In some other areas "Music From Down the Hill" is not so satisfying. Reality creeps into this make-believe when you wonder where Margot comes from and who has been footing the bills for all her years in mental hospitals. But because she is so fully realized during the time of the play, these questions can remain moot without destroying the emotional effect or Ms. Cuervo's fine performance.
More difficult to accept are the reasons for Claire's apparently long hospitalization. She tells lies, but these are transparent. Her rage is expressed in language, not mayhem. Claire seems to be not much sicker than a lot of people walking around outside.
The text and the production otherwise work well, even Edward T. Gianfrancesco's set that, at first, seems to be merely an accurate representation of a big room, full of waste space, at a pricey mental facility. As the play proceeds, the waste space becomes a reflection of the awful emptiness of the two troubled lives within that room.
 
'The Rez Sisters'
 Until you read this, you may not know that Manitoulin Island, which is on the Ontario side of Lake Huron across from Michigan, is the largest fresh-water island in the world. Though large by fresh-water-lake standards, Manitoulin is the small, suffocating, virtually cloistered, principal locale for Tomson Highway's "Rez Sisters." The 1986 play, now at the New York Theater Workshop, is about seven indomitable, very chatty woman, who are onstage from start to finish, and about their men, who are never seen.
"The Rez Sisters" is very much into the kind of consciousness-raising that Mr. Noonan explored in "A Coupla White Chicks." In this case the women are Canadian Indians (as is Mr. Highway), residents of the fictional Wasaychigan Hill Indian Reserve. If men aren't the women's main problem, that's only because life on Manitoulin is so economically depressed that most of their husbands, fathers, sons and boyfriends are off-island trying to earn livings. The reservation sister who has a man to knock her around is, in a negative sort of way, fortunate. That's how bad things are.
"The Rez Sisters" dramatizes the lives of these women, who are proud of their Indian heritage but also caught by the promises of an alien culture. They laugh, gossip, fight, reconcile and seek something more: they play bingo. Bingo gives their lives direction and occasional cash. It's the possibility of winning a $1 million bingo jackpot that sends them off on a riotous and forlorn excursion to Toronto, the play's central event.
As directed by Linda S. Chapman and Muriel Miguel and designed by Anita Stewart, the production has a very spare look on the wide New York Theater Workshop stage. Mr. Highway's writing fills in what the scenery leaves out. He not only bluntly defines each character, but he also tells the audience what the characters are seeing at any given minute. In addition to the women, the cast includes two men: an onstage singer-musician and the actor who plays the trickster spirit called Nanabush, the only one to make a killing during the Toronto bingo blast.
Louis Mofsie, who plays Nanabush, doubles with a brief and spooky appearance as the Toronto bingo caller. Also noteworthy are the performances of Gloria Miguel, as the heartiest, most commonsensical of the reservation sisters, and Murielle Borst, as a sister who talks like a biker. Kevin Tarrant is the singer-musician.
"The Rez Sisters" is not for everyone. Mr. Highway is a colorful but unsophisticated playwright. He's less interested in dramatic subtleties than in creating a sense of life and community. "The Rez Sisters" is an ethnic piece originally written for the people it's about. It celebrates the particularity of customs, loyalties, humor, even of racial predicament. Watching it is like eavesdropping.

(Blanche Mackey/"The Rez Sisters")

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES;
Boston Chefs: A Family Tree

BYLINE: By NANCY HARMON JENKINS; NANCY HARMON JENKINS is working on a book about Mediterranean food to be published by Bantam in the spring of 1994.

 BODY:
GENEALOGY counts in Boston -- in the restaurant business no less than in the old brick mansions on Beacon Hill. Among contemporary Boston chefs and restarateurs, the ancestral line begins with Jasper North End. Despite his comparative youth, Mr. White is the acknowledged dean and godfather of Boston's notable chefs. Lydia Shire of Biba was once his sous-chef at the Bostonian and at the Parker House. Ms. Shire begat Gordon Hamersley, her former sous-chef who has just opened the splendid new Hamersley's Bistro in the South End. Mr. Hamersley, in turn, engendered Jody Adams, his former assistant, now the acclaimed chef at Michela's across the Charles River in Cambridge.
Meanwhile, in another line of descent, Todd English, who started off at Michela's, has established his own bustling restaurant, Olive's, in Charlestown -- across the river but still part of Boston. And Barbara Lynch, Mr. English's former chef at the mini-bistro Figs, which he also owns, is now in charge at Rocco's downtown, while Paul O'Connell, until recently Mr. English's sous-chef, has just opened his own restaurant in Brookline. 
 If all this sounds confusing, it isn't to Bostonians, who follow the careers of their culinary stars as closely as they watch the downs and ups of the Red Sox or the Celtics. There are, of course, many other good restaurants in the Boston area, like the Legal Seafoods group, deservedly famous for the freshness and quality of its seafood offerings, and some unusual ethnic bistros -- especially Elephant Walk, one of the country's finest Cambodian restaurants.
On the whole, the restaurant scene in the New England capital seems to have regained the promising vitality of the mid-1980's that was brought to a halt by the recession. Economically and in other ways, things are beginning to look up once more. As a result, dining out in Boston is more attractive than it's been in some time.
With all those lines of descent from chef to chef, is there something called a Boston style? I think so, though it's a little hard to define. Contemporary Boston cuisine is robust, even gutsy, in character, with assertive flavors that build on solid Yankee ingredients while drawing on the city's strong Mediterranean heritage for garnishes and seasoning. At Biba you see those strands in the magnificent basket of breads that appears on the table -- Italian focaccia, Indian chapatis, millet rye and solid whole wheat, all made here -- but it's also evident in imaginative creations like a delicate strudel roll of slivered red cabbage and potato, sliced and stacked sushi style and garnished with just a touch of white truffle oil to accompany grilled scallops ($16). At Providence, you see it in the fresh Maine scallops that Mr. O'Connell grills over wood embers and serves on a fragrant sauce of dried porcini mushrooms with a risotto enlivened by meaty bits of oxtail ($17.50). And at Olive's, what I call New England-Mediterranean eclectic is evident in a ginger-rubbed leg of lamb that Mr. English sends to the table with a refreshing Middle Eastern cucumber salad accompanied by a savory Armenian flatbread called lahm ajune topped, in this version, with goat cheese and garlic ($19.50).
As befits one of the country's oldest fishing ports, Boston is also distinguished for the quality of its seafood, although the decline of the North Atlantic fishery in recent years has forced fishermen and chefs (as well as diners) to become more adventurous. This is one part of the country where you will find salt cod, that New England staple, used as fearlessly and imaginatively as it is in the Mediterranean. At Jasper's, salt-cod cakes are wrapped in a crisp potato crust and bathed in a velvety sauce of saffron and leeks ($19). At Michela's, Jody Adams roasts fresh and salt cod together and serves them on a bed of wilted bitter greens with polenta crusts on the side ($18).
So-called trash fish, like skate, cod cheeks and squid, also gain distinction in the hands of Boston chefs. At Hamersley's Bistro, skate wings, succulently gelatinous with an almost creamy texture, are served in a crunchy crust enlivened by crumbs of horseradish ($18.50), and at Aigo, Ana Sortun, the restaurant's young chef, breads skate wings with Provencale chickpea flour and serves them on a bed of melting spinach ($16.50). There's a charming sassiness, too, about the crisp cod cheeks and potatoes at Providence garnished with a rich lobster sauce ($16.95).
New England seafood really comes into its own at Jasper's. Perched on the waterfront edge of the North End, the warm and comfortable brick-walled restaurant is not a fish house, per se -- pheasant, pork chops and a double rib of beef were all featured on a recent menu, along with a main-course vegetable platter. But as Mr. White's knowledge and skill with seafood has grown over the years, so has the role it plays on the menu. Raw shellfish, all from northern waters, are sparkling fresh (a selection of oysters and littleneck clams was $12 when I was there). A down-home appetizer like fried clams ($12) becomes, in Mr. White's hands, an apotheosis of crisp succulence.
Mr. White is a staunch advocate of first-rate local ingredients, which he handles with great respect, combining them imaginatively yet allowing the purity of flavors to shine through. The seafood is all from New England or nearby waters, the pheasant breast comes from Vermont, the vegetables are locally grown and range from humble parsnip puree or baked yellow-eye beans to a gratin of artichokes and potatoes.
Lobster preparations are especially masterful here: in a creamy bisque garnished with tomalley-spread toast ($12), as a main-course grill with a drizzle of garlic oil ($35), roasted with a green mince of chervil and chives ($35), or simply turned into a rich butter to garnish a piece of grilled turbot ($26). No lobster desserts yet, but except for the sweet course, you could make a whole meal on lobster here. Main courses range in price from $16 for the vegetable platter to $35 for lobster.
Jasper's has a well-balanced wine list that includes New England fruit wines (try a sweet and lush plum wine from Nashoba Valley with dessert), hard cider from western Massachusetts and a varied selection from California, France and Italy. Of special interest is a section on the wine list called "While They Last" -- end of the bin bottles at very good prices, like a Rex Hill pinot noir from Maresh Vineyards in Oregon for $26.
At Olive's, the handsome, dark-red dining room and bar is crowded, lively, even a little confusing on a Saturday night, at least in part because the restaurant will not accept reservations for fewer than six. Be prepared to stand in line. The Mediterranean is very much in evidence here, whether in a new-fashioned Greek salad made with arugola and dressed with a cumin-lemon sauce ($6.50), or a wonderfully old-fashioned dish like squash-stuffed tortelli, pasta pockets served with a healthy drizzle of brown butter and crumbled fresh sage ($14.95 for a full portion; half-portions of pasta dishes are also available). Olive's tarts (a name Mr. English prefers to the more restrictive term pizza), baked in the restaurant's brick oven, are renowned for unusual combinations like my favorite, lentils with sheep's milk ricotta, crisp raw cucumbers and red onions ($6.95). Main courses range in price from $15.50 for an elegant spit-roasted chicken with roasted garlic and a mashed potato cake, to $25.95 for a steak grilled over wood embers served with roquefort mashed potatoes and a selection of roasted vegetables.
Just up the street from Olive's is the original Olive's, now called Figs, an even more informal pizza-and-pasta place. I shouldn't tell you much about it because my daughter is the chef there, but I will mention that Figs has consistently won the annual "best of Boston" pizza contest sponsored by a local magazine.
One of the problems with Boston dining is that so many of the city's fine restaurants are open evenings only. Fortunately there are exceptions to the rule, among them Biba, an especially nice choice for lunch because outside is a handsome view over the Public Gardens and inside, one of the handsomest restaurant interiors in the country. Designed by Adam Tihany, its dark wood floors and brass fixtures suggest a club-like atmosphere that is transformed by colorful kilims and painted ceiling designs. But food is what we're here for, and the lunch menu, while more restricted than that for dinner, is fully as eclectic. Earlier this year, we tried a thin semolina pizza with a jamlike confit of onions and thin shavings of liver ($13.50) and a wonderful combination of deep-fried Maine clams, sweet little smelts, Cape Cod bay scallops, and chips of carrots and beets, served with a puddle of spicy rouille ($15). A good selection of wines by the glass includes predictable delights like a Kendall-Jackson sauvignon blanc ($4.50) as well as more unusual offerings like Giacomo Conterno's dolcetto from Italy's Piedmont ($5.50). There is also a full list.
Another good spot downtown for lunch, Rocco's, is beginning to win new accolades with Ms. Lynch in the kitchen. Like Mr. O'Connell at Providence, she puts an emphasis on Mediterranean, especially Italian, preparations. Even local ingredients are given a touch of Southern Europe, as in the Wellfleet littleneck clams served with cheese-laced polenta and a spicy tomato sauce ($8.25). Pastas show that rare touch in this country, a restrained hand: A simple spaghetti with a bolognese ragu is almost perfect, the pasta and sauce in elegant symmetry ($8.75), and when I was there, ravioli stuffed with wild mushrooms, beautifully balanced with crisp-fried potatoes, came with a green sauce that recalled pesto but was more complex ($9). Rocco's wine list is strong in Italian entries, with a good choice from $18 and $30.
Boston chefs like these are distinguished by a strong sense of camaraderie. That may seem to have little to do with food, but the friendly rivalries and respect that develop from spending time in each other's kitchens, I believe, go a long way toward explaining the Boston style.

HEADLINE: IT'S A WONDERFUL SCIENCE

 BODY:
Economics is hardly my favorite social science, but your Sunday feature "It's a Wonderful Science" (Dec. 12) is after the wrong villain. The shorter hours "movement" was begun by workers and union leaders, at least in this country, and was already alive and well here at the start of the 19th century, if not before. In fact, most economists, together with the business community, have been against it ever since, using some of your argument. 
 Work-time reduction can work if productivity increases (and the fruits thereof go to the workers); an alternative approach would be to reduce wages, or corporate profits. (The reduction-of-wages approach was used by private firms during the Depression, which is why the Roosevelt Administration pushed the 40-hour week through Congress in 1938.)
 
HERBERT J. GANS
Professor of Sociology, Columbia University
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Updating A Home's Coverage

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
DO you have adequate insurance on your detached house? The question takes on added urgency since the Midwest, Florida, California and even the normally benign Northeast experienced either flood, fire or windstorm over the last 18 months.
The stark pictures of devastation suggest that partial coverage -- based on the notion that a home is rarely totally demolished -- may no longer be adequate, no matter how sheltered the setting might seem. 
 A further concern has been the tremendous growth of the home office. It may require an added layer of insurance or a separate business policy to cover inventory and special equipment or liability issues, such as a customer's being injured on the premises.
"You can't automatically assume that everything will be covered on your regular homeowner policy," warned John Robertson, director of underwriting for the property-casualty division of State Farm Insurance, based in Bloomington, Ill.
Relying too much on the protection of an automatic inflation rider to keep the policy up to date may also be misguided. An article in the February 1992 edition of The National Underwriter, an insurance trade journal, estimated that 67 percent of the nation's homes might lack adequate insurance.
The figure was based on a study of 20,000 replacement-cost estimates by Marshall & Swift, a company based in Bridgewater, N.J., that provides statistics to the insurance and real estate industries. The results have remained valid in subsequent surveys, said Robert Crine, a vice president of the company.
The main problem, the study noted, resulted from inadvertently passing along incorrect information to the insurance company at the outset. Years then would go by without that information's being corrected, or any improvements' being taken into account
Such improvements might have involved a new addition, an updated kitchen or bathroom, a basement fitted out as a playroom or expensive new windows. "You must inform your agent whenever you make changes," said Robert E. Mackoul, president of Mackoul & Associates of North Bellmore, L.I.
John E. Bardes, a partner with the Ralph Solomon and John Bardes Organization, an insurance agency in Boca Raton, Fla., said that another pattern of underinsurance had been found after the havoc caused by Hurricane Andrew. Too many policies, he said, mistakenly reflected market value rather than replacement cost.
Where market value was higher it did not matter. But when market value was lower, coverage was woefully inadequate. The same problem is likely to arise in the Northeast, warn agents, following the prolonged weak market that has sent values into a tailspin while construction costs have remained stable or are rising.
Underinsurance was also prevalent, said Mr. Bardis, in homes that did not meet current building-code requirements. Owners of older homes should therefore be especially alert since any reconstruction will have to meet those standards.
Compounding these errors have been the attitudes of lenders. Very often a lender will insist only upon a level of home insurance that protects the mortgage amount. The borrower may then confuse that figure with replacement-cost needs.
"The bank's figure is never a good source," warned John Hoard, president of Long Island Coverage of Happaugue, L.I.
He gave as an example a house in Huntington, L.I., that might sell for $250,000 (with land) and cost $200,000 to rebuild. By contrast, the same house in nearby Amityville, he said, may sell for only $160,000 but could still cost $200,000 to replace.
Thus anyone who has made a large down payment -- say, more than 20 percent -- and may have relied too heavily on the lender's insurance requirements could also be underinsured.
Another high-risk category is the homeowner with expensive belongings. "The older you get the higher the value of your contents in relation to the building," said Mr. Robertson of State Farm, noting that people tend to accumulate more and more as time goes by.
Basic-contents coverage is normally based on the replacement cost of the home. For example, the Huntington house insured for $200,000 would carry on average $100,000, or 50 percent, worth of contents coverage.
But are your contents worth only 50 percent of the replacement cost of your structure? For too many people, even younger ones, the answer is no. "I've seen $25,000 worth of electronic gear in one rec room," said Mr. Robertson.
Thus another review should be the percentage of contents coverage in relation to the structure. The only homeowners who may be precluded from raising that percentage are those in an assigned risk pool. These are the homes like the ones along the Long Island coast that commercial carriers no longer wish to insure.
In those instances contents coverage may have to remain at 50 percent. However, Mari Ann Cole, vice president at Long Island Coverage, said the shortfall could sometimes be made up by taking out a separate policy for particularly valuable items.
Indeed, insurance agents suggest that any homeowner who has expensive belongings such as paintings, jewelry, collectibles, antiques or musical instruments should have them separately insured.
In those instances the pieces must first be appraised. "That way we both agree in advance on the value of the item," said Mr. Robertson.
But someone in an assigned risk pool may be charged extra to separately insure these items, warned Ms. Cole, with premiums starting as high as $1,000 a year.
Anyone already carrying normal coverage in an area that has recently been deemed off limits to new accounts -- such as homes in certain coastal towns -- should not worry. They should still be able to upgrade or add to an existing policy without paying excessively for the privilege, said James Kalach, a spokesman for The Travelers Companies, an insurer that recently excluded Connecticut shore communities and Long Island from the list of areas in which it will sell insurance to new customers.
How much will all this policy upgrading cost? Not as much as expected, although premiums vary dramatically among companies and also depend on location. State Farm, whose premiums are close to an industry average, offered the following example.
Say a homeowner in Passaic County, N.J., was paying $433 a year for a $200,000 comprehensive policy with a $500 deductible. An additional $44 could raise contents coverage from $110,000 (55 percent) to $140,000 (70 percent); a further $58 would provide a "replacement cost rider" whereby the homeowner would be reimbursed for replacing any item, not just its value when lost.
On a individual basis, $50 would insure a $10,000 violin or a $10,000 painting. Coverage on computer-related equipment could raise the normal $3,000 equipment limit to $8,000 for just $13. Such add-ons may be well worth the price.

HEADLINE: A Secure Rental Oasis For East New York

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN Marvin Williams returns to his Brooklyn apartment complex he reaches not for keys, but for a plastic card that opens the driveway gates leading to his secured community.
Once inside, he rounds a traffic circle and eases his car into the garage under his apartment building, where a reserved space is waiting. One flight up, on the deck of the parking garage, is a landscaped garden and play areas for the pleasure of his family and others who live in Spring Creek Gardens. 
 Mr. Williams and his wife, Roberta, who above all cherish the security of the place they call home, do not live in some luxurious fortress where residents pay dearly for the privilege of a safe haven. Their two-bedroom home is in a low-income housing complex in East New York, a section of Brooklyn more often associated with danger and decay than with attractive, affordable housing.
The creation of Spring Creek Gardens, the community where the Williamses and more than 500 other families live, reflects the city's attempt in the 80's to find ways of providing low-income housing through benefits to developers of market-rate apartments when traditional sources of funds for low-income housing programs had all but dried up.
The East New York complex, which has risen on eight acres of landfill near Kennedy International Airport, has been something of an experiment on several levels. Rather than using traditional forms of government subsidy, the cost of construction was paid for by the sale of tax abatements and tax credits to developers of market-rate housing elsewhere in the city. As a result, when Spring Creek Gardens was completed in 1990 it was debt free, a key ingredient in keeping rents low. Two-bedroom apartments, for example, average $550 a month.
Moreover, its design went against the standard for low-income housing. Instead of high-rise towers, the 585-unit development is made up of a series of four-story, attached town-house-style buildings.
With the first of the Spring Creek Gardens units now five years old, designers, builders, residents and managers are satisfied that the experiment has been a success. Yet even those who express enthusiasm for the Spring Creek Gardens model acknowledge that the community has its problems and it has evolved in ways that its planners did not anticipate.
"LIVING here has given us a sense of safety," said Mr. Williams, in the living room of the two-bedroom apartment he shares with his wife and their 3-year-old-daughter, LaTasha, "without spending a lot on rent we have what people in other buildings pay much higher rents to have and enjoy."
Mr. Williams, a computer processor for a Manhattan billing company, and his wife moved from another part of East New York, where they were paying a third more in rent than they are now. So anxious were they to find a place in the complex that they accepted a studio there until their daughter was born.
The impetus for this development, which occupies a full block just to the south of Linden Boulevard bounded by Loring Avenue, Forbel and Amber Streets, was a 1984 change in the Section 421a tax program.
In response to criticism that the tax abatement was being applied mostly to luxury level housing, the city banned its use for developments between 14th and 96th Streets in Manhattan. In exchange, developers were given the option of using the credits to build low-income housing or selling the credits to developers who would do so.
In the case of Spring Creek Gardens, the developers, General Atlantic Realty Corporation in partnership with the Related Companies, used income from sale of tax credits to companies like Zeckendorf Properties and Sherwood Equities to cover most of the costs of buying the land and building the housing at Spring Creek.
To put up Spring Creek Gardens, the developers also made use of the a Federal low-income housing-tax credit sold to corporations and individuals to spur the development of low-income housing. Supporters of the tax abatement program that created Spring Creek Gardens say it is the best way to provide affordable housing without direct government spending and that without it the city would have no new privately built low-income housing.
But critics have complained that the taxes lost were too high a price to pay for the housing. (For every low-income unit built, a developer could buy 10-year tax abatements on five market-rate units elsewhere.) Detractors also said that by allowing developers to build the low-income housing one place and take tax breaks on market-rate developments in another, the program further encouraged racial and economic segregation.
The total cost of building both phases of Spring Creek Gardens -- the second phase was completed in 1990 -- was about $70 million. But because construction funds were not borrowed, but raised through the sale of tax credits, the complex has no mortgage. Rent paid by the tenants goes toward paying for maintenance and repairs, management fees and recreational programs for the residents.
The rent also provided a small profit for the owners, Spring Creek Associates. Phipps Houses, one of the oldest and largest nonprofit housing management organizations, is the managing agent.
ORIGINAL plans called for a third phase of development that would have brought the number of units to 750. But before construction started the city decided that any additional housing in Spring Creek should be for a mix of incomes. Development of the third phase is now on hold.
The design of the complex was a key ingredient in providing residents with the level of security they now enjoy. Theodore Liebman, a principal of Liebman/Melting Partnership, which with the firm of Birnbaum Kondylis served as the project's architects, said the goal was to avoid following the pattern of the typical low-income housing development -- the high-rise. The result is a series of attached, four-story walkup buildings with flat roofs and white and terra cotta-colored facades.
"It is a myth that the only way to achieve high density is with a high-rise design," said Mr. Liebman.
"High-rises are dehumanizing and can be dangerous. There are so many reasons why high-rises are wrong for this type of housing. Not only do you compromise on security and safety with high-rise design, what is often lost is a sense of community."
The architects maintain that at 50 units per acre, Spring Creek Gardens accommodates nearly as many units as many high-rise designs.
In Spring Creek Gardens, the entrances to apartments lead directly outside instead of to an interior corridor. Just one section of a building, housing elderly tenants, has an elevator. Other residents must climb exterior staircases.
"The exterior stairways provide two functions," said Mr. Liebman, "First they offer more security because they make most of the front doors visible. Also they allow for more interaction between residents. People more likely to stop and chat on a staircase than in an internal corridor."
Save for the driveway gate, the complex is completely enclosed by either building walls or fencing.
City zoning rules required that parking be provided for 70 percent of the units in the complex. To preserve as much open space as possible, the architects tucked the parking under the housing. Ten feet above the ground-level garage is a landscaped deck with playgrounds, benches, trees and gardens designed by Schnadelbach Associates, a landscape architectural firm.
Serena Miller, the manager of the complex, who has been with Spring Creek Gardens since it opened, said that the city required that at least 30 percent of the residents there be from East New York. As it has turned out, Ms. Miller said, about 80 percent of the residents moved from other parts of East New York. Many came from apartments where they have lived doubled up with relatives or friends.
The current income eligibility range for people to move into the complex is $17,500 to $25,000, depending on family size, according to Serena Miller, manager of the complex.
WHAT some residents have to say about their community makes it clear why there is a waiting list of 500 names.
"It can be such a beautiful place in the spring and summer," said Annette Green, who has lived in the complex since the first phase opened in 1988, "when the trees are green and the flowers are in bloom. It is kept very clean." Shawn Lewis, who lives with her mother, grandmother and 5-year old sister said that their apartment offers more room than the one-bedroom apartment where they used to live.
"It is a lot safer here too," said the 26-year-old Ms. Lewis, "My sister has a little jeep that she loves to drive. She couldn't have a toy like that if we lived on a regular street. We'd be worried that a car would run up on the sidewalk or that someone would try to take it from her. But everyone here knows each other and we look out for each other."
But Mr. Williams, who is president of the tenant organization, says that residents and the managers at Spring Creek Gardens now face the challenge of not letting the very thing that most resident most value -- the security -- turn into a spoiler.
"People want to live here because it is safe," said Mr. Williams during a walk through the complex, "We are trying to make sure that the community stays that way."
One unwelcomed side effect of the success of Spring Creek Gardens is that there are more residents than planners had anticipated.
The apartments are small since planners expected that the community would be most attractive to older single people, young couples or single parents with one or two children. But instead of an expected population of about 1,400 residents, managers believe that as many as 2,000 people live in Spring Creek Gardens and that half of them may be children.
"SOME people have added to their families after moving in," said Ms. Miller, the manager, "and in other cases people who live here have been asked by relatives to take in children because it is so safe here."
Mr. Williams is working with Ms. Miller and other residents to revive the boys' club and expand activities for young people in the complex.
"The majority of kids here are good," said Mr. Williams, "Some want to show off or make trouble. We need more parents to be involved. It is not always so easy to get people to take time away from their work and responsibilities. But it's important to keeping the community a place where we all want to live."
Although the tax-credit programs that created Spring Creek Gardens are still in place, it remains to be seen whether they will be used again to duplicate this kind of housing.
"The development of housing like Spring Creek Gardens," said Alan Wiener, a principal of General Atlantic Realty, one of the developers of the complex, "depends on the sale of tax certificates to developers. Right now there is no market for the certificates because there is virtually no development of market-rate housing in New York City."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
For East Harlem, a 135-Unit Midrise Co-op on a Park

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
RISING from a long sleep, the publicly assisted co-op is about to make its appearance once again in New York City, across the street from North General Hospital in East Harlem.
This modern version of the limited-equity co-op is a cousin to the Mitchell-Lama middle-income co-ops of the 60's and 70's, and a complement to the occasional mixed-income rentals that also use tax-exempt bonds. It could become the housing type of choice in some locations as the city seeks to encourage home ownership in multifamily housing. The backing of a major local institution as a nonprofit sponsor -- in this case, the hospital -- will be helpful. 
 The new co-op will rise on the vacant block along Madison Avenue in East Harlem from 122d to 123d Streets, opposite Marcus Garvey Park in the Milbank Frawley East urban renewal area. A six-story building will face the park and two wings of four stories, separated by a landscaped courtyard, will run down the side streets.
"I believe in this product, that's for sure," said Deborah C. Wright, who Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has named Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. In an earlier housing job she was responsible for marketing the 600 apartments of the Towers in the Park mixed-income condominium at the northwestern corner of Central Park for the New York Housing Partnership, a private organization that assists in the development of for-sale moderately priced housing.
Ms. Wright said that Borough Presidents were pushing for higher-density housing on such large development tracts as Melrose Commons in the Bronx and Arverne in Queens. Tenant-owned housing is one way to bring this about, while holding down the level of city subsidies required.
Supplementing city subsidies with private financing, she said, is desirable both for budgetary reasons and to give housing opportunities to families that have outgrown existing low-income rentals and public housing, freeing apartments for successor lower-income families.
Milbank Frawley was the name given to 40 blocks of central and eastern Harlem under the Model Cities program in 1967; it was subsequently broken into sections, with the eastern section running from 116th to 123d Streets along the park.
Redevelopment has been slow in this relatively barren stretch, but it got a major lift three years ago with the completion of the new 200-bed North General Hospital. The hospital moved two blocks south from its former home in the Hospital for Joint Diseases, since demolished.
The hospital has established a housing development corporation to be the nonprofit sponsor of a 135-unit limited-equity co-op, intended for people with incomes of roughly $25,000 to $60,000. There will be 97 two-bedroom and 37 three-bedroom apartments, with 40 percent of the apartments reserved for neighborhood residents.
Although the upper limit excludes many potential one- or two-income middle-income families, it is the income range that defines the "moderate- to middle-income" market under existing housing programs. In contrast to the Mitchell-Lama heyday, there is no government program that currently assists middle-income construction, broadly defined.
THE East Harlem development, called Maple Court, will have a rear courtyard and 7,000 square feet of medical offices and surface parking for 83 cars. Construction will start about the end of this month. Occupancy should start in about a year.
The $17.1 million development is principally financed by $11.8 million in tax exempt bonds issued by the city's Housing Development Corporation and insured by the State of New York Mortgage Agency.
The city will be paid a nominal $500 a unit, or $67,500, for the land at the time of the construction-loan closing with Chase Manhattan Bank. In addition, New York City is supplying $4.7 million in capital subsidies, or $35,000 an apartment. If there is a profit when a co-op buyer sells an apartment it is split 50-50 with the city.
The development is eligible for Section 421a tax abatements, so in the early years it will pay taxes based only on the current low assessment.
The key to the Park Court development in East Harlem was a new state law in the 80's that allowed a hospital serving a low-income neighborhood to sell tax-exempt state-guaranteed bonds to build housing. North General Hospital subsequently set up a housing development company. After a request for proposals from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Sparrow Construction Corporation of the Bronx was chosen to build the co-op, following a design by the Manhattan firm of Ehrenkrantz & Eckstudt.
"You look up and down Madison Avenue and you see too many empty lots," said Eugene L. McCabe, president of North General Hospital. "The hospital sees itself as a catalyst for rebuilding the neighborhood."
As a co-op rather than a rental, residents will have a greater personal stake in sustaining housing quality. Yet because of public assistance and the existence of an underlying mortgage paid off over time, down payments are low. The average cash purchase price for a two-bedroom apartment will be $3,600, plus an additional $1,000 that goes into a debt-service reserve fund required by the state mortgage-insurance agency. The average monthly maintenance charge for this two-bedroom unit is $827, of which 60 percent is used to service the building's debt.
The low cash requirement for the co-op means that working people without substantial savings but with adequate incomes for the monthly costs will be eligible to buy. The monthly maintenance payments will be approximately the same as for recently rehabilitated rental housing in the area, which are $850 to $1,000 for a two-bedroom and $1,000 to $1,150 for a three-bedroom.
Even in locations where new housing is salable without direct subsidies, the co-op form has its uses. The most striking example is the ambitious public-private River West development planned along the East River in the Hunters Point section of Queens, where a designated owner-developer owns or controls much of the land.
A PRIVATE consortium organized as MO Associates has been designated to build a 550-unit building in which apartments are to be sold as co-ops. It will use taxable, federally insured financing, but the co-op form will enable apartments to be offered for cash payments of only $15,000 to $20,000. Monthly tax-deductible maintenance payments will then become equivalent to what an older building might charge as rent in Manhattan. One attraction of the site will be a 12-acre waterfront esplanade running a mile and a quarter along the waterfront, to which the city has committed $30 million.
As for tax-exempt financing, in the current market even sites that might normally use conventional financing are turning to it. Builders say conventional financing for market-rate rentals is unavailable.
Thus the Brodsky Organization's 1,000-unit Manhattan West development closed last month on the financing to build 80 percent market-rate apartments and 20 percent low-income apartments on four acres west of West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets. The purchaser of the $140 million tax-exempt bond was the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.
The co-op model is likely to be done in other locations, even without city subsidies, said Barry Zelikson, housing consultant to Sparrow Construction. "You need inexpensive land, efficient construction and the capacity to squeeze every line item."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

REMEMBERING DOUGLASS
 Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday on Saturday was chosen as an appropriate day on which to present "Mr. Frederick Douglass," a one-man play written and performed by Fred Morsell, the noted stage and television actor. Curtain time is 8 P.M. at the Rich Forum on Atlantic Street in Stamford. 
 The piece was written about five years ago, based on Douglass' powerful speeches and on his autobiography, "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave," which he published in 1845.
Douglass' mother, who was exceptionally intelligent, was a slave, his father was white. His youth was spent in various households, some benign, others viciously disciplinarian. He escaped from servitude in 1838 at the age of 21, changing his name from Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey to Frederick Douglass, and made his way north to Massachusetts.
There and in the British Isles he became an eloquent orator and journalist for the abolitionist movement up to and throughout the Civil War, continuing as a popular speaker afterward. During the 1870's and 80's he was appointed to various diplomatic and other government posts.
Mr. Morsell received a master's degree in theater arts from Wayne State University in Detroit. His father, Dr. John A. Morsell, was Associate Executive Director to Roy Wilkins at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from 1956 to 1974.
Tickets are priced at $15 and $25, or $7.50 for students and elderly people. For reservations, 325-4466.
 
BIG DEEDS, SMALL DOERS
 Three stories from children's literature are incorporated into the Little Theater of the Deaf production titled "Heroes Under Five Feet," to be presented on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and again at noon at the Palace Theater in Stamford.
"Keep The Lights Burning, Abbie" by Peter and Connie Roop is based on the true story of Abbie Burgess, a young girl who, during the winter storms of 1856 kept the lighthouse lamps lit and saved many ships from disaster on the Maine coast.
A historic account of a little girl who wrote to the President is the premise of "Lincoln's Famous Beard." She thought his face was too thin and suggested growing a beard to make it look fuller.
The only fictional tale is "Brother to the Wind," which draws on African cultures and their close ties to nature as positive influences on the development of a young boy named Emeke.
Five performers make up the Little Theater of the Deaf, a division of the National Theater of the Deaf in Waterford. Four of the members are deaf, one has normal hearing. The production is designed for both hearing and deaf audiences, employing sign language, body language and the spoken word.
A warm-up before the show begins introduces the audience to signing, and after the performance the audience is invited to suggest situations that the cast acts out on stage.
Tickets at $6 may be reserved by calling 358-2305 weekdays from 9:30 to 4:30.
 
THE CHANGING LANDSCAPE
 "Toil and Plenty: Images of the Agricultural Landscape in England, 1780-1890," the new exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art, covers the century in which England gradually transformed itself from an agricultural to an industrial economy.
It will open on Saturday and remain on view through March 13, featuring 40 oils, 45 watercolors and drawings, and dozens of prints, photographs and illustrated books. Some of England's greatest artists are represented, including J. M. W. Turner, John Constable, George Stubbs, Peter DeWint and Samuel Palmer.
The show was organized by Christiana Payne, an English historian who also wrote the illustrated catalogue published by Yale University Press. The works on view have been gathered from public and private collections in Britain and the United States, with financial support by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities.
As the pictures in the exhibition advance through the decades, they reflect a more realistic, less idyllic view of the landscape and the farm families who tended it. Agriculture was newly seen by artists as hard work rather than an Arcadian composition. Noontime meals in the fields, informal studies of haymakers and their implements, and the dignity of the lonely farmer performing chores in winter became prime subjects.
Ms. Payne will present a lecture about the exhibition on Friday at 4 P.M., and a symposium will be held on Saturday from 10:30 to 4:30. Scholars, lecturers and professors from four British universities and from the College of William and Mary in Virginia and Indiana University in Bloomington will speak on various aspects of the exhibition's contents and the periods in which the works were created.
Gallery talks by docents will take place for the duration of the show on Thursdays at 11 and Saturdays at noon, followed by a 27-minute video.
The Center, at 1080 Chapel Street, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5, Sunday from noon to 5. Admission to the exhibition and all related events is free. For more information, 432-2850.
 
COMBINING THE ARTS
 A series of interdisciplinary programs called "Dancing Out Loud" begins in New Haven on Friday with a concert organized by the choreographer Mary R. Barnett. She has combined her own innovative dance group, called In Good Company, with a number of artists from the Northeast, weaving them into variegated whole. The performance will take place at 8 P.M. at the Educational Center for the Arts, 55 Audubon Street.
Joining her troup will be Dan Hurlin, a New York performance artist who has created, among other things, a piece called "Quintland, The Musical," about the Dionne quintuplets. Berg, Jones and Sarvis head a modern dance company based in Portland, Maine, performing works ranging from lyrical to raucous, and Alison Farrell specializes in acoustic folk music.
Tickets cost $10 and may be obtained by calling 773-1102.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Jersey City;
The Siren Across the River

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
FOR the last four or five years, downtown Manhattan's landlords have watched vacancy rates soar and rents spiral down. Yet across the river, along the Jersey City waterfront, space is disappearing.
Harborside Center, 10 Exchange Place and 101 Hudson Street have but a handful of spaces left. Even Newport Office Tower, the seeming white elephant in Newport Center, has less than 40 percent of its space left. 
 And to add insult to envy, most of the tenants sopping up that west-of-the-Hudson space came from -- you guessed it -- Manhattan. What gives?
Unfair competition, that's what, New York officials complain.
"Real estate taxes are fixed at maybe $2 a foot, there's no sales taxes, state funds are used to lure business from New York," said Carl Weisbrod, the outgoing president of New York City's Economic Development Corporation. "Maybe Governor Whitman will end these inappropriate subsidies, but for now we can't compete with them."
New Jersey officials hotly deny that they are deliberately raiding New York.
"I have never wooed a Manhattan company," said Anthony R. Coscia, chairman of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, a quasi-independent state agency.
Still, while New York officials have primarily tried to hold on to specific tenants, New Jersey officials have helped developers in ways that enable them to do the wooing.
Two buildings, 101 Hudson Street and Newport Tower, are cases in point.
In exchange for a 10 percent equity in Newport Tower, Mr. Coscia's organization provided $6.6 million to build the kind of tenant improvements that would snag the First Chicago Trust Company and USA Networks, the building's first two tenants. And the development agency floated bonds, secured with a lease signed by Lehman Brothers, to provide the nearly $50 million it may take to build the backoffice space that Lehman has leased at 101 Hudson.
"Those buildings were the area's largest blocks of empty Class A space," Mr. Coscia said. "Until they were rented we would never get a new building in Jersey City."
Actually, that cause-and-effect relationship is fairly recent. A few years ago, Manhattan's space squeeze seemed to be the only boost the New Jersey waterfront needed.
"The pressure cooker of New York's space demand boiled over in the mid-80's, and Jersey City was where the overflow boiled to," said Philip R. Sprayregen, a senior vice president of CB Commercial.
This was particularly true for buildings like 10 Exchange Place, just one PATH stop from downtown Manhattan.
"Executives could see it from their windows," said Martha Burton, a managing director at Edward S. Gordon Company, the Manhattan-based brokerage. "And once they realized how quickly they could get across the river, they were sold by the cost savings."
As Manhattan's economy deteriorated, Jersey City's economic advantages took center stage. There's no corporate occupancy tax. Rents in the best buildings are still in the $20's a square foot, and electric power, real estate taxes and operating costs are well below those in New York. And Jersey City is a state Urban Enterprise zone, where most corporate tenants pay no sales taxes.
"Once corporations focused on real estate costs, Jersey City became a really attractive option," said Michael A. Burgio, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director who is leasing agent for 10 Exchange Place Center.
But neither Newport Tower nor 101 Hudson Street was rented before the recession and accompanying corporate retrenchment stemmed the flow of new tenants anywhere. And that's what makes their current success stand out so sharply.
LCOR, 101 Hudson Street's developer, had the easier job of the two: Its building wasn't up yet and could be customized for users. That, more than anything else, snagged its anchor tenant, Merrill Lynch.
LATE in the 80's, Merrill Lynch had seemingly mutually exclusive goals: It wanted lower occupancy costs, a high-tech building and a location close to downtown Manhattan so that its back-office staff, its systems engineers and its Manhattan traders could easily interact.
"No place in the city met those specifications, and it wasn't feasible to gut out an old, asbestos-rife facility," said Mark E. Brooks, Merrill's director of real estate planning.
In stepped LCOR (called Linpro back then), with an offer to build to specifications. The result was 101 Hudson Street, a 1.2- million-square-foot, 42-story tower -- the state's tallest building. It has huge floors well-suited to back-office operations, high ceilings and raised floors that make wires and cables easily accessible, and a vast supply of power and communications wire.
"One of the principal attractions to us was that we were able to participate in designing the building," Mr. Brooks said.
Clearly, Merrill Lynch, which occupies half the building and has its own lobby entrance, designed to others' liking as well. MFS Communications, a fiber-optics provider, has taken a full floor. Lehman Brothers will move in in August. And just last month, Bierbaum-Martin, another financial-services firm, said it would take 32,000 square feet.
"This building is as good as any in Manhattan, but its being in New Jersey made the economics really compelling," said Frank Riemer, a managing director of Edward S. Gordon who represented Bierbaum-Martin.
Similarly, Joyce A. Oberdorf, a Lehman Brothers spokeswoman, estimated that "we're getting this at half the cost of comparable space in Manhattan."
Like LCOR, Melvin Simon Associates, of Indianapolis, built Newport Tower with an anchor tenant in mind. In fact, the 36-story building got its financing because The Limited, the clothing-store chain, agreed to lease half of its million square feet for executive offices. But by the time the building was completed in 1992, The Limited had consolidated its executive offices in Columbus, Ohio.
The Limited tried to sublease its space while Simon sought primary tenants for the rest of the building, all to no avail.
Newport Tower had drawbacks that 101 Hudson Street escaped. It is easily accessible by PATH from 33d Street but is about 10 minutes farther from downtown Manhattan, the New Jersey waterfront's prime tenant source. All but three of its floors are too small for back-office use, but the mall that it abuts has few restaurants or stores that would appeal to a front-office crowd.
"People can't live on hot tamale lunches every day," Mr. Sprayregen said.
Nonetheless, in August 1992 the Limited and the Georgetown Company, a Manhattan real estate investment firm, bought the building, which is now debt-free, and started pursuing high-profile tenants.
Edgar A. Lampert, Georgetown's president, said that when First Chicago moved its top executives from lower Manhattan to Newport Tower, the building was publicly stamped as suitable for executive use. And, he added, when USA Networks set up its television production facility there, it was marked as technologically up to date.
"Their operation looks like Houston Command," he said.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Solar International Shipping Agency, the LEGENT Corporation and Brown Brothers Harriman have all taken space. About 63 percent of the building is spoken for.
"Not bad for a building that was empty 17 months ago," Mr. Lampert said.
IN fact, space is tightening up all along the Jersey City waterfront. Several real estate brokers feel Colgate-Palmolive will soon develop the huge tract that once held its toothpaste factory because it will find tenants to sign preconstruction leases. And a Singapore shipping company recently bought 15 Exchange Place, a 140,000-square-foot building that it will renovate, part for its use, part for rental.
"They're willing to suffer through a sluggish market for a lot longer than a speculative developer would," said Thomas V. Bermingham, the executive director of Edward S. Gordon's New Jersey office.
Andrew J. Merin, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director, has sold 18 acres to G & S Investors for a discount shopping center and 8.5 acres to Avalon Properties for apartments. Now he is pushing 26 acres at office developers. His pitch: "If you start building office space today, by the time it's available there'll be no space left in Jersey City."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
New Investment Stirs Renewal in South Norwalk

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
SOUTH NORWALK'S renewal, long subdued by the recession, is stirring again with a combination of private and government investment.
Large projects are being designed to encourage tourism in the waterfront area, the site of the $30 million Maritime Center. In addition, some foreclosed commercial buildings have attracted buyers. 
 But disposition of the former City Hall has proven a thorny problem. Built in 1912, it is on North Main Street, a block west of the Maritime Center and a block north of the boutiques, art galleries and restaurants on Washington Street.
Vacant for almost six years, the Federal-style structure needs $1 million in refurbishing, and its woeful appearance has discouraged investment in the neighborhood.
In recent years, several towns in Fairfield County have faced the problem of disposing of municipal buildings that were abandoned for larger quarters.
Norwalk's solution was to buy the old City Hall from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation last month for $248,000, and seek proposals for its use.
The purchase left a profit for the city, which had sold the building to Robert Katz, a local developer, for $1.2 million more than three years ago. At the time Mr. Katz had planned to spend $17 million to convert it into an inn, but economic conditions prevented him from starting the project and the lenders foreclosed on the building.
So far, the suggestion that has generated the most interest the property has come from Ralph Bloom, a city historian. He said he wanted to turn the building into the Norwalk Museum, installing artifacts, documents, records, and industrial and cultural material collected over the last 300 years and held by the Norwalk Historical Commission.
Financing for the renovation could come from the Regional Capital Development Program, through which the General Assembly has allocated $60 million for projects that focus on tourism, manufacturing, and minority-owned small business development in the 11 regions of the state.
Applications for grants from the program had to be approved by all the towns in the region, and filed through a regional planning agency by the middle of last month. Individual communities could not bypass their neighbors and apply directly. The grants will be awarded late this month by the state's Department of Economic Development.
Among the applications in Fairfield County was one filed jointly by Norwalk and Stamford for $2 million to be divided equally to renovate their city halls. Stamford is also considering converting its City Hall to a city museum.
The architectural firm of Beinfield Wagner & Associates is helping to plan the Norwalk renovation. Bruce Beinfield and Jonathan Wagner have been involved in more than 30 design projects in the city during the last few years. Among them is the $8.6 million railroad station, which is under construction two blocks from the Washington Street-Maritime Center Historic District. It is scheduled to be completed in 1995.
Two years ago the architects opened a new office in a two-story, block-long retail building on North Main Street. They got a facade improvement grant of $75,000 from the city, signed on Clayton Fowler, a builder and real estate investor from Stamford, as an additional partner, and bought the building and a one-story warehouse behind it for $800,000.
"We decided that South Norwalk's potential as an arts and entertainment center should be pursued, and we decided to seek creative people as tenants," Mr. Beinfield said.
While the ground floor retains its retail shops, the second floor, formerly storage space, is occupied by their operation, a weaver, fabric designer, graphic designer, an arts marketing firm and an environmental organization. Rents are only $10 to $12 a square foot.
THE brick warehouse that faces Marshall Street was sold to the New England Brewing Company, a small Norwalk beer producer at 25 Commerce Street. Late next spring, the company will move into the building redesigned as a brewery and pub by Beinfield Wagner. The cost, including renovations, will be $2 million.
Added to the building were a second story, a basement and a 45-foot clock tower. Beer will be brewed in two copper kettles from Germany, visible through the front windows and from the pub, which will take up the front quarter of the building and mezzanine.
Patrons will dine on sauerbraten, Wiener schnitzel, soups, sandwiches and cheeses, "foods that traditionally go with beer," said Marcia King, who owns the brewery with her husband, Richard. Visitors will be invited to view the bottling operations and unloading of the grain. A collection of beer-brewing artifacts and memorabilia will be displayed throughout the building. The company's signature beer, Atlantic Amber, won the 1993 gold medal at the National Great American Beer Festival in Denver.
Another Beinfield Wagner project involves the vacant brick building adjoining the Maritime Center, which the architects plan to refurbish and rent in partnership with Mr. Fowler, the Stamford builder, and Gary Chamer, a fourth investment partner.
Commitments have been obtained from two restaurants, a computer-training operation and a children's museum.
"We will present the plans to the Common Council and the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency this month," Mr. Beinfield said. "Once they approve them, we will buy the building from the city and start renovations."
"OUR master plan is to form a loop around South Norwalk that visitors can follow," Mr. Wagner added. "They would walk from the Maritime Center to the children's museum, to the brewery, to the Norwalk Museum at the old City Hall, and wind up at the shops and restaurants on Washington Street."
Mr. Fowler, who owns the Atlas Construction Company, the Soundview Farms office complex and 800 rental apartments, all in Stamford, has also made some independent investments in South Norwalk. In the last year he has bought the Gateway Bank Building and an adjacent office building opposite the City Hall on North Main Street, and a former corset factory on Ann Street that had been partially converted by another developer into stylish one-bedroom residential condominiums of about 800 square feet.
"Only 25 units were finished," Mr. Fowler said. "We will complete the remaining 53 and rent them for around $900 a month, starting next month."
Other outsiders have shown an interest in the district as well. Abdi Mahamedi, a real estate operator based in White Plains, is negotiating with lenders to buy 50 Washington Street. The 185,000-square-foot, foreclosed office building was built in 1972 with 12 stories and an office penthouse. It is almost half empty, and the asking price is $4.75 million.
Through his investment group, Mr. Mahamedi also bought the Norwalk Mall and office tower, a 122,000-square-foot complex on Belden Avenue, near the center of the city. CB Commercial of Stamford was the broker and the price was $2.625 million. The complex is about 90 percent occupied.
Mr. Mahamedi said Norwalk was "the most underpriced town along the I-95 corridor of Fairfield County. Sandwiched between Westport and Darien, it is in one of the highest income areas of the country. Eventually, Norwalk will catch up."
