HEADLINE: Businesses Help Educate Workers

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
JOHN COPANEC JR., 24, an employee of the Hibbert Group in Trenton, thought he had left education behind at the end of high school six years ago. Then he signed up for a refresher course in basic math that was taught at his workplace by an instructor from Mercer County Community College, and his attitude changed.
"The math course worked so well that I went on," he said. Since finishing his first course, Mr. Copanec has taken classes in public speaking, reading comprehension and writing at Hibbert, a marketing and commercial printing company. 
 He has been promoted from his entry-level receiving job to the position of account coordinator for one of the company's major clients and hopes to start work on an associate's degree in business in January. Mr. Copanec said the workplace courses had reawakened his desire to learn and increased his loyalty to his employer.
He is not alone. Companies in New Jersey and across the country have begun workplace education programs to remedy employees' educational deficiencies and prepare them to meet the demands of changing technologies. It is notable that this investment in education has come at a time when lean bottom lines and shrinking work forces have become the norm.
 
Report on Lack of Literacy
 A new report on the state's adult literacy problem makes depressing reading. "Adult Literacy in New Jersey -- Meeting the Challenge of the 20th Century" was issued in October by the seven-month-old New Jersey Council on Adult Education and Literacy. Extrapolating from data gathered from the United States Department of Education's National Adult Literacy Survey, the council estimated that 1.2 million to 1.4 million New Jerseyans function at the lowest literacy level.
These people, according to the report, "may not be able to locate one piece of information in a sports article, locate an intersection on a map or total a bank deposit entry." The report also notes that an estimated 43 percent of New Jerseyans who seek jobs or unemployment insurance have "literacy deficiencies."
Although industry-based education is not new, changes in the work force have made the problem it tackles bigger and more complex than it was five years ago, or even one year ago.
Many workers still need help with basic literacy skills. The number of people who require instruction in English as a second language is increasing rapidly. In a third large category of workers, the employees have basic literacy skills but need specialized courses to help them deal with advancing technology on the job.
Elaine Weinberg, director of workplace literacy at Mercer Community College, has developed education programs for many Mercer County companies. She estimates that in those companies, 15 percent of the employees need help with basic literacy skills and 65 percent need "job-specific" education. Literacy in the workplace, Ms. Weinberg said, encompasses "skills needed by employees now and in the future."
 
Reluctant to Admit Problem
 Helen Archontou, director of the Bergen County chapter of Literacy Volunteers of America, said the health care and hotel hospitality industries had the most pressing need for workplace literacy training, because large numbers of unskilled workers and recent immigrants are attracted to jobs in those areas.
Some companies offer literacy training, but many "don't like to admit there is a problem," said Emily Bledsoe, director of the Bergen County chapter of PLUS (Partners in Literacy-US).
Large and small employers are faced with the need to spend scarce capital on education today in order to have better educated workers in the future. To do the job as effectively as possible, many are seeking help from outside the business community.
That help sometimes comes from community colleges. "We have built up experience with our own credit students," said Ray Campari, director of the Business Assistance Center at Cumberland Community College in Vineland. Community college officials like Mr. Campari seek out local employers to find opportunities to set up workplace education programs.
"We knock on doors of industries to find out their needs," Mr. Campari said. Once those needs become clear, college administrators develop what Ms. Weinberg calls "need-based curriculum." Classes are held either at the workplace or at the community college.
Mr. Campari estimates that in the last year, 20 percent of the classes set up by Cumberland Community College in local companies were devoted to basic literacy skills and the rest to job-specific knowledge.
Ms. Weinberg and her colleagues at Mercer Community College were able to set up programs at several Mercer County industries by obtaining "workplace literacy grants" from the United States Department of Education. The grant money paid for the teachers, and the companies contributed by allowing workers to take courses on company time.
 
Contributions by Companies
 Ms. Weinberg and Mr. Campari agree that companies that pay for all or part of the time an employee spends in class find that many more workers are willing to sign up. "Because of the economy, many cannot do it on their own time," Ms. Weinberg said.
Industries with programs financed by workplace literacy grants and administered by Mercer Community College agreed to "institutionalize" the education programs once a grant has been spent. Ms. Weinberg said one such company was forming a consortium with other local industries to provide customized training programs. Similar consortiums may be a wave of the future, she said.
Another rapidly swelling wave in industry-based education is instruction in English as a second language, or E.S.L. Workers who benefit from this kind of instruction range from Korean executives at Samsung in Ridgewood Park to the recent immigrants who work in the food processing plants in Cumberland County.
"We can't get enough E.S.L. volunteers," Ms. Bledsoe of PLUS said.
Margery Oppenheimer, state director of the Literacy Volunteers of America, estimated that E.S.L. clients would soon account for more than 50 percent of the agency's business.
Samsung, an electronics manufacturer, will soon begin exploring the possibility of coordinating its in-house E.S.L. program with Literacy Volunteers and Bergen Community College.
Peter Altuch, general manager for human resources at the company, said Samsung currently uses a private instructor to teach English as a second language to its workers, about 25 percent of whom are Korean-born. Mr. Altuch, who is also the newly elected president of Bergen County PLUS, said Samsung's commitment to literacy went beyond E.S.L. classes for its own employees to encouraging adult literacy in the community.
"Our business can make contributions to literacy education with product donations, contributions and closed-caption television," he said. The company's Korean owners, he said, are likely to support such efforts because of the high value placed on education in Korea and because of their own interest in having an educated work force in the American communities where Samsung plants are situated.
Such corporate altruism is not rare. Mr. Altuch said Sony was recently recognized by Bergen County PLUS for its outstanding contributions to literacy. On a statewide basis, Panasonic and Schering Plough are the largest corporate sponsors of Literacy Volunteers of America.
 
Literacy Not Only Area
 In the broadest sense, industry-based education can also encompass businesses that do not need literacy programs. Two years ago, Mutual of New York (MONY), which has offices in Bergen County, paid $250 a volunteer to have its employees trained by Literacy Volunteers of America. The MONY tutors, like Phyllis Doloff, an assistant vice president, were also allowed to use MONY's offices after hours for one-on-one tutoring sessions.
Ms. Weinberg, Ms. Bledsoe and others say they believe that the future of industry-based education lies in partnerships among business, government and industry. The key to success, according to the Adult Education and Literacy Council's report, is coordination.
The council recommends, among other things, that the seven state agencies represented on the council work together to make policy. The report also suggests yearly conferences on workplace education and the establishment of a clearinghouse for information on workplace education to be accessible through the state library system.
Literacy experts agree that the problem of an undereducated work force will not be solved by trying to assign blame. "We're all responsible for illiteracy," Ms. Bledsoe said.
Ms. Oppenheimer added that technology, with its rapid changes, has outpaced the ability of institutionalized education to keep up, making industry-based programs essential. "Individuals are not getting less intelligent," Ms. Oppenheimer said, "but the demands of the workplace have increased."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 1808 words

HEADLINE: A New Sphere

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: SAUSALITO, Calif.

 BODY:
The sign in the courtyard said, "Welcome to the Millennium." And next to the offices of the Millennium Whole Earth Catalog -- the forthcoming sequel to the pivotal 60's generational bible -- someone was building an "experiential" multicolored tetrahedron with a metal ball suspended from it. ("Oh, no," muttered a staff photographer, "not again.")
Howard Rheingold, the editor in chief, was dressed in a kaleidoscopic fashion statement that looked as if the parking lot of a Grateful Dead concert had wandered onto his clothes. Then, amid a kazoo chorus, Wavy Gravy, that legendary 60's civil disobedient, lead an invocation to bless the M-WEC, as the millennium catalogue is known. One participant described the group of 30 or so writers and editors who had assembled from all over the country for a one-day millennium powwow as "granola-crunching, endorphin-drenched techno-druids." It was the utopia business as usual at 27 Gate Five Road. 
 Twenty-five years ago, Stewart Brand, then a 30-year-old renegade best known as one of Ken Kesey's Merry Pranksters, gazed out an airplane window into "dark nothing" and slipped into a reverie about how he could best help his friends who were starting communes "hither and yon in the sticks." High above Nebraska, he gave birth to the idea of the Whole Earth Catalog, an enterprise that two and a half million readers, a National Book Award and at least one nervous breakdown later, he would call "a mistake that worked."
He and Lois Jennings Brand, who was then his wife, loaded up a Dodge pickup with mimeographed sheets on subjects like tantra art, cybernetics and seeds, and lit out to visit his friends on the New Mexico-Colorado commune circuit.
Shortly thereafter, equipped with some light tables assembled from old doors, he and his friends wrote and designed a shaggy, witty compendium, an "access to tools," whose publication in 1968 seemed, for a time anyway, to open up the world.
Even now, after the Last Whole Earth Catalog (1971), the (Updated) Last (1975) and the Next (1981) have all come and gone, there remains a palpable sense of idealism about it all. But in 1968, the land itself was deemed the vehicle for remaking the planet. Today, it is the computer.
Where the original Whole Earthers communicated via underground newspapers and the United States mail, these days they commune via the WELL (the Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link), a computer teleconference system. In place of beekeeping and goat farming, the Millennium Whole Earth Catalog, to be published this fall by Harper San Francisco, will include six pages on how to use the Internet and a section on "citizen encryption," private coded messages to prevent computer intrusions.
The countercultural ideal of democratic access to tools, of living a life independent of established political and commercial interests, is now being applied to a new sphere. "It is not just a collection of knowledge," said Mr. Rheingold, who has served as a consultant to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment and whose work includes books on virtual reality and the virtual community. "The idea is to change the way people think."
The original Whole Earth Catalog chronicled changes in thinking in all their overwrought peacock glory. To young women in peasant blouses and young men in fringed buckskin, the catalogue was a revelation. Between its covers -- the front a dreamy photograph of Earth as seen from outer space -- an alternative to an inward-looking world, symbolized by the suburbs, unfolded. Like a Teletype for the counterculture, the catalogue encapsulated the aspirations of a generation and offered breaking news from the front.
"We are as gods," went Mr. Brand's anthem, "and might as well get good at it."
Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett, an early contributor who is now a professor of performance studies at New York University, said the catalogue "came at a time when we had more time than money." "The message was you could defy the status quo in every aspect of your life, whether it was soybean cooking, organic gardening or kitchen pots," she added.
The catalogue's arrival in 1968, the year of Eldridge Cleaver's "Soul on Ice" and Carlos Castaneda's "Teachings of Don Juan," was "like opening a vein," Ken Kesey recalled. Its renegade message was reinforced by the fact that it shunned advertising and was self-published. Printed on newsprint in a jumpy thicket of graphic styles, some without capital letters, even its physical appearance was symbolic of the broader culture escaping genielike from its former bounds.
No subject was too big or small to escape its notice. Although commonly remembered as a back-to-the-land Sears catalogue or as a rural hippie bible, the early volumes were as concerned about exploring technological frontiers -- space, physics, geodesic domes and computer science -- as they were about creative glass-blowing. A certain Whole Earth Catalog dialectic emerged -- "Man's Role in Changing the Face of the Earth" juxtaposed with "The ABC/XYZ of Beekeeping"; "Biology and the Future of Man" versus "Your Key to Psilocybin Mushrooms."
TO Abe Peck, the chairman of the magazine program at the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University and the author of "Uncovering the Sixties: The Life and Times of the Underground Press" (Pantheon, 1985), it was the epitome of thinking globally and acting locally. "Among the hippie papers it was almost like a coffeetable book," he said, "if people had had coffee tables back then."
Many of its tendrils are now rooted in the culture; others withered ignominiously on the vine. As Mr. Brand notes today, geodesic domes, promoted heavily as living spaces in early catalogues, leaked terribly; people left them behind "like hatchlings leaving their eggs." Communes didn't create an enduring alternative economy or society. Most back-to-the-landers found farming, the focus of many of the catalogues' pages, too much work. Instead, they embraced less-taxing organic gardening.
References to "free love" now seem a melancholy anachronism, and the idea of an organic molasses-blacktop driveway is probably best forgotten. But the catalogue was prescient on many subjects that are now mainstream, including computers, ecological restoration, recycling, medical self-care, alternative childbirth, stress reduction and natural foods.
The obvious question for 1994, of course, is whether the Whole Earthers can do it again, particularly since the cultural landscape is more diffuse now. Anxious to avoid a 60's rehash for aging hippies, Mr. Rheingold is striking out in new territory, "because it's the millennium," he said. The most palpably new thrust is the emphasis on "taming technology."
Mr. Rheingold, who arrived at Whole Earth four years ago and also edits The Whole Earth Review, a quarterly, sees a direct link between the counter and computer cultures. "We need to question what we're being sold," he explains, "and know how we can use these tools for positive ends."
The new catalogue will cost $30, compared with $1 in 1968. It will address young cyberculture types as well as those who abandoned social activism in the 1980's who are anxious, as one editor put it, to "get off their butts again." The catalogue will delve heavily into environmental and health issues, from safe sex to how to restore a stream.
It may lose woolly Whole Earthers like Steve Baer, who still lives in a cluster of domes in New Mexico and professes not to understand the information revolution.
The catalogue's new guise is "way less funky," said Stephanie Mills, a Michigan environmentalist and one of several writers who are now deemed old-timers: "There's much less of the dropout stance that prompted the original catalogue. That was the L. L. Bean for literate back-to-the-landers. Now it's less separate from the global karma, a little more Realpolitik."
If a day in Sausalito is any indication, the contrast between the new guard and the old should make lively reading (although it should be noted that in vintage 60's style, the group is predominantly white male). John Sumser, a recent recruit who is the executive director of the Point Foundation, the nonprofit foundation that runs all Whole Earth activities, is a former Westinghouse executive with a specialty in radar technology. He was spotted running around the parking lot in bare feet and tuxedo.
James Baldwin, a specialist in design and alternative energy who is now considered the tribal elder, worked with Buckminster Fuller for 33 years and joined the catalogue in 1968. Now 60, with wavy gray hair tucked behind his ears in a flip, he spent 13 years living in an Airstream trailer powered by photovoltaic panels and now lives in a converted chicken coop in Petaluma, Calif.
The embodiment of what a long, strange trip it's been is Stewart Brand himself, now editor emeritus. He possesses what may be the country's most eclectic resume: he is a former logger who went to Phillips Exeter Academy, has a biology degree from Stanford University, organized the 1966 Trips Festival in San Francisco (the first multimedia rock-and-roll acid test), was an adviser to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and wrote a book on the M.I.T. Media Lab. Today, Mr. Brand lives with his wife, Patty Phelan, on the Sausalito waterfront in a renovated 1912 tugboat, the Mirene. He watches his Whole Earth offspring from afar like a lanky chicken, clucking.
The still-bohemian waterfront, he says, is "the juiciest place to have a scene like ours." Mr. Brand, who has the requisite receding hairline, now indulges in what he calls the "post-managerial" phase of his life, as a principal in the Global Business Network, a $3 million company that charts the future for major multinational corporations. He is also completing a book on architecture called "How Buildings Learn." His research library is nestled in an old shipping container near the tugboat. As befits the founder of The Whole Earth Catalog, at age 55 he remains a pithy font of knowledge (did you know that once a month in America, a dead body is found in a container?).
He is noncommittal when asked whether the world really needs another Whole Earth Catalog. "That's a fair question," he said. "I don't really know the answer. But if the Grateful Dead can have an audience, why can't the Whole Earth Catalog?"
In any event, a yearning for optimistic remedies to "the angst at the end of the tunnel," still looms large, in Sausalito anyway.
"The truth is, a lot of stuff that came into flower in the 60's -- the environmental movement, civil rights, feminism, computer-age consciousness and psychedelics -- are issues still to be dealt with," said Mr. Kesey, who still clings to some of the early catalogue's old remedies. "My theory is it won't be over till the fat lady gets high."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Profile;
The Conscience of the Dismal Science

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
AMARTYA SEN cannot forget. As a boy in India, he handed out a cigarette tin's worth of rice to hollow-eyed, starving refugees during the Bengal famine of 1943.
Perhaps such memories best explain why Professor Sen, the new president of the American Economics Association, is hardly a typical economist, for all his mainstream training. In a discipline devoted mainly to explaining what is, Professor Sen has long chosen to ponder what should be. 
 The 60-year-old Harvard economist and philosopher, who is widely thought to be on the short list of candidates for a Nobel Prize, has long argued that individual rights deserve greater priority than material well-being, even for the poorest people, and that economists and governments should focus on inequality as well as economic growth.
"He is important as a sort of conscience of our profession," said Robert Solow, of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who already claims a Nobel laureate in economics. "He taps something many economists feel, namely that you've put your misspent youth into learning all this stuff but you can't say, as an economist, whether something is the right thing to do."
Professor Sen is best known for his work on the causes of famine, on inequality and on the measurement of poverty. His writings have changed the way governments around the world think about these problems, said Nancy Birdsall, executive vice president of the Inter-American Development Bank. And some of his contributions to the basic theory of how societies make choices that are both fair and rational have become part of every graduate student's training in the foundations of economic theory.
The annual meeting of the American Economics Association last week bore Professor Sen's intellectual and moral stamp. His selection as president attested to the extent to which other economists have become sympathetic to discussions about inequality. There were well over a dozen sessions on the gap between rich and poor, educated and uneducated, men and women and so forth, and most of these sessions were jammed.
"Most economists have tended to neglect the importance of inequality," said Kenneth Arrow, another Nobel laureate, at Stanford University, who has known Professor Sen since the latter was a student. "There is a tradition in economics of assuming that a dollar is a dollar and if the G.D.P. goes up, that's all that matters."
"Amartya has always pushed against that," he said.
Professor Sen spent most of World War II living with his beloved grandfather, a professor and author of a best-seller on Hinduism who engaged the boy in hours of serious discussion of values and beliefs. As a teen-ager, Professor Sen considered becoming a Buddhist, but eventually turned to economics, mathematics and philosophy.
"It is impossible to grow up in India without becoming aware of the economic problem," Professor Sen said. "I wanted to do something relevant. Religion seemed remote."
PROFESSOR SEN'S first name, bestowed on him personally by Rabindranath Tagore, the Nobel Prize-winning Bengali poet, means "one who deserves immortality."
What has made that name seem so fitting inside economic circles around the world, if not outside them, is primarily his work on famines. In his 1981 book, "Poverty and Famine" (Oxford University Press), Professor Sen influenced the way governments deal with hunger. He showed that famine was not just a consequence of nature but also a man-made disaster, an avoidable economic and political catastrophe. True, drought and flood often precede mass starvation. But declines in food production rarely account for it. Typically, even as thousands die, there is enough food in the country to go around or enough money to import it.
Disaster strikes, his research found, when the poorest people can no longer afford to buy food, because of sudden unemployment or a surge in food prices. In the great Bengal famine of Professor Sen's childhood, in which three million perished, India's food supplies were not unusually low. But a war-related boom in the state of Bengal increased purchases of food in cities. Food prices shot up, fueled by panic and manipulative speculation. And the colonial rulers, immune to democratic pressures, simply stood by.
Partly because of Professor Sen's findings, governments have focused less on direct distribution of food and more on replacing the lost income of the poor, through, for example, public-works projects that create jobs.
Professor Sen's work on inequality, some of it highly theoretical, has influenced many development economists and governments because he demonstrated that measures of average well-being -- gross domestic product per capita, for example -- can easily overstate or understate poverty and mislead policymakers.
One of the most dramatic insights to grow out of his research was the devastating consequence of inequality between men and women.
Demographers had long been aware that there were fewer women than men in some poor countries -- instead of more, as in most of the developed world. And economists, including Professor Sen, had documented that girls and women got less food and less medical care than boys and men. But nobody had calculated how many more women would have been alive if the ratio of men to women more closely resembled that of other continents. Professor Sen came up with the startling figure of 100 million "missing " women -- killed, as it were, by discrimination -- including 44 million in China and 37 million in India.
IN a highly ideological profession, Professor Sen is almost unique in commanding the respect of everyone from Marxists at the University of Massachusetts to Gary Becker, the conservative Nobel laureate at the University of Chicago.
If there is any criticism, it is that Professor Sen has spread himself too thin. "His weakness is that he is trying to write too much and say too many things," Professor Solow said of his friend. "He might make a deeper impression if he focused more."
Professor Sen has always responded to such criticism by decrying the narrowness of modern economics and arguing that juggling lots of balls clumsily is far superior to displaying virtuosity with one ball.
The criticism is not new. Professor Sen's thesis adviser at Trinity College in Cambridge, the formidable British economist Joan Robinson, spent several years trying to persuade her brilliant young student that he ought to give up his pursuit of that "ethics rubbish" and concentrate entirely on economic development.
Then, as now, Professor Sen showed the steelier side of his character by ignoring his mentor's advice. If anything, the work that has brought him the greatest joy is his contribution to "social choice theory" -- how democracies reconcile the choices of individuals with the actions of government.
He strongly disagrees with many economists and others who reflexively believe that individual rights are a luxury that poor countries cannot afford, that economic needs deserve precedence over such rights and that democracy is inimical to rapid growth. He argues that, in many cases, individual rights can increase economic security. He thinks, for example, that giving girls access to basic education and widening women's legal rights have helped bring down birth rates as much in one poor Indian state as in China, where violations of individual rights -- forced birth control -- are widespread.
For all his high-minded convictions, Professor Sen is remarkably down to earth. He is known, in theoretical articles, for using racy but apt jokes. Friends say he likes good food and wine and driving fast.
A Renaissance man in an age of intellectual specialization, he is frequently described as the ideal dinner guest -- widely read, witty, intensely curious about other people.
HE has been married to or had long-term relationships with four accomplished women, including a Bengali poet, an American philosopher and an Italian economist. His current wife, Emma Rothschild, 45, is an economic historian and essayist who looks like a softer, gentler Susan Sontag and is a member of the British branch of the Rothschild family. She talks about her husband's "great big laugh," his love of words and "talk" and his devotion to his many friends and his extended Indian family. The couple's houses -- they shuttle between Cambridge, England, where she teaches, and Cambridge, Mass., his base -- are usually crowded with Professor Sen's two teen-age children and their friends.
His close friend of 30 years, Meghnad Desai, an economist who is a member of the British House of Lords, mildly chides Professor Sen for excessive kindness.
A popular teacher, he has a reputation for handling even the most callow students with courtesy. "The first time I met Amartya, I was very nervous -- he was a huge deal in England -- and I was an hour early," said Ben Pollack, a Harvard fellow who was an undergraduate at the time. "It was pouring; he invited me in and he immediately, personally made me a cup of hot tea."
"I asked him the most incredibly stupid questions," added Mr. Pollack, an economic historian and mathematician, "but he never, for a moment, made me feel stupid."
 
Amartya Sen
 
 
 Current position: Professor of economics and philosophy at Harvard.
 
 Born: Nov. 3, 1933; Santiniketan, India.
 
 Education: Presidency College, Calcutta; Trinity College, Cambridge, England.
 
 Family: Married, to Emma Rothschild, an economic historian and essayist; four children from previous marriages, ages 17, 18, 26 and 30.
 
 Recent reading: "Political Liberalism," by John Rawls.
 
 Hobbies: Jogging, socializing, museums.
 
 Drives: Honda Civic.
 
 Ideal escape: London, Venice or Santiniketan.

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 2-7

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
It's the Best of Times (Unless You're Still Out of Work)
The numbers keep showing a recovery with staying power. Last week brought strong data on construction and manufacturing, and a report that consumers did what they can't help doing in December: buy lots of stuff. To top it off, the unemployment rate for the month clicked downward again, to 6.4 percent, a three-year low. The rise in payrolls was a modest 183,000, serving to dampen fear of revived inflation. All this helped the insatiable stock market keep nudging to new records, as the Dow industrials passed 3,800 and kept on going. With a strong 1993 wrapped up, though, some people may stop looking at an economic glass that's half full, and rising, and focus instead on how empty it still is. More than half the new jobs were temporary, and 8.23 million Americans still want any job but don't have one. That's a lot of Fridays without paychecks, a lot of children without new shoes. 

Cars, and Trucks, Are Rolling
The heartening news on auto sales has been dribbling out every 10 days for some time now, but annual figures out last week made it official: people are buying cars again. More than 14 million vehicles were sold last year, an 8 percent rise from 1992 and the best year since 1989. A lot of those were trucks: America's best-selling vehicle was a Ford pickup, far ahead of the Taurus, the No. 1 car. And for all the bad news about General Motors, remember that it still sells more cars than all the Japanese put together, and it's holding its own at the top despite its long slide.
 
Gadgets Crowd Out the Ashtray
A car's dashboard is coming to resemble a well-stocked den, complete with CD player, phone, cup holder, you name it. It's a small den, though, so space is precious, and Chrysler -- in new models introduced last week -- decided that one thing was expendable: the "ash receiver" (Detroitspeak for ashtray). The sedans will be the first mass-market cars since the Model T not to have ashtrays. "It's our step to help the health of Americans," a Chrysler executive said. But Walker Merryman of the Tobacco Institute asked, "What's the name of this model, just so I don't accidentally buy one?"
 
Condoms Make It to Prime Time
If the advertising's good enough, it can sell anything. So it's a hopeful sign that Madison Avenue, with Government backing, has put its mind on promoting condom use. Ads that began last week add flair to public service, with condoms dancing across a room and hopping between passionate sheets, or with this dialogue for a panting, clothes-shedding scene: "Did you bring it?" "I forgot it." "Then forget it." The reaction? "Morally offensive," said a Texas Republican. And Act Up, the AIDS advocacy group, said, "Clinton's dancing condoms won't save lives." But it's a long way from the Reagan era, when sex lessons on the air starred a man pulling on a sock.
 
Amtrak in the Control Tower
It's an odd idea coming from Democrats, supposedly believers in the healing powers of government. But last week the Administration essentially admitted that its bureaucracy was not up to running the air traffic control system, proposing to turn it over to a Government-owned corporation modeled on Amtrak. The Transportation Department foresees a system "more responsive to technological change," with "more efficient management." It was hailed by the airlines, in dire need of efficiency as losses mount. But the applause was not universal. One House critic saw "too many opportunities for safety to be compromised." And who will help pay for it? You guessed it. There'll be a tax on plane tickets.
 
COMPANIES
 
Viacom, Paramount, QVC (Cont.)
It's looking more and more like an auction at which frenzied bidders have lost sight of their Grail. Last week, hours before a crucial deadline, Viacom even made an $8.4 billion merger deal with Blockbuster Entertainment on its way to raising its bid for Paramount. The cash portion of its bid jumped to $105 a share, far above the $92 offer from its rival, QVC. Now the clock's ticking again, as each side was given 10 more days to raise its offer.
 
34th Street Needs a Miracle
For Macy, bankruptcy is proving a lot more than a detour on the road to a new life. It owes $832 million to Prudential Insurance, and Federated Department Stores just paid $449 million for half that claim (with an option on the rest) with an eye to creating the nation's largest department store company. It was a risky, surprising move -- made on New Year's weekend, of all times -- by Allen Questrom, who led Federated itself out of bankruptcy. In the future, a handful of giants may run the department store show, and this deal could be a step toward that because Federated owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus. Of course, if Macy can pay off the debt, it may wriggle away. But then again, Macy is now "in play," as they say, and Dillard Department Stores may be after it too. Clearly, another capitalist mini-series is shaping up.
 
At Merck, It's All Medco
The message was clear. As one analyst put it, "The Medco people are running the show" at Merck. Sensing where things are heading, Merck recently paid $6 billion for Medco, which sells drugs to patients in managed-care plans. And last week Martin J. Wygod, head of Medco, was made No. 2 at Merck, putting him in line to succeed Dr. P. Roy Vagelos.
 
The Mythic and the Mundane
The name evokes almost mythic images: Red Adair, the legendary firefighter who put out oil-well blazes in Kuwait and everywhere else. After his outsize feats, it would probably surprise some people to learn that he's even mortal, not some comic book hero. But last week he descended from Mt. Olympus and became just another prosaic statistic. He sold the Red Adair Company, founded in 1959, and retired from daily operations. As far as we know, there wasn't even an Iraqi Lex Luthor who sent him packing.
 
MCI Wants Its Private Highway
The way things are going, some upstart will come along a decade from now and demand that MCI be broken up, as A.T.& T. was a decade ago. The whole phone-cable-video-data-you-name-it business has gotten so convoluted that anything could happen. For now, though, MCI is spreading its wings. Last week, seeking to trim the $5 billion in access fees it pays annually to local Bells, it said it would spend $2 billion to invade local markets by laying fiber-optic cable in 20 cities. Its vision: to build "driveways" onto the data highway (this imagery has clearly gotten out of hand). But something new, something old: some of its snazzy cables will pass through 19th-century underground wooden conduits, bought four years ago from Western Union.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Made in China? U.S. Says No
So, now that the world trade talks have concluded, harmony will reign, right? Hardly. Washington says China avoids existing quotas by sending clothing to, say, Honduras, where -- fresh with "Made in Honduras" labels -- it is sent on to the United States. Last week the Administration, weary of efforts to end this practice, lashed out by cutting China's export quotas by more than $1 billion. What this means, of course, is that China is now in the big leagues -- it's right up there with Japan in being a trade dartboard for the United States. Not that it savors that distinction, though. China quickly denounced the cuts as "irresponsible" and vowed retaliation. And what this means back in the United States is, perhaps, some jobs saved -- but higher prices. The same old trade-off.
 
Job-Training Advice for Russia
On the eve of his visit to Moscow this week, President Clinton said he would come down strongly on the side of continued economic reform -- and would suggest that Western aid be used to retrain workers dislodged by a shifting economy. If the Russians can learn to do that, though, maybe they'll have something to teach us. We could use it.
 
A Brief Jolt for a Bull Market
There may be debate about the eventual impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the United States, but in Mexico there's little ambiguity: The economy will be far better for it. Mexico's stock market rose steadily as the clock ticked toward Jan. 1, when the pact took effect. But a peasant uprising brought a jolt of reality to Mexico, sending the market down nearly 4 percent on Jan. 3, the year's first trading day. Some saw the drop as overdue, though, and sure enough, the market quickly resumed its climb.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Foreigners Flock Back to Johannesburg

BYLINE: By Bill Keller 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
LIKE a giant applause-o-meter of South Africa's transition, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange has been roaring the world's approval as the country approaches the end of white dominion.
Buoyed by foreign investors, the exchange's index soared 50 percent last year. In the first trading days of the new year, it leapt to a record, receded a bit and then rebounded to close Friday at 5,749.8, a new high. The foreign interest has reinforced the determined optimism of South Africa's own business elite, which has gradually subdued its fears of a Government under Nelson Mandela and the African National Congress. 
 But while the exchange and the business class are basking in the world's confidence, this is not -- not yet, at least -- the kind of investment that South Africa needs if a new Government is to deliver widespread prosperity. And the brokers on Diagonal Street, home of the exchange, warn that the market is pricey compared with its intrinsic values, and riskier than investors seem to understand.
"We're certainly the plum emerging market," said Malcolm Stewart of Kaplan & Stewart, a Johannesburg brokerage. "The politics look like they're coming right. We're coming out of a terrible depression, and out of a severe drought. We're emerging from years of sanctions. And at the same time, we've got a gold boom on our hands." However, he added, "When you play in emerging markets, you play in emerging countries, and those rides are never smooth rides."
A trickle of capital from abroad began in late 1992, turning net disinvestment in the Johannesburg exchange into net investment. It became a stream in the closing months of 1993, after Mr. Mandela formally advocated an end to all economic sanctions.
Western investors were charmed by Mr. Mandela when he visited the United States and Europe to promote investment late last year, and reassured by his promises that the Government he is expected to head would create a hospitable climate for capitalists.
Most major investors in the United States had dropped their South African holdings faster than a molten Krugerrand in the 1980's when cities and states began withholding business from companies that traded with the apartheid state. No trading firm was likely to give up the steady business of selling municipal bonds in America for the right to continue selling South African securities.
As a result, the Johannesburg exchange, which accounts for almost 1 percent of the capital invested in the world's stock markets, is virtually unrepresented in the portfolios of American investors. But investment managers have rushed to catch up, and brokers are anxious to assist.
Now brokers are studying and touting the stocks, and market funds are forming specifically to invest in South African shares.
Last month, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers became the first New York firms to begin selling South African stocks and bonds. One South African firm, Frankel Pollak Vinderine Inc., said it was opening an investment banking operation in New York to raise capital for South African corporations.
"There's been a whole re-rating of our market," added C. J. Buys, economist for the Anglo-American Corporation, the mining conglomerate whose shares have led the market rally. "For example, gold shares in Australia and the States were priced higher and paid lower dividend yields than in South Africa. South Africa had a risk rating applied to it. That has now disappeared. The rating on the gold board is now in line with other countries."
What's more, decent rains last year, after one of the most devastating droughts in the country's history, have put farms back on their feet and allowed the national bank to declare that the economy has begun slowly to grow again.
American and European investors have been concentrating on blue-chip commodities companies like Anglo-American and the steel producer Iskor, but have also been buying Government shares. Eskom, the electrical utility, which has ample power supplies and an aggressive program for electrifying black townships, has been a popular investment.
Stock analysts here are openly amazed at what foreigners are willing to pay for shares many of them consider overvalued.
Mark Wilkes, an analyst and broker at the Johannesburg firm of Hayes Cullen, said the high prices, rather than reflecting underlying worth, simply reflected the fact that demand by domestic institutions creates a chronic shortage of blue-chip scrip.
Analysts point out that foreign investors have to buy in through the financial rand, a volatile currency invented as a means of controlling the country's foreign exchange. And the political stability that underlies a secure market is by no means guaranteed.
Moreover, the Johannesburg exchange is famous for being dependent on the giant markets. If there is a crash on Wall Street, they say, the rubble will be knee-deep on Diagonal Street.
As a tonic to South Africa's economy, the market's boom is largely psychological.
"We need to distinguish between portfolio investment, which is what we are seeing now, and real fixed investment, which is what we need to sustain us," said Mr. Buys of Anglo-American. "What's happening now is not fundamental to the economy."
Maybe not, said Mr. Stewart, "but who's selling? A lot of big institutions are selling, and generating real cash to invest in new ventures. And in terms of morale, it's a huge show of confidence."

HEADLINE: McDonald's Finds There's Still Plenty of Room to Grow

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: MARENGO, Ill.

 BODY:
THERE was the kind of buzz that retailers can strive for but never guarantee when McDonald's opened for business in this small town some 60 miles west of Chicago at 6 A.M. on Dec. 20.
Customers began pulling into the new restaurant's drive-through service lane by 3 A.M. and were backed up out the driveway and around the block long before the first order was taken. Out front, packs of teen-agers chatted animatedly in the frosty pre-dawn darkness while the handful of parents among them observed that the same kids seemed to find it impossible to get out of bed on school days. By lunchtime, one customer had made three visits, and many others had come by twice. 
 "I knew people here were excited, but I didn't expect this," said Sue Singleton, the franchisee who owns and operates the new Marengo store with her husband, Chris.
Marengo's debut was modest compared with the scenes McDonald's and Wall Street are used to seeing when the company opens a giant new operation in Moscow, Beijing or some other wide-open foreign market. McDonald's now has more than 4,700 overseas stores, double its total of six years ago, and it continues to open two stores abroad for every new one it opens at home.
The scene in Marengo, however, highlights why even giants of the fast-food industry, like McDonald's, foresee plenty of domestic growth. Indeed, two decades after social commentators began predicting that the fast-food industry would soon saturate the American landscape, there is no end in sight. Time pressures, the growing number of travelers and the decreasing number of traditional families with a stay-at-home mom devoted to cooking keep bringing new customers to the chains, and increase the frequency with which regulars return.
"Off-premise consumption -- like drive-through, takeout and home delivery -- has fueled the growth since 1984," said George Rice, whose company, GDR Enterprises Inc., tracks the fast-food business from Tampa, Fla. "There's no shortage of opportunity."
McDonald's, which is thicker on the ground in this country than anyone, with about 9,300 stores, has junked its once relatively rigid views on where it can mine that opportunity. It is aggressively adding outlets and different types of stores to try to recapture the market share it lost in the late 80's. It is even experimenting with such services as home delivery.
"It's an exciting time," said Edward H. Rensi, president and chief executive of domestic operations for McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill.
Marengo is one of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of small towns that have become candidates for their first McDonald's, thanks largely to a downsizing and redesign of the company's basic store. This has cut the average development cost to $1.2 million, from $1.6 million, and has increased the focus on drive-through customers. Other towns that got new stores in recent weeks include Corcoran, Calif., and Navasota, Tex.
THE new stores are just over half as big as the typical 1980's design of roughly 4,000 to 4,500 square feet. They have as few as 55 seats, compared with the previous minimum of 80, and they have more efficient equipment and extra windows for drive-through traffic. Skilled franchisees, who earn six-figure incomes from a single store, can make such profits from annual revenues of $1.2 million in the new stores, compared with $1.5 million in the older design.
The lower breakeven point has also opened new suburban niches in areas where other McDonald's and plenty of competitors are just a short drive away. The Singletons, who sold three Chicago McDonald's restaurants to move to Marengo with their two children, recently completed their redeployment by opening a new McDonald's almost identical to Marengo's in Algonquin, Ill., a rapidly growing suburb about 20 miles east of here that already has a McDonald's. A new Burger King is under construction across the street from their store.
Downsizing, new cost controls and better systems for putting market research at the fingertips of district managers have given McDonald's and its rivals new tools to subdivide urban markets further. For example, McDonald's opened an urban equivalent to the Marengo store on New Year's Eve in Chicago's Union Station, within three blocks of four other McDonald's restaurants.
A store opening is not always a community event as in Marengo, but the results elsewhere have been good enough to persuade McDonald's to step up its domestic expansion plans. After two years of adding fewer than 200 stores annually, McDonald's entered 1993 planning to add up to 300 restaurants to its domestic total of 8,959, but actually ended up adding about 330. Last fall, the company told pleasantly surprised analysts that it expected to add as many as 400 annually for the next couple of years at least.
"They are talking about opening new restaurants at a staggering rate," said Michael Meuller, who follows the company from San Francisco for Montgomery Securities.
Last year, McDonald's also opened about 130 satellite sites that are run by existing restaurants, including a seasonal outlet on New York's Coney Island and more than 80 outlets inside Wal-Mart discount stores. The satellites are part of a drive to develop "non-traditional" sites, a trend led by Pepsico's Taco Bell unit and which is now being widely followed by major fast-food chains. Other non-traditional sites where McDonald's recently opened include the new MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, a Mobil gasoline station in Bricktown, N.J., and the airport outside Manchester, N.H.
McDONALD's closest rivals are growing too. Burger King, the Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. subsidiary that is second among burger chains, added 346 stores in the United States in its fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30. Wendy's, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, added more than 280 domestic outlets last year to its base of 3,607, for a growth rate of almost 8 percent, more than double McDonald's. But analysts say that only the Subway sandwich chain and the Little Caesar's pizza chain are opening stores far more frequently than McDonald's pace of about one a day.
"If McDonald's continues at this rate, it will gain market share," said Ronald N. Paul, president of Technomics Inc., a Chicago-based consulting firm that tracks the fast-food industry, which had domestic sales of about $87 billion last year.
GAINING share will be no small feat. McDonald's already controls 40.4 percent of the burger business, which generally has grown more slowly than such newer segments as pizza and ethnic foods. McDonald's also must overcome the perception that its food is not as good or as varied as that of some of its direct rivals, even if it wins top marks for convenience and reliability.
McDonald's share of the overall fast-food market dropped from a peak of 18.8 percent in 1986 to 16.2 percent in 1990, even though quarterly sales continued to set new records. It edged up to 16.3 percent in 1991 as the company waded into the value-pricing wars of the 90's. Although 1993 figures are not available yet, analysts say the greater number of new stores is laying the groundwork for a further rebound, despite the fact the newer restaurants have smaller sales than the larger units the company used to build.
"It helps that the economy is turning up," Mr. Rice of GDR Enterprises said. "When everyone else cuts back their real estate department, McDonald's keeps going, and the moment things turn up, they blow out the doors."
McDonald's executives say the process stays methodical even when it speeds up. Acting as brakes are the company's lengthy training programs for franchisees, its carefully cultivated relationships with suppliers, its quality controls and its determination to hang on to the cost savings achievable from a high level of standardization in store and equipment design.
Even at the current pace, there are glitches, of course. Here, for instance, development and construction went unusually smoothly, but the Singletons and their 40 Marengo employees, from high-schoolers to 70-year-old Rose Doane, faced extra pressure on opening day because McDonald's architectural specifications had not been updated to accommodate the newest coffee machines the company recommends. The Singletons ordered two machines but discovered, too late to correct the problem before opening, that they had just one of the four-pronged electrical outlets they needed.
"The owners had the same coffee problem at the one we just finished in Demotte, Ind.," said Dave Grdinich, who supervised construction here for the Peter Schwabe Corporation, a Merrillville, Ind., contractor that specializes in building McDonald's restaurants.
Such construction and development problems can give franchisees short-term nightmares, but they are the least of McDonald's concerns as it plans its expansion.
"We could open 1,000 stores a year if that's all we wanted to concentrate on," said Mr. Rensi, the head of domestic operations.
 
 
 
EATING EACH OTHER'S LUNCH?
 UNLIKE most chains, the McDonald's Corporation grants its franchises for a specific address rather than for a territory. There is nothing in the agreements to stop the company from selling a franchise for a new store so close to an existing one that its business would be hurt.
But franchisees have the comfort of knowing that McDonald's has a greater stake than most other chains in not undercutting them. Founder Ray Kroc championed the view that franchisees should be partners. He established the requirement that franchisees work full-time on running their restaurants, he charged lower upfront franchise fees than other chains and he relied on higher royalties to generate revenue for the company.
These days, there are so many McDonald's outlets it is almost impossible to open one that does not steal some sales from others in the chain.
A new downtown store, like the one in Chicago's Union Station, is more likely to hurt nearby franchisees than is Marengo's, which is a 15-to-20-minute drive from other McDonald's outlets in the region. Union Station will draw its customers from the 35-story office tower over the station and from the 160,000 commuters who pass through daily, none of whom were more than a few minutes' walk from a McDonald's before it opened.
Still, the vast majority of Union Station's customers are likely to be people who would otherwise go to the adjacent food court or not snack downtown at all --and Faye Jasch, the franchisee, is going after them with a vengeance.
Even before officially opening, she and her husband, Frank, a Chicago policeman, negotiated for permission to set up a variety of satellite operations in the station's waiting room and at entrances to the tracks.
McDonald's negotiates compensation agreements for some owners faced with encroachment from a new store or minimizes the potential for conflict by offering them the new franchise. In general, though, it argues that extending the chain also stimulates people to eat more often at existing restaurants, offsetting encroachment concerns.

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
In a State of Digital Desire

BYLINE: By John Markoff

 BODY:
IF there is such a thing as being a citizen of cyberspace, the global computer network, Joichi Ito is an excellent candidate. The son of Japanese parents who worked in the United States as research scientists, he is one of the few people who can be completely at home in both cultures.
Now the president of Mac Zone Japan, a mail-order software distributor in Tokyo, Mr. Ito crosses the Pacific monthly. He is also working with Magic Box Productions in Beverly Hills, Calif., on multimedia production, and with Energy Conversion Devices Inc. in Troy, Mich., a development company working on memory storage technology. 
 Mr. Ito discovered computer networks as a teen-ager living in Detroit. Currently his Internet connection is a Sun Sparcstation I that sits in the bathroom of his Tokyo home -- the only room with sufficient spare space. He's scheming for even more bandwidth, considering leasing a 1.5-megabit-per-second satellite connection between the United States and Japan -- making for a genuinely international data highway.
Question: What was it like to grow up both in Japan and America?
Answer: I was lucky. I was born in Japan and then lived in the United States through junior high school. I went back to Japan for high school and came to the U.S. to go to college. By being forced to adjust back and forth I was forced to adapt to two cultural paradigms.
For me, the issue is to be bicultural rather than bilingual -- to understand the culture and the mindset of both countries. I feel like I'm getting better and better at it. Eventually, being able to melt into Japan when I wanted to and being able to hang out with Americans, it was ideal.
Q: Do you ever get confused?
A: I do. But when you drive on the left and then the right, if you go back and forth enough times, then when you get between two countries it becomes seamless. It's like beating jet lag. I've gotten to the point where there is no pain.
Q: What's the difference between Japanese and American computer cultures?
A: If you look at Japan, their model is master-student. Local area networks are still black boxes. Everything is still proprietary and as a result they have five different companies with five times the staff working on the same problem.
That sort of redundancy and vertical integration is what the Japanese software industry is about. In Japan you have one of the lowest rates of productivity per capita in the world. Programming power is still calculated in boring "man months." They don't have the idea of high-quality software wizards like in the U.S.
From the point of view of a global citizen, though, American insularism is very annoying. It's changing, but it's bad.
Q: What captivates you about the Internet?
A: In Japan people have an image of anyone who sits in front of a work station for long periods as a hacker, but they never criticize a Buddhist monk in prayer. It's essentially the same: a bad hacker is to a good hacker as a drunk is to a monk.
Cyberspace is my spiritual environment. That's my inner space. By the time I'm old, a majority of my inspiration will come from the Net. There is physical desire and digital desire. Physical desire is considered bad, but I think digital desire is good.
The Japanese have become obsessed with things, but the cash-based economy is not right for dealing with information. If you're dealing with entertainment, it shouldn't be cash-based. I shouldn't be paid in cash but in something else instead. I should be paid in inspiration.
Q: What do you think of computer network hooligans or cyberpunks?
A: I think that cyberpunk is a bad word, because punk is a destructive image. I think net surfing is a better image. Actually the word gets overused. I drew a lot on cyberpunk, but I realized it was more useful to do constructive things. That's the different between the 60's and the 90's. Now we can take over.
 
JOICHI ITO

HEADLINE: Russian Entrepreneurs Aren't All Gangsters

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "What's Good for the Mafia Is Good for Russia" (Op-Ed, Dec. 26) Michael Scammell argues that the appearance of "slick wheeler-dealers" in St. Petersburg and Moscow is a harbinger of economic freedom. Perhaps, but his comparison to American robber barons of the last century is not constructive. 
 There is a rapidly growing group of honest entrepreneurs in Russia struggling to publish books, manufacture doors, sew winter clothes, make chocolates and create software. Russian bureaucracy, heavy taxation and the "mafia" present immense problems for these business people. As Professor Scammell points out, Russian intellectuals compound the problems by considering all profitmaking activities immoral.
Ironically, some stereotypes of American history are in the same (Marxist) tradition, referring to all 19th-century American capitalists as robber barons.
In Russia (and in the United States) there is a need for teachers and journalists who are able to distinguish between gangsters and honest, responsible entrepreneurs, who are, perhaps, the most optimistic Russians. Our support should include capital for these business people. Confusing them with "slick wheeler-dealers" does them a real disservice, as I am sure Professor Scammell agrees.
 
GRAHAM HUMES
Cherry Valley, N.Y., Dec. 30, 1993
 
The writer is chief executive officer of Caresbac-St. Petersburg in Russia, which invests in small Russian-owned businesses.

HEADLINE: The World;
Clinton's Attention Heartens Europe (Even the French)

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WESTERN Europeans, at first, said of course they understood President Clinton's need to tackle domestic problems before worrying too much about foreign policy. They even thought this would bolster the 12-nation European Union's influence and independence in world affairs. They certainly never imagined that life would be quite so lonely without strong American leadership.
It is a measure of Europe's current mood of insecurity, then, that Mr. Clinton's arrival in Brussels for the NATO summit meeting tomorrow has brought a sigh of relief. Not that he has instant fixes for such intractables as the Bosnian war and instability in the former Soviet bloc. But he will be returning here three more times this year, and that alone should keep his focus on Europe. 
 His immediate job is to reassure. Western Europe needs to know that it is still Washington's main ally; Eastern Europe that its welfare and security are important to the United States; Russia that he supports its economic reform program despite the recent nationalist backlash. The question, of course, is: How much can he deliver?
The confusion of American foreign policy all through last year has tempered expectations. But in recent weeks Washington has helped NATO begin to shake off its post-cold war identity crisis. Tomorrow, the alliance will for the first time recognize that Western Europe has security interests of its own to defend. It will also offer a so-called Partnership for Peace to former Warsaw Pact countries as a step toward possible membership. And on these points, all 16 NATO members -- including ever-maverick France -- are agreed.
Eastern Europe's emerging democracies are less happy. Three years ago, all the talk was about their place in the "new architecture" of a united Europe. But they waited in vain for the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to become an effective pan-European organization. The European Union, as the European Community is now known, said the likes of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic were not yet ready to join. And now, while offered a partnership with NATO, they have no guarantee of eventual membership.
Unsurprisingly, they feel they are once again hostages to Moscow -- in this case, to Russia's warnings that expansion of the alliance could feed nationalistic resentment and undermine its wobbly democracy. "It seems that we should talk to President Yeltsin about our joining NATO, not to the West," Poland's President, Lech Walesa, noted acidly last week.
And, in a sense, he has a point. The West is clearly unwilling to offer the ultimate security guarantee of full membership -- an attack against one NATO member is an attack against all. No less than Washington, London, Paris and Bonn believe stability in Russia is the key to stability in Europe. This was most clear last week in the sharp -- but predictable -- scolding that Russia gave Lithuania (and the inaudible response from the West) when the Baltic republic voiced its wish to join NATO.
"We are looking for a new balance of security which cannot exist against Russia," a close aide to France's President, Francois Mitterrand, explained. "We cannot rebuild the division of Europe. If we act too quickly, it could be entirely counterproductive. So we have both to give security to Eastern Europe and not stimulate nationalistic and destabilizing groups in Russia."
And, in this, even France wants the United States to play a central role. Only two years ago, France, which in 1966 left NATO's integrated military command, was leading the drive to give Europe an independent defense capability. Today, it has moved closer to NATO and is eager for the American military presence in Europe (already down from 314,000 in 1990 to 150,000 today) to be maintained.
Like other European allies, France hopes that President Clinton's visit (which includes a summit meeting in Moscow as well as stopovers in Prague, Minsk and Geneva) will mark Washington's re-engagement in Europe.
This nostalgia for American leadership is of course a function of Western Europe's own crisis of confidence, brought on mainly by an economic recession and its failure to settle the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. "I'd say we're looking for impetus and reassurance from the United States," said Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute for International Relations. "Impetus because we've realized sadly that, without the United States to kick us, we don't move. Reassurance because Europe is again becoming a dangerous place. And we don't feel at ease alone with ourselves."
But how far is Washington willing to go? For many Europeans, the immediate test is Bosnia. Last spring, the Clinton Administration was rebuffed by Europe when it proposed lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia's besieged Muslim-led government and launching air strikes against Bosnian Serb artillery positions near Sarajevo. In response, it stepped back and left the problem for Europe to resolve. Having decided to pull out of Somalia in March, Washington has made it clear it has no appetite for direct military involvement in Bosnia.
On the eve of tomorrow's summit, however, France, which has 6,000 peace-keeping troops in the former Yugoslavia, called on the United States to play a bigger role in Bosnia. It asked for American air support to relieve the Muslim enclaves of Tuzla and Srebrenica and, without any real hope, suggested that American ground troops participate. And -- along with Britain, Spain and Canada, which also have peacekeepers in Bosnia -- it also raised the stakes by suggesting that it may soon have to withdraw its forces.
By implication, then, Washington is being posed a test question: Can it be truly present in the new Europe without sharing responsibilities in Bosnia? It would certainly like to try. And, as a first step, it is struggling to prevent the NATO summit from being dominated by the Balkan conflict. But will the alliance not lose credibility if it is seen busily preparing for the future while pointedly ignoring the present?
The proposed changes in NATO's military structure give the United States an out. Until now, while the Clinton Administration was arguing that Bosnia is a European problem, Western Europe could respond that, despite moves by France, Germany, Belgium and Spain to create a 50,000-strong "Eurocorps" by 1995, there was as yet no purely European military structure capable of acting on its own. Under the plan to be approved tomorrow, however, NATO could lend its resources to enable European countries to operate in crises of no immediate concern to, say, the United States or Canada. Crises such as Bosnia.
For many experts, though, the issue is less one of military strength than of political will. And that is where the vacuum of American leadership has been most felt since President Bush turned his attention to his re-election campaign in mid-1992. When the cold war ended, the initial presumption was that the trans-Atlantic relationship would be principally economic. But, as old problems have resurfaced and new problems have appeared, security against the fury of national and ethnic passions has returned as a central issue. For 45 years, Europeans were happy the Americans were protecting them. With a dose of humility, they are now admitting they're not ready to stand on their own.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Redressing the Harms Of the Nuclear Age May Not Be Cheap

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
KEITH L. PRESCOTT worked as a miner in the 1960's, digging radioactive debris out of the deep tunnels beneath the Nevada desert where the Government tested atomic bombs. Mr. Prescott has told interviewers that he was ordered to work in underground chambers so contaminated by radiation that he became nauseated and dizzy. In 1969, Mr. Prescott developed multiple myeloma, a bone marrow cancer known to be caused by radiation, and in 1980 he sued the Government.
For 14 years, the Government denied that it had anything to do with Mr. Prescott's illness and fiercely battled to keep him out of court. But last week, the 67-year-old Mr. Prescott took the stand in a Federal trial in Las Vegas and accused the United States of negligence. And his testimony found a sympathetic audience at the top levels of the Clinton Administration. 
 Several Administration lawyers said privately that they were appalled at the Government's behavior. "Every time we look at the Government's position, this tough approach becomes increasingly unfathomable," said one official close to the case.
There are few industries that the Government has more aggressively defended than its own cold war complex for the design, manufacture and testing of atomic weapons. Since 1956, when ranchers in Utah asserted in a lawsuit that radioactive fallout killed 4,500 sheep, the Government has steadfastly resisted assertions that the industry could have caused harm. Justice Department lawyers have accused citizens of making up complaints, lying about their injuries and attempting to enrich themselves.
But now, the words heard in the Department of Energy, the Department of Justice and the White House about radiation-related cases are "compassion," "moral behavior" and "doing what is right."
 
Growing Liability
 The implications of the Government's change of heart, both legally and economically, are far from clear. Last week, President Clinton directed aides to assemble a task force to coordinate an investigation of cold war records that could lead to proposals for compensation. The issue that attracted the President's attention was an extensive Government program during and after World War II in which Americans were exposed to radiation in human medical research. But the lawyers involved said it is likely that other cold war era claims will be considered.
What Government lawyers want to know is is how to develop compensation programs for the research subjects, which they hope will be a limited, well defined group, while keeping costs fairly predictable and contained. But they acknowledge that the cost could climb into the billions if a compensation program is expanded to others who say they suffered injuries caused by the nuclear weapons industry.
The central issue the Administration faces is how to weigh the cost of doing good against the cost, in cynicism and distrust, of doing nothing.
By Washington standards, the Administration is moving at breakneck speed. Once before, in 1979, the Carter Administration formed a task force to consider whether to compensate military veterans and residents of the desert Southwest who were exposed to radiation from atomic blasts at the Nevada Test Site. The White House group recommended compensation for both groups.
But it wasn't until 1988 that military veterans became eligible for disability benefits as a result of radiation exposure. And it was not until 1990 that President Bush signed a bill to compensate "downwinders" -- residents of certain areas of three Southwestern states -- and some workers who participated in above-ground atomic tests.
Just as they did 15 years ago, budget officials in the White House want to know how much an additional compensation program would cost. They have few available measures.
In 1988, for instance, Congress approved legislation to compensate Japanese-Americans interned during World War II. That program has cost $1.58 billion and paid benefits to 79,136 people, according to the Justice Department.
Other compensation programs, though, are less expensive. The 1990 legislation has cost $111 million and paid benefits to just over 1,500 people, so far. It is likely that all those eligible could be compensated by the program's trust fund of $200 million, or about what it costs for a mile or two of new urban highway.
The Energy Department has given additional funds to plaintiffs, including a $78 million settlement in 1989 of a suit involving uranium contamination from a plant in Fernald, Ohio.
Since 1990, thousands of workers and residents have filed eight class action lawsuits over radiation from nuclear weapons plants in Colorado, New Mexico, Ohio, Tennessee and Washington State. The suits are aimed at corporations that managed the plants for the Government, and because of its contractual obligations, the Energy Department has spent $47.1 million since 1991 to reimburse the companies for legal fees connected with the cases.
To be sure, said lawyers at the Energy and Justice departments, the Government has ample legal authority to hold off lawsuits and, if they go to court, the chance of winning them.
But Stewart Udall, a former Secretary of the Interior, who as a private lawyer has battled the Government on radiation-related cases since 1979, noted that the courts may be changing their attitudes about such litigation.
"One of the options the White House has is to say, 'We can win, we'll fight them on every issue,' " said Mr. Udall, who helped Mr. Prescott. "But God help us if the Clinton Administration uses that old line. The Government's paid a huge price for that approach. It's caused public distrust that runs so deep now."
The woman behind the Government's about-face is Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary. Last May, after studying her department's relations with the people who live around its weapons plants, she began a project to make amends. One element of this involved declassifying millions of records in Energy Department archives. After learning of the human radiation experiments, Mrs. O'Leary announced last month that she would investigate and make public records dealing with this problem as well.
In an interview, Mrs. O'Leary said the Government could begin to draw down the enormous reservoir of cynicism and fear left by the nuclear weapons industry.
"I know this is courting some risk, lawsuits and the like," she said. "But there is a great need to assess what happened and to own up to what happened."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
