HEADLINE: Old Scores;
Left Behind, Mexico's Indians Fight the Future

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico

 BODY:
PHILLIP McDONALD, a young Canadian tourist who had been making his way around Mexico for some weeks, was sitting in the tree-shaded square at the center of this colonial city, drinking tequila and watching the last of the New Year's fireworks with friends when he noticed a column of uniformed young men and women with rifles marching into the plaza.
"We had no idea what was going on," he recalled. "It was New Year's Eve; it didn't make sense. But they definitely had a plan." 
 If Mr. McDonald could not imagine a new army of peasant guerrillas in the country with which Canada and the United States had just initiated free trade at midnight, neither could most Mexicans. Although there had been rumors of subversive activity in the area, the Government had denied them, apparently out of concern that such revelations might hurt the chances for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the United States. With its passage won, however, the implementation of the accord was immediately overshadowed by the first Latin American revolutionary movement of the post-cold-war age.
 
Zapata's Heirs>
 The rebels announced themselves as the Zapatista National Liberation Army, a force of mysterious antecedents and surprising proportions. Seizing this city three sizable towns and several villages in the forested hills along the Guatemalan border, the insurgents broke open a prison, kidnapped dozens of people and took over a state radio station. They then declared war on the Government and perhaps changed Mexico's future.
Before the week was out and the Mexican Army had chased the retreating rebels from all the towns they had seized, more than 100 people lay dead. As fighting continued in the hills, it was impossible to forecast how long the outnumbered guerrillas might hold out. But it was apparent that the army of mostly uneducated Tzotzil and Tzeltal Indian peasants had already dealt a sobering blow to the central, shining promise of Mexico's Harvard-trained President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
In timing their strike to Nafta's implementation, the rebels took aim at the official faith that by fixing their economic destiny to that of wealthier neighbors, all Mexicans would be raised into a modernity of more jobs, cheaper imports and a fuller democracy. "The free trade agreement is a death certificate for the Indian peoples of Mexico, which are expendable for the Government of Carlos Salinas de Gortari," said a rebel leader calling himself Commandante Marcos.
 
Caught Off-Guard>
 Who the insurgent leaders are, how they had organized a force that officials estimated at as many as 2,000 combatants, and how they caught the Government so obviously off-guard were questions that Mr. Salinas and his aides were just starting to answer days later. What Mr. Salinas knew implicitly was that Indians in the southern state of Chiapas were unlikely to see through nearly five centuries of poverty and political control to his vision of a new Mexico.
The rebels seemed to embody an attempt at revolution quite different from those of South American guerrillas of the 1970's or Central American guerrillas of the 1980's. Befitting tradition, commanders of the Zapatista army, which took its name from Emiliano Zapata, the leader of peasants who rose up against dictatorship in the 1910 Mexican Revolution, described their world view as socialist. Yet it was clear from interviews with rebels that ideology was more an afterthought than an engine of the uprising. "The struggle is for people to have a better life," a 20-year-old rebel platoon leader said simply.
After seeming initially to evade the crisis, Mr. Salinas highlighted what he called an essential difference between the impoverished guerrilla rank and file and the "professionals of violence" commanding them. Officials claimed some of the leaders were radical Catholics, some had ties to earlier Mexican and Central American rebel groups, but all had interests different from those of the peasants they led, officials claimed. "This is not an Indian uprising," Mr. Salinas said, "but the deliberate work of this violent group that leads it."
 
Left Behind>
 While poverty and mistreatment of Indians in the region date to their conquest by the Spanish in 1528, some advocates of indigenous rights say those problems have eased somewhat under Mr. Salinas. Yet throughout the region that became a war zone last week, the painted symbol of the President's vast anti-poverty program, Solidarity, stood out in town after town, a haunting leitmotif. It was not that the poor had necessarily grown poorer, said the vicar of San Cristobal's archdiocese, Father Gonzalo Ituarte; it was that roads and radio and television had made it so much easier for them to see the wealthier people of Mexico leave them behind.
That tension is repeated throughout less-developed parts of southern Mexico. Like the peasants of Chiapas, many of them driven off their lands by ranchers or the Government oil monopoly, other poor people, like subsistence corn farmers or jobless sugar workers in states like Oaxaca and Guerrero, have yet to find their places in the new North American economy. Among middle-class Mexicans, approval of the trade accord bolstered Mr. Salinas's promise that things will get better; among many of the 40 percent thought to live in poverty, the expected flood of cheaper imports has caused concern.
Chiapas also anchors a Mexican south marked by political underdevelopment. In the past, stirrings of dissent had been controlled by local bosses or put down by security forces. Over the last two decades, though, independent peasant and Indian groups have proliferated and grown more militant.
"These are not people who were tricked or taken along at the last minute," said Araceli Burguete, who worked as a political organizer in Chiapas before being shot and leaving seven years ago. "But most of these Indians who have taken up arms have been organized for years, and they have always been under attack by the Government. Now you see guerrillas. But there has never been peace in Chiapas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Indian guerrillas take cover from government attacks in the town of Altamirano in the impoverished Chiapas state. (Francisco Mata Rosas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Banks Learning to Make Loans to Help Poor Areas

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
It was Small Business Day at the Fordham Road branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The bank, once run by David Rockfeller, is trying to find new customers among the shopkeepers and small-factory owners in lower-income areas.
Millie Peartree was the first person on line this bright day in December. A director of the Christ Jesus Baptist Church in the Bronx, her congregation, founded a year ago, wanted to buy a brownstone from New York City so it could stop meeting in the Pastor's house. 
 Still wearing her tan trench coat, Ms. Peartree answered questions from Carolyn E. Smith, who heads small business lending for Chase's community development unit. Ms. Peartree explainedthat the church, with only 40 members, had raised $20,000 through regular tithing, as well as candy sales, spare penny drives and other fund raising. She wanted to borrow $50,000 to buy the building and pay for renovations.
Like other large banks, Chase is trying to comply with the Community Reinvestment Act, a 1979 law meant to force banks to lend money in the areas in which they do business.
 
A Push to Create Jobs
 Until recently, banks sought to comply with this law mainly by trying to make more mortgage loans to members of minority groups. Now government and members of community groups are also pressing them to lend to businesses that can create jobs in low-income areas.
For Chase, finding the people and businesses who need the money is easy; but it is harder to find borrowers with the experience and financial strength to repay the bank.
"You have all the qualities we're looking for," Ms. Smith told Ms. Peartree, handing her a loan application and explaining that she would have to submit written financial statements from an accountant much like those a commercial borrower would prepare.
In place of money, Ms. Smith gave Ms. Peartree a Chase shopping bag with bank souvenirs -- a letter opener, a Post-It note holder and a refrigerator magnet -- all bearing the Chase logo, and offered her some cookies and sandwiches from a nearby table.
For Chase, as for the government officials and community organizers who scrutinize its inner-city lending record, lending to nonprofit groups like churches is as important a part of community development lending as financing businesses. Such organizations create jobs, and often provide important social services. And like small businesses, many nonprofit groups have traditionally found it difficult to get the loans they need, often because the banks do not understand their finances.
Yet banks like Chase are starting to learn about the particular financial characteristics of urban businesses and nonprofit groups, just as they have found new ways to approve mortgage loans to minority borrowers after the disclosure that their old ways were producing racial disparities in their lending.
It is largely a process of mutual education: The borrowers, often new to business, must learn the art of writing a business plan and presenting financial statements to appear creditworthy. And the banks must understand the dynamics of businesses that have different sorts of collateral and cash flow than those of the traditional corporate borrowers they serve.
 
No Approval Formula
 The small business loans are not the sort that banks would make if they were trying to maximize their profits. "We'll spend far more money to process the application for a $5,000 loan than we will ever make on it," said Mark A. Willis, president of Chase's development corporation.
That is because the loans cannot be approved by a formula, as most loans to consumers are, and require a lot of individual attention by bankers. "You may go through 60 applications to make one loan," Mr. Willis said. "You have to use judgment and say, 'Here is a person who will work hard to pay you back.' "
Yet despite the protests by the banks about the difficulty of small business lending in low-income areas, they concede that they do not lose much money from bad loans. And most of the loans they make are guaranteed in part by the Small Business Administration or a new loan fund set up by New York City.
To some community organizers, the problem is not so much that banks cannot make money lending to these businesses, but that they have not tried.
"The lack of access to credit for small and micro-sized businesses, particularly from larger banks, is a problem that is continuing to worsen," said Alan Fishbein, legal director with the Center for Community Change in Washington. "You used to hear lenders say they couldn't make money making mortgage loans to low income people; now all of them claim they do make money at it. If banks spent the time and effort, they could develop economies of scale, but they need laws like the C.R.A. to nudge them to do it."
 
Lending Records Vary
 Chase, in fact, has lagged somewhat in small business lending in low-income areas. In New York City's small business loan program, European American Bank has made the most loans and Chemical Bank has committed the most money, said Joy M. Taylor, senior vice president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
Chase began a series of Small Business Days in the Bronx in the fall in hopes of increasing its lending there. Of the three dozen interviews she had done at five branches in the Bronx, Ms. Smith said she was pleased to find five borrowers whom she expects will qualify for loans -- a locksmith, a fruit market, a laundromat, a dentist and a manufacturer of travel accessories.
"These loans take a lot of time and you have to ask a lot of questions," said Ms. Smith, a banking industry employee for 17 years.
By the time Ms. Peartree departed, several other people were waiting on the benches in the hallway of the branch.
The next was Pedro Baz, the co-owner of a small grocery store on Sedgwick Avenue. The cash from a weekend's worth of sales was stolen in a robbery, and he wanted a $5,000 credit line on his business checking account so he could pay his suppliers.
 
Using a Specialized Lender
 Mr. Baz already had a loan, but not from a bank. He had borrowed $100,000 from the Sea Crest Linen Supply Corporation at 24.5 percent interest, on which he paid weekly. Many stores like his receive their startup financing from a handful of specialized companies that lend money at interest rates much higher than those charged by the banks.
Historically, banks have provided forms of financing that were not as risky, like loans secured by mortgages or inventory. Sometimes they have also provided established businesses with unsecured working capital, which is what Mr. Baz needed.
"People don't realize it, but banks have not traditionally lent money for people to start a business," said Mr. Willis, of Chase. "Historically, a lot of people got their start taking a second mortgage, but the problem in New York is most people don't own a home to get a second mortgage on."
The Clinton Administration has proposed tough new rules to enforce the Community Redevelopment Act with emphasis on encouraging banks to lend to small businesses in low-income areas. And it is clear that even as regulators started to toughen enforcement of the existing rules of the act, many banks had already begun to look harder for creditworthy borrowers in areas that they had previously ignored.
 
'Missing Good Deals'
 "Bank regulators can play a big role in forcing banks to focus on small business," said Ms. Taylor, of the Economic Development Corporation. "The banks are missing good deals out there primarily because they are not out in the neighborhoods looking for them."
At the same time, Ms. Taylor cautioned that even when banks reached out, as Chase was doing this day, they were sure to disappoint many business owners. "A lot of businesses don't get the loans they say they need because they can't demonstrate to the lender they have a reasonable ability to repay the loans," she said.
In fact, Ms. Smith did not shut the door completely on Mr. Baz. "We lend to bodegas," Ms. Smith told him reassuringly, referring to small urban grocery stores. "They are an important part of the Hispanic community," She gave him a loan application and the white bag of souvenirs, but she was noncommittal on his particular circumstances.
As of earlier this week, Mr. Baz had not received word on his loan application.
 
Turned Down for Credit
 Ms. Smith met next with Eric Vaheb, the owner of an electronics store that had been across from the bank branch for 15 years. He came to complain that he had been turned down for a credit line he needed to buy more inventory for Christmas. He was enraged because he had repaid two previous loans from Chase, but because his business had been hurt by recession, the bank would not lend to him again.
He was also saddened, he told Ms. Smith, over the fall of Fordham Road, once a main shopping street, that had lost many of its big merchants.
Ms. Smith appeared impressed by his business acumen, and offered to re-evaluate his application. She also gave him several copies of the bank's brochures to give to other business owners along with the bag of Chase trinkets.
Mr. Vaheb, however, was not satisfied. "I'm very upset with the bank," he said later. "In the good years we built up a good credit rating. Now there is no reason not to give us a loan." He said last week that he had not reapplied for the loan because he had been too busy with Christmas.
Neer Deen, the owner of Rosans Auto Parts on Jerome Avenue, said he was not happy either. Chase had rejected his application to refinance the mortgage on his business, and he sat angrily holding his application form, waiting to see Ms. Smith.
She offered to reconsider his application, too, but warned him that using conventional standards, falling real estate values might make the loan hard to approve. She prompted him to try to frame his request in a way that would appeal to the special programs for low-income areas that she runs.
 
Lower Payments Sought
 "I ask you to say how debt relief would allow you to hire more people or expand your business," she said.
Shifting impatiently in a black cloth swivel chair, Mr. Deen brushed aside the suggestion. He was not interested in community development issues; all he wanted was lower loan payments.
"I don't feel like paying 12.5 percent; I want an 8 percent mortgage," said Mr. Deen, a native of Guyana who had worked for several years in Saudi Arabia to earn the money to start his store.
Mr. Deen and Ms. Smith parted with very different impressions of how well the bank was meeting its obligation.
"I bank at the Chase branch here, and they are very nice people," Mr. Deen said later. "But they are not the ones that approve the loans; it is the people upstairs, who are removed from the personalities of the small business. To them, you are just a bunch of numbers."
Despite Ms. Smith's offer to reevaluate his loan, Mr. Deen said late last month that he had decided to try another bank.

HEADLINE: U.S.-North Korean Atom Accord Expected to Yield Dubious Results

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Even if the Clinton Administration completes its long-brewing deal with North Korea to reopen seven nuclear sites to international inspection, diplomats and intelligence officials say the limitations on the first round of inspections virtually assure that nothing new will be learned about how close Pyongyang has come to making a nuclear weapon.
Experts say the inspections, heralded by the Administration as a diplomatic triumph, will probably prevent the Communist Government of Kim Il Sung from diverting more nuclear material from its reactors to its weapons project. 
 That is especially important as the North Koreans prepare to shut down their biggest reactor and change the fuel rods, an opportunity for them to gain more nuclear fuel for a bomb.
 
Months of Negotiations
 But the new inspections, won after 10 months of negotiations, simply restore the situation to where it was a year ago, when the International Atomic Energy Agency first found evidence that it was being deceived by North Korea.
The agency officials will still be barred by Pyongyang from conducting special inspections of suspected nuclear sites that North Korea has not declared part of its atomic program. The agency's demand for special inspections touched off the crisis last year.
 
Two Biggest Questions
 Not until those inspections are conducted is there much chance of answering the two biggest questions about North Korea's nuclear program: How much plutonium, the element at the core of nuclear weapons, has North Korea already produced, and are American intelligence agencies right when they say that Mr. Kim's scientists probably have already pieced together a crude nuclear weapon?
"We know nothing more than we knew last spring," a senior South Korean official lamented here the other day, referring to the period when North Korea threatened to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and halted all inspections. "And by some measures, you might say we know less."
 
U.S. Insists It Is Not Backing Down

Administration officials insist that they are not backing down from President Clinton's pledge that "North Korea cannot be allowed to develop a nuclear bomb." In a briefing this week in Washington, Lynn Davis, the Undersecretary of State for International Security Affairs, disputed reports suggesting that the Administration was softening its position in order to keep North Korea talking.
"Our objectives are as they've been from the start, and that is to gain the North's full cooperation," including inspections of any sites that the International Atomic Energy Agency believes will shed light on Pyongyang's past nuclear activities, she said. "In no way will we change those goals."
But in reality, diplomats here say, it will be virtually impossible to be sure that the bomb project has been halted, much less reversed.
North Koreans are known to be master tunnel builders. Several tunnels big enough to drive tanks through were secretly dug underneath the heavily armed demilitarized zone in apparent preparations for any eventual attack on South Korea, and most experts presume some part of the North Korean nuclear sites are underground as well.
"You have to take a pragmatic view," one Western diplomat involved in the issue said. "Finding a bomb in an environment like that would be a little like trying to find a subway token you dropped somewhere on the IRT."
 
Special Inspections Are on Back Burner
 For now, the Administration has put the question of special inspections on the back burner, saying its first priority is to force North Korea to resume compliance with the basic elements of the nonproliferation treaty.
But the State Department and South Korean leaders say the special inspections will be a major part of the next phase of talks. That phase is the one in which the United States and North Korea are expected to discuss a package deal involving broad access to Pyongyang's nuclear program in return for diplomatic recognition from the United States, expanded trade and possibly some foreign aid from countries including Japan and South Korea.
But even while they acknowledge that North Korea is showing more flexibility, some American and South Korean officials here are beginning to say that the next round of talks could drag on for months, giving Mr. Kim even more time to build a bomb.
And it could take years to find the truth about the nuclear project, in part because both sides, for different reasons, are so eager to avoid confrontation.
Many involved in the talks now believe that North Korea will try over the next months to stave off sanctions by the United Nations Security Council by allowing just enough access to its sites. Meanwhile, Pyongyang will try to benefit from the uncertainty surrounding its nuclear program, hoping that the fear it may have the bomb will prove as valuable as the bomb itself.
At the same time, Washington and its Pacific allies seem increasingly inclined to embrace the view that it is not worth risking a potentially devastating military confrontation on the Korean Peninsula, especially when dealing with a country like North Korea whose crippled economy may soon collapse. But they insist they are willing to impose sanctions if diplomacy fails.
 
White House Faces Increased Criticism
 The Clinton Administration, however, has come under increasing criticism from sources as diverse as George Bush's former national security advisers to some in the South Korean military establishment, who say the United States is negotiating too much and demanding too little. Speaking in Tokyo today, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, warned against being "satisfied with some kind of compromise."
There are two kinds of inspections at issue, each playing a very different role in the process of keeping North Korea in check. The first are the regular inspections, conducted routinely around the world at the nuclear sites of countries that have signed the nonproliferation treaty. The second are the special inspections, requiring a country to open up an area it has not declared as an atomic site.
Special inspections are new, a result of the intelligence failures in Iraq. Those inspections mostly involve keeping inventories of nuclear fuel and the waste it produces, and installing automatic cameras and seals that insure the material is not tampered with between inspections.
North Korea signed the nonproliferation treaty in 1985, but prevented regular inspections for seven years. It finally signed an agreement to permit inspections in early 1992, designating seven sites at Yongbyon, the heavily guarded nuclear complex 60 miles north of Pyongyang.
Of the seven, the two most important are a 5-megawatt nuclear reactor and a small reprocessing facility that can convert used fuel rods into plutonium. The North Koreans call it a "radiochemistry laboratory," and insist they have reprocessed only tiny quantities of plutonium as part of a civilian research project.
 
Atomic Detectives Discover a Clue
 The inspectors found that the reprocessing building was only partly complete and that the reactor was operating at a low level. But suspicions were raised on their sixth inspection, when the samples they took of nuclear waste did not match samples of nuclear fuel. It was a remarkable piece of detective work, and a tip-off that North Korea had reprocessed more than the tiny amounts of plutonium it has admitted to producing.
Around the same time the United States gave the atomic energy agency some satellite photographs of two concealed nuclear waste sites at Yongbyon. As the inspectors' questions grew more searching, Pyongyang gradually cut off their access, taking them to some sites only at night or when the power had failed and blocking them from others altogether. North Korea's leaders flatly refused a demand by the atomic energy agency for a special inspection to force the opening of the two suspected waste dumps.
"They were apparently astounded about what we could detect with such a tiny amount of samples, and what the Americans could see from the satellites," a senior agency official said last year.
When the agency kept pressing the issue, and raised the possibility of United Nations sanctions, North Korea announced it would withdraw from the nonproliferation treaty. That set off the alarms in Washington, which opened talks with Pyongyang for the first time since the Korean War. It has spent the past year trying to nudge the North Koreans back into the treaty, but so far they have only agreed to suspend their decision.
 
Does North Korea Have the Bomb?
 Meanwhile, according to most American intelligence estimates, work has been proceeding on a bomb, presumably using plutonium obtained from the reactor when it was shut down for about 100 days in 1989. The C.I.A. and most other United States intelligence agencies concluded recently, in a classified report for President Clinton, that North Korea has probably already developed one or two devices, but the State Department disagrees. Even if it exists, the bomb has not been tested, so no one would know whether it works.
Officials of the atomic energy agency say it is critical that its inspectors attend the next shutdown of the 5-megawatt reactor, already long overdue. That is largely to make sure that North Korea does not use the old fuel rods to augment its relatively meager supply of plutonium. The shutdown will be North Korea's best chance to get enough plutonium to produce two or three weapons; it helps explain why there was so much attention in recent days in Washington to the question of whether Pyongyang was ready to allow repeated inspections of its sites.
By measuring the radioactive decay in the old rods after they are removed, inspectors may also be able to determine if other fuel rods were taken out in recent years. That would be another piece of evidence of continuing diversion of fuel to a weapons program.
To avert sanctions, though, officials say North Korea will finally have to relent on special inspections, and that is expected to be a major stumbling block. The two nuclear waste sites may only be the beginning. Hans Blix, the director of the atomic energy agency, suggested in 1992 that other reprocessing sites, including a smaller "pilot plant," may have been built. American intelligence officials have other sites they believe warrant inspections.
"We have a lot of places we may want to see," one South Korean official said. "Unless we can, in three months the crisis will be back."

URANIUM FUEL: Inspectors say the reprocessing plant, which turns nuclear waste into plutonium, is only partly completed inside. But testing the waste would probably help determine how much plutonium North Korea has in hand. Other sites are belived to be located in deep tunnels beneath the Yongbyon complex.

HEADLINE: Clinton Going to a Europe Poised 'at Turning Point'

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
As President Clinton begins the longest foreign journey of his young presidency, he is preparing to cast himself and the United States as forces of stability for an uneasy Europe and a politically divided Russia.
Far from the congratulatory idyll he may once have expected, the eight-day trip across the Continent from Brussels to Prague, Moscow, Minsk and then Geneva is shadowed by new difficulties arising from the strong showing of rightist candidates in Russian elections last month. 
 For Mr. Clinton, who last visited Moscow as an Oxford University student in the late 1960's, the trip presents an opportunity to cast himself as a true statesman who can address the deep concerns of European governments and put the United States behind the right forces at an uncertain time in history.
"All of Europe stands at a turning point with deep implications for our own security and prosperity," Vice President Al Gore said in a radio address he delivered today on behalf of Mr. Clinton, who was returning from the funeral of his mother in Arkansas and preparing to depart again around midnight for the NATO summit meeting in Brussels.
Mr. Gore described the President's trip as one "that can help make our nation and our world more secure in every way."
 
NATO Meeting of 16 Leaders
 Leaders of the 16 NATO nations are to meet in Brussels on Monday and Tuesday. Mr. Clinton heads next to Prague, where he will meet with leaders of Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Slovakia; then on to Moscow on Wednesday for meetings with President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Mr. Clinton will also visit the former Soviet republic of Belarus, which he will praise for its efforts to eliminate nuclear weapons, before continuing to Geneva next weekend for meetings with Swiss officials and the President of Syria, Hafez al-Assad.
The President has said he will seek on his trip to reinvigorate the Atlantic alliance, encourage political reform in the former East bloc, limit the dangers posed by stocks of nuclear weapons and promote economic renewal throughout Europe.
But he must also contend with complaints from Eastern Europeans angered by his refusal to grant them immediate membership in NATO and with the challenges to political and economic reform in Russia personified by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist whose faction is now the second-largest bloc in a freely elected Parliament.
 
A Tangled Agenda
 So tangled is the agenda that on the eve of Mr. Clinton's departure, Administration officials said they had not decided exactly how to finesse the political uncertainty in Moscow.
Still undecided, for instance, was whether Mr. Clinton should reach out to the agrarians and Communists who now make up about half of the new Parliament's membership.
He is also facing criticism at home from some of leading foreign policy figures of the Bush Administration, who have described his plan to offer Eastern European countries the status of "association" with NATO instead of prompt membership as a decision that history will view as a mistake.
Even Mr. Clinton acknowledged this week that he could not say with absolute confidence that he had chosen the right course. "You always have these judgment calls," he told newspaper columnists in a moment of candor, "and only history can render a verdict."
 
Meeting 23 Leaders
 His trip will include meetings with at least 23 heads of state or government, including the session in Geneva with Mr. Assad, who will be pressed for a commitment on bringing about peace in the Middle East.
It is in Brussels, Prague, Moscow and Minsk, the settings for discussions about Europe and the former Soviet empire, that Mr. Clinton will come into closest contact with the issue of resurgent nationalism that Mr. Gore described this week as "a dark cloud on the horizon of Europe."
When planning began for the President's trip in the middle of last year, the journey promised to be something of a stroll through Europe, where Mr. Clinton would be greeted by erstwhile allies, grateful Eastern Europeans and a strong partner in Mr. Yeltsin.
Aides said they hoped Mr. Clinton would perform as well as he did on his previous overseas journey, a six-day trip in July in which he attended an economic summit meeting of the leading industrialized democracies in Tokyo and stopped in South Korea to visit American troops.
But the gathering of NATO leaders in Brussels, the main occasion for Mr. Clinton's current trip, is likely to be clouded by the alliance's embarrassing failure to come up with a plan to halt the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. With the fighting there having worsened in recent days, American officials are bracing for embarrassing pressure from France for NATO to assume a greater peacemaking role.
 
Seeking Russia-Ukraine Accord
 Perhaps the best news the White House hoped to draw from the summit meeting with Mr. Yeltsin -- an announcement that Russia and Ukraine had resolved a dispute over the formidable nuclear arsenal left on Ukrainian soil -- remained only a slight possibility as Mr. Clinton departed, although The Associated Press reported tonight that progress had been made toward an agreement.
"We're very, very close, though there are some details to be ironed out," mostly between Ukraine and Russia, The A.P. quoted a senior Administration official as having said.
If a deal is struck, President Leonid Kravchuk of Ukraine would likely go to Moscow this week to join President Clinton and President Yeltsin in initialing the accord, the official said.
From the moment he lands in Brussels on Sunday afternoon, Mr. Clinton is expected rather to emphasize his plan for a "Partnership for Peace" as an alternative to any arrangement that would etch new lines across Europe.
The partnership, which is to be approved by NATO's 16 members during the meeting in Brussels, would offer cooperation but no security guarantees from NATO to former Warsaw Pact states, to Russia and the other former Soviet republics and to Europe's neutral countries -- Switzerland, Sweden, Austria and Finland.
It is intended to satisfy the Eastern Europeans without complicating matters in Moscow, where the rise of Mr. Zhirinovsky and other nationalists has caused Mr. Yeltsin and his fellow reformers to warn against anything that looks like Western encirclement.
 
Forging New Bonds
 A senior Administration official has described the plan as an effort by Mr. Clinton to address "a moment of extraordinary strategic importance" and forge new bonds on a continent that was divided for four decades.
A senior Defense Department official said Mr. Clinton would seek to persuade the leaders of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia when he meets with them in Prague that the proposed "partnership" is "not a gilded outhouse" but an entryway that could lead to ultimate NATO membership.
But with some Eastern European leaders pressing for immediate guarantees of NATO membership, and a spokesman for Mr. Yeltsin denouncing an application by Lithuania to join the alliance, Mr. Clinton will have difficulty convincing both sides that the United States is responding to their concerns.
That Mr. Clinton's mission suddenly seems so delicate is a stark reflection of how complicated American foreign policy has become in a world in which alliances are less clear.
So important has Eastern Europe become to the United States that Mr. Clinton's Prague visit, which begins Tuesday night, is described by his aides as a crucial "part two" of the NATO summit. And by traveling later from Moscow to Minsk, the capital of Belarus, he will demonstrate a growing American recognition of the significance of the other former Soviet republics -- particularly those that, unlike Ukraine, have already given up their nuclear weapons.
 
Final Meeting With Assad
 Mr. Clinton's final meeting, with Mr. Assad in Geneva, is intended to complete what he began in September in presiding over the handshake at the White House between Prime Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Assad told visiting United States envoys last month that "big things happen when big people meet." American officials hope that gesture will be an agreement by Syria to normalize its relations with Israel.
When he arrives on Wednesday in Moscow, Mr. Clinton will find a capital whose political mood has changed not only since his last visit 23 years ago, but in the weeks and months since his trip was first planned.
Looking forward to a series of meetings with Mr. Yeltsin, including a private dinner at his dacha, Mr. Clinton has made clear that his main goal during the visit will be to encourage the political and economic reforms favored by the Russian President and many aides but opposed by perhaps half of the newly elected Parliament.
Mr. Clinton plans to meet with Russian lawmakers to show support for reformers other than Mr. Yeltsin. But as he prepared to leave Washington, Administration officials said the only firm decision he had made was not to meet with Mr. Zhirinovsky.

HEADLINE: Many in Haiti Now Believe the U.S. Has Given Up on Aristide

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Whatever the intention, President Clinton's pessimistic assessment of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide this week convinced many Haitians that Washington's halting efforts to restore him as President of Haiti were drawing to a close.
Mr. Clinton's remarks, in which he seemed to be calling for a reassessment of American support for Father Aristide, were banner news in Haiti's press, the talk of radio commentators and for many in a conservative elite that rejects the exiled President, an occasion for champagne toasts. 
 Reacting to Mr. Clinton's comments, American diplomats quickly began issuing statements saying that despite Mr. Clinton's statement that Father Aristide's prospects for returning to power were now "clouded," the United States remained committed to restoring the Haitian leader to office.
 
'It's All Over'
 Nonetheless, few across the political spectrum in Haiti seem to believe that Washington still has any enthusiasm for reviving a long-stalled diplomatic strategy for achieving that goal.
"It's all over," a wealthy Haitian businessmen said with glee after what he viewed as a signal that Washington was finally dropping its insistence that a return to democracy in Haiti include the return of Father Aristide to the presidency. "It's just a question now of when they lift the sanctions."
The United Nations Security Council reimposed sanctions on fuel deleveries in October when military leadership reneged on a negotiated agreement to surrender power and make way for Father Aristide's return. Continued defiance by the military has brought threats of reinforced sanctions beginning as early as Jan. 15, with a ban on commercial air traffic and a total trade embargo reportedly under consideration by the international community.
Diplomats have declined to spell out what new punitive measures will be taken, but many Haitians including supporters of Father Aristide say they no longer believe that strong new sanctions will be applied, especially after President Clinton's remarks to journalists on Wednesday.
"I don't see the point," said a member of Father Aristide's Government, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If they are applying sanctions just for the sake of doing something, what good does that do the Haitian people?"
For months, Haitian commentators on the left and right have criticized Washington for imposing economic sanctions only to quickly introduce major exceptions or fail to enforce them.
 
Clinton's Withdrawal of Ship
 In the most embarrassing turnaround, two weeks before Father Aristide's negotiated return, scheduled for Oct. 30, the Clinton Administration ordered the withdrawal of a ship carrying about 300 Canadian and American troops who were intended in part to cement the diplomatic settlement.
If the international community has lacked consistency, so too has Father Aristide, whose statements and decisions have brought criticism from his supporters and unusually public expressions of frustration from Washington, leading up to Mr. Clinton's comments.
Father Aristide's slide began last month with the resignation of his handpicked Prime Minister, Robert Malval, after the exiled Haitian President withdrew support for a national conference that Mr. Malval was trying to organize.
Afterward, the Clinton Administration's reservations began to surface more publicly when Father Aristide made thinly veiled threats to end his cooperation in discouraging Haitians from trying to flee to the United States and instead help focus public attention on the plight of Haitian boat people. He finally relented to strong diplomatic pressure on Friday by inviting the Haitian military to take part in a political conference of his own in Miami, but did so only grudingly.
 
New Year's Speech
 On New Year's Day, Haiti's independence day, Father Aristide broadcast a speech to his nation in which he urged the people to emulate the Haitian revolutionary leader, Jean-Jacques Dessalines, whose motto against French colonialists was: "Cut off their heads and burn down their homes." In his speech, he seemed to endorse violent resistance against the Haitian Army by saying the people should use "iron to cut iron."
Days later, in an interview with The Miami Herald, he came close to endorsing a "surgical strike" by the United States to remove the army leaders in Haiti, a call that the State Department described as "unhelpful."
"The President has not helped himself recently," said one of Father Aristide's ministers, who like others spoke on condition of anonymity. "He has ended up projecting an image of incoherence at a time when he can scarcely afford it."

HEADLINE: Prominent Blacks Stress Family, Church and School as Instruments to Fight Violence

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
A group of black politicians, sociologists, ministers, entertainers and civil rights leaders, meeting to build a strategy to fight violence, produced an agenda today that was heavy on the old-fashioned notion of reaching out to save wayward young people through family, church and school.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose National Rainbow Coalition convened the three-day meeting, called for blacks to take the "moral offensive" in fighting violence. 
 He also pushed some of his own political causes, like voter registration and pressing the Clinton Administration to put together an urban policy and take a stronger position on civil rights.
"Oftentimes, what a movement does is determine the options of a President," Mr. Jackson said. "Urban policy, for the first time in a long time, will be discussed at the White House on Monday."
Mr. Jackson said he would take the agenda to President Clinton. No meeting date had been set as of today.
Mr. Jackson called the meeting to discuss what leaders of black groups have called an alarming rise in murder, assault and other violent crime among blacks. Homicide is the leading cause of death among young black males, and the killer typically is another young black male.
 
Stressing Responsibility
 Mr. Jackson said he would hold similar meetings in other cities, giving priority to states with upcoming Senate elections.
Participants came away calling today's agenda a watershed, and said it would be received enthusiastically in inner-city communities struggling with violent crime.
"This is the first meaningful and measurable blow to deal with the problem," said Representative Kweisi Mfume, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. "While black people are not a monolith, on this issue we are pretty close to a consensus."
Mr. Mfume suggested attacking the problem with an all-out traditional values campaign that stresses responsibility, respect for the elderly, pride in black heritage and stronger connections between black parents and teachers.
The Rev. Al Sharpton, the New York civil rights leader, suggested that blacks press for criminal penalties for gun manufacturers whose weapons turn up on the black market. That is where most youths, often as young as 11 years old, get their guns, Mr. Sharpton said.
The meeting today also forged an alliance between high-profile leaders and grass-roots leaders who felt abandoned by them.
 
'Walls We Must Knock Down'
 "These are some of the walls we must knock down," said Minister Fontian, who works with the Black Disciples, a Chicago gang with about 35,000 members. "They need us as much as we need them. Now I can go back and give a reasonable report."
The agenda included these proposals:
*Mentoring 10 youths each at 100 churches in 100 cities.
*Antiviolence pledges between students and parents.
*Urging parents to enforce studying and attending school.
*Employment programs for young people ages 17 to 30.
*Degree programs at black colleges for prison inmates.
*Supervised after-school programs.
*Removing barriers to family life in social service programs.
Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros pointed to rules in public housing that tie rent to a family's income. In many cases, he said, husbands and fathers leave the household so their income will not be included and the rent will not go up.
Mr. Cisneros said he wanted to delete such rules from housing policy. Those barriers aside, he said, families can then help themselves.

HEADLINE: California's Tide of Illegal Aliens Ebbs

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Even as public resentment over a perceived invasion of California by illegal aliens has soared, the tide of illegal immigration here may in fact have begun to ebb.
While thousands of illegal aliens from Mexico and Central American still illegally cross the California-Mexico border every day, their numbers seem to be declining even as substantial numbers of aliens already illegally here appear to be returning home. The effect has still been a net increase in illegal immigrants in California over the last year, the experts say, but in declining numbers. 
 Many of the aliens who say they are returning home report that they are unable to find work or are fed up with crime, poor schools and urban congestion.
 
End of a Dream
 "The American dream is not true," said Jose Chavez, a 20-year-old laborer from Michoacan, Mexico, who said he was returning home after three years in Los Angeles. "It didn't happen. I have no more dreams, no way to pay the rent."
Standing on one of the hundreds of street corners where such aliens wait daily for job offers, Mr. Chavez said he had not had a day's work for more than two weeks.
The Mexican Consulate here reports that the number of Mexicans seeking permits to ship their household belongings back to Mexico from the Los Angeles area in 1993 nearly doubled to 1,330 from 735 in 1992.
As ever, with the elusive world of migration from Mexico, in which families are often made up of both legal and illegal residents, these figures can be misinterpreted. Many Mexicans use these permits to ship televisions and other consumer goods to sell at a profit or give to relatives in Mexico. The shippers do not necessarily intend to repatriate themselves. But the consulate's figures tend to corroborate other data.
 
Apprehensions Down 6%
 According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, apprehensions of illegal aliens trying to cross the California-Mexico border dropped by about 6 percent in the year ended Sept. 30 compared with the same period a year earlier, to 531,689 from 565,581. And the Census Bureau reported last month that for the first time in 20 years, California's population grew at a slower rate than the nation's as a whole.
All of this will have only a slight immediate effect in a state that absorbed half of all legal and illegal immigration into the United States in the 1980's, bringing massive social and economic change to Los Angeles and other cities. Immigration experts estimate that of California's 30 million residents, 1 million are illegal aliens, most of them Mexicans.
While initially welcomed as a source of cheap, hard-working labor when California was booming, the Mexican immigrants are now widely perceived as taking jobs away from Americans, causing street crime, graffiti and housing decay and for placing huge financial burdens on school districts, welfare agencies and other public services.
Politicians, including Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and liberals like Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, have joined a growing chorus demanding tighter border controls and other measures to discourage immigration.
 
Economy Tighter Than Border
 But it appears that California's protracted economic slump has begun to have the same effect. The slump devastated the industries in which the immigrants, both legal and not, have long worked as day laborers, like construction and landscaping.
"Street-corner labor markets have become overpopulated relative to the demand," said Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego. He said that he believed that men like Mr. Chavez were returning home and telling others in Mexico not to come to California because there was not enough income to be earned, especially for families with children.
 
Excess of Farm Workers
 Much the same is happening in farm areas, said Don Villarejo, director of the California Institute for Rural Studies in Sacramento. "There is an oversupply of available workers," he said.
Reliable statistics on illegal immigration, given its nature, are difficult to obtain. But anecdotal evidence from interviews with more than 20 illegal aliens on the streets of Los Angeles and Orange Counties suggests they are becoming discouraged. Many men said they had sent their families home.
Jorge Lopez, another Mexican immigrant who stood at the same corner waiting for work as Mr. Chavez, said things had gone from bad to worse in the last three years. "I think I will return to Mexico," said Mr. Lopez, 20. "Everyday it's more difficult."
Mr. Lopez said he had gone five days without work and was struggling to pay bills in the hotel where he lives with three other workers. "There's just no work," he said.
Indirect indicators also point to a slower flow of illegal aliens. School enrollments this year in cities with large Mexican populations, like Santa Ana and Anaheim in Orange County, are lower than expected.
Since 1987, Mexican researchers at the Colegio de la Frontera Norte, a private research institute in Tijuana, have been surveying illegal aliens crossing almost the entire 2,000-mile border from California to Texas. The director, Jorge Bustamante, said that the early years of the American recession had seen no letup in northward migration but that researchers had recently noticed a small decline in the increase in illegal entries into the United States: 5 percent in 1993 and 8 percent in 1992.
Illegal immigration from Mexico, as gauged by the United States Border Patrol's apprehension of would-be immigrants, soared in the 1980's until the enactment of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The law gave amnesty to long-term illegal residents but sought to deter further immigration by imposing heavy penalties on employers who hire people without proper documentation.
 
Big Drop in Apprehensions
 The law achieved its purpose at first; apprehensions plummeted after it went into effect. The number of illegal aliens apprehended peaked at 1.7 million in 1986 before dropping to 891,000 in 1989. The number has been rising steadily ever since. And while apprehensions on the California border dropped in 1993, the total number rose to 1.3 million from 1.2 million the previous year.
The reasons for the decline in California are unclear, but one possibility is that immigrants have switched destinations to economically healthier states like Texas and Colorado.
If illegal immigration is indeed abating, experts cite a variety of reasons, including the recession, greater American political and government efforts to stop it, the end of civil war in El Salvador and the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has bolstered hopes of economic improvement in Mexico.
"Everybody thinks the streets are paved with gold here and they find that is not the case," said Alan C. Nelson, a former commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service who is now a consultant and lobbyist in Sacramento for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a national anti-immigration group.
"It's not as easy to get jobs and welfare benefits as it used to be," he added. "They read the papers, listen to radio and TV. Word gets around that things have tightened up."
 
'Gangsters, Guns and Drugs'
 Carol Pacheco, a medical clerk who lives in Long Beach, is a legal resident who came here as a child with her mother and married an American. Ms. Pacheco, now divorced, was at the Mexican Consulate a week ago to prepare to emigrate to her birthplace of Colima, Mexico, along with her 10-year-old daughter.
"I don't want to send her to school here," she said, clutching her papers. "As soon as you start junior high, it's gangsters, guns and drugs. I don't have nothing against Americans. It's just the city itself, how it's going."
Some aliens are leaving because tougher law enforcement has made it much harder to get the counterfeit green cards and other papers that used to be so available. Jose Jaramillo, a 37-year-old mechanic, is planning to repatriate to Veracruz, Mexico, after 20 years in California because he fears it will be impossible to get more work.
"I used to have a green card that I bought," he said. "But I lost it, so I'm in trouble. When I first came, it was easy to get I.D. Right now you can't get anything."
But that is not the only reason. He and his wife, Marta, have three boys, and he is reluctant to have them grow up in gang-ridden Los Angeles County. "I am trying to get my children raised in Mexico, to learn other ways," he said. "I don't want to see my boys getting involved with gang bangers."
 
Job Offers Drying Up
 Mr. Chavez, the 20-year-old Mexican, is among the several dozen day laborers who line up each morning along Sawtelle Avenue in West Los Angeles, hoping to get job offers from contractors and homeowners. In 1991, before the recession bit deeply, Mr. Chavez said he could earn $250 a week in roofing, street paving and landscaping.
But the last time he had more than a day of work in a week was in November, he said, when he earned $150 for three days of roofing. He lives in a small apartment in the rough Pico-Union district near downtown where his four roommates are lending him his share of the $450 monthly rent.
He has reached the end of the line in the United States. Mr. Chavez said he was flying back to his hometown of Morelia to try to make a living in the fields where his parents and 10 brothers have worked most of their lives.
"I have no way to pay the rent," he said. "I don't want to live in the streets or in the mission. If there are employers, there's lots of work. But when there's no work, I don't eat."
He said he had no illusions that he could earn much money in Mexico beyond enough for food. But, he added, "I miss my family."

HEADLINE: Clinton on the Continent

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Waiting at the door for Bill Clinton, Europe is as edgy and defensive as an executive who has asked the boss home to dinner.
"This is a critical moment for them and for him," said Pamela Harriman, the friend, adviser and fund-raiser whom the President sent to Paris as Ambassador. "The Europeans don't know him. Too many of them see him as a man who plays the saxophone by night and wears running shoes by day. Next week he needs to show them his brains, his scope, his leadership."
 
Sources of the Anxiety
 When Mr. Clinton arrives on Sunday afternoon for his first visit to Europe as President, he will have completed almost a year in the Oval Office. For all those months, Europeans have been watching, trying to take his measure from afar, studying his policies (or what many see as the lack thereof) and wondering why he has waited so long to come. 
 Their anxious mood is compounded of many things: an apprehension about the unknown, an unsettling generational change, a sense that history may be flowing away from them. All that was probably inevitable. So, too, in all likelihood, is the low-key resentment felt by proud countries that find their fortunes controlled, to some degree, by the world's only superpower.
Europe is beset by problems of its own, including stalled economies, a dearth of strong leaders and troubles with ambitious plans for further integration. But Mr. Clinton's actions have also played a part in creating serious strains.
He found time to visit Tokyo, then to meet with leaders of the Pacific Rim nations in Seattle but he was too busy for us, European politicians and editorial writers complain. He has called relations with Japan the most important the United States has, and has repeatedly hailed the vibrancy of the new Asian economies. Trading with them is vital to the creation of new jobs and economic vigor in the United States, the Administration says.
Suddenly, Eurocentric has become a dirty word in Washington.
"We are starting to feel isolated," a prominent German said. "It used to be Europe and America, the Atlantic nations, taking on all comers, especially the Communist bloc. Now we're afraid it's you and the Asians, the Pacific nations, who are setting the pace, with us off by ourselves."
Such apprehensions are magnified by the lack of familiar players in Washington. Not only is Mr. Clinton a fresh face on the international scene, none of the top figures in the foreign-policy team have extensive experience here.
Neither Secretary of State Warren Christopher nor Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, has spent the years on the European conference circuit that many predecessors had, and for the first time in many years the State Department hierarchy lacks a prominent specialist in Western European affairs.
 
The Shadow of Bosnia
 "There always used to be someone we knew to go to for a clear reading on where you were heading," said Sir Charles Powell, who was Margaret Thatcher's main foreign policy adviser. "If not Henry, then Zbig. If not Colin Powell, then Brent Scowcroft. We may not have liked the policy, but at least we usually understood it, and we knew how strongly views were held.
"To put it mildly, that has not been the case in recent months."
An American ambassador with long experience in Europe agrees. Even making allowances for the difficulties of policy-making in the post-cold-war world, he said, even allowing for the usual slippage involved in the transition from one Administration to another, "we have not spoken with a very clear or forceful voice."
The mutual failure of Europe and the United States to come to grips with the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina still rankles here. And European officials gripe all the more loudly about what they term the feebleness of American leadership because, as a few of them concede, they are all too painfully aware of their own lack of unity and creativity on Bosnia.
Still, as Lord Owen, the European Community negotiator on Bosnia, sometimes says, "The United States is the only country that can actually decide anything these days." So Mr. Christopher's failure to push strongly for Mr. Clinton's original Bosnia plan on his ill-fated European swing early last year stands as a metaphor for what many politicians here see as a kind of spiritual disengagement from Europe and its problems.
 
The NATO Puzzle
 By contrast, Europe has more or less agreed to the President's "Partnership for Peace" -- a half-a-loaf plan to hold off a definitive decision on whether the former Soviet satellite countries should be allowed to join NATO.
The plan is widely recognized here for what it is, a fudge, "all smoke and no steel," in the words of one French official. But Washington has made a strong case for the proposition that it is the best answer possible now, and the Europeans have welcomed Washington's rigor as well as the continued commitment to NATO it implies.
Like Henry A. Kissinger and other American specialists, however, many Europeans worry that the Administration is so determined to avoid offending the Russians, who oppose NATO membership for Poland, the Czech Republic and other Eastern European nations, that it has given Moscow a virtual veto over NATO policy. The power of Strobe Talbott, the newly named Deputy Secretary of State, who has spent his entire career on Soviet affairs, reinforces those worries.
In general Europeans are less sanguine than Americans about the chances of democracy taking root in Russia. So they are more inclined to put the emphasis on strengthening the new Eastern Europe.
 
Diplomatic Fuzziness
 "In terms of European stability, I think that Poland is the most important problem," one Briton said. "But it's not easy to get an airing for that view in Washington, with Strobe and the Russia-firsters in charge."
A few here are ready right now to extend NATO membership, and with it the American nuclear umbrella, to the East. But there is a good deal of support for a more specific commitment, a declaration that if the Eastern Europeans satisfy certain requirements by a certain date, probably three to five years hence, they can expect admission then.
That is not going to happen at the NATO summit talks this week in Brussels. As much as possible will be left dangling. Unintentionally, no doubt, Ruud Lubbers, the Dutch Prime Minister, made that clear this week in a television interview in which he avoided words like pledge and timetable and filled 15 minutes with talk of "process" and "prospect" and "possibility."
As a result, some Western Europeans say the allies will miss a chance to reinforce democratic tendencies, not unlike the chance that was seized, with great success, when Spain, Portugal and Greece were admitted to the European Community after they threw off right-wing dictatorships. Clearly, despite promises of joint military maneuvers and other sweeteners, there will be widespread disappointment in Warsaw and other East European capitals.
But what will matter most is first, whether Mr. Clinton can convince his peers that he is a capable leader who takes foreign policy seriously, and second, whether he can offer a vision for revitalizing the European-American partnership even as the United States, with its resources stretched, focuses on problems at home and pursues new opportunities in Asia.

HEADLINE: Bid to Revise Education Is Fought in Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 7

 BODY:
A movement to improve the public schools that has gained a rare consensus among Presidents, governors, business leaders and educators is coming under attack in Connecticut, as it has across the country.
The movement is driven by a simple-sounding theory most commonly called outcome-based education: that the way to improve schools is first to decide what skills or knowledge graduates should have, and then to design the schools to achieve those outcomes. 
 "Outcome-based education has been around since the 1920's," Greenwich's Superintendent of Schools, John Whritner, told a crowded forum on Thursday where he spoke in support of the philosophy behind the proposals. "It made a lot of sense: know where you want to go before heading down the road."
But to opponents, who vary from parents in upper-class suburbs like Greenwich to religious fundamentalists, outcome-based education has grown to symbolize everything they fear from public schooling, from mediocrity to mind control and meddling in family values. And here the concern is focused particularly on whether efforts to improve struggling schools in the inner cities will affect the quality of those in the suburbs.
The fight has been provoked by a sweeping set of proposals offered by a state panel to fulfill the Connecticut Legislature's mandate of promoting an "outcome-based, world-class educational system." If adopted by the Legislature, the plan would overhaul the way schools are run in the state and the way students are taught.
 
Proving Skills Were Learned
 For instance, instead of graduating by earning enough credits, students would have to prove they had acquired a specific set of skills, the skills demanded by colleges and by employers needing highly trained workers. Also, teachers would be retrained, and emphasis would be placed on helping everyone learn a lesson, rather than issuing grades that leave some students behind.
Schools would be reorganized to give teachers and administrators the freedom to decide how to attain the standards. They would also be held more accountable, and the state could take over school districts that failed to progress.
But critics in many suburbs here say the proposal would unnecessarily disturb and drag down their schools, which they believe are doing a good job, in a misguided effort to solve a separate problem: the failure of schools in cities like Hartford, which are overwhelmed by large numbers of poor children.
The only way the plan would close the gap between Greenwich and Hartford, they fear, would be by bringing Greenwich down to the city's level.
"There is a problem, but it's in the cities," said Kathleen Renton, a Greenwich P.T.A. Council vice president who objects to many of the commission's proposals. "Why do you have to apply the solution universally, where it's not needed?"
 
Surprise at Parents' Hostility
 The opposition here has mirrored the reaction in other places where outcome-based plans have been proposed. In state after state, business and education leaders, confident that they finally knew how to improve the schools, have been surprised to encounter emotional opposition from the very people they expected to support them: parents.
"What is so striking is their opposition to something that is led by all the relevant forces in the country when there's such a widespread sense that we need to do something about education in the United States?" said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States.
The opponents, however, see the unanimity among national business, education and political leaders as proof that something more than improving the schools is afoot.
"It's not a program that improves education; it's a program that rounds out education with all sorts of social goals," said Kay Wall, a Greenwich P.T.A. member who has criticized outcome-based education in forums across Connecticut. "And it hurts a lot of children it's designed to help."
 
Panel Bans Emotional Phrase
 The emerging opposition in Connecticut has caused great concern for the state's Commission on Educational Excellence, which after 18 months of study is taking its plan for remaking Connecticut schools to public hearings next week.
In fact the commission contends that the issues that opponents have collected under the banner of outcome-based education have so little to do with the panel's work that it has struck all references to "outcome-based" from its proposals, even though its legislative mandate is to promote just that.
"In Fairfield County, we have a great deal of passion being stirred up through a terrifying vision that is being called outcome-based education," one commission member, Christopher Bruhl, told his colleagues on Tuesday at their last meeting before the hearings.
"And it is a terrifying vision," he said, "even though nothing like it is being proposed; it is the Devil. We have simply got to recognize that that name has been tarnished and lost."
 
Potentially Tough Audience
 At two forums here this week, the commission's plan had a preview before a potentially tough audience, several hundred parents, teachers and residents of Greenwich, a wealthy town that takes great pride in its schools, and is home to Mrs. Wall and other critics of the commission.
Mr. Bruhl, president of a Fairfield County business group, argued that the state's public education system must be redesigned because while many towns like Greenwich have good schools, those in poorer communities are failing their children.
Changes in the world economy are eliminating or driving down wages for unskilled factory jobs, he said, and to compete for high-paying jobs with countries like Japan and Germany, the United States must raise education levels for everyone.
The solution, he said, is to set high expectations for all students, and then to redesign schools so that teachers and administrators have the flexibility to help them succeed and are held accountable if they do not.
 
More Control for Schools
 Schools would no longer be measured by how much money they spent on students, but by what they learned. Those who learned quickly would move on quickly. Others would take longer, but a teacher's job could no longer be to present a lesson and then distribute A's to some and F's to others. "All children can learn" is the movement's motto.
To make teachers and principals accountable, each school would have more control over its budget and its curriculum, and retraining would be provided, but the state's tenure law would also be changed.
To prepare poor children to learn, Head Start programs and preschools would be expanded. To prepare everyone for the computer age, $75 million a year would be spent on upgrading schools' technology. The entire proposal would require $200 million the first year.
"Much of what we're doing is because in much of Connecticut, for 50 percent of the students, the standards we are talking about are not in evidence," said Lawrence Miller, a regional director of cooperative education. "If everyone were like Greenwich, we'd be in much better shape."
 
Conservative Groups Are Foes
 Across the country, advocates of the changes say, opposition to outcome-based plans has issued from conservative groups like the Eagle Forum and Focus on the Family. Those concerns are present in Greenwich, where sex education was the focus of a hard battle a year ago.
But critics like Mrs. Wall have also found a response in communities like Greenwich because many parents there expect their children to go on to good colleges and don't believe there is a crisis. City schools have problems, they acknowledge, but applying the same drastic solution in both Bridgeport and Greenwich would only drag all schools down to Bridgeport's level.
To them, even the idea of holding all children to high standards is unrealistic. Outcome-based education, they say, closes the achievement gap only by holding all students to the pace of the slowest learners.
Mrs. Wall and other critics say the philosophy of outcome-based education is to eliminate differences among children, and so it relies on cooperative learning among children and eliminates grades and tracking.
 
A 'Dumb-Down' Dispute
 "Some people are competitive, but many people have become less competitive, and have decided they don't want their children to be put in competitive, pecking-order situations," Mrs. Wall said. "It's not really an education question. It's how do you feel about life."
Advocates of the new proposals are frustrated when their talk of raising standards is turned around into a plan to "dumb-down" the curriculum.
"We think that even in our best school systems we need to produce better results, but somehow that's not being translated by this group," said Connecticut's education commissioner, Vincent Ferrandino.
But some advocates say the concern over such issues as eliminating grades reflects a correct perception by some parents that the proposed changes, by helping all children do well, would increase competition for theirs. Now, schools sort children into winners and losers, they said, and the goal of the proposals is to have far more winners.
 
Preserving Lots of Losers
 "Now they know their children are doing well because other kids are getting C's, D's and F's," said Marjorie Ledell, a consultant in Littleton, Colo., who advises school officials on how to present plans for changes to the public.
The ultimate problem for advocates of change, Ms. Ledell said, is that they doing a poor job of explaining complex proposals.
"There is, indeed, deep distrust of what public education has done so far," she said. "That's because our educators have done what they thought was best, and the public just passively trusted them. Now that they're getting clear-cut information from our critics, it looks like what you're getting from school systems is a lot of jargon. It looks like educators are trying to put something over on the public.


GRAPHIC: Major proposals of a commission studying public education in Connecticut.
Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Fixing the Schools"

 Curriculums should provide students with the skills required for entry into the work force or higher education.
 The state should adopt a results-oriented system that sets world-class content standards and high performance standards.
 Assessments must focus on a student's ability to demonstrate and apply knowledge. A variety of assessment techniques is needed, because no one method can measure achievement.
 New standards and assessments should incorporate a multicultural perspective.

 The council and principal will make decisions on the curriculum and teaching methods.
 Local districts will determine the composition of school councils and have to remove principals at schools with patterns of failure.
 Every five years teachers should provide a dossier demonstrating their efforts to help their students.
 Tenure will be granted after the fourth year of teaching in a district, rather than the third.
 Teachers should be held accountable for their students meeting performance standards. (pg. 27)
