HEADLINE: Financial Climate Warms for States

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Forty-five states say they are fiscally sound this year, nearly twice the number that could make such a claim a year ago, according to a survey by the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Moreover, few states say they are likely to raise taxes or employ accounting gimmicks to balance their books this year, reflecting the slow but steady growth in the national economy as well as the ability of states to learn to live within their means. 
 The conclusions of the survey, made public on Thursday, show a reversal of a trend that began in the 1990 fiscal year, when the recession began battering state budgets and most states collected less revenue than anticipated and had to spend more money than they had budgeted. The combination led to huge tax increases and extensive reductions in service.
"It's a dramatic change in the number of states that have turned the corner," said Ronald K. Snell, the fiscal director of the National Conference of State Legislatures, the Denver-based organization that advises states. "States are adjusting to a very unexciting economy."
 
Matching the Forecasts
 The survey of legislative budget analysts, which the conference conducts annually in December, found that most states were collecting and spending tax money in accordance with budget forecasts that they made last spring.
Of the 50 states, only Alaska, Hawaii, Kentucky, New Jersey and Rhode Island reported lower-than-expected tax collections in the first half of the fiscal year.
Still, some states -- most prominent among them California, Maine and Vermont -- have yet to emerge from the recession. California has not recovered from the loss of hundreds of thousands of high-tech and defense-related jobs, and northern New England still suffers from a depression in the real estate and construction industries.
Tax revenue in 45 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia were coming in at or above anticipated levels between July and early December, the survey found. Expenditures for programs were also on target in most states, and officials in 23 states said they had resources to cover overruns in one or more programs.
 
'Solid Fiscal Condition'
 "Forty-five states are in solid fiscal condition this year, up from only 25 a year ago," Mr. Snell said.
State finances are improving so much, he added, that officials are again focusing their attention on underfinanced social programs, which dropped in priority after the recession took hold in 1989.
When asked to list their most serious problems in terms of financing, nearly half of the state officials mentioned social programs like welfare and mental health care.
Growth in consumer confidence, personal income and spending made the strongest showing in Arizona, where sales tax receipts were up 7 percent and income taxes were up 8 percent. States in the Rocky Mountains and Plains generally had the strongest growth in tax revenues. The Northeast continued to have more fiscal problems than other regions.
Alaska still finds itself in trouble because 85 percent of its tax revenue comes from the oil industry, and the average price of Alaskan oil fell to $10.95 this month from $17.50 a barrel last June, said Darrel Rexwinkle, the State Commissioner of Revenue. That slide is expected to create a $500 million shortage in the state's $3 billion general fund budget. But, Mr. Rexwinkle said, the blow will be cushioned by more than $1 billion in reserve money.
 
Bad News for New Jersey
 In December, when the survey was taken, New Jersey's tax collections were running 2 percent below revenue projections, or about $70 million, said Alan R. Kooney, the legislative budget and finance officer in the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services. If the economy does not pick up, Gov.-elect Christine Todd Whitman and the Legislature will face a $250 million shortage in this year's $12 billion general fund budget. The state is already trying to cope with an anticipated shortage of more than $1 billion next fiscal year, which begins July 1.
New York, by comparison, expects revenue to continue exceeding projections and expenditures to be less than budgeted. Such a turn of events has not occurred in many years, said Paul C. Reuss, secretary of the state Legislature's Senate Finance Committee. The state anticipates a $500 million surplus on its $31 billion general fund budget this fiscal year, which ends March 31 in New York, Mr. Reuss said.
Connecticut must still rely on at least $30 million in reserve money to get through this year, even though state tax collections have been coming in slightly stronger than expected, said Robert D. Harris, the assistant director of the nonpartisan Office of Fiscal Analysis for the Legislature. "At least things are going in the right direction," he said.
California's revenue is on target, but officials there say the figures are misleading because unemployment continues to rise, foreshadowing sharp declines in income tax and business tax revenue later this year. In November, unemployment in the state was 8.6 percent. As a result, the state Commission on State Finance estimates that there will be a $1 billion shortfall in this year's $39.6 billion general fund budget and a $1.3 billion shortfall to be dealt with in the budget for next fiscal year. The commission, a part of the state Treasurer's Office, was itself recently disbanded to save money.

HEADLINE: Mayor Given Array of Ideas On Privatizing

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
A transition committee on privatization has recommended to the Giuliani administration that New York City sell WNYC, the city-owned television and radio stations, and contract out a vast array of municipal services, including garbage pickup, bus routes, street-sign maintenance, solid-waste disposal and parking-meter collections.
The committee has also suggested that the city could try to lease or sell the East River bridges in return for the right to levy tolls, although it acknowledged that the political opposition could be enormous, according to committee members and officials familiar with the report. 
 The committee, headed by Arthur Fefferman, the president of AFC Realty Capital Inc., is one of about 40 panels created by Rudolph W. Giuliani before he became Mayor to scrutinize the municipal government and make recommendations for change. The committee also recommended the sale of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, a move that the Dinkins administration had already been pursuing. The committee estimated that its recommendations could save more than $500 million a year.
 
Keeping 'an Open Mind'
 Senior aides to Mr. Giuliani said that they had not yet considered the recommendations and that they did not represent policy decisions. In fact, Mr. Giuliani, who made streamlining government a centerpiece of his campaign, suggested this week that it could be two to three months before he finished reviewing proposals for allowing private companies to bid for services now carried out by municipal employees.
"It's going to take a while for all of them to be examined, and you have got to keep an open mind about them," he said.
The report includes a menu of options for the new Mayor, including numerous proposals that have been examined and rejected in previous administrations. Mr. Fefferman expressed optimism that Mr. Giuliani would move forward with the ideas put forth by the group.
"It works if a lot of the impetus comes from the Mayor's office," he said. "Mayor Dinkins was not a strong advocate of privatization." Mr. Fefferman said his group had called for Mr. Giuliani to appoint an advisory committee on privatization "to be somewhat of an advocate and watchdog."
With the city facing a budget gap of as much as $2.3 billion next year, the report suggests such money-saving options as one-time sales of assets as well as reduced operating costs through competition between government agencies and private companies.
In the area of competitive contracting, some committee members said their most innovative idea was to take bus routes now run by private bus lines, longtime monopolies, in Queens and parts of Brooklyn and the Bronx and open them to competitive bidding both by other bus companies and by the city's Transit Authority.
 
Easing Unions' Fears
 They said the move could ease the fears of municipal unions over Mr. Giuliani's privatization efforts because it raised the possibility of providing more government jobs.
"It's very attractive and would show the Mayor's openness," said E. S. Savas, a professor of management at Baruch College who served on the committee. "It's not anti-public sector by any means. You could argue he's introducing discipline into the private sector."
The municipal unions have been leery of proposals to contract out services because of questions of job security for their members, and because some private companies can bid at lower cost because they save money through lower pay scales and benefits.
The seven private bus lines -- four of which run in Queens -- are the only private companies in the country that provide traditonal bus service on local streets, city officials say. The companies operate like the Transit Authority's buses, holding franchises on their routes and charging the same fares.
There is an incentive to save money: Since 1974 the city has been subsidizing the lines, at first almost entirely with Federal funds, but increasingly with the city's own money. The subsidies now amount to almost $100 million, half in city operating funds and half in state and Federal funds.
The subsidies have generally been arranged to cover the companies' expenses and guarantee a 3 percent profit. The city owns the companies' buses.
Under the new City Charter, the franchises are supposed to be put up for competitive bidding over the next five years, but city officials say the Transportation Department's efforts to draw up specifications have been bogged down in negotiations with the City Council.
 
Shulman Is Cautious
 Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, expressed caution about the proposal, noting that many riders in her borough depend on the lines. She said many private bus lines want to provide more lucrative express service but not local bus service. While she said she was not opposed to competitive bidding, she said the move would raise "complicated issues" and she would want to insure that the same level of service could be maintained.
Labor concerns could also be a sticking point, officials said. "You have a union issue when anybody starts bidding on anything," said Joseph Strasburg, the chief of staff to Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, also of Queens. "Unless there was some level of job security, it would probably be a very difficult fight."
In a related recommendation, the committee said that Transit Authority bus routes should be opened up to private competition, with van services allowed to bid as well as bus companies.
Committee members said they recommended the sale of WNYC, which is made up of a television station and an AM and a FM radio station, arguing that no other city owns such stations and that there is no need for them because of the variety of broadcast outlets in New York. The committee estimated that the sale of the assets and licenses could bring $45 million.
Similar proposals to sell WNYC during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's died because of public and political opposition. WNYC-FM is one of two classical-music stations left in the city, and with WNYC-AM is an outlet for National Public Radio.
 
No Decision on WNYC
 "No decision has been made so far as I know about WNYC," said Thomas B. Morgan, president of the WNYC Communications Group. "Our status remains as it has always been."
In other areas, the committee said that private companies should be solicited to collect coins from some of the city's 60,000 parking meters, that municipal parking garages should be leased to private operators and that a pilot program should be tried in one borough to privatize pothole repairs.
The committee also said the city should consider entering into contracts to use landfills outside New York. "The market for landfill space has dropped dramatically and prices are weak," Mr. Savas said. "It's a good opportunity for the city to enter into contracts with landfills outside the city at much lower cost than building and operating incinerators."

HEADLINE: Safeguards Already in Pension System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Daniel F. McGinn's call for "second opinions" for actuaries pressured into unreasonable assumptions by companies eager to reduce pension contributions ("To Guard Pensions, Shield Actuaries," Viewpoints, Dec. 26) ignores the many safeguards still in the system. Actuarial mathematics has developed financing methods that adjust for bad assumptions. The Internal Revenue Service even provides a range of interest rates for what it calls "current liability" calculations. 
 Second opinions are a false hope. If a company wants to maintain artificially low contribution rates and can afford to pay one actuary to compromise his or her principles, it can certainly pay a second, in lieu of properly financing the plan.
 
JOHN BURY
Kenilworth, N.J., Dec. 27
 
The writer is an enrolled actuary with Furlin & Steiner,a pension administration firm in Montclair, N.J.

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo Asks for Another Go

 BODY:
What we are seeing in Gov. Mario Cuomo's decision to seek a fourth term is a deliberate downsizing. The unaccustomed modesty of his announcement -- almost too late for Friday's 6 o'clock news -- matched the modesty of the program he set before the Legislature in Albany earlier in the week. A man known for soaring rhetoric now speaks only of his gritty determination to see New York through a clinging recession.
Unspoken, of course, is his hope to end his political career with a broader range of achievements than he could possibly have claimed had he chosen to retire next January. 
 The rap on Mr. Cuomo is that he does not deliver. A man of intelligence and compassion, he was twice a plausible possibility for the Democratic Presidential nomination. On issues of great principle, like abortion and the death penalty, he has stood his ground. Yet what people remark upon when they speak of Mr. Cuomo's 12 years in Albany is a maddening gap between oratory and substance, between poetry and accomplishment.
Is this fair? He says no. He points to, among other things, a doubling of state aid to schools, a rise in spending on infrastructure, a timely easing of New York's oppressive income tax burden in the 1980's and the passage of the state's first government ethics law. When asked why more ambitious projects never bore real fruit -- the "Decade of the Child" comes to mind -- he points to budgetary constraints imposed by the recession and political constraints imposed by a supremely unimaginative, Republican-dominated State Senate.
Yet on many matters of consequence he has been reluctant to spend his political capital. He doomed his own environmental bond act by refusing to fight for it. He has not delivered on his pledges to reform Medicaid or the state's balkanized school system. Even in good times, he resorted to dubious fiscal gimmicks -- plundering the state pension fund, for example -- that produced a balanced budget but also helped earn his state one of the lowest credit ratings in the nation.
So here he comes again -- low key this time, with a low-risk agenda of welfare reform, tax relief for business and crime control that the Republicans cannot in good conscience oppose. But there is no underestimating the political risk of running, despite the Republicans' unerring instinct for choosing inept opponents. His approval rating is a ghastly 34 percent; unless he can make a solid case that this time he'll match performance to promise, it is not beyond imagining that a once-incandescent political career could end with an ignominious fizzle.

HEADLINE: Include Russia, Too

 BODY:
The strong showing by right-wing nationalists in Russia's recent elections has intensified Eastern Europeans' fears of a resurgent Russia and increased their desire to ally with NATO. Such an alliance would commit the U.S. to their defense. But as Bosnia showed, neither the U.S. nor its allies seem eager to assume such commitments.
Moreover, the military threat that frightens Eastern Europe is, at worst, years away. One way to keep that threat from ever becoming a reality is to begin treating both Russia and the Eastern Europeans as partners -- cultivating habits of military cooperation throughout the region. 
 For starters, NATO could help Russia's reform-minded politicians shrink and reorganize Russia's armed forces, keeping the military engaged in professional tasks and out of politics. Russia would have to begin behaving like an ally by bringing its interests into closer harmony with NATO's -- curbing weapons proliferation, for example, and participating in peacekeeping operations.
And if NATO opens its doors to new members, Russia should be in line along with Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. The prospect of NATO membership could encourage the Russian Army to become a force for peace; that alone would justify reshaping an anti-Russian alliance into an altogether different security structure.
The U.S. Army needed at least 10 years to recover from the Vietnam War. The Russian remnant of the Red Army has endured greater trauma, losing not only a war in Afghanistan but also an empire. Many of its finest officers left for another country, Ukraine. Its weapons are rusting away. And officers are returning home without housing or jobs. Little wonder that a third of the military voting in the election backed candidates who rabble-roused about restoring the empire.
Little wonder, too, that the people of Eastern Europe fret about a Russian military resurgence. But it would take years for Russia to build a fighting force anything like the Red Army, and many more years before the military-industrial complex could equip it with state-of-the-art weapons.
What should the West do in the meantime? Right now, it is mainly trying to move Russia's politics and economy in the right direction, without doing much about the military. Some urge an updated version of containment, inviting Eastern Europeans into NATO while leaving Russia in not-so-splendid isolation. Others would revive old spheres of influence, shifting Russia's toward Central Asia.
These policies would be prudent if Russia reverted to vengeful nationalism and began to revive its military. To adopt them now would only embolden the Zhirinovskys at the fringes of Russian politics. The better way is to begin treating Russia like a potential ally. That worked in Germany and Spain, where NATO membership helped tame militarism.
The Clinton Administration has already taken some astute steps in this direction. It has encouraged more military-to-military contacts. And it has joined Russia in cutting nuclear forces and taking the remainder off hair-trigger alert.
But cooperation must embrace non-nuclear forces. A U.S.-Russian study group, including John Galvin and Edward Meyer, two retired generals, Fred Ikle and Paul Wolfowitz, Pentagon officials in the Reagan years, offers useful suggestions.
The group recommends a joint military planning staff to deal with issues of common concern, like proliferation. It proposes joint peacekeeping missions. It would increase aid to relocate the Russian forces that are leaving the Baltic republics. It urges shared understandings about the operating practices of U.S. stealth aircraft and other forces that Russia sees as threatening. And it would separate the U.S. and Russian Navies, which have a nasty habit of bumping into each other.
In like manner, NATO should also encourage Eastern Europe's armed forces to cooperate with NATO, Russia and -- not least -- one another, through joint exercises and peacekeeping. And it can cultivate civilian control and other democratic practices in Eastern Europe's armies.
But in the end, Eastern Europeans won't rest easy until the Russian Army is transformed through an active partnership with its onetime enemies. It will not be easy for either side to abandon the hostile reflexes of 50 years and nurture a new, inclusive spirit of cooperation. But that needs to be done, starting at this week's summit meetings.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Silver Lining

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
On his Inauguration Day as the new Mayor's Best Showbiz Friend, Ron Silver failed to give Rudolph Giuliani the most essential advice a professional actor can bequeath to an amateur: Never share a stage with a child or a dog.
This was not the first time Mr. Sil ver was missing in action while the Mayor floundered in artistic affairs. Earlier, the new Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, John Dyson, had stepped into a front-page embarrassment by waving a budgetary hatchet at New York City's already starving smaller arts organizations. 
 Mr. Silver, in case you missed act one, had been a controversial player in the mayoral campaign. A liberal Democrat, he bolted to the opposition, endorsing Mr. Giuliani in commercials that cast the actor as a kinder, gentler incarnation of the character Jackie Mason played so disastrously during the '89 Dinkins-Giuliani race. The mission was to achieve a reversal of his candidate's fortunes with Jewish voters.
Now that his man has won and his Streisandesque showboating moment as inaugural master of revels is over, is Mr. Silver shedding his political role? Yes, he told me late last week while dexterously distancing himself from the Dyson flap. Having helped screen candidates for the soon-to-be-filled job of Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, he intends to return to his careers as actor, director and president of the union Actors' Equity. Mr. Silver subscribes to the pragmatic Giuliani brand of arts boosterism -- "Rudy sees the arts as a serious economic player in the city" -- but he plans to schmooze his friend on this and other subjects informally rather than take on any official duties.
If the new Mayor really believed what he said about the arts in his inaugural address -- "they are important industries that will and must grow to create more jobs for us" -- he shouldn't let Mr. Silver slip away so fast. A collapse in one of those industries could happen on the new Mayor's watch, and Mr. Silver, who has credibility with both the new administration and the fractious constituencies within show business, may be the only New Yorker who can play Lee Iacocca.
The industry in trouble is, of course, the Broadway theater. Even as Mr. Giuliani was being sworn in over New Year's, Variety reported that Broadway ticket prices, which have already driven away countless theatergoers, would rise to a $75 top by fall. While holiday tourists may have thought that every marquee on the central theatrical block of 45th Street was aglow, a closer examination revealed that most of the marquees were dummies, installed temporarily for the filming of a television commercial.
Costs are sky high, scaring away investors as well as ticket buyers. New productions, except of musical revivals, are more rumor than reality. New pledges of state loans to renovate often-empty Broadway theaters are mere Band-Aids.
And yet when Mr. Giuliani talks about the arts as an economic engine for the city, the theater is essential to his vision. In the recent Port Authority report that credited the arts for a $9.2 billion contribution to the New York City economy, $900 million of that figure was attributed to the commercial theater.
The economic woes of the theater industry are not the fault of the majority of its artists, many of whom are sustained by the small institutional companies Off Broadway frightened by Mr. Dyson. The commercial theater's troubles are of its own making, through its Stone Age business practices. There's plenty of blame for everyone, from the theater owners who have preserved the rusty status quo for decades to often intransigent unions like Mr. Silver's, which even he concedes is a "19th-century mechanism trying to drag itself into the 20th century before the 21st century hits."
A crash civic effort at resuscitation is desperately needed. Mr. Silver would be perfectly cast as Broadway's savior: the canny head of a crisis task force that would knock theatrical management and labor heads together to rethink Broadway economics and insure the industry's survival. Mr. Giuliani could go down in history as the best friend the theater has found in City Hall since the last Republican Mayor, John Lindsay. And Andrew Giuliani, the town's newest performing hopeful, could rest assured there will still be a Broadway to welcome him when he is old enough to star in a revival of "The Most Happy Fella."

HEADLINE: Russian Entrepreneurs Aren't All Gangsters;
Skip the Robber Barons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
in "What's Good for the Mafia Is Good for Russia" (Op- Ed, Dec. 26), Michael Scammell compares the situation in Russia to the "robber baron days" in the United States, justifying this as a necessary stage in the emergence of a market economy. 
 There is an essential difference, however. A century ago, when capitalism was in its "wild" form all over the world, newborn American millionaires (of both good and questionable intent) could find no better place to invest their money than back in the American economy.
Now, newly rich Russians (who, I agree, get their wealth mostly by bribing government officials and selling natural resources for ultralow prices abroad) realize that it is more secure to invest their new-found capital outside unpredictable and turbulent Russia. As a result, both money and resources drain from Russia like water from a sieve.
Capitalism cannot develop from scratch in Russia, just as new life cannot emerge on earth: It would be immediately consumed by better-equipped life forms.
Russia does not need to wait 100 to 200 years to develop a civilized market. The economies of countries such as South Korea and Hong Kong indicate that it is possible to do this much faster, skipping the robber baron phase.
 
VASILY OGRYZKO
Chevy Chase, Md., Dec. 29, 1993

HEADLINE: The Nation;
When O'Neill Was Young, And City Hall Was Irish

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
THE death of Tip O'Neill on Wednesday, only seven weeks after the inauguration of the first non-Irish mayor elected in Boston since 1917, is more than a milepost in the nation's gaudy urban history that spans the Curleys and the Kennedys and the Daleys.
It is that, of course. Today, the only big cities with Irish-American mayors are Chicago and Los Angeles, and Los Angeles hardly counts, for Richard J. Riordan is a Republican. But if the Irish are not what they once were to the cities, the teeming cities themselves are not what they once were to the nation. They have less clout generally, and especially in Thomas P. O'Neill's House of Representatives. The leading Irish-American holds a big job, of course, but Speaker Thomas S. Foley represents Spokane, an airy city of 185,000. 
 The Irish are hardly gone from the political stage, especially here. Seven of the 13 City Council members are Irish, though only one of the seven school committee members is. And the Congressional delegation is heavy with them, too, from Ted Kennedy on through Joe Moakley and Joe Kennedy, who holds Mr. O'Neill's old seat in the House. There is another Kennedy on the way, the Senator's son Patrick, who is running for the House just over the border in almost Massachusetts, locally called Rhode Island.
Just as Thomas C. Mennino's election marked a start for the Italian-Americans who never made it to Boston City Hall, so too did it mark the end of a remarkable 71 consecutive years of Irish mayors, long after an Irish mayor was the norm in cities like New York and Philadelphia or Baltimore.
The change is at one level a simple function of demographics. No American city is as Irish as it once was. And their new immigrants, as Mr. Mennino's own Hyde Park neighborhood reflects, come most heavily from the Caribbean, Latin America and Asia.
But it is not just a matter of one sort of ethnic politics replacing another, as the Boston Irish wrested power from the Yankees, and as Italian-Americans pushed the Irish aside in Providence. The New Deal, welfare and pervasive civil service have removed, or at least lessened, all those boons that city machines once used to earn the allegiance of immigrants.
Mr. Mennino, like Rudy Giuliani in New York, hardly ran as an Italian-American politician representing one particular contingent of immigrants and their descendants. For that matter, Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago just moved out of the ancestral Irish neighborhood of Bridgeport, and he owes his success in his father's footsteps largely to an inclusive style.
But while Tip O'Neill was not the sort of candidate who ran against some other clan -- indeed, he was closer to no one in the House than to Silvio Conte, a Republican from Western Massachusetts who died in 1991 -- he did stand for the Irish who had had a tough time. He didn't hark back to the potato famine, as some did, but the memory of scraping through college in the Depression never left him.
Mr. O'Neill's death, after 14 years in the State Legislature, 36 years in the House and 7 years in retirement, is a marker for a change perhaps even more profound in American politics -- a change in its spirit.
It would be foolish to characterize him as typical of Irish politicians. Many of his colleagues were as likely to be haters as politicians from any other heritage. And as Jack Beatty, author of the definitive James Michael Curley biography, "The Rascal King," observed last week, "He marks an exception to the Boston rule, that Boston politics was all about revenge."
It was not just that he could be jolly, though his funny stories, often on himself, are legendary. He was also a very tough politician. He told an interviewer from the Lyndon B. Johnson Library in 1976 about a lesson from his early days in the Legislature, when "you tread on the toes of the other fellow."
"If the Republican leader's wife died and a delegation of Republicans were going to the wife's funeral, that was the day the Democrats put through their program," he recalled. And he could play hardball with Presidents of his own party, too, protecting the Boston Navy Yard by threatening to miss key votes on their bills in the Rules Committee.
But if the politics of his day could be tough, tougher in practice than most legislative politics today, there was hardly ever anything personal about it. He thought of Ronald Reagan as an amiable, deeply inattentive and ignorant leader whose politics were mean in their impact on people like those he grew up with in Cambridge. But he didn't personalize it, and got Mr. Reagan to appear at a jolly evening in Washington that raised $2 million for his alma mater, Boston College, in 1986.
He could turn away wrath. Once, when Bernard Cardinal Law was complaining that Mr. O'Neill wasn't helping the church on the abortion issue, he asked the Cardinal if his eminence knew how many bishops lived in his district. As the Cardinal calculated, the Speaker supplied the answer: three. How many schools? Again, three. How many parishes? Eight hundred and fifty. How many nuns? Six thousand.
Now, he asked the Cardinal, if the church, with all those resources couldn't persuade his very Catholic district, whose people opposed prohibitions on abortion by a 2-to-1 majority, what could a Speaker do?
One more thing. The politics of Tip's time was not only less personal, it was also less pretentious. When he used his influence to help Cambridge and Somerville and the other neighborhoods he inherited from John F. Kennedy, or to get the money for a harbor tunnel to the airport that the Yankee Governor, Bill Weld, now wants to name for the baseball hero Ted Williams, he was proud of it.
Tip's successors, harassed by public interest organizations, and other reformist mouthpieces, might think it necessary to defend such a tunnel with experts describing potential reductions in air pollution, or the importance to the economy of the whole Eastern seaboard of better access to the airport. Not the politician who never tired of explaining his watchword: "All politics is local."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1994, Wednesday

An article on Sunday in The Week in Review about the late Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. and changes in the ethnic politics of Boston misspelled the name of city's new Mayor. He is Thomas M. Menino.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH;
Raucous Board Finds Peace

BYLINE: By Lynette Holloway 

 BODY:
Once paralyzed by protests so bitter that its meetings turned into free-for-alls requiring a heavy police presence, Community Board 14 has been conducting its business in relative peace for the past four months.
The board was the target of a three-year campaign by the African People's Political Club of Flatbush to increase the number of blacks on the largely white board and increase services in heavily minority areas. Backed by the community organizer Sonny Carson and the lawyer Colin Moore, the protesters, some of whom were involved in the volatile boycott of a Korean grocery on Church Avenue, disrupted meetings with threats and anti-Semitic remarks. 
 The conflict reached a critical point at a chaotic meeting in January 1992 when protesters pushed a table that crushed the left foot of Community Board Manager Terry Rodie, aggravating an injury she had received at a different board meeting a year earlier. That incident sparked a three-day closing of the board's offices, as its employees sought psychological counseling from counselors provided by City Hall. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins said he would try to end the bitterness.
The protesters won't say exactly why they cooled their tactics. Their move comes as the board has been experiencing change.
Representation of blacks, who make up 40 percent of the district, has increased from 3 to a dozen on the 50-member board, a result of the election in recent years of two local black councilmen who are among those who make appointments to the board. The board itself is also reaching out more to members of minority groups, rotating its monthly meetings throughout the district.
"I still see Flatbush as being just like South Africa and that the board operates under a racist and apartheid system," said Ernest N. Foster, a leader of the protesters who ran unsuccessfully for City Council last fall. "We had to find a way to make our voices heard because African people have never received anything any other way."
But, he said, maybe the group's fashion of protesting had run its course.
The board's chairman, Alvin M. Berk, who is white, accused Mr. Foster's group of never making a substantive contribution to board business.
"They've never sat down with us in a constructive manner," Mr. Berk said. "We are a multiracial, economically diverse and geographically distributed board that does not need this kind of negative attention."
Mr. Berk said that since the protests faded, members have been concentrating on ways to maintain and improve services throughout the district, which includes Flatbush and Midwood, in spite of the city's tight budget.
A heavy police presence still exists at the board's meetings. At least one board member is looking forward to the day when the police will no longer be required, saying the officers' presence is a symbol of the board's stormy past.
"I look forward to the day when we will have a few friendly cops around who are there observing the meeting on their own," said Edward Powell, one of the black members on the board. Asked about the protests, Mr. Powell said: "There is a need for constructive criticism, but there are different ways to approach it. One way is to pursue it in concert rather than in conflict."
 LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Pizazz at Rockefeller Center, And It's Not the Rockettes
After struggling for years with the image of its retail space as a place to buy T-shirts and souvenir mugs, Rockefeller Center is adding some sizzle. The latest example is Television City, a restaurant venture by David Liederman, the founder of David's Cookies. 
 The restaurant will celebrate the world of television much as the Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood combine their themes with cuisine. There will be "Flintstones" and "Gunsmoke" nights and interactive television devices on each table.
Television City, which is to replace Lindy's restaurant and the Fanny Farmer store on the southeast corner of 50th Street and Avenue of the Americas in the fall, follows a plan drawn up 10 years ago to add pizazz to the 18-building complex. Mainstay businesses like banks are being replaced by tenants like Dean & DeLuca, which moved in last year, and the upscale Wall Street Deli, which has leased space.
 
Manhattan Leads in List Of Fastest-Growing Companies
Of the 50 companies that made the Crain's New York Business list of the fastest-growing businesses in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area, about half are in Manhattan. Only two are in the other boroughs.
The list reflects the city's economy, experts say, since high-growth service businesses tend to be based in Manhattan, while manufacturing and distribution companies are outside.
"Regionally, manufacturing has been declining over the years, which is why it's nice to see these businesses on the list," said Catie Marshall, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation. "We would like to see more, obviously, but manufacturing just hasn't been growing."
In Long Island City, Queens, the Recoton Corporation, which makes consumer electronics accessories, has more than doubled its annual revenues since 1991, to $120 million in 1993. In Sunset Park, Brooklyn, Esquire Radio and Electronics has annual revenues of $102 million and an average growth rate of 31 percent.
 
Harlem Is City's Pick As Federal 'Empowerment Zone'
In one of his last acts as Mayor, David N. Dinkins selected Harlem as the city's nominee for a new Federal program to help economically distressed areas.
In six cities around the nation, the program is to create "empowerment zones" where businesses will receive a total of $3.5 billion in tax credits and other subsidies over five years. It is the Clinton Administration's answer to the enterprise zones of the 1980's.
Under empowerment zones, businesses hiring residents will receive a break on employer-paid payroll taxes, and the Government will spend more within the zones on social services. Critics say such zones don't work, partly because businesses are suspicious of moving into high-crime areas.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY TERRACE;
Teaching An Old Mall New Tricks

BYLINE: By Bruce Lambert 

 BODY:
One store at a time, the expanded and renovated Bay Terrace shopping center has been emerging from a cocoon of construction work. The old-style commercial strip on northern Bell Boulevard at 26th Avenue has been under reconstruction for 18 months and now, with the project just a few weeks behind schedule, resembles the modern, upscale suburban malls that flourish across the Nassau County line.
The 45-store complex added about 100,000 square feet of retail space, bringing its total to 289,000 square feet. The project also spruced up the site with landscaping, improved lighting, more parking (for 1,533 cars) and new brickfacing that unifies the exterior. 
 Several major new businesses opened in the last two months, in time for holiday shopping: a Barnes & Noble "superstore," a Gap, a six-screen Loews movie theater, J. Skyler clothing, Foot Locker, Alicia's Golden Dream jewelers and Cohen's Fashion Optical.
The Parade of Shoes store opens this weekend. Ben's Kosher Deli and a relocated Bayside Federal Bank office are to open in the next few days. Joy Island restaurant and Boston Chicken are coming in March. Mr. Mollen said the Limited was negotiating for space, which would leave only 5,000 square feet vacant.
The work cost the owners, Cord Meyer Development Company, more than $20 million, and the commercial tenants made additional investments. The project was done piecemeal to minimize disruption to existing businesses.
Completion is expected this month, said Scott E. Mollen, a lawyer and spokesman for Cord Meyer. The remaining phase is the demolition of an obsolete section of the old building. Cord Meyer, a local firm that dates to 1899, built the first stores on the site, once a farm, 36 years ago.
New Yorkers are often wary of commercial developments, and some of the mall's neighbors expressed concerns about the project. But Community Board 7 endorsed the plan by a vote of 41 to 2 and says it has no regrets. "The high-quality shopping and terrific selection" are drawing big crowds, said the board's manager, Regina Colletta.
"The skeptics will have a change of heart now that they see it's really a credit to the community," Ms. Colletta predicted, "a welcome addition."
 B.L.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Air Fare Reductions In Honor of D-Day

 BODY:
To mark the 50th anniversary of the D-Day landings in Normandy in 1944, British Airways and Air France are offering fare reductions for those likely to remember the historic day. Both airlines' fares are available from now until the end of 1994.
Air France offers a 30 percent reduction on round trips on all fares except those lower than regular advance purchase rates. On the D-Day offer, as an example, an unrestricted advance-purchase round-trip economy ticket in January from New York to Paris would cost $540 without airport taxes. The reduction is available to World War II veterans and up to three family members, including grandchildren. Documentation of the veteran's status is required. The fare is available from the nine United States cities that Air France serves. For information: (800) 237-2747. 
 British Airways is offering its 30 percent reduction on round trips to France through Britain -- no stopovers -- to all travelers over 60 years old and one companion of any age. The discount applies to seven-day and 14-day advance purchase tickets leaving from 17 United States cities. British Airways flies to seven cities in France from Heathrow and Gatwick in London and Birmingham, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Manchester, Newcastle and Jersey. As an example, a 14-day advance purchase unrestricted economy round-trip from New York to Paris via London on a midweek day in January on this offer would come to $334.60 without airport taxes. For information: (800) 247-9297.

HEADLINE: The Drug Makers Are Listening to Prozac

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
FOR six years the antidepressant drug Prozac has been lifting the spirits of millions of Americans and thousands of Eli Lilly shareholders.
Sales of the drug reached a record $1.2 billion worldwide last year, helped by word of mouth and the best seller "Listening to Prozac," in which a psychiatrist describes the drug as making his patients more calm, confident and cheerful. And some industry executives see a far larger market as more doctors prescribe the feel-better products even for problems that are not clinical depression, to patients from college students to nursing-home residents 
 But Americans may soon be listening to a lot more than Prozac. Two newer antidepressants, one from Pfizer Inc. and one from SmithKline Beecham, P.L.C., are already challenging Prozac in the $3 billion market for antidepressants. Two weeks ago the Food and Drug Administration approved a third entry, from the American Home Products Corporation.
Analysts expect the Government to approve a Bristol-Myers Squibb drug early this year. At least three others are already being sold abroad, by Roche Holding of Switzerland, Synthelabo S.A. of France and Solvay S.A. of Belgium. The Solvay drug is also awaiting F.D.A. approval, and would be co-marketed by the Upjohn Company.
Seven more competitors are in the late stages of research, and at least 15 others are farther behind them in the pipeline.
Analysts say the late arrivals will have to fight for relatively small segments of the market, so investors do not expect much, if any, stock market reaction when they are approved in the United States. As for the companies with products already on the market, profits from antidepression drugs are especially important to Eli Lilly & Company and SmithKline Beecham. Both face difficult days with the expiration of patent protection on lucrative drugs -- the Ceclor antibiotic in the case of Lilly and the Tagamet ulcer treatment in the case of SmithKline. But at Pfizer, the antidepressant Zoloft is just one more winner in a slew of new drugs.
There are plenty of potential patients for the drugs. At least 11 million Americans have a bout of depression every year, and only about 30 percent currently get the medication that could help them, according to Government and industry estimates. Many millions more whose symptoms don't amount to clinical depression might also look to such drugs. That's a sobering thought for Americans concerned that so many people would be reliant on drugs. But it's also troubling for health-policy makers, because an explosion in demand could overwhelm any savings wrought by health plans driving a hard bargain with drug companies. On the other hand, if the drugs head off illnesses that lead to higher mental-health bills and lost productivity, the nation might come out ahead financially.
Prozac, meanwhile, seems to be holding its own. The drug has been prescribed for more than six million people in the United States since it was introduced in 1988. New prescriptions in this country increased 15.7 percent in the year ending Nov. 30. The gain followed two years of low or negative growth while Lilly fought lawsuits attacking the drug on grounds that have not been proven but that encouraged some patients to try the competition.
ALTHOUGH Lilly still faces more than 160 suits contending that Prozac was responsible for violent behavior or suicides, judges have dismissed 78, and there have been no cash settlements, said Edward A. West, a company spokesman.
Prozac, which enhances the action of serotonin, a chemical transmitter of messages between nerve cells in the brain, had the field nearly to itself for four years, until early 1992, when Pfizer introduced Zoloft, a similar drug. Zoloft's 1993 sales were $460 million worldwide.
Last March, SmithKline Beecham jumped into the market for this family of antidepressant drugs. The company introduced Paxil, which quickly racked up $225 million in sales around the world. The latest entry to be approved by the F.D.A., Effexor, from the Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories subsidiary of the American Home Products Corporation, will be introduced in the spring.
Effexor works on a second brain transmitter, norepinephrine, as well as serotonin. Wyeth-Ayerst said its drug was effective for some patients who had not been helped by Prozac and the other serotonin-related drugs.
One drug in the late stages of research, milnacipran, from the Swedish company Astra A.B., resembles Effexor and makes similar claims.
Analysts expect the F.D.A. to accept the recommendation of its advisory committee and approve Bristol-Myers Squibb's Serzone (known generically as nefazodone), probably early this year. The drug enhances the action of serotonin, as Prozac does, and also makes the nerve cells more receptive. Tests have indicated fewer sleep disturbances and sexual problems than with Prozac, and suggest that Serzone can take effect within a week.
Fluvoxamine, the Solvay drug to be co-marketed with Upjohn, is also awaiting F.D.A. action and is already on sale in 36 countries. It got a favorable advisory committee recommendation for obsessive compulsive disorder last October.
The drugs that zero in on serotonin avoid some unpleasant side effects that were common in earlier classes of antidepressants, known as tricyclics and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. The earlier drugs are also more toxic, which makes it far easier for depressed patients to commit suicide by taking an overdose.
But the older drugs have an enormous price advantage, selling for pennies now that their patents have expired, while Prozac and the others wholesale at $1.75 per pill and up. While the older drugs, which are produced by generic drug makers, are gradually losing market share, they still hold about 35 percent of the antidepressant market. Now some companies, including Roche and Synthelabo, have reduced the side effects of the monoamine oxidase inhibitors.
VIREN MEHTA, an analyst at Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Research, projects that the entire market for antidepressants will double, to more than $6 billion, by 1998. And the number might be even higher if more people try the drugs for uses that are not now approved.
"People take Prozac for things other than clinical depression," said Henry Blissenbach, president of Diversified Pharmaceutical Services, a managed-care unit of the United Healthcare Corporation, the big health maintenance organization company. "They say, 'Doctor, I just don't feel very good.' And the doctor says, 'A lot of people I've given it to feel better.' "
Some health plans require physicians to get authorization before prescribing certain expensive drugs. But Mr. Blissenbach said that solution seemed impractical with Prozac because "our phone would be ringing all day long." Diversified Pharmaceutical asks pharmacists to make sure patients have been prescribed the drug for depression or obsessive compulsive disorders, he added.
Mr. Blissenbach said that unlike, say, high cholesterol levels, which show up in laboratory tests, the diagnosis of depression is often subjective. "What do you use as criteria?" he asked. He said drug makers and managed-care companies needed to conduct studies to determine the conditions for which the drugs are cost-effective. "Maybe an individual is not clinically depressed, but he or she still feels depressed and goes to the physician 15 times a year and misses 30 days of work," he said. "If the individual takes the drug and doesn't go to the physician and doesn't miss any work, the benefit to total health care cost would be there."
BUT Sidney Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a consumer advocacy group in Washington, warned against "popping a pill instead of helping people to cope with underlying causes of depression such as a death in the family or separation from a loved one."
"I see this as a 1990's version of Valium," he said. "These drugs are being used in an overly broad fashion just as the tranquilizers were." After years of widespread use, Valium was found to be seriously addictive.
"These things are relatively new," said Dale Kramer, a pharmacy director for the Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, the nation's largest health maintenance organization. "Sometimes it takes a number of years before the real bad stuff comes to light."
Cost-containment efforts by insurers and competition in the rapidly changing pharmaceutical business have held down the prices of most drugs. Prozac's average wholesale price is $2.09 per pill (the daily dose), Zoloft's is $1.88 and Paxil's $1.75, according to a December tabulation by the Medical Economics publishing group. But health networks that buy in volume can negotiate big discounts. For example, Kaiser buys pays as little as $1.15 per pill for the new serotonin-related drugs.
Patients without access to such discounts typically pay a retail price reflecting a pharmacy markup of 40 percent or more.
Many drug makers are sponsoring cost-benefit studies to help justify their prices. A recent study for the National Mental Health Association, a group supported by the drug industry, estimates that depression costs employers of $23.8 billion annually in reduced productivity and lost workdays.
An unpublished study for Pfizer says newer drugs like Zoloft, while more expensive than tricyclics, actually can save an insurer 10 to 15 percent over the tricyclics. One reason is that patients are more likely to stop taking tricyclics because of the side effects, leading to depressive episodes that are expensive to treat.

HEADLINE: Helping Hand for Potential Booksellers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
DID you ever have dreams of opening a bookstore? Dreamer beware -- entering the retail bookstore business requires more than enthusiasm and a love of books.
There is the financial investment: adequate capital is critical. And as in the real estate industry, success very often depends on "location, location, location." Also important is the willingness to do a fair amount of physical labor. Such things as unpacking and shelving books, waiting on customers, gift wrapping, operating the cash register are all part of the bookseller's daily routine. 
 One of the most valuable sources for those who want to enter the world of book selling is the American Booksellers Association, a 92-year-old trade organization committed to protecting the well-being of book retailers and promoting the availability of books. The association, which has 8,000 members, moved to temporary headquarters in Tarrytown from Manhattan two years ago. Members include independents, specialty, franchise, college and university stores, chains and others with a special interest in book selling.
Bernard E. Rath, executive director of the association, said: "Judging from the number of provisional members we have -- 1,200 -- which are those who are serious about becoming retail booksellers but haven't yet opened stores, there are more people today who want to open bookstores than ever before."
Despite competition for the consumer's dollar from videos, movies and from nonbook outlets like mass merchandisers and supermarkets, Mr. Rath said that a recent survey conducted by the United States Commerce Department showed that sales in bookstores across the country increased at a faster rate than total retail sales. Last year, bookstore sales reached nearly $8 billion.
"Yet while the book-selling industry as a whole is experiencing record growth and fared far better than other types of retail outlets over the past few years," Mr. Rath said, "it appears that a larger than usual number of independent bookstores are for sale or are considering closing, as a result of competing against mass merchandisers, mall chain stores and price clubs."
 
Opportunities Are Still Available
 For example, such well-established bookstores as the 15-year-old Huntington's Book Store in Hartford, Odergard's in Minneapolis and Jocundry's Books of East Lansing, Mich., closed their doors in 1993, Mr. Rath said. "Competition from nearby superstores combined with a depressed economy is the situation in which more and more independents are finding themselves today," he said. "Jocundry's, for example, which carried 50,000 to 60,000 titles in its heyday and was well known for hosting a lot of community events, was planning expansion just two years ago. But when three mega-chains opened stores nearby, the effect was disastrous."
Although some areas are saturated with bookstores, Mr. Rath added that there are many areas that are not.
"There still are communities in need of good bookstores," he said. "There are locations in malls in which favorable leases and rentals can be found today. And those people who are well prepared for opening a bookstore can still thrive selling books and make a living."
More than 50 percent of all books sold by members of the association are fiction, and while recent studies on the extent of reading in the United States have been mixed, sales of children's books have nearly doubled in the past few years. Mr. Rath said that the large baby-boom generation, better educated than any previous one, appears to be buying books for its children in record numbers and that boomers themselves will continue to read in their retirement years.
 
Some Required Reading
 The 55-member staff at the association's headquarters is available to give prospective members guidance and help them solve problems that arise in opening a bookstore. "Prospective booksellers can learn what lies ahead by attending our national convention, which is held in late May-early June," Mr. Rath said. "It is the largest English-language book event in the world."
Abacus, the association's annual financial profile of member independent bookstores, is also required reading for anyone seriously considering opening a bookstore, Mr. Rath said. In it, the operations and financial data of 200 bookstores are analyzed in order to provide benchmarks and trends for those in the industry. Equally valuable is the association's Book Buyer's Handbook, available only to members. It lists most trade publishers and their pricing structures.
The next logical step in planning to open a bookstore might be to attend a prospective bookseller's school sponsored by the association. "They are intensive three-and-a-half-day seminars taught by successful booksellers in various locations throughout the country," Mr. Rath said.
 
School in the Carriage House
 Later this year the association will move to permanent quarters in Tarrytown. In a campus-like setting near the Tarrytown Conference Center will be a mansion, a library and an administration building. A booksellers' school will be conducted for prospective bookshop owners in Westchester.
"We are planning on running the school in the carriage house on the grounds," Mr. Rath said. "It will consist of four-day sessions, which will be limited to 70 students who will be put up at the Tarrytown Conference Center, which will be conveniently connected to the school by a pathway." The cost of the four-day session, including room and board, will be $700.
Mr. Rath, who is 44, was executive secretary of the Canadian Booksellers Association in Toronto, when he was recruited 10 years ago by the American Booksellers Association.
"It was a big move leaving Toronto in more ways than one," he recalled. "For one thing, the A.B.A. is 10 times as large as the Canadian Booksellers Association. In Canada, booksellers are more restricted by the government, since they operate without the advantage of a First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of the press. That First Amendment makes this work very exhilarating." The American Booksellers Association will present 400 books to the White House Library as a gift to the Administration from the booksellers, he said.
Mr. Rath, who lives with his family in the town of Cortlandt, said that although he is still a resident alien, he plans to become an American citizen.
"For one thing, I want to be able to vote in school board elections and have a voice in things. Our children love it here, and they think of themselves as Americans."

HEADLINE: A Midterm Assessment of Mayor Zaleski

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
IN this tough and gritty riverfront city, where a disgruntled populace has elected successive administrations in and out of office with increasing frequency in recent years, Mayor Terence M. Zaleski -- a lifelong Boy Scout and an admitted zealot when it comes to Yonkers -- says he is determined to succeed where others have failed. His stated goals: to resuscitate an ailing economy and revitalize the city's shabby image.
Half-way into his first four-year term of office, Mayor Zaleski, a Democrat, has won an equal share of disapprobation and loyal support for his work as the city's first chief executive in 50 years under a strong-mayor form of government. While supporters applaud their leader's tough stand on issues like corruption in government and fiscal responsibility, detractors say the Mayor has been autocratic and unable to build a consensus with critical power blocs in the city -- among them, the City Council, the Board of Education and local labor unions. 
 On a recent gray afternoon, the spectacled, fair-haired Mayor raised the blinds in his office onto a view of the cityscape of apartments and low-cost housing projects outside the window. As he did, the 40-year-old leader of this city of 188,000 pointed to the site where his family's cold-water flat once stood.
Mayor Zaleski grew up here, the son of a sugar-refinery worker and the grandson of Polish immigrants, and he went on to win a Boy Scouts of America Silver Beaver Award for meritorious service and to be named a Columbia University Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar for superior scholastic achievement. He was a high school science teacher, a lawyer and a State Assemblyman before winning the mayoralty in 1991, garnering 36 percent of the vote in a three-way race.
Slight of frame -- he is 5 feet 7 1/2 inches tall -- the Mayor still displays a Boy Scout earnestness, especially when discussing the future of the city under his administration. One of his supporters, Stephen F. Byrns, an architect and local community activist, described Mr. Zaleski as "a man who wants to fight the good fight, a squeaky-clean kind of guy and kind of nerdy, but in a good way."
The west side of Yonkers, where the Mayor spent his boyhood among white European immigrants, is inhabited today mostly by blacks and people of Hispanic background, many of whom are trying to raise themselves out of poverty like those who came before them. But of late, this section of the city is also where much of the drug traffic, gang wars and other crimes have occurred. Recently, two multiple shootings took place a half-mile apart from each other on successive nights -- one in a neighborhood store and the other in an elevator -- leaving three dead and five wounded.
Conscious of how mention of Yonkers conjures up visions of crime and surliness -- the latter mostly associated with the city's refusal for years to comply with a Federal housing-desegregation order -- Mayor Zalesksi maintained during the interview that his city, the fourth-largest in the state, was a safe one.
"This was an aberration for Yonkers," he said of the early December shootings. "Ours is a remarkably safe city."
He cited statistics to back his arguments -- figures from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which ranked Yonkers near the bottom of the list of 100 cities for murders and property crimes in 1991. The city was 93d for the number of murders per 1,000 residents and 96th for crimes like burglaries, robberies and car thefts per 1,000 residents.
"You see, there's a misperception about Yonkers," he said.
He went on to extol the virtues of the city and list his accomplishments.
"I laid off 70 workers when I took office," he said, adding that he had cut $9 million from the budget over two years. "I run a tight ship, because we have to bring our finances in line."
Mayor Zaleski also talked about the creation six months ago of a Police Professional Standards Panel, a complaint review board that is serving as a model for other cities in Westchester and the country.
 
'A Pattern of Corruption'
 And he spoke about his role in encouraging the state's Organized Crime Task Force to continue its investigation of corruption in Yonkers. The task force's efforts so far have resulted in the indictment of Michael Calvi, a former Planning Commissioner and Republican ward leader, on Federal and state charges of taking and soliciting almost $50,000 in bribes, allegedly as a reward for steering contracts for a jail-renovation project. Mr. Calvi's trial is pending.
"There's a pattern of corruption throughout the city," Mayor Zaleski said, also mentioning the alleged embezzlement of $500,000 by at least one employee of the city's Industrial Development Agency. An indictment is expected in that case.
Although the housing-desegregation issue is not yet fully resolved, the first phase of a Federal plan is almost complete, with 200 public-housing units built and a remaining 58 scheduled for completion this year. Under the long-range Federal plan, another 800 units of affordable housing are to be built in mixed-income, privately owned housing areas.
Marilyn Melkonian, who was recently appointed housing specialist master by Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan, said Mayor Zaleski was "cooperating and doing his best to carry out the city's agreement."
Nevertheless, an appeal of Judge Sand's decision to use a housing specialist rather than the Mayor and City Council to carry out the plan was filed by the city late last year.
 
Critics' Complaints
 Not all of his constituents agree with the Mayor's assessment of his administration, and some leaders in the city have not welcomed efforts to cut expenditures, root out what the Mayor calls "the worst types of old bossism, overreaching labor unions and corruption" and direct Yonkers along a new path.
One of the Mayor's detractors, former Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, who served from 1974 to 1979 and from 1982 to 1987, called Mr. Zaleski dictatorial.
"Yonkers has become almost like a police state, the way Terry is going after and trying to discredit people," said Mr. Martinelli, a Republican who ran as an independent in the 1991 mayoral race.
Another critic, John D. Spencer, Republican majority leader of the City Council, criticized the Mayor's relationship with the legislative body.
"As an executive mayor, he has treated the City Council with disdain," said Mr. Spencer, who plans to run for mayor in 1995. "Mr. Zaleski lacks people skills, and that's the No. 1 reason that executives derail."
The Councilman criticized Mr. Zaleski for not consulting with the legislative body about important city matters and for boasting about budget reductions that resulted in cutbacks in some municipal services, like snow removal and leaf collection.
Representing the unions, Anthony Pagano, president of Local 628 of the International Firefighters Association, said, "I was a fan of the Mayor -- we were the only union to support his election -- but my views have changed."
Mr. Pagano, who is also chairman of United Unions for a Better and Safer Yonkers, a coalition of 10 locals, said the Mayor "has not sat down to listen to our problems." He added: "Nine out of 10 unions don't have contracts, and we don't believe that there isn't any money. There is."
The Mayor's relationship with the Board of Education has also not been a smooth one. Mr. Zaleski, who holds a master's degree in education, said there was "not enough excitement in the classrooms."
He has also questioned why the former Superintendent of Schools, Donald M. Batista, testified last year in Federal District Court in Manhattan -- in a lawsuit to get the state to pay for the second stage of a Federally mandated school-desegregation plan -- that minority students in the Yonkers school system continued to lag behind their white classmates. The Mayor said that Dr. Batista, in requesting more money for the education budget, reported to City Hall that all was well in the schools.
But Dr. Batista said the budget issues only represented "a red flag, the thing that got us going." He added: "The real issue was power. Mr. Zaleski went over that fine line and imposed his will on the Board of Education."
Dr. Batista resigned last fall and is now director of education for the Leake and Watts Children's Home in Yonkers. "That was the essence of the rub between us," Dr. Batista said. "He may appoint members of the board, but they are by law officers of the state. The board is not just another department of City Hall."
 
'Willing to Bite the Bullet'
 In contrast, supporters say Mayor Zaleski is the first responsible politician in many years to lead Yonkers.
Gail S. Shaffer, New York's Secretary of State and chairman of the State Emergency Financial Control Board, which oversees Yonkers finances, said: "A lot of Byzantine politics go on in Yonkers, and historically it has not had leadership that was willing to bite the bullet. I do think Mr. Zaleski is an improvement -- more receptive, more professional -- although we do not agree on everything."
Ms. Shaffer disagreed with Mr. Spencer, the City Council majority leader, on his criticism of the reduction of services under Mr. Zaleski. "We need more in the way of cost efficiencies, not less," she said.
On the issue of union contracts, Ms. Shaffer said the locals' demands have been unrealistic, considering the difficult finances of the city. During a November 1992 visit to Yonkers, Ms. Shaffer said she and two staff members were "roughed up" by union members after they were informed that their contracts were rejected, and $2,000 in damage was reported to a state-owned auto during the encounter.
 
'Tougher Than Any Other City'
 "It was a very black mark on the city," Ms. Shaffer said. "It reinforced the image of Yonkers that needs to be changed, and that's one of the things that Mayor Zaleski is trying to do."
Alfred B. Del Bello, who served as Mayor here from 1970 to 1974, agreed. "Historically it has always been pure politics in Yonkers," he said. "There's something in the water there that makes it tougher than any other city."
Mr. Del Bello said the Mayor "got a slow start, because of two things." He added, "He was bogged down in his efforts to root out corruption, and it has taken time for the new strong form of government to register in everyone's mind. But now we are going into the second half of his term, and we are starting to see some results."
On one issue, the 4.5-mile-long waterfront area, most critics and supporters have praise for Mayor Zaleski's efforts to restore the area -- although some are skeptical, saying similar waterfront plans have been promised before.
"This time it's different," the Mayor said. "It's too important to mess with, and it is as much mom and apple pie for the future of this city as anything else we're trying to do."
Of his plans for the city, the Mayor added: "I could talk for 10 hours straight. Being mayor is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for a kid who grew up in the streets to try and change the direction of the city for generations to come."
Brushing aside his detractors' criticisms, he said, "It's very simple. They are threatened by what I represent -- the need to reclaim this city and its reputation for its people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers with Corporation Counsel Christina Lomolino looking at model of the planned 4.5-mile-long waterfront restoration. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)
