HEADLINE: What Clinton Won't Find in Russia: Misty-Eyed Nostalgia for Jeans and Coca-Cola

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Back in the old Soviet days, an American-Soviet summit meeting was a time for the Kremlin's propaganda machine to go into overdrive with a torrent of shows, books and articles about the United States.
No matter that most of it was tendentious stuff about the "Negro problem" or American "militarism" -- nobody listened to any of that. 
 Instead, everyone watched for the glimpses of glittering stores, dream cars, bright clothes, soaring skyscapers. Many a middle-aged Russian can still remember the first time he saw "The Magnificant Seven" or got his first pair of Levi jeans.
The summit meeting itself would be grand, every event televised, every handshake a testament to a desperately desired recognition by that dreamland across the seas.
 
Protest in a Minor Key
 But that was way back then. This time, newspapers have carried only staid reports on President Clinton's visit this week, usually focusing on the debate over which country should join NATO and in what capacity.
The only emotional event somehow linked to the visit was a demonstration by a clutch of unrepentant reactionaries who placed a wreath in memory of those killed in the assault on the Parliament building in October. The group then moved on to United States Embassy across the street to chant, "Yankees Go Home!" and speakers asserted that the assault on Parliament had been coordinated from Washington and that uniformed Americans had fired on the building from the Embassy.
 
The Old 'America' Is Gone
 That position was not one that many Russians would take seriously. Despite such oratory, and the xenophobia of the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, there have been no serious signs that anti-American sentiment is growing. What has happened, rather, is that familiarity and hard experience have succeeded where the Communists failed: in dispersing the American myth.
"America, the hope we realized and lost, left us as irretrievably as youth," wrote Evgeny Kulakov, in a reflection in the magazine Obozrevatel. "Even if we once again put on our faded jeans, we've grown up, and our America has ceased to be -- although, of course, it never existed."
In part, of course, the relative lack of advance excitement over Mr. Clinton's arrival also reflects the fact that Russians have far more immediate concerns, including the first meeting of the new Federal Assembly on Tuesday, and the expectation of a Government shuffle by President Boris N. Yeltsin that will determine the country's economic course.
More important, America no longer packs the magic it once did.
In the first years of reforms initiated by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and in the first years of the "new Russia" of Mr. Yeltsin, there was the faith that once Russia lifted its barbed wire, elected a parliament and opened a stock exchange, an exultant West would rush in with aid and investments, quickly bringing Russians the dimly glimpsed fruits of the West.
 
Who Can Afford a Big Mac?
 The fruits did flow in: kiwis, Mars bars, Cadillacs, Cokes and Big Macs have flooded Moscow. But for most Russians, who cannot afford such goodies, they only underscore their poverty.
Western advisers also flowed in, but the neatly bound reports they produced after a few days in a luxury hotel did not do much good. Little of the promised billions in aid ever materialized, and Russians watched in growing disenchantment as first Mr. Gorbachev, then Mr. Yeltsin, returned from the West with empty hands.
At home, hasty economic reforms, loudly applauded by the West, created a brash underworld and a newly rich nomenklatura, but served largely to impoverish most Russians. Freely elected deputies proved as greedy and power-hungry as they had been when they were Communist apparatchiks.
Coupled with the economic and political disillusionment was the humiliation as Washington and the West seemed no longer to reckon with Russia in their global pursuits. Interventions in Iraq and Yugoslavia struck into regions that Russians considered their spheres of interest. And applications for NATO membership by ex-satellites seemed to confirm the worst fears of Western encirclement.
 
'Twin Peaks.' Yes, 'Twin Peaks.'
 Still, the dominant reaction was not indignation or resentment, but acceptance of realities once hidden.
For one thing, once it became accessible, America lost the allure of forbidden fruit. In recent weeks, for example, Russians have been intrigued by the television serial "Twin Peaks." But if a few years ago the Russians would been shocked at such sordid goings-on in America, most now seem to watch with the same familiarity as any Americans.
For another, most Russians realize that the United States, like Russia, acts first out of self-interest.
"There is no longer a sense that Great America will save us, but there's no hatred, either," said Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a reform economist and member of the new Parliament. "What there is, finally, is a normal attitude."
That will not prevent most Russians from tuning in for the drama inherent in any summit meeting. But this time they will not be looking for instant remedies or relief, or for a whiff of a distant dreamland.

HEADLINE: Casino Boom Along Gulf Coast Brings Fears of Glut and High Toll

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BILOXI, Miss.

 BODY:
Anyone who doubts the astonishing economic effect of the nation's headlong dash toward legalized gambling should come to this quirky hodgepodge of moss-draped live oaks and white-columned mansions, ragged beach and cheap bars that has been turned into a boom area by the arrival of eight major casinos over the past two years.
But if the Mississippi Gulf Coast from Biloxi to Bay St. Louis is a revealing window onto the economic power of legalized gambling, now a $30 billion nationwide business that has tripled in a decade, its experience is also raising two questions with national implications: how many communities can expect to make money on gambling -- and at what cost? 
 To proponents of gambling, the boom along this 35-mile stretch of Gulf Coast, once defined by modest tourist attractions like pastel-colored souvenir shops, goofy miniature golf courses and mom-and-pop seafood joints, is proof of what a powerful economic engine gambling has become.
 
Saturating the Market
 "To say the least, we've hit a home run, a long home run," said Chevis Swetman, president of People's Bank in Biloxi, where at one point recently 28 construction cranes towered over the shoreline. "Right now, we feel like we're probably the hottest spot in the United States for growth. And when was the last time you heard Mississippi being No. 1 in anything?"
But with plans to triple the number of gaming establishments here and to build the world's biggest casino and nine riverboat casinos 60 miles down the coast in New Orleans, and similar proposals sprouting up from Chicago to Mobile, Ala., many economists are asking how many areas can realistically expect to cash in on gambling. As many as 90 riverboat and dockside casinos could be operating around the nation within two years.
"There's probably not a major city in the United States that's not considering gambling," said Tim Ryan, dean of the college of business administration at the University of New Orleans. "It's an incredible explosion of gambling. This market is going to be saturated. It may already be saturated."
And if the Mississippi coast shows the economic potential of gambling to produce jobs and tax revenue, it also shows the risks, both in businesses displaced and lives ruined. Already, social service agencies and courts are seeing marriages destroyed or residents sinking into debt because of problem gambling.
"It's my observation that there's a lot of wreckage coming out of this gambling business here," said Judge William L. Stewart of Chancery Court in nearby Gulfport, who said he had seen at least 20 divorces and numerous failures to pay child support as a result of gambling losses.
 
Big, and Getting Bigger
 When a casino boat called the Europa Star began trips into the gulf a few years back to offer dockside gambling, it struck more than a few people as a rather forlorn effort to be a poor man's Las Vegas. No one is laughing now.
In Harrison County, home of Biloxi and seven of the eight casinos, the value of building permits for the first eight months of 1993 surged by 825 percent over the same period in 1992, to $102 million from $11 million. Unemployment fell to 4.2 percent in 1993 from 7.1 percent in 1992. The gaming establishments here, all dockside casinos in elaborate buildings, have already created more than 11,000 jobs. The 13 casinos operating in November in Mississippi produced $80 million in revenues; 17 casinos are now open, producing a tax bonanza for the state and local governments.
In neighboring Hancock County, one project, Casino Magic in Bay St. Louis, bills itself as the largest dockside casino development in the world. Owners say the 530-acre project will eventually include a 1,500-room hotel, 5,000-seat auditorium, 60,000 square-foot convention center, a park for motor homes and a golf course. The casino itself features 68 tables for games like blackjack, roulette and poker and more than 1,100 slot machines.
Another Casino Magic hall, down U.S. 90 in Biloxi, has just doubled in size to 55,000 square feet of gambling space with 70 gambling tables and 1,148 slot machines. Open since June 5, it welcomed its one millionth customer on Dec. 21.
Some skeptics worry that competition from New Orleans and other Mississippi towns will cut into business here. But Marlin F. Torguson, president of the Casino Magic Corporation, which reported $31.8 million in profit for the first three quarters of 1993, said there was plenty of business for everyone.
"They cater to the convention business, and they'll do great in New Orleans," Mr. Torguson said. "We'll do great here. People are looking for more entertainment options, and gaming is something new that's vying for the entertainment dollar."
 
Bitter Taste of Success
 Despite success that has exceeded all expectations here, residents may be more uneasy about gambling now than when it began.
Some, like Patrick Burke, worry about what the casinos are doing to the quality of life. Mr. Burke moved back to the Gulf Coast from Los Angeles two years ago seeking a more peaceful life and now finds his beachside cottage 200 yards from an all-day traffic jam and the state's largest casino.
"I want out of here so bad, I can't stand it," he said, complaining that he has not been able to sell his little plot of land to a casino. "I firmly believe local politicians and especially the planning department don't have the education or skills to deal with what's going on. They are country boys used to playing in sewers, and what's coming here is big time."
The shrimping business, once the dominant industry on the coast, is being forced out by casinos taking over the docks, leaving no room for shrimpers's boats and closing businesses like processing plants and ice plants. And despite the influx of visitors, some other tourism-related businesses say the casinos have siphoned off their customers.
Louis Skrmetta's Ship Island Excursions is a 66-year-old family-owned business that transports tourists to an offshore barrier island. After years of steady growth, business fell 10 percent last year, Mr. Skrmetta said.
"I've never worked harder, and anticipated more and been more disappointed," he said. "Now that the casinos are here, I think a lot of people would like to vote them out."
 
Convenient and Addictive
 And, if gambling is an affordable recreation for most customers, with slot machines as cheap as 5 cents, gambling problems are soaring here. The number of Gamblers Anonymous Chapters has grown to five from none, and counselors at Recovery Resources, a private center that helps compulsive gamblers, say they are seeing an increasing number of middle-income people who have piled up debts of $25,000 to $35,000, taken second mortgages on homes and emptied savings or retirement accounts.
One 31-year-old waitress and mother of two said that she had been a casual bingo player before the gaming halls arrived, but that with big-time casinos so convenient had found herself gambling her whole paycheck and savings before she sought help.
"It got to the point I was going almost every day," she said. "It's like those machines hypnotize you. I used to dream about them at night, ching, ching, ching, the sound of the slots. I didn't vote for or against the boats, but I really think it's a bad thing now."
Still, few doubt the overall economic impact thus far has been positive. It has certainly been a windfall to struggling local governments.
Dianne Harenski, a member of the Biloxi City Council, said the city originally expected $500,000 a month in revenues from its casino tax. The figure for the most recent month was $1.2 million. That has allowed the city to end its $6.50-a-month garbage fee, buy seven police cars and two fire trucks, and plan major capital projects that had been needed for years.
Ms. Harenski said a shakeout was inevitable and doubted that every community could profit as Biloxi has. Still, she said, it is hard to argue with an industry that has transformed a "very, very depressed" area and brought in the kind of revenues and jobs no one could have imagined a few years back.
But Professor Ryan of New Orleans said the casinos' business would taper off, just like lottery revenues have, as the novelty wore off and the market became glutted. That should be a warning to cities like New Orleans, which could find dollars diverted from restaurants and other attractions for gambling.
"This industry has been tremendously oversold," he said. "We need to separate the casino industry from new manufacturing companies or new agricultural industries. Generally, the casino industry is not creating new wealth; it's only recycling wealth and putting it in different pockets."
But Professor Ryan conceded that there was still a huge pent-up demand for gambling. When even conservative Mississippi is willing to legalize 24-hour gambling with 24-hour liquor and no limits on betting, it is clear that people believe there is money to be made.
Gary Letterman of Hickory, N.C., was feeding coins into the $5 Home Run slot machine at Casino Magic in Bay St. Louis one chilly December morning, after flying in for the day from Charlotte on the charter flight the casino arranges to some 35 cities. He rolled his eyes at the notion that an earlier generation of Southerners might have frowned on the casino dream world springing up now.
"We've been doing this in back rooms for years," Mr. Letterman said. "Now we can just get on with it."

HEADLINE: 1993 Homicides Fewer but More Clustered in New York City

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY

 BODY:
From the rectory of the St. Jerome Catholic Church in the South Bronx the Rev. John Grange hears gunfire every night on the streets below. "We used to do about a funeral a month here," Father Grange said. But with shootings and other tolls of urban life, he said, "now we do a funeral a week."
But on the east side of Manhattan, in the neighborhood of United Nations diplomats and quiet streets of exclusive apartments, the gunfire might as well be in a distant city. "We all feel sorry and feel bad about all the crime and violence in the city," said Gloria Sandmeyer, who lives in Tudor City. But as for crime in her neighborhood, she said, "We don't think about it much." 
 Although police statistics show that the number of homicides in New York City declined in 1993, for the third year in a row, the improvement is occurring largely in neighborhoods like Ms. Sandmeyer's, while neighborhoods in the South Bronx, eastern Brooklyn and upper Manhattan are bearing a greater proportion of the killings.
 
Clusters of Killings
 In fact killings are so clustered that 12 of the city's 75 police precincts -- all in those areas of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan -- reported a total of 854 homicides, or 43.6 percent of the 1,960 homicides reported by precinct and borough officials citywide in 1993. Although the total number in those precincts declined slightly in recent years, their percentage grew, from 39.2 percent in 1990.
By contrast, the 12 precincts reporting the smallest number of homicides -- six or less -- are sprinkled in every borough except the Bronx. Taken together they reported a total of 37 homicides, less than half the number they registered three years ago, when the city's murder rate hit a peak.
Thirty-one precincts reported an average of one homicide a month or less last year. Three of them -- the 123d Precinct on the southern end of Staten Island, the 6th Precinct on the west side of Greenwich Village and the 20th Precinct on the west side of Central Park between 59th and 86th Streets -- each reported just one homicide. And Manhattan's 17th Precinct, east of Lexington Avenue between 30th and 59th Streets, was the only one reporting none.
 
'Movement to Safety'
 Robert McCrie, an associate professor at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said the growing disparity reflected "a movement to safety by people who can afford to move to safer neighborhoods."
"The safer neighborhoods become safer and the other neighborhoods suffer because of the economic disparity," he said. "Our neighborhoods have become more concentrated in terms of their socio-economic culture. A century ago, rich and poor lived closer to each other."
Philip McGuire, director of the crime analysis section of the Police Department said of crime: "When it goes down it pulls back into the areas that are more economically depressed. These are areas where criminals come in to do other things, deal drugs and rob."
The tally of 1,960 homicides for 1993 is based on unofficial figures gathered by The New York Times from the city's 75 police precincts. Although the Police Department last week said there were 1,995 homicides last year, a top police official later said the number was in error and released an estimate of 1,960 to 1,970. Still, officials said the final tally, due in March, was likely to change as homicide reports are examined over the next two months.
The preliminary total shows a steady decline from the city's homicide record of 2,245 in 1990. In 1991 there were 2,154 homicides, and in 1992 the number was 1,995.
 
Community Policing Credited
 Police officials credit the overall decline in murders to its community policing program, which puts more officers on the street. Also, the number of police officers has grown. In 1990 there were 26,000 officers; and by next month the department expects to have 31,351 officers, said Chief John Timoney, the commanding officer of the New York City Police Department's Office of Management Analysis and Planning.
But community policing may have its limits, particularly in places like the East New York section of Brooklyn, with its high concentration of housing projects, said Deputy Police Chief Kenneth Gussman, commanding officer of the Brooklyn detective command. "There's a sense that community policing works better in middle class, homogeneous neighborhoods," he said. "There's a real sense of community in those areas.
"You take where I live, out in Bay Ridge, people get excited about double-parked cars. People have owned their homes there for 20 years. It's less transient than in areas with a lot of housing projects."
Mr. Timoney also blames the availability of guns for the high murder rates in certain neighborhoods. "What happens is it's almost self-fulfilling," he said. " 'I carry it so I have to use it.' It's a circle and it's spinning faster."
 
Fear, Even in Church
 And in those neighborhoods the violence is difficult to avoid, and everyone seems to have a perspective on it.
Father Grange opened his church's death registry last week and read the ages of the people he had buried last year: "29 . . . 15 . . . 23 . . . "
"If it isn't a bullet it's AIDS," he said. His church is in the 40th Precinct in the Mott Haven neighborhood of the South Bronx, which reported 70 homicides last year.
Even though his church is across the street from the precinct police station, Father Grange said altar boys had told him they would not leave through the back door of the church for fear of being shot. "It creates a sense of unfairness of life," he said, "that you can become a victim without cause."
Danielle McDaniels, 23, rounded a corner in the South Bronx walking home last July and was stopped by neighbors who told her there had been a shooting on her block. A 20-year-old friend of hers had been killed instantly when someone driving by shot her in the head and abdomen, Ms McDaniels said.
"You don't know when it's going to happen," she said. "You could be coming from the store and if they want you, it could be you or your children."
A color picture of a mural painted in memory of Ms. McDaniels's friend Jessica hung recently on the wall of a church on Prospect Avenue along with 16 pictures of similar murals for other neighborhood victims of the violence. They were hung around a sign that said "Thou Shalt Not Kill" in both English and Spanish.
Heidi Neumark, the pastor of the Transfiguration Lutheran Church, said she feared that the violence in the inner city glanced off the consciousness of the general public.
She marvels at the public attention stirred by the shootings on the Long Island Rail Road. "That's a horrible tragedy, but this is a much more horrible tragedy if you talk about numbers," she said. "People have given up in a lot of cases. 'Well, it's the Bronx, what do you expect?' That's not what we should expect."
On Good Friday last year, as Pastor Neumark and other adults at the church led children on a procession down the sidewalk they came to a subway stop where men were gathered, selling drugs, Pastor Neumark said. The men saw a car approaching, filled with people they thought were there to shoot them. "They yelled for everyone to take cover," she said. "The people in the car, out of respect, or whatever, shot up in the air."
"The war they're having is not a private war," Debra Simmons, a church member said of the drug dealers. "We're all in it."
 
Atmosphere for Killing
 The steadiest rise in homicides in recent years has been in a string of neighborhoods across eastern Brooklyn where three precincts reported the most slayings last year. The 75th Precinct reported 126 homicides, up from 109 in 1990; the 77th Precinct reported 82 homicides, up from 70; and the 73d Precinct reported 74 homicides, up from 60.
Deputy Chief Gussman said the large number of public housing developments in the eastern end of Brooklyn "provides a ready clientele for drugs," an atmosphere that often leads to shootings.
James Bowens, the chairman of the community council in the 73d Precinct in Brownsville, said his neighborhood was a working-class community increasingly overshadowed by "these idiots out there shooting people with no apparent reason."
"Everybody says, 'I need a gun to protect myself from him' and the others say, 'I need a gun to protect myself from him,' " Mr. Bowens said. "It's frightening to the point that as a citizen you can't walk down the street without worrying."
 
Some Large Reductions
 Even among the most crime-ridden neighborhoods there are examples of large reductions in murders. The 34th Precinct in Washington Heights, which had 103 homicides in 1990, reported 75 homicides last year, making it the fourth leading precinct for homicides in 1993.
Police officials said the precinct had been the focus of increased police activity by narcotics agents and other officers following a July 1992 disturbance there ignited by the fatal shooting of a man by a police officer.
Mr. Timoney, of the police department's office of management analysis and planning, said he expected the areas of Brooklyn now plagued by growing numbers of murders would see increased police activity.
But he said he was concerned that over all, the public would become complacent as the city's total murder level continues to decline.
"I think we have become inured to this stuff," Mr. Timoney said. "Now we're happy if we keep it under 2,000. That's ridiculous."

HEADLINE: After Snow, Cold Alone Isn't So Bad

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Heads and shoulders braced against the freezing wind, the Falzone family trudged through the chunks of ice and snow drifts outside Giants Stadium yesterday, the parents laden with blankets, the two boys wrapped so that little more than their cold-chapped cheeks showed.
Wicked a day as it was, there were no complaints about the cold from this bunch. It was kickoff time. Pointing a gloved finger at her heavily bundled sons who waddled toward the stadium behind their father, Angela Falzone, of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., said, "It was too cold to tailgate, but they wanted to be here, so we came." 
 Not everyone had a National Football League playoff game as an excuse. But across the region, as if itching to shake cabin fever after a week of rain, snow and sleet, the hardy ventured out yesterday, moving cars onto slippery roads, walking through iced-over parks and plowing down ski slopes.
"I lost a few days this week because of all the snow," said Marianne Addicott of Fairfield, Conn., who took her usual four-mile walk despite temperatures in the low to middle 20's. "When that happens I start getting real antsy and fidgety. It's cold, but real pretty out here today. As long as I'm bundled up enough, I'm fine."
 
A Switch to Sand
 Others were outside with work to do, as cities and towns were still struggling to keep roads and sidewalks clear of ice. Though the primary roads in New York City were mostly clear by midday yesterday, many side streets, from Manhattan to Queens to Staten Island, remained covered with chunks of ice and snow.
Anne Canty, a spokeswoman for the Department of Sanitation, which is responsible for clearing the roads, said that every road had been cleared or salted at least once. But with the freezing temperatures, she said, the department had suspended salting efforts (which help melt the ice) in favor of spreading sand, which provides extra traction for car tires. More than half the department's workers -- 4,000 people -- were called in on overtime.
"Everybody we could reach, we have," she said.
Conditions today are expected to improve slightly, with temperatures reaching the upper 20's and winds abating after an overnight dip into the low teens. And the road-clearing efforts should pay off for commuters. By late yesterday, most major thoroughfares in New Jersey and Long Island were reported clear; in Connecticut, the Department of Transportation said the state highways would be clear by this morning.
 
A Return to Normal
 Homeless shelters also found themselves working in overdrive, with men and women huddling at their doors looking for a warm place to sleep.
Josh Taylor, a spokesman for the Partnership for the Homeless in New York City, said the group's 150 shelters were filled to capacity over the weekend. He said 35 people, the most ever, spent Saturday night in the group's drop-in center on West 23d Street because no room was left in its shelters. And yesterday morning, when the temperature fell to 13 degrees in Central Park, 120 people showed up for breakfast, more than twice as many as usual, he said.
But as the sun came out and the air cleared, some things slowly moved back to normal.
On Long Island, for example, though as many as 36,000 Lilco customers were without power on Friday at the height of the storm, a spokeswoman for the Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that all service had been restored. In New Jersey, nearly all of the 130,000 customers whose electricity and gas service was interrupted had service restored by 6 A.M. yesterday.
And residents from Massapequa to Morristown took advantage of more tranquil weather to venture out of their homes for the first time in days.
 
Fun Beats the Cold
 At the Channel Home Center on Hackensack Avenue in Hackensack, N.J., snow removal items vanished from shelves just as quickly as they could be stocked, as people moved outside to shovel snow and wrench ice from their cars.
"I've got nothing left with the exception of maybe a gallon or two of windshield washer fluid, and that's probably gone by now too," said Robert Saker, the store's manager. "Snow shovels are gone, de-icer fluid, salt, scrapers -- I've even sold the last of my garden shovels left over from the summer."
In Prospect Park in Brooklyn, dogs raced across the hard-packed snow, following owners who pulled their children on sleds. Some adults and children slid and spun down little hills in plastic saucers. Earmuffed runners made their way down the park's main road.
"Fun beats out the cold any day," said Brigid McGinn, 32, of Park Slope, as she pulled the strap of a toboggan holding 3 1/2-year-old Rosie Zion-Malloy, a neighbor's daughter, over the icy slopes.
Nearby, Marti Andersen, 33, walked up a steep slope of the park with his wood tripod on his shoulders, his cameras in a large white bag. "All you have to say is: Look how beautiful it is," Mr. Andersen said, looking up at the crystalline tree branches. "For all the people who can't get to Vermont to photograph the real forest, you have this one here."
 
Ski Areas Thrive
 At local ski areas and parks, attendance was back to normal as well, officials said.
At Catamount Ski Area, located on the New York-Massachusetts border, more than 4,000 skiers were on the resort's 23 slopes. At Bear Mountain State Park near West Point, N.Y., where the temperature stayed in the teens, about 1,200 people turned up to skate, about normal for a weekend day in better weather, said Sean Mahon, a supervisor of the rink.
And on the Staten Island Ferry, Ricardo Ramos, 30, an unemployed salesman from Greenwich Village, sat on an orange bench on the deck, braving winds that sent others scurrying inside. He was on his way to Staten Island to see his mother.
"I'm wearing my wool coat; I had this made for me," he said, referring to a knee-length Hudson Bay coat with thick brown leather patches sewn onto the elbow and chest areas. "I like the air out here and I can feel the chill on my face, but I'm warm in this coat. My advice is to invest in one good huge coat."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Wagner Legacy Survives in Counsel to Giuliani

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
A LARGE ceremonial guest book was kept in the front foyer of Gracie Mansion when Robert F. Wagner Jr., then still known as Robert F. Wagner 3d, was growing up there during his father's three terms as Mayor.
"I peeked into it, and noticed that the name of Robert F. Wagner 3d appeared on almost every page," Philip Hamburger wrote in 1954 in The New Yorker. "I gathered that almost every time the Mayor's oldest son enters the Mansion, he signs his name." 
 Mr. Wagner was 10 then, not much older than Andrew Giuliani is today, and for nearly 40 years more he regularly viewed his city with the gentle grace and the acquired sagacity of a privileged visitor. Mr. Wagner's legacy is more than the name in the guest book, or even his distinguished record as City Planning Commission chairman, deputy mayor and president of the Board of Education. Mr. Wagner, a lifelong Democrat, died last November before his time, but not before outlining a vision for New York that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate whom Mr. Wagner endorsed, largely embraced and may now embody.
Eulogizing Mr. Wagner last week at Cooper Union, Mr. Giuliani recalled that as he crammed for the campaign two years ago, one of the first experts who agreed to brief him was Mr. Wagner. That tape-recorded soliloquy provided the foundation for Mr. Giuliani's platform, and a copy of the tape, obtained from the Giuliani staff, still offers clues to his philosophy in formation. The words are a reminder of how much Mr. Wagner already is missed as a moral gyroscope for the fledgling administration and as a Talleyrand to the new Mayor. This is the gist of what he said:
The city remains ascendant as it lurches toward the millennium, but at the pace of a struggling mountain climber, not a jet plane. With more people leaving the work force than entering, for the first time since World War I everybody who wants a job might have the opportunity to get one, but only if they are armed with a high school or college degree. Today the problems of poverty and maintaining upward mobility are greater than ever.
To spur the economy, often the best thing city government can do is get out of the way. Encourage development of downtowns outside Manhattan, of Broadway theater and of other cultural and economic resources. Let the Housing Authority assume all responsibility for low-income housing. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development, using the Nehemiah home-ownership project as a model, should revive a 1990's version of the Mitchell-Lama program that combined tax subsidies and lowered land costs to create apartments for the middle-class and working poor.
Simplify waterfront planning and rationalize zoning codes to make development less dependent on official whims. Maintain the role of community boards.
To curb congestion and pollution and to pay for transportation improvements, regulate use of cars. One way is to impose tolls on the free East River bridges ("I would advise no candidate to say it"). Build rail links to the airports and to New Jersey. Spending more than 13 percent of the budget to repay borrowing for public works is not too much, given the demands of the water supply, waste disposal, health and school systems and shortchanged city parks.
Granting hospitals autonomy and imposing accountability may be more practical than selling them off ("I don't know that there are people who are anxious to buy municipal hospitals"). Nursing homes for the frail elderly and community-based care for AIDS sufferers would relieve hospital overcrowding.
Official policies sometimes reward dependency rather than promote early intervention by social workers and settlement houses. More schools, services and sex education are crucial for young women who are pregnant or likely to beome so ("I would stay away from the condom issue"). So are residential programs that combine education and job training for "disconnected" young men. Model Cities, which singled out neighborhoods in which social services were integrated, is a concept worth resurrecting. Docking women on welfare who have more children tends to punish the child more than the mother.
Despite the city's vast overall budget for education, spending per student in regular classrooms lags behind suburban schools. Joining with other mayors and county executives might persuade the state to assume a greater share of Medicaid and welfare costs. But the only way to correct inequities in state aid formulas may be to sue.
The combination of collective-bargaining rights and Civil Service protection hobbles good management. (Why, Mr. Giuliani asked, does a commander of a precinct where crime declines gets no reward but one in a precinct where crime increases receives more resources?). Without accountability, turning services over to private contractors does not guarantee improvement ("I happen to be somewhat skeptical of it").
Buck a bureaucracy where innovators can become enemies of the system. Give the boroughs, not necessarily the borough presidents, more say over delivery of city services. Don't create five borough boards of education ("one is bad enough").
"What troubles me," Mr. Wagner said, "as much as any of the fiscal problems is the lack of leadership. What can determine what kind of city we are in the next century will be leadership as much as a set of specific policies."
Mr. Wagner, sensing in Mr. Giuliani the potential for leadership, was just starting to place his signature on the new administration when he died. Now, with his voice surviving only on tape, the last legacy of the little boy whose immortality began modestly with the Gracie Mansion guest book is up to Mr. Giuliani to redeem.

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A CONTROVERSIAL inventor, Jerome Lemelson, and a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist, Lester Thurow, are expected to announce today the establishment of a program that will award annually the largest cash prize ever given to an individual inventor.
The prize, the amount of which is expected to be announced today at a lunch at the "21" Club in New York, is part of a $6.5 million innovation and invention program to be directed by Mr. Thurow at M.I.T. The program is endowed by Mr. Lemelson, who holds 500 patents, more than any other living American. 
 Mr. Lemelson, 70, is a heroic figure to many individual inventors and holds patents for, among other things, a fax machine, a copy machine and a cordless telephone. Mr. Lemelson's critics have said that he is a shrewd litigant who wields patents for paper inventions to force corporations to pay him millions of dollars in licensing fees. Mr. Lemelson has countered that independent inventors can only protect their rights through litigation.
 
Method to Speed Computer Processes
 Dao-Long Chen and Robert D. Waldron, both engineers in Fort Collins, Colo., have come up with a speedy equation that they say cuts by half the time it takes a computer to approximate the square root of a number. They recently received a patent that protects their algorithm, which appears to be at least the third such square-root equation explicitly covered by a patent.
Computers, which think in mathematical equations, must often compute square roots as they perform various functions. For example, the manipulation of three-dimensional drawings on a computer screen requires a computer to perform many square-root calculations. In semiconductor chips, the square root of the current running through an individual transistor is proportional to the voltage applied to the transistor. A sophisticated chip might have more than a million transistors, meaning that more than a million different square roots must be calculated.
A computer approaches its square-root calculations much as a human does: first by making an educated guess, plugging that guess into an algebraic formula (most often a variation of an equation called the Newton-Raphson method) and then using the answer to make an even more educated guess. This process repeats itself until the square root has been approximated.
Mr. Chen and Mr. Waldron said they had come up with a simplified version of the Newton-Raphson method that cuts by half the time a computer takes to make its educated guesses in calculating a square root.
Patent 5,268,857 was assigned to the NCR Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, which said it was not developing any products based on the patent, but it might license it.
 
Harnessing Wind From Moving Cars
 Thomas Alva Wither, a computer and electronics consultant in Royal Oak, Mich., has patented a way to capture electricity from wind generated by automobiles as they drive along highways.
"I came up with the idea while I was driving down the expressway, watching weeds being blown by the cars ahead of me," Mr. Wither said.
Mr. Wither said he envisioned a column of turbines marching down the median strips of urban expressways. The turbine rotors, which when viewed from the top or bottom resemble the letter S, would be pushed counterclockwise by the wind generated by the vehicles passing along either side of the median.
The turbines would be sheltered by a median structure 8 to 10 feet high and 3 feet wide, which would help keep what Mr. Wither calls "hostile" winds from slowing the rotor. The rotor would be attached to a flywheel that would turn a motor generator. The resulting electrical energy produced by the generator would be transmitted to a utility using a conduit encased in the base portion of the median.
"The beauty of this is that it's a clean source of energy that's available on a predictable basis when the utility companies need it -- during business hours," Mr. Wither said. "Most other wind-powered systems use natural wind, which is very unpredictable and often generates electricity during nonpeak hours."
Mr. Wither said he calculated that each mile of highway could accommodate 792 turbines, and that the optimal distance from the vehicle to the turbine was five feet.
Wayne State University, in conjunction with Mr. Wither, recently conducted a study on an expressway in Detroit and found that the winds generated by vehicles averaged 15 to 25 miles an hour, according to the inventor.
"That's enough wind to make it feasible," said Mr. Wither, who acknowledged that many other questions remained. Chief among them is how many miles of the turbines would be necessary to produce a significant amount of electricity.
Mr. Wither, who is promoting the invention through his company Vehilectrical Power Systems, received patent 5,272,378.
 
Nominees Sought For Inventor Award
 Intellectual Property Owners, an association based in Washington, will accept nominations until March 4 for its 21st annual Inventor of the Year award.
"Nominees should epitomize the American traditions of technological leadership and Yankee ingenuity," the association said in a brochure calling for nominations. More information can be obtained from the organization by calling (202) 466-2396.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Tries to Protect Tourist Season From Spill

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 10

 BODY:
While Puerto Rican officials worked today to clean up the hundreds of thousands of gallons of heavy oil leaking from a grounded barge, they were also frantically working to prevent a disaster for its tourism industry.
Through faxes and telephone calls to tour packagers and travel agents around the United States, officials sought to dispel the notion that a large proportion of the island's beaches was despoiled by the gooey, black substance still escaping from the crippled barge, the Morris J. Berman, as it sat on a coral reef just 300 yards from the San Juan beachfront. 
 After all, officials say they do not know when the cleanup will be completed, and Puerto Rico's Governor, Pedro J. Rossello had called the incident "a catastrophe" just hours after it happened, a remark that travel industry figures privately criticized as ill-considered.
Today, however, Luis Fortuno, the head of the government's Tourism Company, defended Governor Rossello's assessment as accurate at the time but said the weather and other factors since then had limited the spill's impact.
As they were declaring a qualified victory in their effort to let people know that only 3 out of 258 miles of beach here had been affected, even tourist industry officials were willing to be magnanimous toward the Governor.
"I'm sure it is a major disaster in his mind in terms of environmental impact, but I think it was overstated in terms of tourism," said Richard Abati, the manager of the Sands Hotel and Casino on the Isla Verde section of San Juan, which is five miles from the spill area but is unaffected. "The information we have is that tour packagers have had a lot of calls about the spill, and because they have information from us they are able to tell people that the impact is concentrated and limited."
Mr. Abati, president of the island's Hotel and Tourism Association, said there were only sketchy numbers on the impact of the spill on hotel occupancy.
 
First Hearing on Incident
 The details of what happened before the spill on Friday are likely to be revealed tomorrow when the Coast Guard holds its first hearing and publicly questions the crew of the barge and its tug boat, the Emily.
The chief investigator, Capt. Larry Doyle, a marine safety officer in the Coast Guard's Miami office, said the inquiry would discover whether the cause of the incident was human error, equipment failure or regulatory inadequacies. He said a final report was not expected for perhaps two or three months.
More than 3.7 million people visited Puerto Rico in 1992, tourism officials said, and the industry accounts for about 6 percent or $2.5 billion of the island's $34 billion gross national product and employs 45,000 people, directly and indirectly. The largest sector of the economy, manufacturing, accounts for 41 percent.
 
Moving to Other Hotels
 Tourism officials said that some reservations had been canceled at the five hotels whose beaches were most affected by the spill and that some frustrated vacationers had checked out early. But they said the impact on tourism overall had been minimized because many visitors had transferred to unaffected hotels.
At the largest of the hotels affected by the spill, the Caribe Hilton, only 50 percent of the 733 rooms were occupied immediately after the incident. The hotel lost 20 to 30 reservations a day and had to ferry an equal number of guests to hotels farther from the spill.
But by today, occupancy was up to 85 percent as oil skimmers, pumps and tank trucks continued to clean the hotel beachfront along a sheltered cove, where much of the oil had drifted with the currents and been corraled. Some of the hotel's rooms were occupied by workers brought in for the cleanup and investigation.
 
Ice Storms vs. Black Sand
 "Fortunately the weather up north has outperformed the oil spill as a factor for us," said Brian Gamache, vice president for marketing for three hotels along the beach. The snow, sleet and cold weather that have gripped the Northeast have brought many people to the island, Mr. Gamache said, regardless of the spill.
Mr. Fortuno of the tourism office also said none of the 25 cruise ships that dock here in an average week had canceled stops in San Juan.
In New York, Steven Lassman, a sales director for Travel Impressions, a tour packager, said he had talked to all of the travel agents who had booked January visits to the five beachfront hotels. Visitors were given the option of moving to other hotels, flying to other islands, or canceling.
"I can tell you that the early returns were surprising because you would have thought that a lot would have been saying, 'I'm out of here,' " said Mr. Lassman. "But the majority are staying put. Only about 35 percent wanted to move to other hotels, but very few are canceling or going elsewhere."
Richard Ellis, senior vice president for marketing for Liberty Go-Go Tours in New Jersey, also said there had been "no pullback in Puerto Rico bookings."
Today, the white beach at the Sands Hotel was more crowded than usual, the numbers swelled significantly by those vacationers shuttled there in government vans from the affected hotels.
 
Line Broke Twice
 In addition to announcing the start of hearings, Captain Doyle gave some details of the grounding. He said the tow line connecting the barge with the tug boat broke for the first time at about 10 P.M. on Thursday and was repaired so that the vessels could resume their trip to Antigua a day and half away. But it a few hours later it broke again, at another spot along its 1,000-foot length, and this time the currents made the line difficult to retrieve.
"It is impossible to make a permanent repair of the towing cable at sea," said Captain Doyle. "We will be looking at the captain's decision to go on after the first repair and whether it was prudent. There are instances when this is done without any problems."
Captain Doyle said that he did not know where along the line the first break occurred but that the second break in the inch-and-a-half cable came at the point where it connected with the barge.
Commander Bob Ross, the San Juan marine safety officer directing the cleanup, said choppy seas had slowed the operation to empty the remaining oil from the crippled tanker. On Sunday, he estimated that workers had transferred 350,000 gallons of the 750,000 gallons of oil aboard the grounded Berman.
But he revised his estimate today, saying that much of what had been pumped was a mixture of oil and sea water that had been carried into the vessel by surf. He said that now he could say only that 850,000 gallons of the oil-water mixture had been transferred so far and could not predict exactly when the operation would be completed and the barge salvaged.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars 44.74 and Hits 4th Straight Record Close

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
Stocks soared to yet another high yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting its fourth consecutive record close.
The Dow jumped 44.74 points to close at 3,865.51, led by stocks of cyclical companies that benefit most in an expanding economy. Already in 1994, the widely watched index of blue-chip stocks has advanced 3 percent. Trading continued to be heavy, with 319.4 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, thus exceeding 300 million shares for the fifth straight session. 
 Analysts attributed the year's early run primarily to an improving economy and continuing low interest rates. Helpful seasonal factors, such as pension fund managers' need to invest new funds at the start of the year, also fueled the rise, they said.
"People think it's the best of all possible worlds now," Michael Metz, investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, said. "The economy is growing at a sustainable pace, the bond market is strong, and inflationary pressures seem to be under control."
Reflecting the sense that inflation holds no threat, gold for February delivery fell $1.50, to $385.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. On the New York Stock Exchange, American Barrick fell 1/4, to 29 1/4.
Inflation jitters that traders have had recently abated on Friday, when December employment data showed that nonfarm payrolls had grown by just 183,000 jobs -- fewer than the 215,000 jobs that economists had expected. That news prompted investors to conclude that the pressure was off the Federal Reserve to tighten short-term rates, setting the stage for a healthy bond market rally on Friday.
Further cheering Wall Street's bulls yesterday was across-the-board participation of stocks large and small: The Nasdaq composite index rose 3.75 points, to 786.69; the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 5.37 points, to a record 475.27, and the Dow Jones transportation average surged 20.37 points, to a record 1,819.58.
Chrysler was up 1 5/8, to 58 3/4; General Motors gained 1 3/8, to 59 1/4, and Ford was up 2 5/8, to 67 1/4, as analysts raised earnings estimates after meeting with auto executives at the Detroit Auto Show.
Eric Miller, investment strategist at DLJ Securities, said that the market was also benefiting from a temporary advantage in the supply-and-demand cycle of stocks. "For the early part of the year, demand just tends to be strong," he explained. "And at the moment, there is a slight lessening of new supply from new issues, because of the holidays."
 
 
Worry Over Speculation
 Mr. Miller added that while he saw no imminent end to the bull market, stocks were expensive in relation to corporate earnings. And, he said, investors are engaged in "a fair amount of speculation" -- a factor that always raises concerns about stock prices. And while Mr. Miller does not anticipate a meaningful rise in interest rates, he said it was worth noting that the significant declines in rates were over.
Mr. Metz said that while American stocks were being helped by short-term factors, like a move of investable money out of overseas stocks, there was reason to rein in optimism.
"The market is dominated by trend followers and fund managers trying to deploy the inflows of the last week or so," he said. "But I think it's time to take the money off the table. The market thinks it has the best of everything, and it's not justified."
Those most optimistic about stocks are overlooking a paradox in their bullish argument, Mr. Metz said. If investors are enthusiastic over cyclical stocks because they expect a surge in corporate earnings that comes from the ability to raise prices, "then what happens to the disinflation story?" he asked.
Investors can't have it both ways, Mr. Metz argued: either companies will enjoy noteworthy earnings increases because they can get prices up, or inflation will stay in check because companies can get only modest price gains.
Peter Eliades of Stockmarket Cycles, a West Coast investment newsletter, called the gains of the last week a stock market "blow-off," adding that the current price of the 30 Dow Jones industrial stocks divided by their dividends was at a measly 2.62 percent -- a sign that stocks are too expensive.
 
 
Yield Low for Years
 Optimists are making a case that dividend payouts will "grow into" the high stock market averages, putting the dividend yield closer to the 4.3 percent it has averaged over the last 80 years. Mr. Eliades acknowledges that the dividend yield has been low for several years, and that in the current enthusiasm over stocks, "even cats and dogs will do well."
On the New York Stock Exchange, U.S. Surgical gained 2, to 25 7/8, after the company said its restructuring would result in an improvement in results for the balance of 1994.
And in Nasdaq trading, Compression Labs was up 2, to 14 1/4, after signing a nonbinding agreement with Intel to develop videoconferencing products. Carl Karcher Enterprises, gained 2, to 13 5/8, after announcing that it had signed a letter of intent with Boston Chicken to develop and operate as many as 300 Boston Chicken stores. Boston Chicken gained 3 3/4, to 41.
Standout losers amid all of yesterday's winners were the companies involved in the protracted drama to purchase Paramount Communications.
In the wake of Friday's news that Viacom would merge with Blockbuster Entertainment and raise its offer for Paramount, Viacom class B stock fell 2 3/4, to 38 1/4; Blockbuster lost 5/8, to 27 5/8, and Paramount was down 1 7/8, to 77 3/8. QVC, which said yesterday that it would extend its tender offer for Paramount for two weeks, dropped 1 3/8, to 39 1/4.

HEADLINE: UKRAINE GIVES IN ON SURRENDERING ITS NUCLEAR ARMS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton announced tonight that the United States, Russia and Ukraine had reached an agreement for the destruction of Ukraine's entire nuclear arsenal, 175 long-range missiles and more than 1,800 warheads. He described the deal as "a hopeful and historic breakthrough" that would not only benefit the three signers but enhance world security.
If it takes effect -- and questions lingered tonight about important details of ratification and timing -- the agreement would mean that all three of the non-Russian republics left with nuclear weapons at the breakup of the Soviet Union would have undertaken to surrender them voluntarily. Kazakhstan and Belarus, the other two countries, agreed last year to give up their warheads.
 
Accidents Feared
 Ukraine was the most difficult case, and the negotiations on the deal continued by telephone through this morning. Their success, Administration officials hoped, would help to reduce tensions between Moscow and Kiev, shore up the tottering Ukrainian economy and stabilize a shaky region. 
 Most important, however, the agreement would get the weapons out of the hands of a country ill-equipped to handle them. The Administration had feared they might be poorly maintained, leading to disastrous accidents, or that they might be transferred to some other nation or fall into the hands of reckless people within Ukraine itself.
American officials said that over the next two decades, sales of nuclear fuel made by reprocessing the uranium in warheads from former Soviet states would produce about $12 billion for those states, including more than $1 billion for Ukraine. Only modest American seed money would be involved in the reprocessing program, they asserted.
 
 
Meeting in Kiev
 Mr. Clinton has added a brief stop in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, to his current European itinerary. In a symbolic gesture, he will meet at the airport there late on Wednesday night with President Leonid Kravchuk, who will later travel to Moscow for a signing ceremony on Friday with Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
The agreement could still fall apart; Mr. Kravchuk has failed in the past to bring the Ukrainian Cabinet and Parliament with him on the disarmament issue. This time, Mr. Clinton said, "we have no reason to doubt the ability of the President to keep the commitment that he is prepared to make." But a senior Defense Department official sounded less certain.
"It's a good deal," the Pentagon aide said. "Let's just hope the Ukrainians and their Parliament recognize their own national interest and decide to go along with it."
Ian Brzezinski, the son of Zbigniew K. Brzezinski, President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser, said by telephone from Kiev, where he is working as a parliamentary adviser, that Washington "may be underestimating the constitutional and political complexity of this issue." The Ukrainian Constitution, he added, does not make clear how far the President's powers to sign and enforce treaties extend.
An Administration specialist on Ukraine said that all the warheads would have to be out of Ukraine within seven years after the agreement is signed. The deal, she said, would not in itself be submitted for ratification by the Ukrainian Parliament. But after a new Parliament is chosen in March, she said, Mr. Kravchuk has pledged to resubmit for ratification the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty and participation in the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which were approved with conditions by the old Parliament last November.
The new deal would be a part of the new package, other American officials said, and some legislative leaders have voiced their approval.
 
Economic Cooperation
 As a result of the agreement, President Clinton said, the United States plans to expand its cooperation with Ukraine, "especially in the economic area." He added that Ukraine, which he termed "an important country at the center of Europe," would also benefit from the "security assurances that go with this sort of agreement" -- mainly the promise of the nations with nuclear weapons "not to use them against them, ever."
"This is a hopeful and historic breakthrough that enhances the security of all three parties and every other nation as well," he said.
During a brief news conference following a day of meetings at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters here, Mr. Clinton said that the agreement covered 176 missiles and 1,500 warheads. But his specialists later amended those figures. There are in fact 175 missiles, they said, including older SS-19's, which may be starting to fall apart after poor maintenance, and newer SS-24's. The warheads for the SS-24's will come out first, increasing the possibility of trouble with the older models.
According to the amended figures, the total number of warheads involved is 1,240 for the long-range missiles, plus roughly 600 more for air-launched cruise missiles.
 
Some U.S. Aid
 The missiles themselves would be broken up in Ukraine. About $175 million in American aid would be supplied for this process, through the so-called Nunn-Lugar program for the safe disposition of nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union. Most of the cost would be borne by the Ukrainians, who would get some of it back through scrap sales.
The warheads would be shipped intact to Russia -- a procedure the United States insisted upon because Ukrainian technicians would be more likely to make mistakes in dismantling them and might also learn secrets of the weapons-builder's art that Washington would not like them to know.
In Russia, the highly-enriched nuclear fuel would be removed. There or in the United States, or both, that fuel would be blended with other materials in a kind of nuclear cocktail to create less highly-enriched fuel of the type used in nuclear power plants. Processed into rods for such plants, the less-enriched fuel would then be sold by the United States Enrichment Corporation, which maintains a market for nuclear rods throughout the world.
 
Formula for Proceeds
 Proceeds from such sales, which would take place over a period of about 20 years, would flow back to Russia, which would then share them under a complicated formula that has still not been entirely worked out with the three non-Russian states giving up the warheads. In the case of Ukraine, at least, some of the payment would take the form of fuel rods for its own reactors, with the rest coming in hard currency badly needed for its hard-pressed economy.
"For the Ukrainians, the money was always the thing," said an American close to the negotiations. "They're broke, and these warheads were their best, their only chance to get hard currency quickly."
The leading American negotiators, who persuaded the Russians and the Ukrainians to complete the final steps in talks that they had begun months ago, were Strobe Talbott, soon to be the State Department's number two leader as deputy secretary; Lynn Davis, Under Secretary for International Security Affairs, and Rose Gottemoeller, who handles such matters on the National Security Council staff.

HEADLINE: THE NATO SUMMIT;
4 Countries In Audition For NATO

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Jan. 10

 BODY:
When President Clinton arrives here Tuesday to explain the partial membership in NATO that Washington is offering Eastern European nations, he will find four leaders who are essentially eager for the regional security.
But each leader -- from Poland, Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic -- has different concerns. 
 The Czech hosts are showing the most support. But they are also displaying a streak of independence, saying they want to negotiate their own entry separately from the other three.
Today, for example, the Czech Republic became the first Eastern European country to pledge financial support when it offered to accept a 1 percent deficit in the budget this year to bring its armed forces up to NATO standards. The total projected Government spending is $12.7 billion.
If all the extra spending is by the Defense Ministry, as seems likely, the Czech defense budget will rise about 12 percent this year, to $1 billion.
 
The Czech View
 In a radio address Sunday night, President Vaclav Havel said: "Czech policy emphasizes that we are independent countries -- each has to act for itself. We cannot be continually thrown into some common bag of post-Communist countries."
With the lowest unemployment in the region and a political climate that is unlikely to elect former Communists, the Czechs say that if they separate themselves from the rest of the East European crowd, they have a clear shot at early entry to NATO.
"It won't take long, and the Czech Republic will be a member of NATO," Defense Minister Antonin Baudys said today after meeting with the United States representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.
Prime Minister Vaclev Klaus, in a statement over the weekend, was quite open about his nation's westward thrust: "The Czech Republic is a little bit farther West than Poland. We have not lived through so many divisions as Poland. For Poles this is more sensitive than for Austria. In this matter, I'd rank us closer to Austria than Poland."
 
The Polish View
The Poles, who have voiced loud reservations about Washington's plan, formally blessed it today at a Cabinet meeting.
But they point out that the Czech Republic does not have a border with the former Soviet Union and thus are less agitated about the possible resurgence of Russian nationalism.
President Lech Walesa, who has lashed out at the Clinton plan as "blackmail," issued a more restrained statement today, calling the plan "too little but in the right direction."
But over the weekend, Mr. Walesa condemned the West for listening too intently to the Russian objections of a Western alliance at the border of the old Soviet Union.
"At the moment there is no sign of partnership," Mr. Walesa said, referring to Partnership for Peace, Washington's label for its plan. "There is Russia, which threatens; there is the organized West, which is afraid, and there are those of us in the middle who say: there's nothing to be afraid of, one should only try to increase the potential of Western Europe, both physically and technically."
"We understand the reasons why the West, and particularly the United States, is so concerned about Russia's reaction," Mr. Walesa. But he added, "We are also concerned about Russia's reaction."
 
The Slovak View
 The Slovak Prime Minister, Vladimir Meciar, is coming with still another view.
His Government, dominated by nationalists who have taken a tough stance against the large Hungarian minority in Slovakia, engaged in considerable debate before endorsing the idea of NATO membership, and an alliance with Ukraine was considered as an alternative.
In the eyes of many NATO members, Slovakia, because of its faltering attempts at economic and political reforms, has only a small chance of meeting the criteria for membership.
When the Slovak Cabinet announced its acceptance of the Washington plan over the weekend, it made clear that its concern was not Russian neo-imperialism but the separatist demands from the Hungarian minority.
 
The Hungarian View
 The Government of Hungary, to be represented by President Arpad Goncz, has been less critical of the Washington plan than the Poles but also less warm than the Czechs.
Last November, Secretary of State Warren Christopher chose Hungary as the first country to explain the offer of partial membership in NATO because of Hungary's strategic location bordering Serbia.
Today the Hungarian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Janos Harman, said the Government was concerned about the division of opinions among the four countries, which call themselves the Visegrad Group, for the Hungarian town where they formed an association in February 1991.
"We cannot disguise that problems did arise with the group," Mr. Harman said. "There are bilateral differences of views between countries, and some Visegrad countries do not attribute the same importance to cooperation."

HEADLINE: Economist Is Said to Be Favorite for Fed Position

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Three of President Clinton's top economic policy aides are advising him to nominate George L. Perry, a Brookings Institution economist, to the seven-member Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Perry, who has recommended caution in raising interest rates, would replace Wayne D. Angell, one of the board's most outspoken advocates of raising rates in response to early signs of inflation. Mr. Angell's term expires at the end of this month. 
 Before he could join the Fed, Mr. Perry would have to win President Clinton's approval in an interview, pass a background investigation and be confirmed by the Senate. If he survives these tests, Mr. Perry will become the lone Democratic appointee on a board filled with members appointed by Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
In recent writings, Mr. Perry has called for some restraint in raising interest rates when doing so might hurt short-term economic growth.
Opinions varied widely today on whether Mr. Perry's joining the Fed would actually affect interest rates and the overall economy. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat on the House Banking Committee, said Mr. Perry's reputation as a gifted economist would give him influence on the board beyond his single vote.
But Wall Street economists predicted that a substitution of Mr. Perry for Mr. Angell would have little effect on monetary policy because Mr. Perry's views are broadly consistent with the existing majority on the Fed.
"Just his appointment alone is not enough to shift the balance significantly on the Federal Reserve Board," said David M. Jones, a longtime Fed watcher at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
Mr. Jones said, however, that Mr. Perry could become much more influential next year if President Clinton elevated him to the position of vice chairman. David W. Mullins Jr. is the current vice chairman, but his term in that position will expire on July 24, 1995. His term on the board will expire on Jan. 31, 1996.
It has been widely expected that Mr. Clinton will elevate his own appointee rather than renew Mr. Mullins's tenure. If nominated and confirmed, Mr. Perry's term would last 14 years.
David C. Munro, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a New York consulting company, said that while Mr. Perry's arrival might not affect policy much, it would affect the tone of public debate. "It makes quite a difference in the atmospherics in the sense that Wayne Angell went out and spoke a lot," Mr. Munro said.
He estimated that given the many political and legal hurdles ahead of Mr. Perry there was less than a 50 percent chance of his actually ending up on the board.
Mr. Jones and Mr. Munro said the credit markets had not been affected by reports of a possible Perry nomination, which was first reported today by The Wall Street Journal.
A consensus in favor of Mr. Perry was reached last week by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said Administration officials who insisted on anonymity. The three have been in charge of finding a candidate, the officials said.
President Clinton has been known to reject his aides' recommendations after actually meeting a candidate. Administration officials said that while they had no reason to believe this would happen with Mr. Perry, it was possible that the eventual nominee would be someone else.

HEADLINE: Retailers' Drive to Consolidate

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
If Federated Department Stores succeeds in merging with R. H. Macy & Company, it would become the largest department store company in America -- but it would probably not hold the top spot for long.
Just as the number of major warehouse club operators has shrunk to two from five, some predict that by the end of the decade, the country will be populated with only three big department store operators and a smattering of niche players. 
 The department store industry has been slowly consolidating for the last three decades, as small two- and three-store businesses merged or were purchased, leaving a handful of national and regional companies. Now, Federated's grab for Macy is expected to accelerate the process.
 
Stakes Raised
 "It raises the stakes because it would increase Federated's ability to compete, which will send others out looking for ways to counter that," said Gilbert Harrison, chairman of Financo, an investment banking boutique that has many retail clients. "And about the only way to counter is by buying something else."
The department store industry has been struggling for the last decade to compete with more efficient retailers like discounters and mail-order catalogues. Growing their business allows them to spread costs for such things as advertising, senior management and distribution over a broader base.
Allocating costs over a much bigger universe of stores improves efficiency so much that Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant, said he believed a merger of Federated and Macy would be "the first step in a consolidation process that will by the end of the decade leave us with two or three big operators."
Indeed, the factors pushing Federated and Macy together are almost guaranteed to weigh equally on other department store chains.
These are among the factors:
*Department stores face far more varied and vigorous competition today than just a decade ago.
*The consumer is in the driver's seat, demanding high quality and service at low prices.
*What used to seem like an ever-expanding marketplace, generous to all retailers, has become a battlefield where sales gains come only at the expense of competitors.
*No one is clamoring to finance and build new, lavish 200,000-square-foot department stores, when there are already too many.
"The department store concept is in its maturest state, so how to get growth has become their biggest problem," said Therese Byrne, publisher of Retail Maxim, a newsletter that covers retail real estate. "About the only way left is to buy it."
To be sure, some department store companies still have building plans. The May Department Stores Company, which would be unseated as the nation's largest department store operator should Federated win Macy, plans to build 100 more stores over the next five years. And Federated itself expects to put up 40 new stores, some to replace old ones.
With as much as 15 percent too much space for department store retailing, by some estimates, buying stores is cheaper than building them. "There's very little regional mall development anywhere, and where there is, it is for other retail concepts," Ms. Byrne said. "To get space, you almost have to buy it."
Real estate developers that used to plan malls around department store anchors are now wooing Wal-Mart, Target and Toys "R" Us.
Despite their building plans, Federated and May, as well as Dillard Department Stores, have made it clear that acquisition is their best vehicle for growth. Dillard has assembled a $5 billion empire by picking off local and regional chains, valuable mainly for their real estate. May has achieved its $11 billion weight by swallowing bigger competitors.
 
Story of the Whale
 "It's the old story of the whale," said Peter J. Solomon, an investment banker whose father once ran the Abraham & Straus chain. "The little fish gets eaten by the big fish, which gets eaten by the bigger fish and so on until they're all swallowed by the whale."
Thomas Gould, chairman and chief executive of Younkers, a department store company that operates 53 stores in the Midwest, is not afraid of being swallowed by a bigger operator. "The Dillard's of the world are searching for places they can put down a cookie cutter and stamp out 150,000- to 200,000-square-foot stores, which limits them to major metropolitan areas," he said. "Markets we're in are just not worth their while."
Yet Mr. Gould agrees that consolidation is the trend, pointing to Younkers's own acquisitions of the Brandeis stores in 1987 and the Prange chain in 1992. "I'd guess that there are approximately 500 department store chains out there today, but by the end of the decade, there will be less than 200," he said.
 
Established in 1929
 Federated, Dillard and May are the three biggest "whales." Federated was the first company created by cobbling together family-owned department store chains. It was established in 1929, when Abraham & Straus and F&R Lazarus & Company and its subsidiary, Shillito's, banded together to form a holding company.
After adding Rich's in 1976, Federated stopped expanding through acquisition until it was purchased in 1988 by Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate developer. He merged Federated with the Allied Stores Corporation, which he also owned. With a debt-laden balance sheet, the company landed in bankruptcy.
Now, two years after emerging from bankruptcy, it has kicked off a scramble for Macy, a bankrupt company with stores largely in coveted markets like the New York metropolitan region and Southern California. Dillard and May, which is rumored to be buying a privately held chain in the Northeast called Steiger's, are reportedly also interested in parts of Macy. With $6 billion in sales, it would be the largest "fish" any department store retailer has tried to swallow.
Macy -- or even a part of it -- would give any of those three companies instant revenue growth, which is hard to come by when a 3 or 4 percent sales jump at stores open at least a year is considered admirable.
Of May's $11 billion in sales, almost $6 billion was added by the purchase of competitors since 1986. Dillard, by adding 10 stores here and 20 stores there, has lifted its sales at least $1.5 billion over the last decade.
"There's not a lot of sales growth in the department store sector, and there are just so many economies of scale you can achieve with existing stores to squeeze more to the bottom line," Mr. Solomon said.
 
Cost Cutting Necessary
 But that and cost cutting are where much of the earnings growth in the department store business, particularly Federated's, has come from. May has consolidated numerous regional chains and even its buying offices to reduce expenses. Dillard, which is known as the low-cost operator, slices out layers of middle management when it makes an acquisition. Federated buys about 75 percent of the merchandise it sells in its nine store chains as a single entity and uses a centralized computer system to manage its inventories, accounting and back office functions.
Even Macy, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, has dramatically improved its cash flow by cutting costs. Its sales, however, have declined slightly, and analysts say its revenues must grow if it hopes to emerge as a viable business.
In retailing today, having the lowest prices can make the difference between a poor showing and a good one. When they were the dominant retailing format, department stores could price their wares for a comfortable 40 percent gross profit margin. Those days are long gone.
With slim profits, they need to increase operating efficiencies, spreading the costs of one computer system over more stores or using the muscle of multistore orders to gain a better price from their suppliers.
"Over the years the margins have allowed them to have the luxury of services and functions that today's operating environment just won't permit," said Marie Beninati, director of retail market strategy at Kurt Salmon Associates, a retail and apparel consulting firm. "The consumer is demanding value, and department stores have to learn to pass it on in the same way that Wal-Mart does."
It costs Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retail company, only 15 percent of its revenues to operate 2,400 stores and warehouse clubs, which enables it to offer its customers lower prices and still make a profit.
And department stores must compete not only with discounters like Wal-Mart, but also catalogue companies like L.L. Bean, specialty stores like the Gap and, increasingly, electronic retailers like QVC.
According to Kurt Salmon Associates, department store companies' slice of the retail pie shrank from 17 percent in 1980 to 11 percent last year. "Now we're just a small part of the business," said Allen I. Questrom, Federated's chairman. "In order to thrive, we've got to compete on their terms."
