HEADLINE: THE NATO SUMMIT;
In NATO Talks, Bosnia Sets Off A Sharp Debate

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The NATO summit meeting opened today with continuing tensions over Bosnia -- mostly between France and the United States -- that competed for attention with the signing of a document opening the alliance's doors to the countries of Eastern Europe.
President Francois Mitterrand called on the allies to reinforce United Nations peacekeeping troops in the former Yugoslav republics. French commanders, who lead the largest United Nations contingent in Bosnia and Herzegovina, have also chafed at the reluctance of the allies to use air power to stop the shelling of Sarajevo. 
 When he spoke to the closed-door meeting, President Clinton did not refer directly to France, but he seemed exasperated with a call for more action by countries that had opposed such moves, White House officials said later.
 
To Repeat Their Threat
 By tonight, the 16 leaders agreed that in a communique on Tuesday, they would reiterate their five-month-old threat to begin air strikes against Serbia "to prevent the strangulation of Sarajevo, the safe areas and other threatened areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina."
In what they intended as the centerpiece of the meeting, the leaders of North Atlantic Treaty Organization issued a formal invitation today to their former Warsaw Pact adversaries to join a so-called Partnership for Peace, which is intended to forge closer military ties between Western and Eastern Europe without guaranteeing eastern countries full membership in NATO.
In addition to that well-scripted success, the Administration's ability to secure a deal with Russia and Ukraine calling for the surrender of the Ukrainian nuclear arsenal allowed Mr. Clinton to boast tonight of "two giant steps toward greater security for the United States, for Europe and the world."
But with France and some others pressing NATO to assume a more active role in Bosnia, the most forceful words of the gathering came as Mr. Clinton arose this morning to warn his colleagues that the alliance risked losing its credibility if cannot make good on its threats to use force in Bosnia.
"If we are going to reassert this warning, it cannot be seen as mere rhetoric," the President said of the threat of air strikes. "Those who attack Sarajevo must understand that we are serious." His comments were relayed to the news media by White House officials.
 
Stances Have Been Swapped
 Mr. Clinton, who is finding that roles have reversed since last summer, when Paris helped to block a Washington proposal for military intervention in Bosnia, was said by Administration officials to have sharpened the tone of his remarks after Mr. Mitterrand urged reinforcements.
Mr. Mitterrand's call reflected both his desire to show political leadership in Europe and his need to convince the public at home. One recent poll showed that most French favor military intervention on behalf of Bosnia's Muslims.
There was no sign tonight of any decision that could lead to immediate military action. But with Sarajevo staggering under heavy Serbian shelling and the allies still divided over a suitable response, the 16 leaders discussed the issue at length among themselves tonight at a private dinner in the historic Chateau Val Duchesse.
At news conferences earlier in the evening, President Clinton and his senior advisers tried to shift attention from disagreements over Bosnia to NATO's overture to the east.
 
A Partial Role in NATO
 The proposed arrangement falls well short of the full membership and security guarantees that Poland, Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic have sought. But Mr. Clinton and his colleagues, who had opposed immediate expansion of the alliance on the ground that it would inflame resentment in Russia, were adamant in defending the proposal.
The plan offers military cooperation and possible membership to all of the former Soviet bloc countries and neutral countries in Europe.
"I do not view it as some sort of half-hearted compromise," said Mr. Clinton, who later described the plan as one that would be more important to the future of Europe "than whatever is or is not done with the tragedy of Bosnia at this late date."
 
'We Care,' NATO Says
 Manfred Worner, NATO's secretary general, said this morning: "Our message to the new democracies of Central and Eastern Europe has been equally consistent: We shall not leave you alone. We care about your security, which is of direct and material concern to us."
Apart from the offer to Eastern Europe, the alliance also formally endorsed a plan that will allow European countries for the first time to form joint military task forces under NATO's auspices, a step welcomed by Mr. Mitterrand and by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany.
But the Bosnia issue lingered, and Administration officials said tonight that the 16 leaders, in addition to reaffirming their readiness to carry out air strikes, agreed to commend the European Union for its efforts to mediate peace in the Balkans.
The United States refused to go along with a European request for a more explicit endorsement of that effort because Washington remains leery of a European Union proposal to lift economic sanctions against Serbia in exchange for progress toward a political settlement.
What remained unclear and apparently unresolved was whether the allies were anywhere near deciding that the attacks on Sarajevo had become so serious that the long-threatened air strikes should begin.
After his dinner tonight, Mr. Clinton said that he and other leaders had discussed "some other options," and that they would resume those discussions on Tuesday.
German officials said France and other countries with troops in the Balkans were hardening their positions, and were pressing for either reinforcements or withdrawal of their contingents.
NATO's first warning about air strikes came on Aug. 9, but in the months since, it has led neither to military action by the alliance nor to a halt in Serbian attacks.
Any decision to go ahead with air strikes would require the approval of the North Atlantic Council, which is the political arm of NATO, and the United Nations Security Council. United States officials acknowledged tonight that there was mounting sentiment among some allies, including France and the Netherlands, to go forward with the attacks.
United States officials here have suggested that the fact the Bosnian Army has begun a major military operation against Croatian forces in central Bosnia should make the United States even more wary about coming to Bosnia's aid. A senior Administration official who briefed reporters here on Sunday said the situation in Sarajevo was "still not as grave" as when NATO first issued its warning last August.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury issues were mixed yesterday, as investors failed to follow through on last week's rally, which had been stimulated by a December jobs report that showed economic growth was easing.
The 30-year bond was down 10/32 , to 1004/32 , sending the yield up to 6.24 percent, from 6.22 percent on Friday. 
 Treasuries slumped in early trading, but managed to regain some of those losses. Traders said the early weakness came on active selling in the long end of the market and was attributed to an overseas seller of bonds, rumored to be Japan, although no one was sure through what underwriter the bonds might have been sold. However, many said it looked as though Japan was selling bonds, especially because of the way the market rebounded. Bond traders say Japanese investors may be setting up for the new United States Treasury bond in the February quarterly refunding.
 
Searching the Yield Curve
 It was a day when buyers were searching along the yield curve to get the most return for their money. Analysts believe that there is an enormous amount of money on the sidelines poised for investment, with buyers seemingly favoring the intermediate maturities. The five-year issues are the most popular among investors because their yield spread is close to that of the seven-year note but without the longer commitment. A five-year note yesterday was trading at a price to yield 5.02 percent while a seven-year note was at a price to yield 5.17 percent.
Economic data continue to show there is a reduced risk of the Federal Reserve's raising short-term rates because the economy's growth is moderate. Friday's jobs report that showed December nonfarm payrolls rising by 183,000, instead of the 215,000 that had been forecast, expelled much worry about any immediate tightening.
The market is likely to ride out the next couple of days without any major swings as it awaits scheduled inflation data, the Producer Price Index tomorrow, and the Consumer Price Index on Thursday. Retail sales are also due Thursday.
 
Reviewing Numbers
 Matthew F. Alexy, a Government trading specialist with CS First Boston, said market participants were still reviewing last week's numbers, trying to determine the prospects for the rest of the week.
"While the market is not likely to see the frenzy that we saw on Thursday and Friday in conjunction with the jobs data," Mr. Alexy said, "we could see a more steady kind of movement leading into this week's data."
He said that since the idea of the Fed's raising interest rates in a preemptive strike on inflation had faded, the market's focus should now be on how the Fed is perceiving the economy. Instead of investors wondering when in the first three months the Fed will tighten short-term rates, Mr. Alexy said, they now would be betting on whether the tightening will come in the first or second half of the year.
 
Corporate Debt
 The largest issuer of corporate debt yesterday was the Eastman Chemical Company, with $1 billion of securities equally divided between 10-year notes and 30-year debentures through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Ten-year notes due in 2004 were given a 6 3/8 percent coupon and priced at 99.897 to yield 6.389 percent, or about 74 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The 30-year debentures were given a 7 1/4 percent coupon and priced at 98.974 to yield 7.335 percent, or 97 basis points more than a comparable Treasury issue. Eastman Chemical, which spun off from Eastman Kodak on Jan. 1, said the debt being offered was noncallable before maturity and was rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Municipal Offerings
 In the municipal sector, the Department of Transportation of the State of Kansas negotiated the sale yesterday of $125 million of tax-exempt highway revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney Shearson.
The revenue bonds were initially priced to yield from 3.90 percent for an issue due in 1999 to 4.45 percent in 2003, 4.95 percent in 2008, and 5.20 percent in 2012 and 2013.
At yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills, analysts said investor interest was strong at the average rate of 3.02 percent and 3.18 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Broad Front Despite Tepid Job Figures

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against most leading currencies yesterday as traders looked beyond Friday's weak employment report. In late New York trading it was quoted at 1.7343 German marks, up from 1.7278 late Friday. It also rose to 112.27 Japanese yen from 111.90.
Gold prices slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery fell $1.50, to $385.70 an ounce. 
 The dollar fell Friday after the Labor Department reported a moderate rise in payrolls in December. But dealers said weak economic fundamentals in other countries suggested the dollar was still the best buy.
Data released yesterday showed western Germany's economy shrank by 1.9 percent in 1993. Eastern Germany's new capitalist economy jumped 6.3 percent last year, but the German economy as a whole contracted 1.3 percent.
"I don't think people are willing to junk" the dollar yet, said Jim Phoenix, foreign exchange dealer at theCanadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
But few dealers were willing to buy dollars aggressively until there was new information on the pace of growth. Some suggested that the dollar would remain confined to its recent range until economic data for January became available.
"The obvious trend for the dollar is higher, but short term it could be range-bound," said Ian Foster, treasury manager at Bank of New York in London.
The dollar also firmed against the yen, despite a surging Japanese stock market and talk that Tokyo would soon disclose a stimulus package. While an attempt by Japan to spur its economy and encourage imports could dampen speculation that the White House will call for a firmer yen to narrow the bilateral trade gap, most analysts believe a growth plan is in the end supportive of the yen.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4930, down from $1.4935 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4725 Swiss francs, up from 1.4669; $1.3170, Canadian dollars, down from $1.3193; 5.9085 French francs, up from 5.8828, and 1,710 Italian lire, up from 1,690.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Rally Ends After Doubts Arise on Early OPEC Talks

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
A modest two-week rally in crude oil ended yesterday as the market laid aside hopes for cuts in petroleum production. Prices fell sharply despite the bitter cold weather in the Northeast.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for February delivery dropped 65 cents, to $14.67 a barrel. February unleaded gasoline futures shed 2.12 cents, to 41.70 cents a gallon, and heating oil fell 1.41 cents, to 46.76 cents a gallon.
The prices fell after a respected publication played down the chance of an early meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 
 The publication, the Middle East Economic Survey, said it was highly unlikely that OPEC would push up its scheduled March meeting before the Islamic fasting month of Ramadam starts Feb. 11.
Oil prices had rebounded from five-year lows on faint hopes that OPEC would act to cut the flow of petroleum. Harsh winter weather contributed to the price recovery, since it was expected to drive up demand for heating oil.
 
'Market's Optimism Premature'
"Other than the weather, the fundamentals haven't changed," said Shannon Burchett of Chase Manhattan Bank. "The market's optimism that there would be an early meeting may have been premature."
Prior to the price collapse, the crude-oil market was poised to challenge a gap on charts that began at $15.65. But when that level went untouched by the active February contract, many investors bailed out of long positions.
Recent gains in gasoline prices have made the domestic market more attractive to imports from Europe. As a result, more supplies are expected at a time when American refinery output is more than 5 percent above a year ago.
On other commodity markets, orange juice futures soared amid concerns that a cold front would strike Florida next weekend. January orange juice gained 2.55 cents, to 111.95 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange,
Cold weather reached Florida over the weekend, but temperatures only got down to the mid-40's in the lower half of the state, not cold enough to damage the orange crop. Fruit damage occurs when temperatures dip below 28 degrees for at least four hours, while sustained temperatures in the low 20's and upper teens can kill the trees.

HEADLINE: An Inflation Index Is Said to Overstate the Case

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Researchers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics believe that its Consumer Price Index overstates annual inflation by up to six-tenths of a percentage point, a finding with implications for policy makers and the public.
The index showing December results is scheduled to be issued on Thursday. For the latest 12 months, the rise in the index was reported at 2.7 percent, but the researchers say it actually rose by only 2.1 percent, meaning that inflation, for a variety of reasons, is being overstated by about one-fourth. The same phenomenon is showing up, they say, in many other developed countries. 
 The discrepancy comes about not only because of the complexities of calculating inflation, but also because of the way people respond to rising prices, by shopping at discount stores or eating chicken instead of steak.
 
Big Political Issue
 It suggests that people whose incomes are tied to the index, like Social Security recipients, may have done better maintaining their standard of living, one of the major political issues of the 1990's. "People may not be doing as badly as they thought, said Paul A. Armknecht, assistant commissioner for consumer prices and price indexes.
But while the discrepancy between reported inflation and what might be called actual inflation seems to be larger than previously suspected, researchers here and elsewhere have realized for a decade or more that official gauges are prone to overstatement.
The Federal Reserve and other central banks, for example, are said to take this fact into account in formulating monetary policy. Even as they do so, however, they may be conveying a misleading impression of how much inflation they regard as tolerable.
And though analysts have identified the factors causing overstatement, a host of technical and conceptual obstacles face bureau statisticians as they approach the next overhaul of the Consumer Price Index, which typically occurs every 10 years and was last conducted in 1987. But the work is sufficiently advanced that the bureau included five technical articles on the subject in the December issue of the Monthly Labor Review, to be distributed shortly.
"We'd reached the point where we had something we wanted to share," said Deborah P. Klein, an associate commissioner.
The bureau plans experimental alternative versions of the index for 1995. The issue is separate from the Government's planned introduction next month of an updated version of basic labor-market statistics that currently appear to understate the unemployment rate by about four-tenths of a point.
Methodologically, the overstatement of inflation, to which Social Security and other Government and private-sector payments are linked, involves two central issues.
The most obvious is the fact, periodically flaring into public debate, that the Consumer Price Index is a statistical artifact in that it is designed to measure a "basket" of goods and services that changes only infrequently and thus does not capture changes in what people actually buy.
If the price of steak, for example, should rise sharply and consumers decide to buy chicken instead, the index, everything else being equal, would rise but the consumer's cost of living would not.
"We work on the assumption that no substitution is made," Mr. Armknecht said.
Although the Government has surveyed consumer spending patterns annually since 1979, the index is currently based on what people bought in the 1982-84 period. Since then, Americans have reduced the share of their budgets spent on alcoholic beverages, for example, while raising the proportion going for medical care and tuition.
Price is often the reason for such shifts, but other common reasons are changed tastes or cultural attitudes, the lack of availability of a product, technological improvements or demographic changes in the population.
Mr. Armknecht said the substitution effect accounted for about two-tenths of a point, or one-third of the overstatement.
Most of the rest is attributed to a highly technical estimating process -- even the appendix to the bureau's equation-laden explanation contains footnotes -- currently used for the Consumer Price Index. Its formula, involving an arithmetic mean and named for a 19th-century French statistician named Etienne Laspeyres, tends to overstate price changes by giving more importance to increases than to declines. The effect is strongest when combined with consumer substitution of less expensive goods for more expensive ones.
If a quantity of lettuce, for instance, rose to $5 from $4, this would be a 25 percent increase. If the price then retreated to $4, the decline would be 20 percent. Employing a geometric mean, however, would treat these changes symmetrically and avoid the upward bias, which is most pronounced when applied to items with gyrating prices, like fresh fruits and vegetables, which are often substituted.
Using the geometric formulation, the price relatives -- 1.25 for the rise and 0.8 for the fall -- are multiplied together and then averaged by taking their square root.
Another potential source of overstatement is in adjusting for changes in the quality of a product or service, such as when auto makers make previously optional equipment standard. To the extent that improvements, because of imperfect techniques for adjusting the Consumer Price Index, are counted as price changes, the index will overstate true inflation.
While this process can also cause an understatement of inflation, the bureau notes that the chief contention is that it is improvements that are "predominantly missed" in the compilation of the index. Changes in quality also include such generally hard-to-value amenities as convenient store hours, delivery service and various options for paying.
Similarly, bureau researchers acknowledge that failure to add new products promptly to the index exaggerates reported inflation. Typically, high-technology and some other products command very high prices when first reaching the market as supplies are limited and producers are seeking to recover high investment and start-up costs.
The longer it takes for the Government to include the new product in the index, the less likely the inflation gauge is to pick up the almost inevitable, often rapid, price drop.
Even if these technical problems can be resolved, however, and the Government is shown to be able to save billions of dollars a year through lower outlays for entitlements, strong opponents seek to preserve the current Consumer Price Index mechanism.
One would be organized labor, whose leaders insist that being forced to give up steak, regardless of feelings about its replacement, reduces one's standard of living.
"If they substitute hamburger, it's not that they have a preference for hamburger," observed Rudy Oswald, director of economic research for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "You want to have a measure of the harm."

LENGTH: 1035 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Amy M. Spindler

 BODY:

Embracing What Works
The elements that seemed to be keeping fashion afloat through the last few years -- supermodels, basics, life-style marketing -- are now being cast as this era's villains. 
 But don't tell Fabrizio Ferri, who seems to be embracing the formula with a vigorous bearhug.
Industria, his photography studio in Milan, Italy, and New York, is the crossroads for the international fashion community, a community that also feels at home in the Industria label clothing collection.
In two months, everybody else will be able to shop alongside those professionals at the new Industria store, at 755 Washington Street (between Jane and West 12th streets), where Mr. Ferri is moving his studio. "We're starting work in a week, and we'll be there in two months," Mr. Ferri said. "That's what I hope." Until now the line has been available to friends and colleagues through the studio, and in a few upscale stores.
In that new store, customers will also find two new Industria collections: Lavoro, which in Italian means work, and Industria Knits. Lavoro will be a lower-priced, utilitarian clothing line, and the knit collection offers 35 sweater styles. "There is always room for a better Gap," Mr. Ferri said of the knit collection, whose hang tag carries a picture of Isabella Rossellini.
Industria will be offering denim jeans for the first time, made in New York "because for me, a jean has to be done in America," Mr. Ferri said.
Mr. Ferri has become a fashion expert by osmosis , surrounded as a photographer by the working class of the fashion industry, whose uniforms, despite their field, can be as regimented as those of postal workers.
"One of the problems of the fashion business is that it follows the creativity of designers," Mr. Ferri said. "Things get more beautiful, and more expensive, all the time. The research of the designer brings the collections further from the needs of people. But Industria starts with a different approach, to meet needs."
All three collections will be presented together during the showings of men's-wear collections this week in Milan, and in February during the women's shows.
For his expansion, Mr. Ferri has bought, with a partner whom he said he cannot yet name, a 30,000-square-foot factory in Modena, Italy. Industria's collections will all be produced there. "Our growth has been so good, we'll be able to produce the whole thing ourselves," Mr. Ferri said.
 
45 and Comfortable
 CK, Calvin Klein's second line, now has a design director all its own, Ann Ogden, who cut her teeth at Basco before starting her label a year ago. At 45, Ms. Ogden said that CK "is for people like me: for women who like to be casual and comfortable, but smart."
Ms. Ogden's appointment is the sort of life preserver many designers in this troubled economy can only dream about. She was first contacted by Barbara Warner, the corporate president of Calvin Klein's women's division. "What was great was when Barbara and Calvin looked at my line, we all decided there was no conflict of interest, so I can continue to do it," Ms. Ogden said.
She started working on CK in December, she said, but the first collection she'll design in full will be Holiday, shown in June. She said her CK would be more men's-wear-oriented and would have more color. But it will still be young. "I'm the oldest young designer in the world," Ms. Ogden said. "I'm just a baby boomer, and all of us aren't getting any younger, but at the same time, we don't want to dress like our mothers, do we?"
 
Pastrylike Clothes
 Even surrounded in Charivari last week by the seven dressmaking dummies she had outfitted in yellowed muslin, Pia Myrvold did not really want to say she was a designer. She and her partner, Randy Naylor, think of themselves as multidisciplined, dabbling in performance art, installations and video. And for a while, Ms. Myrvold, born in Stavanger, Norway, treated her fashion shows as theater, and her theater as fashion shows. Which may be why the clothes Ms. Myrvold is selling at Charivari look as if they'd been sculptured from frayed artists' canvases.
She and Mr. Naylor used textiles to create an installation last summer at the Parc de la Villette in Paris, commissioned by Bernard Tschumi, the dean of Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, who is a deconstructivist architect. The pieces look like huge sails, for bright ships in the Caribbean.
Many of Ms. Myrvold's jackets and skirts look like pale pastry, with muslin sewn in layers like mille-feuille.
Barbara Weiser, president of Charivari, said of Ms. Myrvold's work, which sells for $200 to $700 at the store: "What fascinates me is the treatment of the fabrics, all the pieces that have been sewn together. It is not about ripping fabric apart; it is about building the fabric. It is very elegant."
 
When Art and Fashion Meet
 Sylvia Heisel's simple slip dresses have been worn by Bridget Fonda, Madonna and Mariah Carey, mostly because of what they aren't: ostentatious clothes that make a statement. Yet, those same dresses are being used by artists to do just that. First, Kenneth Goldsmith, a conceptual artist, silk-screened a print for an ivory dress, which ended up in an exhibition called "American Art Today: Clothing as Metaphor." Then Matthew Barney, who was a winner at this year's Venice Biennale, wore one of her dresses for a drag performance-art videotape. Now, Ms. Heisel will be curator and host for the New Jersey Network's "State of the Arts," a weekly program examining a different arts field each week; she will film one segment, on fashion. In it Ms. Heisel will present fashion as art, using work like Todd Oldham's Mona Lisa beaded miniskirt from last fall.
Ms. Heisel's role as arbiter of art-meeting-fashion isn't accidental. She was an art history major at Barnard College, before she dropped out. Now, her salon-inspired clothes, with Italian ice colors and glamorous 50's forms, are sold at stores like Linda Dresner, Ultimo and Barneys New York.
She is taping "State of the Arts" on Jan. 20. She said she would be combining aspects of craft, couture, pop culture and the contemporary fine- arts movement.

HEADLINE: In an Era of Change, Polish Film Industry Struggles to Stay Vital

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
At a recent conference in France on the future of European film, the Polish director Krzysztof Zanussi took a pessimistic line. Freedom, he said worriedly, had proven a very mixed blessing for the Polish film industry: protective barriers had been lowered and Hollywood had conquered all. "Before, we were dominated by the Russians," he said. "Now, it's the Americans."
With an inflation rate of 35 percent and steady devaluation of the zloty, with a worldwide recession and uncertain experience in developing private enterprises, the Polish film industry might indeed seem in trouble. Its best-known directors -- Mr. Zanussi, Krzysztof Kieslowski, Agnieska Holland and Andrzej Wajda -- either lie low or work abroad. In 1993, the 10 most popular films in Poland were American. 
 Yet movies keep getting made here, more each year, and people keep paying money to see them. The Communist victory at the Polish polls this fall is unlikely to change that. New Polish films may not all be the earnest moral explorations or stirring dissident manifestoes of yesteryear. But they appeal on a visceral level to an audience grown cynical from the machinations of their politicians or prurient from their new-found freedoms.
Two especially popular Polish films of the last two years, not classy enough for the major Western film festivals or accessible enough for Western distribution, can speak for the state of Polish film today. And their producers offer varying yet complementary strategies to confront the Hollywood behemoth.
"Pigs" (the producers' equivalent of the original "Dogs," a Polish epithet for the police) is a story of corrupt, brutal, cynical former Communist secret policemen confronting the new realities of contemporary Poland. It won the Golden Duck (Poland's improbably named version of the Oscar) for best director (Wladyslaw Pasikowski) and best actor (Boguslaw Linda) in 1992.
"The Kidnapping of Agata," based on a true story, is a 1993 film about a Polish politician who accuses his daughter's boyfriend of kidnapping, after the two young lovers run off together. The film offers delightful performances, modest but overt sexiness, a trenchant look at the abuse of power and a light touch that fails to prepare one for the brutal ending. At a recent Warsaw screening, a mostly teen-age audience loved it.
"Pigs" was produced by Zebra Film Productions, founded in 1989 and still technically owned by the state, and hence technically a nonprofit holdover from the former Communist system. Two of its three chief executives, Jacek Bromski and Jacek Moczydlowski (the third is on leave teaching in New York), speak with a residue of dissident idealism of the need to foster young directors and to make serious films that resist the commercial ethos.
"Agata" is a production of Heritage Films, an enthusiastically capitalist venture of Lew Rywin, who attended a Brooklyn high school before he was deported from the United States as an illegal alien and who served as Steven Spielberg's Polish line producer for "Schindler's List."
Mr. Rywin has set up his office as a sort of homage to cigar-chomping Hollywood studio bosses of yore. Despite his decade at the Communist state television network, he talks like a cinematic Adam Smith. Yet he, too, has been involved in high-art projects, notably Mr. Kieslowski's 10-part series of hourlong films called "Decalogue," made for Polish television, and Mr. Wajda's last three films.
Perhaps because of his experience in the United States, his fluent English and, now, his Spielberg cachet, Mr. Rywin professes confidence that he can work with Hollywood.
"I cannot complain," he said. "My portfolio is full. If a train is coming your way, you can either be crushed by it or you can jump on it."
Mr. Zanussi was hardly so buoyant, and neither was Mr. Moczydlowski. Like so many former dissidents, he and his partner feel at sea with their new freedoms, lamenting the loss of the intensity and excitement of their dissident years.
"Under Communism, film was the freest way to express ideas," Mr. Moczydlowski said. "Of course there was censorship. We had to figure out a way to say what people wanted to hear without saying it specifically. It was a game of wits. Now that anything can be said in the open, there's nobody to fight against. We don't know what stories people want us to tell them."
Part of the problem is a perceived gulf between the Polish audience and the rest of the world, at least when the subject is contemporary Poland.
"You have to simplify things to be understood by foreigners," Mr. Moczydlowski said, and indeed both "Pigs" and "Agata" are full of sly references to Polish life that most outsiders would miss. "You have to compromise for the rest of Europe but not be too naive for our own market," he added.
 
$250,000 Grants
 Whether the production is public or private, nearly all movies in Poland are seeded with a grant of approximately $250,000 from the Ministry of Culture and then require additional outside investment. The trouble is, the Polish audience by itself is not enough to reward investors. Capital and audiences must be sought outside Poland, which dilutes the native film product.
"There is no way I can hope to return my investment if I address myself solely to the Polish market," Mr. Rywin said. That has led to most film producers expanding to television or to serving as local coordinators for spectacles bankrolled from abroad.
"Poland is taking advantage of the Yugoslav situation," Mr. Rywin said. "Before, most American producers would go there to do period pieces. Now, they go to Poland or Russia."
The number of films produced in Poland has actually risen steadily, according to the Ministry of Culture's State Cinematography Committee, from 22 in 1990 to 25 in 1991 to 28 in 1992 (the 1993 figure is not yet in). But Polish film attendance has plummeted, meaning that a No. 1 box-office hit, even if it is an American film, sells fewer tickets than before. From 38 million in 1990, overall annual attendance dropped to 18 million in 1991 and 11 million in 1992. The ministry estimates that 1993 will show a rebound to 15 million.
The problem is partly the recession and inflation, with ticket prices leaping from 20 cents in 1990 to $2 now. And partly, Mr. Rywin argues, it has to do with the limited number and poor condition of Polish theaters. He says he is working to interest the French U.G.C. chain in investing in new Polish theaters.
There is also more or less rampant piracy, although Mr. Rywin places less weight on that than do the Zebra executives. According to them, Poland has the highest per-capita number of videocassette players in Europe, the majority of available cassettes are illicit and their use has severely depressed film attendance. On Jan. 7, the Polish Parliament finally passed a new copyright law intended to protect intellectual property and curb the pirating of films.
 
'Room for Everybody'
 For Mr. Rywin, who shares with the Zebra team a professed lack of concern about the resurgent Polish Communists, the only way to survive is to adjust. "We must remain open to the products of the West," he said. "I'm not afraid of American products. There's room for everybody."
Mr. Moczydlowski hopes to buttress state support for Polish film makers and protection against Hollywood, and says the Polish system is already based on the French model. Consistently among the Polish box-office leaders, Zebra is still only marginally profitable. Mr. Moczydlowski said there was no point in privatizing the company since its mission, to make quality films (however brutal and bloody "Pigs" may be) and to encourage young talent, was not inherently profitable. "We would be the first to privatize if it made sense," he said.
Like so many Eastern European intellectuals, he longs for a system of values in which profitability is not paramount.
"For us, culture was a substitute for everything else," he said. "When I was a teen-ager, we could go to the cinema and see everything by Fellini or Bergman. We didn't have anything else to do. We had no money, and cinema was cheap. A director could go to a car factory and show his film and have a very interesting discussion.
"Now, we are losing this. Go to Belgium and ask a doctor who is Bergman and he won't know. It's a consumption society in the West, and now here, too. Young people just go to the cinema to have fun."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
An Eastern Visitor in London's Impolite Clutches

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

The Man From Japan
By Clive James
173 pages. Random House. $20.
Michael Crichton, the author of the sensationalistic potboiler "Rising Sun," is hardly alone in his interest in Japan. In fact, as Japan has assumed an increasingly high-profile role in the world of trade and economics, the Land of the Rising Sun has become a ferocious magnet for Western novelists. Brad Leithauser ("Equal Distance"), Jay McInerney ("Ransom") and John Burnham Schwartz ("Bicycle Days") have all portrayed young Americans coming of age in Japan, while T. Coraghessan Boyle ("East Is East") and Meg Pei ("Salaryman") have chronicled the adventures of young Japanese men abroad in the United States. In each case, Eastern and Western customs, values and sensibilities are contrasted and compared; in each case, a hero's search for identity is played out in an alien land. 
 Similar dynamics are at work in Clive James's sprightly new novel, "The Man From Japan," a comic Bildungsroman that features an aspiring Japanese poet who is set adrift amid the temptations and pitfalls of contemporary London.
As the first volume of his autobiography, "Unreliable Memoirs," so adeptly demonstrated, Mr. James -- who is well-known in England as a critic, novelist, poet and host of a popular television interview show -- has a delightful gift for the antic anecdote and the witty apercu. His prose skims lightly over the surface of life, spinning its mundane embarrassments into comedy, its banal absurdities into brightly spangled stories.
In "Unreliable Memoirs," Mr. James used those gifts to recount his own youthful confusion, growing up in the wasteland of the Australian suburbs. In "The Man From Japan," he uses them to recount the sentimental education of one Akira Suzuki, an aspiring Japanese writer who finds himself working in a London bookshop.
For all his artistic aspirations, Suzuki seems, at first glance, like the very model of the stereotypical Japanese businessman: like Jun Shimada in Ms. Pei's "Salaryman," he's polite, careful and hard-working. He saves practically every dollar he makes, and keeps his London flat meticulously tidy. He works out every day to maintain control of his body, and attends one cultural event a week to improve his mind. To him, London is a lewd, crude metropolis, a city of bad manners and worse decorum: the sort of place Englishmen tend to associate with the United States.
"In Japanese the levels of politeness were so precisely codified that one could convey an insult merely by eliding the end of a verb," writes Mr. James. "But the point was that both speaker and listener knew exactly what was going on. All speech was conversation: it was communal or it was nothing. In English you could talk to yourself in the presence of other people, as if their feelings not only did not matter but did not even exist. Suzuki found this aspect of his voluntary exile the hardest to get used to. Merely listening to people talking in the tube, he took a linguistic battering that frequently left him punch-drunk. In the street, asking someone the way to somewhere, he would receive a reply which left him no honorable alternative except to challenge his interlocutor to a duel."
As it happens, Suzuki's efforts to educate himself about the West take an unexpected leap into hyperspace when he makes the acquaintance of a punked-out girl who calls herself Jane Austen. Jane seems to suffer from assorted emotional disturbances that cause her to lurch about wildly while uttering obscenities, and she exacerbates this condition by imbibing vast quantities of alcohol and drugs. Her favorite pastime is threatening to commit suicide.
For some reason, Suzuki is instantly smitten. He is soon hanging out in front of Jane's apartment, in hopes of making a date, and it's not long before he has given her all of his money.
Jane isn't the only woman in Suzuki's life. Indeed, their romance seems to have turned this mild-mannered gentleman into a veritable sex object. Suddenly, he is being pursued by his lonely landlady and a beauteous stockbroker, who's the mistress of one of the world's richest men. Needless to say, it's only a matter of time before these assorted affairs dangerously collide, resulting in headlines proclaiming Suzuki the "Japanese Rambo."
Mr. James orchestrates these silly, implausible adventures with careless ease. Many of his jokes rely shamelessly on Suzuki's difficulties with English -- everyone he meets, from a guy named Lionel to a Mrs. Thelwell to Lilian Pflimmlin, seems to have a name filled with unpronounceable L's -- and the author's satiric comparisons of English and Japanese culture are similarly cliched. The Japanese see themselves as cogs in a large machine; the English embrace individuality and eccentricity. The Japanese like food that's spare, precise and delicately arranged; the English prefer meals heavy with grease and fat. And so on.
Fortunately for the reader, such tired observations are served up with brio and affection. In any case, they aren't really central to Suzuki's story: a story, in the end, that has less to do with the clash of cultures than with the efforts of a lonely, uptight man to embrace the confusions and risks of "a richer, wider world." All in all, a charming trifle of a book.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE;
N.C.A.A. Vote On Athlete Aid Irks Coaches

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 10

 BODY:
An impassioned effort by basketball coaches to restore a 14th scholarship to Division I men's teams, an effort that escalated into a symbolic appeal to provide greater opportunities for minority-group athletes, was decisively defeated at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention today.
"Nobody won in this," said Judith Albino, president of the University of Colorado and the incoming chair of the agenda-setting Presidents Commission, who took a conciliatory approach and hoped the issue could be discussed again next year as part of a more complete package of financial changes. But after an emotional debate ended with a vote of 191-119 against the increase of one scholarship per team, disappointed members of the National Association of Basketball Coaches and the Black Coaches Association were left to decide their response to a difficult defeat. 
 More than 61 percent of the voting representatives of colleges and universities sided with members of the Presidents Commission. The commission had firmly maintained that the addition of a scholarship would risk breaking the momentum of the reform movement, signal a highly visible reversal of its cost-cutting initiatives and invite similar appeals from coaches of other sports.
Less than a day after the association's new executive director, Cedric Dempsey, emphasized that refinement of past legislation should not be interpreted as a retreat, voters upheld their past decision. And coaches, having failed to influence the political process after weeks of public and private lobbying efforts, were left with the feeling that the politics of inclusion had been defeated by the politics of economic and ethical reform.
A person familiar with the coaches' discussion, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said coaches were discussing reactions that included the potential for an unspecified "job action" by coaches and even players.
The debate and result overshadowed the overwhelming acceptance of a proposal to review the stricter standards for freshman athletes that are scheduled to take effect in August 1995. Inspired by a disclosure that a research group advising N.C.A.A. committees had ties to a psychiatrist with controversial and possibly racist views on social engineering, 97 percent of the voters approved a resolution that could eventually lead to changes or a delay in the new requirements.

 
 
Thompson No Longer Talking

 
 Those possibilities provided little consolation to members of the two coaches organizations. Until the moment the resolution was introduced, Presidents Commission members had encouraged advocates of the scholarship addition to withdraw the proposal and work to include it on next year's agenda as part of a larger financial package.
Rudy Washington, the president of the Black Coaches Association, was not available to discuss the vote because his Drake University team played a game tonight. George Raveling, the Southern California coach, said through a spokesman that it was too soon to discuss the issue. John Thompson, the Georgetown coach, withdrew from the public verbal conflict in a surprising and potentially telling response. "I have no intention of talking about this issue anymore," Thompson said through a university spokesman.
Although the exclusion of minority-group athletes became a central issue in the discussion, the effort to restore a scholarship involved a variety of issues, including the struggle for a competitive advantage. The strongest support came from Division I-A schools, the highest level, where depth of talent can often provide the slim difference between teams. Of the 116 voting division I-A members, 46 percent approved the resolution.
 
School Differs With Own Coach
 The complexity of the issues could be found in contradictions such as the one at Holy Cross College, which voted against the proposal while its coach, George Blaney, was among the resolution's most visible supporters here. Blaney, the president of the N.A.B.C., characterized the outcome of the vote as having more to do with face-saving than anything else.
But the plight of economically disadvantaged high school prospects was at the center of the discussion that led to the vote. "Those 330 scholarships are so critically important to our community, in the sense that the message is going to go out to thousands of young black men who are in the underbelly of our society," said Dennis Coleman, general counsel of the Black Coaches Association. " . . . There is going to be some Reggie Lewis somewhere. Or some young kid in south Boston somewhere that his only access is going to be through this scholarship."
Charles E. Young, chancellor at U.C.L.A. and a Presidents Commission member, had supported a resolution last year that restored women's basketball scholarships to 15. But he urged delegates to vote against an increase for the men today.
"It is important that we maintain the kind of direction, the kind of pressure, that has been applied over the last several years to bring about the kinds of changes that have been made," Young said. "I think it is very clear that if this proposal is passed, we will see a move backward in a direction in which we do not want to go."
Brother Thomas J. Scanlan, the Manhattan College president and another member of the Presidents Commission, contested the notion that a vote against the resolution was a vote against opportunities. "I take exception to some of the connections being made between a 14th scholarship in men's basketball and the larger issue of higher education and access for minority and generally disadvantaged students," he said. "I think that that is not a good connection to make.
"All of our institutions," Scanlan said, "are committed to greater access to all of the young people of America. And all of our institutions are spending annually some $3 billion in institutionally funded financial aid to provide access to disadvantaged students. Most, if not all of our institutions have outreach programs for disadvantaged students. So to talk about supporting Proposition 42 as the way for youth of America to get access to higher education, I think lacks perspective. . . . People have put too much emphasis on their sport and have not looked at the overall effect and the overall commitment of higher education."

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
NBC Wakes Up the Echoes for Five More Years

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Notre Dame football will remain in NBC's ecstatic embrace through 2000.
Although NBC's five-year, $38 million deal with Notre Dame doesn't expire until the end of the 1995 season, the two sides yesterday announced their intention to remain married for five more years. In addition, NBC agreed to air four Notre Dame basketball games yearly starting with the 1994-95 season. 
 NBC will pay nominally more than $38 million for the five years of the current deal to provide for the costs of producing the basketball games.
"It's been an idyllic relationship," said Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports. "If you're happy, you want to extend."
The new agreement is less controversial than the first one, which found Notre Dame bolting the College Football Association's television deal with ABC, causing the value of the C.F.A.'s deal to be reduced from $200 million to $175 million.
That decision enraged much of the college football community, which accused Notre Dame of greed and duplicity. Those feelings were engendered in part by the reality that Notre Dame's national popularity makes it the only school capable of having a separate network deal.
NBC's Notre Dame telecasts peaked this season, with a six-game rating of 6.7, up from the 4.8 recorded in 1991 and 1992. Included in the 1993 average was a 16.0 rating for the Florida State game and a 7.7 for the Boston College game.
Ebersol and Dick Rosenthal, Notre Dame's athletic director, talked regularly about an extension and agreed on it in mid-December. Ebersol denied that the announcement was timed to coincide with the first day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention.
"Today was just my first day back in the office since Dec. 17," he said.
Ebersol and Rosenthal also denied that they rushed the extension to forestall other parties, like Fox and CBS, from bidding for Notre Dame games.
 
NBC Out of Nagano Bidding
 Ebersol said NBC would not bid for the rights to the 1998 Winter Olympic Games in Nagano, Japan, to be negotiated next Wednesday in Manhattan. NBC won the rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics for $456 million last July.
"I get a sense the economics will be very big with Fox entering the fray," Ebersol said of the Nagano bidding. "It's too much to step off into that netherland."
Dick Pound, the chief negotiator for the International Olympic Committee, said: "Not many people were persuaded that NBC had a consuming interest in this. I don't think the players are affected by this."
 
Will They Leave Kerrigan Alone?
 In the aftermath of the attack on Nancy Kerrigan last Thursday, which knocked her out of last weekend's United States Figure Skating Championships, one hopes the news media will leave the shy woman with the fragile psyche alone. Already uncomfortable in the spotlight, she otherwise could well become the focus of a torrent of publicity in the remaining month before the Olympics just when she needs to spend time in rehabilitation with an eye toward being at full strength.
"She's a very withdrawn person," said Jimmy Roberts, who interviewed her during the women's program Saturday night on ABC. "She hasn't quite figured out how to handle fame."
His interview with Kerrigan was shot from a camera on the ice, though he and Kerrigan were in a luxury suite in Joe Louis Arena, high above the ice. "I kept trying to turn her to the camera" to get a better angle, Roberts said. "I gently touched her arm, but it was rigid."
ABC will interview her this week for a figure-skating program Saturday. "It's a very sensitive situation," said Joel Feld, who co-produced the ABC telecasts. "I don't want to be intrusive. But she's a major star and her status will dominate the sports news for the next few weeks. We will be responsible. We're not going to do a kamikaze and try to get shots of her leaving her doctor's office."
Here's hoping the usual tabloid-TV suspects -- "Inside Edition," "Hard Copy," and others -- will show some decency and let Kerrigan recover in peace.
ABC's telecast covered the Kerrigan story well. Doug Wilson grabbed the viewer with his directing decisions and Dick Button was his usual candid self, never gushing over the ordinary and keeping the excellent in perspective.
Julie Moran, doubling as the play-by-play announcer and the new host of "Wide World of Sports," seemed uncomfortable and had a tendency to speak when quiet was needed or when Button and Peggy Fleming's analysis would have sufficed. And when she read off a Teleprompter, you clearly knew it.
Saturday's program generated a 17.0 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating, the highest such rating for a non-Olympic figure-skating event.
During the telecast, Button returned regularly to the theme of maturity. "Two of the skaters were 16 and one was 13," he said in a telephone interview. "That's not a negative. I won my first national senior title at 16. It's difficult to be a great athlete, be technically and dramatically mature, and have a personal style when you're 18. Boitano was 24 before he knew what it was all about. I didn't know what it was all about until I'd won two Olympics, seven U.S. titles and seven world titles."
At age 24, Button said, "Nancy Kerrigan is just learning what it's all about."

HEADLINE: A Smaller, Better World

 BODY:
Ask many Americans about their ancestors and you'll be told that their great-grandfather was one of seven and their great-grandmother the fifth of nine. They themselves, however, will most likely be parents of two or three at most. Why? Because, like the residents of other industrialized countries, they know that smaller families mean bigger futures -- and are able to act on that knowledge.
Fortunately for them, and for an increasingly impoverished planet, much of the third world has arrived at the same conclusion. As the demand for contraceptives rises, so the birth rate in countries like Thailand, Morocco and Bangladesh is dropping. 
 Government commitment to population control is one reason; foreign aid in the form of family planning programs is another; and the gradual realization of Marshall McLuhan's "global village" a third. The last is almost certainly what accounts for a much sharper drop in fertility rates in developing countries than the decline in Europe several generations back, when a newly educated populace saw that too many children added up to too many economic liabilities.
Conventional wisdom says that lower birth rates come only after living standards have risen. In this case, as Bangladesh illustrates, that thinking is now passe.
Bangladesh is among the least likely countries to experience a spontaneous drop in fertility rates. Living standards and the literacy rate are low, and so is the status of females. But fertility rates in Bangladesh have declined by 21 percent between 1970 and 1991, and contraceptive use among married women of reproductive age has risen from 3 percent to 40 percent.
Bangladesh has one of the world's largest and most successful marketing programs for contraceptives. Working closely with the Government, the U.S. provided most of the contraceptive supply and, through the Agency for International Development, the expertise to produce a delivery system that is virtually door-to-door.
What has happened in Bangladesh, and could happen in all developing countries, is of advantage not only to the world's poorest people but to everyone living on a planet that may have to support at least double our current number by 2150. By that measure, what America and other industrialized countries give to family-planning programs shouldn't really be called "foreign aid." It is world aid.

HEADLINE: Peace Corps Aid in Sub-Saharan Africa

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Africa, Out in the Cold" (editorial, Jan. 2) overlooks the contributions the Peace Corps has made to development in African countries below the Sahara. You thus overlook the contributions of 32 years and 54,000 American Peace Corps volunteers who have served in this region. 
 While you describe an increasingly difficult political and economic climate, Peace Corps has not let this "become a pretext for doing little or nothing." Over the last 10 years, the number of volunteers in these countries has increased from 2,231 to 2,418, while the number of countries served has been gone from 26 to 32. The demand for Peace Corps volunteers has continuously exceeded the supply allowed by its budget.
Certainly, the composition of requests has shifted in response to the changes in international development over the decades. The first 51 Peace Corps volunteers, a group of secondary-school teachers, arrived in Ghana in August 1961.
By the early 1970's, Ghanaian English teachers had moved into the classrooms, and Peace Corps volunteers began assignments in teacher training.
Today's sub-Saharan Africa programs of the Peace Corps include reforestation in Mali, urban sanitation in the Ivory Coast and AIDS education and prevention in Malawi.
The Peace Corps has not retreated from its commitment to empowering ordinary Africans. Participatory development efforts engineered by grass-roots organizations hold the promise of political, economic and human rights for sub-Saharan Africa.
But, for every remarkable gain, we may expect an unconscionable defeat. A "clamoring" at the local level in Gabon will often be drowned out by the wails of a Somalia.
Meanwhile, in the United States, 54,000 former volunteers are ambassadors for Africa -- many of them in positions to influence foreign policy and investment -- and bring Africa in from the cold.
 
CAROL BELLAMY
Director, Peace Corps
Washington, Jan. 4, 1994

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall After Blasts In Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10

 BODY:
In its first trading session since several powerful bombs shook Mexico City and signaled a possible expansion of the violence in the southern part of the country, the Mexican stock exchange recorded its biggest one-day loss in six years today, dropping 166 points, or 6.32 percent.
The exchange, the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores, ended the day at 2,459.11. 
 The loss came on a day of heavy trading, with 135 million shares changing hands. There were 100 losers and only 5 gainers, with 12 issues ending without change.
The losses raised concerns, first heard last week, that the violence in the southern state of Chiapas would damage Mexico's carefully cultivated image of an open economy entering the industrialized world. Armed rebels have declared war on the Government and say they are fighting for the rights of poor Maya Indians.
 
Social Spending Increases
 The Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has signaled that its long-term reponse to the uprising will be to increase social spending in Chiapas. That also has some analysts worrying.
In their latest report on Mexico, analysts at Citicorp said that increased Government spending would make it probable that Mexico would have a budget deficit this year, the first in several years. They also project that the newly autonomous central bank of Mexico may exceed its goal of holding inflation to 5 percent in 1994, allowing the rate to rise as high as 7 percent while loosening monetary policy in an attempt to stimulate the economy.
 
A Jittery Market

The Bolsa has been jittery since armed rebels attacked several cities in the state of Chiapas in the early hours of Jan. 1, the day the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect. But losses early last week were somewhat balanced by gains later in the week.
Then Friday afternoon, the exchange itself appeared to have been caught up in the wave of violence. Workers were evacuated and riot police with bomb-sniffing dogs entered. Workers said they were told over a public address system that a bomb had been found inside. Exchange officials have denied that, saying it was just a scheduled fire drill.
Over the weekend, a bomb scare at Mexico City's international airport forced tightened security measures and four bombs exploded in and around Mexico City. A powerful car bomb exploded in a shopping center garage in the southern part of the city and an explosion went off at the base of a suburban electric tower.
Jonathan Beatson-Hird, director of Latin American equities at Baring Securities in New York, said today's heavy loss in the Bolsa was not surprising "given concern at the speed of terrorist actions" around the capital.
 
Called a Positive Sign
 But he said that the Government's willingness to negotiate with the rebels -- Mr. Salinas extended an invitation last week -- was a positive sign, in spite of fierce counterfighting by the Mexican Army in Chiapas.
Lawrence D. Krohn, chief economic for Latin America at Lehman Brothers, said the violence, while serious, had not changed the fundamentals of the Mexican market.
The violence in Chiapas is seen as a blow to Mexico's chances to have the country's bonds upgraded to investment grade this year. Guillermo Estebanez, a Mexico analyst for Moody's Investors Service, said his firm would keep Mexico at a Ba-2 rating.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday, about a steep drop in prices at the Mexican stock exchange, referred incorrectly to a record set on Monday by a larger percentage decline. That drop -- 166 points in the exchange's index, amounting to 6.32 percent -- was the biggest percentage loss in more than four years, not six.

HEADLINE: A Draft State Dept. Report Finds China's Rights Record Is Still Poor

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
A draft of a State Department report on human rights has concluded that China did not make significant progress in curbing widespread abuses last year, senior Administration officials said today. President Clinton has said such progress is necessary for China to win extension of preferential trade status next summer.
The officials said the report's findings underscore the repeated warnings by Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher that unless the Chinese move forward urgently on human rights, Beijing will lose the right to export goods to the United States under the same low tariffs enjoyed by most other countries. 
 By one analysis, the loss of this most-favored-nation status would raise the average customs duty on goods imported from China to 40 percent, from 8 percent.
Several senior Administration officials said the draft of the annual report had found that although China must be credited with improvements in some areas in 1993, there were also serious setbacks in its human rights performance, including arbitrary arrests and torture and ill-treatment of political and religious dissidents.
The report, which is undergoing final review before it is sent to Congress in three weeks, also says Beijing continues to use repression to control its people, primarily through the state security forces.
 
Struggle Over Trade Policy
 The disclosures about the report come in the face of an emerging policy struggle within the Administration over the wisdom of making the renewal of China's trade status totally dependent on its performance on human rights.
In an interview last month, the United States Ambassador to China, Stapleton Roy, said that Beijing had made "dramatic" progress in improving the lives of its citizens and that this record should be taken into account. But senior State Department officials insisted today that Mr. Roy was not reflecting official policy.
While the draft report is overwhelmingly negative, it does praise China for what one senior official described as "our intensive human rights dialogue with China" and signs of "positive developments," including the release of some prominent political prisoners and China's announcement that it is willing to consider allowing the International Committee of the Red Cross to visit political prisoners.
According to a report in November by the human rights group Asia Watch, however, the releases of several prominent political prisoners "were overshadowed by more than 200 arrests or trials that took place during the year of people who had engaged in peaceful political or religious activities."
"There was no indication that the economic reform offensive was leading to any political liberalization," Asia Watch said.
 
Critical of Bush
 During the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton criticized President George Bush for "coddling" the Chinese Government after its bloody repression of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations for democracy in 1989, and Mr. Clinton's policy has been somewhat tougher than that of the Bush Administration, which resisted all attempts by a Democratic Congress to attach conditions to the renewal of China's trade benefits.
But the economic pressures for greater trade with China, the fastest-growing economy in the world, are enormous. A number of the Administration's top economic advisers, led by Robert E. Rubin, chairman of the National Economic Council, and W. Bowman Cutter, deputy Assistant to the President for Economic Policy, have argued that punishing the Chinese hurts the United States more than it hurts China.
Reflecting those conflicting factors, President Clinton moved last fall to a policy of what Administration officials call its "engagement strategy," meant to encourage Beijing into better behavior on a wide range of issues, including human rights, the spread of weapons and drug trafficking.
 
Top-Level Meeting Expected
 Until now President Clinton, Mr. Christopher and some senior State Department officials have argued forcefully that China must be held to the letter and the spirit of an Executive Order last year that required "overall significant progress" in specific human rights areas if China's preferential trade status is to be extended. The order does not link the trade status to an improvement in China's trade and arms-export policies.
China's human rights performance is expected to be the centerpiece of an expected meeting between Mr. Christopher and Foreign Minister Qian Qichen at the end of January. The meeting has not been formally scheduled, but a senior official said it may occur in Paris, Geneva or New York.
If the meeting occurs, Mr. Christopher will stress, as he has in the past, that China must show a pattern of good behavior in the coming months and cannot rush in with a few concessions on the eve of the deadline for renewal of its trade privileges.
Despite a series of Cabinet-level meetings with Chinese officials in Beijing since September, Mr. Christopher has not visited China as Secretary of State. A number of his senior advisers have urged him to make his first visit when he travels to Australia in March.
But he has said privately that he would not do so unless there was substantial progress on meeting the human rights criteria.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen will also raise the issue of more cooperation on human rights when he arrives in Beijing on Jan. 19 for high-level trade talks with Chinese leaders.
"We want the Chinese to understand that they have not made enough progress, that the longer they wait to do certain things the harder certain attitudes will be against them in this country," said one senior State Department official.
 
Points for Prosperity
 The debate over the China policy has begun to heat up as some senior officials have suggested both publicly and in private that economic prosperity in China is an important factor in evaluating its human rights record.
"We can't continue to have an on-off switch with China because of M.F.N.," said one senior Administration official, referring to the most-favored-nation trade status.
Some senior Administration officials are concerned that the Chinese may misinterpret Mr. Bentsen's visit, which is aimed at improving the economic relationship and will deal only peripherally with human rights.
In a speech last week, Mr. Bentsen signaled the tone he will strike: that improving United States access to China's market will be at the top of his agenda, and that "one of the ways to improve human rights is to encourage market reform and trade."

HEADLINE: The Bankruptcy Business Hits Hard Times

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The legions of lawyers, accountants and investment bankers who have made good livings in the last few years working out the bad-debt cases of the 80's are about to face their worst fears: the bankruptcy business is going bust.
Last year, for the first time since 1989, fewer companies entered bankruptcy than left, helping slow the volume of billion-dollar cases to a trickle. 
 That helps explain why the country's roughly 20,000 bankruptcy specialists are clinging fast to the clients they have left -- and are turning the last mega-dollar cases like R. H. Macy & Company into all-you-can-eat buffets.
"If you take a look around, there really aren't too many other major busted 1980's deals sitting there in bankruptcy," said Robert Miller, a lawyer at Berlack, Israels & Liberman who represents Macy's bondholders. "This seems to be the last one."
The bankruptcy fees in the Macy case, while not the largest ever, are a stunning illustration of the meal-ticket mentality. Already 11 professional firms, representing Macy, the creditors and bondholders, have wrung more than $37.9 million in fees from the two-year-old case and the clock has another year or two to run.
"The debtor is a cash cow, and the court is the milking stool," said Peter A. Chapman, the editor of R. H. Macy & Company Bankruptcy News, a newsletter based in Princeton, N.J., that tracks the professional fees down to the penny.
Weil, Gotshal & Manges, Macy's chief law firm, alone has billed $13.5 million, more than a third of the total fees. Macy has its own staff of 10 lawyers, but at Weil, Gotshal, 126 people call Macy their client: 31 partners, 50 associates and 45 other employees. And at least 24 of those lawyers each billed more than $10,000 for the three-month period that ended on Oct. 31.
In one such period the firm charged $50,000 just for the time it says it spent preparing its bill, according to bankruptcy filings. Weil, Gotshal says any criticism of that figure is unfair since much of that amount reflects time it spends as the company's lawyer notifying other parties of the status of their requests for fees.
For five years now, one big company after another has sought refuge under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, clogging the courts and making those filings as routine as a Hollywood hangover. Consumers learned not to care when a beloved airline or retailer took the cure -- although competitors often complained that bankrupt rivals could lower prices ruthlessly by taking advantage of the temporary moratoriums on their debt.
As the mega-bankruptcies swelled, so did the number of people feeding off their carcasses. Nearly 20,000 Americans now make their living from bankruptcy-related work, according to Joel W. Lustig, the publisher of the National Directory of Corporate Distress Specialists. That headcount includes 12,500 lawyers, 2,000 turnaround managers, 700 accountants and 650 investment bankers, and does not begin to cover the thousands of people ranging from auctioneers to collection agents who operate on the fringes or spend only part of their time tending troubled businesses or their creditors.
 
Attracting Investors
 The securities of bankrupt companies have also cast off their stigma, attracting droves of investors. Drawn by the rich annual returns of bottom-fishing, funds representing at least $13 billion in assets are trawling for opportunities among corporate America's downtrodden. These so-called vulture investors range from household names like T. Rowe Price and Fidelity Investments to lesser-known outfits like Morgens Waterfall, a bankruptcy boutique.
But as the economy improves and companies renegotiate their debts, the bankruptcy banquet is coming to a close. Indeed, last year, 93 companies left bankruptcy while only 83 companies entered, according to Edward I. Altman, a New York University finance professor who studies distressed companies.
What's more, fewer of those filing are of spectacular size. Large companies with lots of layers of debt and equity are generally where the biggest killings are made since each faction wants its own representatives, traders have more ways to take positions and bidding wars tend to erupt.
But last year, only two barely billion-dollar companies -- the USG Corporation and Envirodyne -- filed for bankruptcy, according to the Bankruptcy Datasource in Boston. That is down sharply from the peak in 1991, when 18 behemoths sought refuge, including Maxwell Communication, Pan Am and Best Products.
With fewer filings, the price of entry for investors is climbing, meaning they might be in for a jolt. As recently as August 1992, Professor Altman could put his finger on some $200 billion in public and private debt that was either in default or in distress, an adventurer's bazaar where debts sell for an average of 52 cents on the dollar, if at all.
 
Dwindling Opportunities
 Since then, he reckons, the supply of troubled debt has shrunk to $135 billion, as Trans World Airlines and other fallen titans have reached consensuses with their former creditors and crawled out from under their former debts. The contraction has forced prices closer to 60 cents on the dollar, and is causing institutional money managers to begin pondering their next gig.
Theirs are not the only jobs on the line. "A lot of people have ridden the crest," said William Jarblum, a partner at the Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon law firm, which represents the trustee to a class of Macy's bondholders. "People will either have to rechristen themselves or they'll make a lot less money."
Mr. Jarblum, for one, expects to return to the old-fashioned corporate financings he once did, and has his eye on troubled California real estate that may yet need his assistance. Mr. Miller, a noted bondholders' lawyer, has a possible career as a jazz musician to fall back on and looks forward to a comfortable future as the very sort of corporate lawyer he once took pleasure in tormenting. When troubled companies like Buckhead America, a hotel company, swapped their old debts for new, his clients often ended up in charge and named him to the reorganized companies' boards.
Others will find it harder to retrench. "If it's the last supper, they'll be hungry for just a while, but food will be on the table again," Professor Altman insisted, looking upon the $68 billion of junk bonds issued last year, a record, as an incubator for tomorrow's disasters.
 
Submitting the Bills
 Until then, some advisers in the Macy case are gorging themselves. The Blackstone Group, Macy's financial advisers, for instance, has only four people assigned to the case. Nonetheless, during one quarter, the firm billed $6,912 under the heading of "local transportation" and another $4,889 for meals, including one skimpily documented $419 lunch. Those totals nearly equal what Weil, Gotshal's 126-person crew runs up for such expenses in most quarters.
Bankruptcy Judge Burton K. Lifland has paid some lip service to reining in fees, but has approved nearly every request. One exception concerned Peter J. Solomon, an investment banker who has been advising Macy's suppliers and union. The judge eventually allowed him to raise his fees from $400 to $500 an hour. He also raised the rate of the underling who calculates the bill for Mr. Solomon's firm from $200 to $250 an hour. The judge had disallowed the price increases the first time they were submitted.
The other exception concerned BDO Seidman, the accounting firm that represents the suppliers that Macy's stiffed. BDO wanted Macy's to pay the $20,000 it says it spent on software it bought from a vendor partly owned by the wife of one its partners. That expenditure was disallowed by the judge.
To avoid jeopardizing an assignment that has generated $9.4 million in fees, Deloitte & Touche, Macy's accounting firm, voluntarily reduced the charge to tote up its bill each quarter to $40,000 or $50,000. The 800 or so hours it generally spends on the task would ordinarily cost a client more than $100,000.
As everyone running up the tab at Macy is quick to point out, this bankruptcy is not the costliest. The all-time lallapaloozas were more complex cases like LTV ($237 million over seven years) and Federated Department Stores ($132 million over two).
"Doesn't Leonard Rosen bill $600 an hour?" Harvey Miller, a $500-an-hour lawyer at Weil, Gotshal who is Macy's chief bankruptcy lawyer asked about a well-known competitor at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.
And Macy professes to be satisfied that it has received good value for its money. "I'm comfortable the fees here are not anywhere out of line for the size and nature of this bankruptcy," said Herbert Hellman, Macy's general counsel, volunteering that Federated, which is now a Macy creditor, paid more.
Nonetheless, such feeding frenzies have a way of sweeping up just about everybody in their path -- including management. Macy's, for instance, apparently could not attract Roger N. Farah, the top merchant at Federated Department Stores, without throwing a car and driver into his $11 million five-year package.
Not to be one-upped by his new hire, Myron E. Ullman, Macy's chief executive, fought to have his employment contract improved. When pressed by a creditor for an explanation, a person who was there said that Mr. Ullman became indignant and pointed to a family photo on his wall saying, "I have five children to feed."
He got his raise.
