HEADLINE: Army Officers' Trials to Test Democracy in Peru

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Hurrying before the light of dawn exposed their work at a Peruvian Army firing range, a group of hooded gunmen lined up nine students and a professor kidnapped hours earlier from dormitories at a teachers college here. In the final minutes of that night 18 months ago, all 10 were shot in the head.
Returning two days later to study the site in daylight, the gunmen found a foot protruding from the desert sand and hastened to cover up traces of the killing, according to participants quoted in press accounts here. 
 Similarly, the killings on July 18, 1992, of the 10 people from La Cantuta University will not go away. Ten army officers and soldiers have been charged with kidnapping and killing the professor and students in the belief that they were responsible for car bombings carried out by the Shining Path guerrilla movement.
The army, however, opposes trying the accused men in open civilian court, and there is doubt that any found guilty would be punished harshly.
 
A Test Case for Democracy
 Today the killings stand as a test case of new civilian institutions that replaced the courts and Congress closed by President Alberto K. Fujimori in April 1992. The United States has warned that $100 million in economic aid will not be disbursed unless those who carried out the La Cantuta killings and other major abuses of human rights are punished.
"La Cantuta is shaping up to be the test case that will make or break aid to Peru," said Juan E. Mendez, executive director of Americas Watch, the New York-based human rights organization.
The American concern about human rights abuses in Peru is to be conveyed later this month, when Alexander F. Watson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and several United States congressmen are due to come here in the highest level American visit since President Fujimori seized expanded powers.
Most American aid was frozen after Mr. Fujimori's action, but recently Peru has campaigned to win the money back, arguing that the human rights situation is improving. Last year, for example, forced disappearances dropped to about 75, down from an average of 300 a year over the previous decade.
Despite the improvements, a satisfactory resolution of the Cantuta case is regarded in Washington as an essential precondition for aid. The army here thinks differently. Last April, Peru's Army Commander in Chief, Gen. Nicolas de Bari Hermoza, thought he could silence an investigation by the Peruvian Congress by sending tanks rumbling menacingly through streets of this capital.
But in fits and starts, investigations lurched on, fed by crusading magazine journalists, relatives of the students, opposition members of Congress, pressure from the United States, and a dissident faction within the army, Peru's most powerful political institution.
 
Officers Under Barracks Arrest
 Today, in a major civilian challenge to army privilege, two generals and six officers are under barracks arrest and are facing trials for the La Cantuta killings. Two others who have been charged have not been detained.
During the last 12 years of army warfare against the Shining Path, 3,033 guerrilla suspects were detained and secretly killed by security forces, human rights groups charge. In the same period, the army conducted two courts-martials for unjustified killings.
Although the suspects in the Cantuta case reportedly believed that they were kidnapping members of a Shining Path bomb squad, guerrilla activities by those killed has never been conclusively proved.
"The soldiers think they are the masters of the world, that they can do whatever they want with poor people," said Rayda Condor Saes, whose oldest son, Armando Armaro Condor, was one of the students killed. "When I went to the barracks they laughed in my face and said that my son had probably run off with some woman. Until his keys were found, I always thought that I would find him alive."
After months of army denials and Government stonewalling, a turning point in the case came last summer when investigators sifting through human remains at a common grave found a set of keys. The keys opened locks at Armando Amaro's school locker and at his mother's house here.
That grave, and another at the army firing range, were discovered after members of a dissident army faction called Sleeping Lion sent hand-drawn maps pinpointing two burial sites to Ricardo Uceda Perez, editor of the Lima newsweekly Si.
The Government never responded to American offers of free forensic analysis. Instead, officials shipped remains to Britain for identification through genetic mapping. Now the Government contends it does not have the money to pay for the necessary tests.
 
'Anatomy of a Cover-Up'
 "From the moment these 10 people vanished, the Government has done its best to keep the truth from public view," Americas Watch wrote in a report in September, "Anatomy of a Cover-Up, the Disappearances at La Cantuta."
According to the report, witnesses, including the third-ranking general in the Peruvian Army, have been harassed, threatened and forced into exile. Several have been arrested. General Hermoza has refused to allow any of his subordinates to testify in civilian court or before congressional investigators. The Attorney General's office dragged its feet, leaving most investigative work to journalists. Police officials have branded investigative journalists as terrorist dupes.
But with the keys, the maps, and clothing identifications by relatives, a civilian prosecutor, Victor Cubas Villanueva, decided that he had enough evidence and on Dec. 16 he formally charged 10 officers and soldiers with kidnapping and murder.
The tenacity of some Peruvians in pursuing the case is explained in part by the easing of a war psychosis that only a few months ago gripped Lima, home to one third of Peru's 22 million people.
"Under the stress of the bombs, the population demanded that terrorism be wiped out at any price," Fernando Rospigliosi wrote recently in Caretas magazine, recalling the panic atmosphere caused by a Shining Path bombing campaign in the summer of 1992. "To kidnap and murder 10 university people from a study center where it was known that there was Shining Path activity only made a handful of people nervous."
 
Fewer People Killed
 But with much of the leadership of Shining Path in jail, its ability to wreak havoc has diminished. Last year saw a drop of nearly 50 percent in the number of people killed in political violence and in the economic damages caused by the insurgency. With tensions easing, Peruvians seem increasingly to favor curbing the army's dirty war tactics.
With newsmagazines publishing photographs of the ringleaders of an army death squad suspected of carrying out the Cantuta killings, the Government has been forced to dismantle the 30-man unit, which was formed three years ago to combat Shining Path activity in Lima.
Named the Colina Group after an army war hero, the group is suspected of carrying out a string of other killings around Lima over the last two years, including the killing of 15 people attending a chicken barbecue in downtown Lima and the disappearance of a left-wing radio journalist, Pedro Yauri Bustamente. The 15 were suspected of attending a Shining Path fund-raiser but apparently were all innocent.
In a final attempt at damage control, the military is reportedly pressing Peru's Supreme Court to rule later this month that the Cantuta case should be tried in a military court instead of a civilian court.
Unlike courts-martial in the United States, most military trials in Latin America are closed to outsiders. In Peru, military court proceedings are closed to all civilian observers -- journalists, diplomats, human rights workers and relatives of the victims.
 
Concern Expressed in U.S.
 "It's a test of how autonomous civilian power really is in Peru," said Enrique Bernales Ballesteros, a former congressman who runs a political research institute here. "If La Cantuta goes to a civilian court, it will be a public trial. Military judges are not autonomous. The sentences could be decided in the army high command."
The Supreme Court decision will be watched closely in the United States, where Congress has held up American economic aid to Peru, largely because of human rights abuses.
In a letter in November to President Fujimori, leaders of the House of Representative's Human Rights Caucus raised the Cantuta case and concluded, "We remain concerned about the lack of progress in prosecuting military and police officials implicated in human rights violations."

HEADLINE: Leader to Quit Post-Riot Panel In Los Angeles

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11

 BODY:
In the latest upheaval for the riot-recovery effort here, Rebuild L. A., the group's chief operating officer said today that he would announce his resignation on Wednesday as part of a revamping of the organization.
The official, Bernard W. Kinsey, a former Xerox Corporation executive who also served as Rebuild L. A.'s co-chairman, was appointed in June 1992 to strengthen the group's management. He was also picked in response to calls for more diverse racial representation in the organization's leadership. Mr. Kinsey, who is 49, is black. The organization is seeking to create jobs and economic opportunities in riot-torn neighborhoods here. 
 But Rebuild L. A. has come under heavy criticism from community and political leaders. They say the group has not worked closely enough with the neighborhoods and has failed to attract enough corporate support to offer full-time, well-paying jobs. The furor led to the resignation in May of the group's first chairman, Peter V. Ueberroth, the former commissioner of Major League Baseball and the president in 1984 of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee. Mr. Ueberroth said at the time that he had quit because of harangues by local political leaders.
 
'A Labor of Love'
 In a telephone interview today, Mr. Kinsey said Rebuild L. A. "had been a labor of love, despite all the problems," but that he would step aside to return to his business-development consulting firm, KBK Enterprises Inc.
"I joined Rebuild L. A. because I really believed in the vision that private industry could do a lot more to make things better in the inner city," Mr. Kinsey said. "If there is one thing we learned at Rebuild L. A., it's that without equity dollars to do real estate deals, economic development projects do not work."
Mr. Kinsey had been second to Mr. Ueberroth as Rebuild L. A.'s chief spokesman and handled much of the organization's day-to-day operations. Mayor Tom Bradley's appointment of Mr. Ueberroth was quickly criticized by minority groups and local political leaders, who viewed Mr. Ueberroth, a white Republican from Orange County, as an unlikely deliverer of the inner city. The complaints led to the appointment of Mr. Kinsey and later of three other co-chairmen, a white man, a Hispanic man and an Asian woman.
 
New Leadership Structure
 Under a reorganization announced in November, Rebuild L. A., a public-private consortium, will no longer be headed by four co-chairmen. Instead, at the request of the new Mayor, Richard J. Riordan, who asked whether the organization was unwieldy, the group will be managed by a single unpaid volunteer who has yet to be named.
Asked if Rebuild L. A. had been successful so far, Mr. Kinsey said the organization had been the most effective post-riot effort in the nation's history. He cited several accomplishments: $585 million in commitments from corporations; promises to build 32 new supermarkets, 24 automobile-parts stores and 8 drugstores in inner-city Los Angeles; the creation of 12,000 jobs; the establishment of a $20 million loan fund for minority businesses, and the rebuilding of 61 percent of the structures destroyed in the riots of 1992.
Much of the $585 million pledged by corporations, however, is in the form of donated equipment and buildings, job-training programs and increases in contracts reserved for minority suppliers.
Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas, who sits on the Rebuild L. A. board and who has also criticized the organization, said Mr. Kinsey's leadership had been a failure.
"In all candor, it's very difficult to give Mr. Kinsey high marks," Mr. Ridley-Thomas said. "I view his being there as more of a liability than an asset."
 
'He's Been a Great Blessing'
 But not everyone agreed with Mr. Ridley-Thomas. Several community leaders and educators praised Mr. Kinsey for introducing them to business people who they said had been of great help. Dr. Anyim Palmer, founder of the Marcus Garvey School, a well-regarded private school in the South-Central area, said that Mr. Kinsey had helped the school obtain a new van to transport its students and a discount on concrete to construct a new building. "He's been a great blessing to the school," Dr. Palmer said. "The tragedy is that he will no longer be with Rebuild L. A."
Anthony Downs, a senior fellow who specializes in urban development issues at the Brookings Institution, a research organization in Washington, said that inner-city revitalization efforts like Rebuild L. A. were rarely successful because corporations had few incentives to place jobs and plants in the inner city.
Mr. Downs said inner-city areas suffered from four major problems that made them undesirable for business: crime and violence, the large number of children being reared in poverty, poor-quality schools and an inability to integrate residents into the mainstream work force.
"You can't expect a few businessmen and a few residents to cope with those monumental problems on their own," Mr. Downs said. "The job of an organization like Rebuild L. A. is probably impossible without some greater change in society."

HEADLINE: THE NATO SUMMIT;
Bosnia's Legacy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Jan. 11

 BODY:
In the end, the summit meeting President Clinton called to assure the future of NATO could not escape the alliance's past failures, and those of the United States as its leading power, in Bosnia.
The dominant topic in the last 24 hours was not the President's "partnership for peace" to build a new relationship between NATO and formerly Communist countries to its east, but growing frustration throughout the alliance over NATO's inability to deter or stop Serbian aggression in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 The re-emergence of long-suppressed ethnic hatreds and nationalistic pride was precisely the theme Mr. Clinton used in forcefully reasserting the American interest in the stability and security of Europe. European leaders, demoralized by their own failure to deal with the war in Bosnia and by the worst economic recession in decades, welcomed Mr. Clinton's support.
 
Regaining Sense of Purpose
 But whether his overture to the east can prevent turmoil between Russia and Eastern Europe may well depend on whether the alliance can recover the sense of purpose it lost when, with the cold war ended, it failed to prevent war in Croatia and Bosnia.
Before flying to Prague this afternoon, Mr. Clinton said his aim was ultimately "a security based not on Europe's divisions, but on the potential of its integration." But he also heard European leaders tell him repeatedly that this enterprise would depend on American support -- and, in security issues, on American leadership.
The Clinton Administration tried last spring to get the European allies to agree to let the United States carry out air strikes against the Serbian forces responsible for most of the violence in Bosnia and to let the besieged Muslim-led Bosnian Government have access to arms. But Secretary of State Warren Christopher did not carry the day with the Europeans. Some of them said that he might have persuaded them to go along if he had been less tentative.
 
Threat of Air Strikes
 Last August, with Sarajevo still under siege, the allies did agree to threaten the Bosnian Serbs with air strikes if they did not stop their "strangulation" of the city. Since then the garroting has continued, as if in open contempt of NATO's threats, and France and Britain have grown weary of seeing their soldiers killed and wounded in the United Nations forces in Bosnia.
On Monday, Mr. Clinton found himself in the position of arguing with the French and the British -- the European countries that have the most soldiers in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia -- that NATO should not make yet another bombing threat unless it was actually prepared to carry it out this time.
The allies did repeat the threat regarding Sarajevo today, and also specifically mentioned two of the five other towns designated "safe areas" by the Security Council last August: Srebrenica, where Serbian forces have prevented the relief of a Canadian peacekeeping contingent, and Tuzla, where the Serbs have been blocking the reopening of the airport for civilian relief supplies.
 
A Request for Plans
 But the latest threat could also turn out to be an empty one. All the allies did was ask the United Nations military commanders in Bosnia to draw up urgent plans, implying that air support would be there if needed. Under the procedures it established last summer, NATO will not drop a single bomb unless the United Nations commanders on the scene ask it to, and then only if Secretary-General Boutros-Boutros Ghali concurs.
"What happens now depends upon the behavior of the combatants, principally the Bosnian Serbs, and what the military commanders come back and recommend," Mr. Clinton said.
But if the request for air strikes does come from the United Nations, what happens then will depend more importantly on whether NATO's 16 members are really prepared to follow through.
 
Fear of Russian Nationalism
 The possibility of aggression by nationalist forces in Russia that might be tempted to reassert Russian imperial sway over Eastern Europe is the reason why NATO made its overture to the east, and why the new democracies in that region are accepting it.
But for many ordinary Europeans, what NATO does in Bosnia will do more to determine its relevance in the future than a partnership plan the details of which have to be worked out with each participating country, case by case, over the next few years.
German officials here said that the violence in Bosnia was increasing, that it was getting harder to blame most of it on the Bosnian Serbs. United Nations officials said that a particularly vicious Serbian barrage last week was a retaliation for a Bosnian Government attack.
Given the danger and ambiguities, the German officials said that the NATO countries providing troops for the peacekeeping forces were moving close to the point where they would either have to use air power to back them up and make them effective, or else give up on peacekeeping and pull them out.
"I think on today's facts there are clearly some differences among the allies," Mr. Clinton said today, speaking of Bosnia. "We'll see if our resolve is there. My resolve is there, I can tell you."
The NATO secretary-general, Manfred Worner, has said that the alliance could not be blamed for the failure in Bosnia because it had not yet been called upon to use force to stop the war.
"The instrument is there," Mr. Worner said. "The main thing still is the political will and the determination of our member nations to use it."

HEADLINE: Survival at Ground Zero: For the Hard-Core Homeless, Life at 15 Degrees

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
The vast sheet of ice under the Brooklyn Bridge was smooth and still Monday night on the streets of lower Manhattan. A rat had been trapped and frozen in the amber of the glacier, and the only sign of life was the distant rumble of traffic far above.
Suddenly, men began to materialize from the shadows, walking and sliding across the ice toward a van that had just pulled up. They came from the dark chambers and crannies built into the bridge's great foundation, and they came from the benches and hollows along the street the city has named the Avenue of the Finest. They lined up in an orderly file, and as the back door of the van was flung open, they breathed deep the scent of the hot chili that would be their evening's warmest moment. 
 "I'm not homeless," said Mike, waiting in line. "That's my home over there." He was a skinny man in his 40's, encased in layers of cloth and a few of paper, and he pointed toward an open door that led to one of the pitch-black storerooms under the bridge. "This is takeout. I order it every night."
He laughed as he slid away, carrying his 12-ounce plastic cup of chili, his orange, his half-pint of milk, his fresh roll and his spoon.
The meal was a gift from the Coalition for the Homeless, which operates the van that was making its first stop on a dim and relentless nightly circuit of Manhattan encampments where hundreds of people make their winter home. The coalition's deliveries of hot food are a vital element in the men's arsenal of tools to cope with the cold, but each man in line seemed to have a different strategy for getting through a 15-degree night.
Some, using only a few blankets, insisted their bodies were impervious to any temperature above zero. Others practiced the layering system, with the only limitation being the difficulty in finding enough clothing. Some made use of new high-tech sleeping bags donated by a Wall Street firm and distributed by the coalition. Others pirated their heat from nearby electrical wires of lampposts, or took it from steam pipes or exhaust fans.
 
A Secret Spot
 "I've got five blankets and two boxes, but mostly I've got the Municipal Building, because I know a warm spot there no one else knows," said S.J., a cook who accepted his chili at the van's second stop, in the parking lot in front of Family Court on Lafayette Street. "The first few weeks I thought I couldn't take it. I thought it was over. But then you know you can deal with it."
The van dispenses only food and, occasionally, clothes, not advice or criticism or public policy. After several frigid weeks, most of those who are still on the street have considered and rejected the idea of public shelter, and there is no point in preaching to the hard core. Some, like the man under the South Street viaduct, by the East River, whose box reads "Don't leave food," practice the extremes of self-sufficiency. Most, however, appreciate a hot handout, as demonstrated by the lines that form at each of the van's eight scheduled stops and occasional unplanned deliveries to the hungry who flag it down.
At City Hall Park, 25 men waited for dinner, a modest number compared with the 100 or so who gather there during the summer, but still the largest crowd of the night. Most men were veterans of the stop, but one looked out of place in a wispy coat and a particularly frightened expression.
 
His First Night
 "It's my first night out here," said Carl Baptiste, an unemployed man who said he left his Brooklyn apartment earlier in the day after a disagreement with his girlfriend. "I was over at the World Trade Center and the others told me to come over here for food. But I don't really know where to go."
Mr. Baptiste was planning to sleep in a subway station, but had been warned by others in line that some stations were dangerous while others were subject to police sweeps. He seemed to know nothing of the city's shelter system, which can provide for 6,300 people a night.
So when he got to the front of the line, he took his chili and then asked Michael Polenberg, director of the coalition's food program, where he should go. Mr. Polenberg gave him a quarter and a slip of paper with the coalition's telephone number, and urged Mr. Baptiste to call for a list of public and private shelters. Mr. Baptiste promised that he would.
"The others, they know how to live in the cold," Mr. Baptiste said. "I don't know how to do it. But I'm glad they are here because then I'm not alone. If I can't find a place, these guys will show me what to do."
 
Spare Gloves or HatsSensing the Mood
 One of the other men in line told him to ask Ron Taylor, the jovial driver of the van, if there might be any spare gloves or hats. Mr. Taylor rummaged around inside the van and found a pair of canvas work gloves and a knit watch cap. Another man came up to Mr. Taylor pointing to his thin pair of pants, which were about to fall off.
"What are you, about a size 44?" asked Mr. Taylor. "Check this out." He produced a pair of cotton engineer's overalls, donated in bulk by the Transit Museum in Brooklyn. The man thanked him and headed off for a darkened doorway, where he put them on over the pants he was wearing.
Living from place to place often means developing a carefully calibrated sense of the mood of public authority, often hour by hour. The people who live in and around the Staten Island Ferry terminal, the van's next stop, can sometimes sense it moments before the police come through to roust them, a regular occurrence since 1991, when homeless residents were blamed for the fire that damaged part of the terminal.
A man named Doug, who had been living there for two months, said officials were sometimes more generous on extremely cold nights, but not always. Several times a week, he said, he and his friends are ordered to ride the ferryboat all night, or are simply forced out onto Whitehall Street. Sonny, another regular terminal resident, said he actually prefers the disorder of a city shelter, but lately has not been able to get a bed because of overcrowding. So he takes his chances under the bright lights of the terminal.
"I've got my sleeping bag here, but they won't let you use it in the terminal, so I'd rather have a bed," said Sonny, a 30-year-old Guyanese. "But if they kick me out of the terminal I can use it outside, except that I'm worried about my feet. I've got five coats but my shoes are no good and I may have to go to Bellevue if I can't find any better shoes."
There were no extra shoes aboard the van. Sonny said he had a bad feeling about the terminal this night, so he stuffed the orange in his pocket and took his chili to his hiding place, behind the building.
 
The Coldest Place
 Everyone in the van agreed that the coldest men in New York that night were the ones who live under the South Street Viaduct, which carries the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive over the Fulton Fish Market and provides little protection from the blistering winds off the river. They are also the surliest of the van's clients, occasionally cursing the volunteers or simply refusing to emerge from the chaos of boxes, planks and tattered canvas that is their housing project.
At several of the South Street encampments, Mr. Taylor got out of the van and yell, "Coalition!" but no one stirred to take the offered food. One man, acting as a representative for the others, finally stepped out of the darkness, bearing a milk crate.
Mr. Taylor said there was no question that the man would distribute the food fairly. Such matters of protocol are simply understood on the street.
"What's your count tonight?" Mr. Taylor asked.
"Eight," replied the man.
The volunteers filled the crate with eight of each item, and the man silently withdrew with the crate into his rooms. A long trail of chili steam followed him and seemed to hover in the air, and then disappeared over the river.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A cup of hot chili is often the warmest element of a frigid night for the homeless. Ron Taylor, with glasses, helped hand out food on Broadway near City Hall from a van operated by the Coalition for the Homeless. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Westinghouse to Lay Off 3,400, Cut Dividend

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
In his first major action as chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Michael H. Jordan cut the dividend in half yesterday and announced a pretax charge of $750 million to cover the costs of laying off 3,400 employees, selling operations and settling legal disputes.
Mr. Jordan, who was named chief executive in July, has disclosed little since then except to announce in September that earnings would fall considerably short of the investment community's expectations. Paul Lego, the previous chairman, was forced out a year ago as a result of disastrous losses in the now-disbanded financial services subsidiary. 
 Following yesterday's announcement, the stock fell 12.5 cents to close at $14 on the New York Stock Exchange. On Monday, the price of Westinghouse shares had risen 50 cents each, apparently on rumors the company would take a large charge and dismiss more people.
In presenting his plan yesterday at a meeting of securities analysts in Manhattan, Mr. Jordan said his intent was to take all the necessary steps and charges at once. "Our plan," he said, "was to seek out all potential exposures and put them behind us."
Analysts noted that with the grab bag of financial and accounting actions past it, the company could be prepared to increase earnings without any lurking surprises.
While the cost-cutting measures were not so deep as some big investors might have liked, some analysts praised Mr. Jordan for rolling all the measures into a single package.
"I was glad to see him take a broad, Draconian sweep," said Kemp Fuller Jr., an analyst with RAS Securities. "I think the Lego plan of having the company cleaned up by the end of 1995 will take place, but in a different way."
NatWest Securities also praised the sweep of Mr. Jordan's announcement. "He's cleaning all the cobwebs out," Nicholas P. Heymann, a NatWest analyst, said.
In addition to cutting the annual dividend to 20 cents a share from 40 cents, and taking the special charge, the company said it would seek to improve its debt-to-equity ratio during the first half of this year by issuing $500 million in preferred stock that must eventually be converted to common stock. Moreover, at the annual meeting on April 27, the company will seek authorization for additional common shares. Both issues would dilute the value of the current stock.
Westinghouse also announced these measures yesterday:
*An after-tax charge of $255 million to adjust for more conservative assumptions on pension plan assets as a result of lower interest rates.
*A contribution of $200 million in common stock to the pension fund.
*An after-tax charge of $56 million for benefits paid to laid-off employees.
*An after-tax charge of $95 million for the sale of the Westinghouse Communities real estate development subsidiary, which is to be completed this year instead of in 1995, as previously announced.
*A decision not to sell its Knoll furniture-making subsidiary, which had been marked for sale by Mr. Lego.
"We are taking these actions to improve our operating performance, accelerate the divestiture of noncore businesses, rebuild our equity base, and improve financial flexibility," Mr. Jordan said in a statement.
 
Layoffs to Cost $350 Million
 The $750 million pretax charge has three components. Revamping related to the layoff of 3,400 of the company's 105,000 employees over the next two years will cost $350 million.
An additional $215 million will account for the sale or closing of what the company describes as "certain noncore businesses," which it declined to identify.
Environmental cleanup and the settlement of other unidentified legal disputes will be covered by the remaining $185 million. The company manufactured electrical capacitors from 1958 until 1989 near Bloomington, Ind., and six landfills in the area are contaminated with chemicals known as PCB's that are used in capacitors.
Mr. Jordan said the company's debt, most of it related to bad investments in financial services, was reduced by $3.2 billion during 1993 to a total of $5.2 billion. He said debt would be pared by an additional $1.1 billion when the previously announced sale of Westinghouse's electrical distribution and control business to the Eaton Corporation was completed. That is expected within months.

HEADLINE: Union Local Agrees to Court Monitor to Bar Any Association With Mobsters

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 11

 BODY:
Roughly 35 years after Federal investigators first accused Local 813 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters of being controlled by organized crime, the union has agreed to have a court-appointed officer monitor its employees and members to insure that they do not associate with mobsters.
The move is part of a larger drive to end organized crime's influence over the private garbage-hauling industry in the New York metropolitan area, particularly Long Island, an effort that has gained momentum over the last decade with the criminal indictments, convictions and civil actions against a host of key players. 
 Local 813, which represents roughly 2,400 sanitation workers, has long been seen as a linchpin of the mob's domination of the industry, with authorities regularly describing it as a tool of the Gambino family. Today, as Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn announced the consent judgment they had negotiated with Local 813, they said it could end the allegations that the mob used the union to pressure private carters and keep them from bucking the garbage cartel established by organized crime on Long Island.
Joseph D. McCann, a Federal prosecutor, said: "Organized crime has had a very valuable tool in Local 813 for decades, and it is not something they're going to easily relinquish. The existence of an investigative officer will insure that they won't continue to exert control."
Mr. McCann and Jody Kasten, both assistant United States Attorneys in the Eastern District of New York, negotiated the agreement with the Teamsters.
 
16 Inquiries in 4 Decades
 The plans for the officer, who has yet to be appointed, is the latest development in the Government's long effort to rid the private hauling industry of corruption. Over the last four decades, there have been 16 investigations into the problem, and on several occasions, people who were cooperating with law-enforcment officials and were challenging the system were killed.
Authorities said the mob's control of the industry on Long Island is shared by two organized crime families that split the racketeering profits. The Lucchese family, they said, controlled the association that represented the carters and divided up the commercial and residential territories that local government did not serve. The Gambino family controlled the union through its secretary-treasurer, Bernard Adelstein, and law enforcement officials said that in some instances when a hauler tried to underbid or take over another's, they found themselves threatened with a strike.
Because of the mob's domination of the industry, law-enforcement officials explained, haulers were able to charge higher rates. A 1987 study by Peter Reuter of the Rand Corporation, prepared for the Justice Department and the State Organized Crime Task Force, estimated that the collusion had raised prices by about 50 percent for commercial customers and about 15 percent for residential customers on Long Island.
The union, which has members in New York City and Westchester County as well as Long Island, came under public scrutiny as early as 1958 during hearings by Senator John L. McClellan's Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Managenment Field. As a result of the committee's findings, Mr. Adelstein was indicted and convicted of extortion, though the conviction was later overturned.
 
Pact Hailed by Both Sides
 In the last few years, Local 813 has come under increased pressure from the Government and has adopted a series of reforms. After a civil racketeering suit against the teamsters in 1988 and the election of a new president of the international, the teamsters set out to clean house. In 1992 Mr. Adelstein was barred from the union for his association with organized crime figures. The next year the international suspended most of the local's executive board members, and appointed a trustee to oversee the local.
The consent judgment announced today is the settlement of another racketeering suit, which listed Local 813 as a defendant. In this suit, filed in 1989 by Federal prosecutors in the Eastern District of New York, the local was one of more than 100 defendants accused of racketeering in the garbage hauling industry on Long Island. The suit continues against the remaining parties.
Although the Government has taken over unions in the past, today's agreement was hailed by both sides as a novel solution.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times to Seek Cost Savings Including Some Cuts in Jobs

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
After six years of sharp declines in advertising, The New York Times reported yesterday that it had a "tiny -- but nonetheless real"-- advertising gain of 1 percent for 1993, compared with 1992.
But in a memorandum to the staff, the newspaper's publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., said that while The Times's financial picture "has stabilized, we still find ourselves facing serious difficulties" that will force the newspaper to seek cost savings, including a reduction in its white-collar work force. 
 The New York Times Company yesterday announced a special pretax charge of $30 million (approximately 19 cents a share) for the fourth quarter of 1993 "for severance and related costs resulting from anticipated white-collar staff reductions." It had earlier projected 1993 earnings of $59 million to $67 million, or 70 cents to 80 cents a share.
Mr. Sulzberger said that the newspaper had lost more than a third of its advertising volume since the 1987 stock market crash and that despite signs of an improvement in the economy, "there is little to suggest that much of this lost linage will return."
Because of increased competition for fewer advertiser dollars, Mr. Sulzberger said, the newspaper "must respond to diminished revenue by rethinking the way we operate" and reducing costs without affecting the quality of the newspaper.
He said the newspaper would seek savings, including reductions in the number of white-collar employees and managers. He said that the newspaper would try to achieve the reductions through voluntary measures, but that he could not rule out the possibility that some employees "will have to leave with severance packages."
Nancy Nielsen, the spokeswoman for The Times, said the newspaper would evaluate all categories of white-collar employees, including those in the newspaper's newsroom, as it determines where reductions would be made.
 
Union Involved
 The newspaper's contract with the New York Newspaper Guild, the union that represents white-collar and some other employees, expired on March 31. Negotiations are continuing.
The Times has contracts through the year 2000 with its production unions. Mr. Sulzberger's memorandum noted that the newspaper had reduced its staff by about 10 percent over the last six years, with most of the reductions coming from the craft employees. Mr. Sulzberger said it was "reasonable to assume" that the newspaper would need a similar reduction over the next few years from white-collar employees.
The Times made its announcement after the stock market closed yesterday. Earlier, the Times Company's class A shares ended trading at $29.125, up 37.5 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Errors Are Found in Report on Welfare Costs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Federal investigators who said last week that the cost of running the nation's welfare programs was rising twice as fast as the number of recipients did not adjust the numbers for inflation, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services says.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a private organization, analyzed the report by the department's Inspector General's Office and said it found that after accounting for inflation, the costs of the welfare bureaucracy have kept pace with the increasing number of welfare recipients. 
 The spokeswoman, Melissa Skolfield, said on Monday that the center's findings were correct and that the Federal investigators had failed to adjust for inflation.
She said that the Inspector General's report, obtained by The Associated Press under the Freedom of Information Act and reported on Jan. 3, was a working draft and that its purpose was to "point out the complexities in the system and recommend areas of further study."
 
'Serious Error' Cited
 Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research and advocacy organization that focuses on issues affecting the poor, said the draft report "makes a serious error," and added, "When inflation is factored in, there is no unexplained rise in administrative costs."
According to the draft report, the Federal Government is spending $6 billion to $8 billion a year to help the states in programs involving food stamps, Medicaid and Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
The investigators said the administrative costs of those programs had risen 43 percent from 1987 to 1991, while the number of people on the rolls increased an average of 18 percent.
But Mr. Greenstein said that if inflation was taken into account, the increase in administrative costs was just 19 percent. The center said adjusting for inflation was necessary because state and local welfare programs had seen increases in the costs of employee salaries, health benefits, postage and office supplies.
 
Reports Called Valuable
 Ms. Skolfield, the Health and Human Services spokeswoman, said the Clinton Administration was still committed to reducing the complexity of the welfare bureaucracy, and called the Inspector General's reports valuable.
A task force named by President Clinton to overhaul the nation's welfare system is also considering ways to simplify the system to reduce costs and fraud. The President has called for a two-year limit on welfare benefits, improvements in child-support collections and more education and training for low-income mothers.
Today a bipartisan group that represents state human service departments and local welfare agencies made public its blueprint for overhauling the welfare system. Many of its recommendations parallel the findings of Mr. Clinton's task force.
The group, the American Public Welfare Association, said its proposed restructuring would cost more in the short term but would save money in the long run.
A. Sidney Johnson 3d, executive director of the association, said at a news conference this morning that the cost of expanding education, training, jobs and child care for parents on welfare would exceed $15 billion over five years. But the association's report does not suggest ways to pay for its proposed changes.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
A Time Editor Is Said to Get New York Magazine Offer

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Kurt Andersen, an editor at large at Time magazine and a founding editor of Spy magazine, has been offered the job of editor of New York magazine, people at its parent company, K-III Magazines, said yesterday.
An announcement is expected by the end of the week. 
 Michael Kinsley, the co-host of the Cable News Network's "Crossfire" and a senior editor of The New Republic, had been offered the job two weeks ago. On Monday, however, he told officials at K-III that he was no longer a candidate for the job. He said that his contract with CNN posed complications but that the real reason he was turning down the job was that he did not want to live in New York.
"I found it was hard to work up any enthusiasm for living in New York and I decided that I wouldn't be the best editor of New York magazine if I couldn't live there with real enthusiasm," Mr. Kinsley said yesterday.
 
Job Vacant Since October
 The job, which is considered one of the plums of the magazine industry, has been vacant since Edward Kosner left in October to become editor in chief of Esquire magazine. Peter Herbst, who was Mr. Kosner's second in command, has been acting editor since then and was one of the candidates on the final list.
Mr. Andersen, who is 39, was appointed editor at large at Time last year. He writes a weekly column on American culture, entertainment, the media and the arts. He also created the magazine's new front section, Chronicles, which is a collection of short news reports and commentary. He is also the magazine's architecture and design critic.
Mr. Andersen was co-founder and co-editor in chief of Spy with Graydon Carter, who is now editor in chief of Vanity Fair.
New York was a survivor among city magazines after the recession forced local advertisers throughout the country to cut back on advertising pages. Last year, New York's advertising pages increased by 4 percent from 1992 levels. Its circulation for the first six months of 1993 was 434,000, virtually the same as in 1992. Newsstand sales, however, were down 9 percent.
K-III Magazines, which is controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, acquired New York from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in 1991.

HEADLINE: First-Time Givers Help the Neediest Cases Fund Grow

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Each day, they witnessed the growing poverty on New York's streets, portrayed in newspaper articles and on television. In small, piecemeal ways, they tried to ease the suffering by giving to panhandlers or pitching in at soup kitchens. But with so many in need, deciding who to help overwhelmed them.
So for the first time, they turned to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. By giving to the Neediest Cases, they said, they knew their money would be used to lift thousands of people out of poverty and help make sure they do not fall back. 
 They are first-time contributors like Joyce H. Selter of Glen Ridge, N.J., who gave $100. "I do this because I've been very touched and moved by your account of neediest cases," Ms. Selter wrote. Similarly, Charles Lemonides of Manhattan said he has read accounts of poverty in The New York Times for more than 15 years, but this year he gave his first contribution to the fund, $75, because he believes the recession has driven many more people into poverty. "I hope it becomes a tradition," Mr. Lemonides wrote.
Others, like Monis M. Ring of Fort Lee, N.J., who worked as a high school mathematics teacher in New York City for 28 years, gave for the first time despite hardship of their own.
"I am recently retired, with a life-threatening illness and before I leave the area, which will be shortly, I want to make a contribution to this fund," Mr. Ring wrote in a letter with his $20 contribution. "All the cases are so needy, I wouldn't know where to begin."
 
Policy on Expenses Cited
 Several who contributed for the first time said they chose the fund, which is in the midst of its 82d annual appeal, because all donations go directly to seven social-service agencies. The Times pays the campaign's overhead to make this possible.
"I read about your services to needy people and I was convinced that this small amount of money will help a little and not go for salaries, etc.," wrote Nina Vallone, of Rochester, N.Y., who donated $25. "Many of us have become very discouraged with agencies which give very little for the purposes they solicit for. I wish I could do more."
The employees in the marketing division of DC Comics in Manhattan, celebrating an increase in business, decided to give to the Neediest Cases Fund this year's because they felt more acutely the disparity between their success and others' suffering.
"Superman returned to life, in his comic book and in the marketplace," wrote Martha Thomases, a spokeswoman for the company, in a letter with the employees' checks for $386.09. "Bruce Wayne's spine was broken, but his indomitable spirit and determination showed millions of readers that heroism is more than a perfectly trained body. We're very lucky to see profitable results from our hard work."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Edge Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slightly higher yesterday, but within a narrow range ahead of scheduled reports of key inflation indicators, beginning with today's Producer Price Index.
Traders attributed the steady pricing in part to an article yesterday in The New York Times that suggested a key United States inflation indicator was overstated. The article reported that researchers at the Bureau of Labor Statistics considered the Consumer Price index overstated by as much as six-tenths of 1 percent. 
 While some traders said the revision was "old news," it is useful to the market because it reinforces a growing belief that the Federal Reserve will not tighten credit anytime soon. "Even if the markets were aware of this," one trader said, "they are more apt to react to it when they see it in the media."
 
C.P.I. Report Due
 December's Consumer Price Index is due out tomorrow at 8:30 A.M. Eastern time, and economists surveyed by Reuters expect it will rise two-tenths of 1 percent over all and three-tenths of 1 percent at the core, which excludes the volatile food and energy components.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue Inc., an information service for institutional investors, said: "Essentially what has been happening is that the economy has been losing some of its momentum as we came out of December into this year. That's fine, since that was forecast and expected by economists to happen. But for some of us, the drop in the momentum is happening a little earlier than expected."
He noted that the bond market had responded favorably, and for a while it looked as if rates would move up. But they have since come back down to the levels of much of last year's fourth quarter.
 
Long Bond Yield Unchanged
 By late in the day the Treasury's 30-year bond was trading at a price of 1003/16 to yield 6.24 percent, unchanged from the previous session. Shorter-maturity bill rates were down slightly, as a three-month issue dropped 4 basis points, to 2.96 percent, and a six-month bill dropped 3 basis points, to 3.13 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Mr. Frank expected the market would be comfortable with today's producer price numbers, since lower energy prices give an early indication of the numbers. "The real danger, but one with a low probability, is that the market will be surprised by unfavorable data indicating higher inflation than expected," he said.
If the market decides the inflation number is favorable, as expected, interest rates should not change much. Only disaster would cause it to sell off. "This is the same bond market which was very concerned about inflation about two weeks ago," Mr. Frank said.
Forecasts for the consumer price data are for a gain of about one-tenth of 1 percent, down from two-tenths of 1 percent in November, which the market would love, Mr. Frank noted. "There is some concern that the food component will increase," he said, adding that lower energy prices were likely to offset it.
 
Economic Calendar Light
 Yesterday's economic calendar was light, with only the Johnson Redbook weekly survey of sales at leading retailers. But the timing of the retailing report, which indicated stronger-than-expected activity, made it a little more important as an early indicator of the first quarter, since many market participants are now wondering how much economic strength would cause the Fed to respond.
Elsewhere, Japanese investors were again the subject of market speculation. Market watchers believe the Japanese have been selling American bonds to take advange of currency profits generated by the dollar's rise against the yen.
Yesterday the National Association of Manufacturers said its outlook for sustained economic growth could be tempered by "several downside risks, which could result in a slower growth path." At its annual outlook briefing, the group forecast 1994 gross domestic product would climb 3 percent.
But it said a rise in the dollar's strength versus foreign currencies could jeopardize growth. Widespread expectations for an appreciating dollar could spur speculative buying and cause a rapid jump. "If this takes place, the trade sector will improve more slowly than projected," the N.A.M. said.
The report also noted the potential for domestic monetary policy to be tightened too rapidly or too aggressively.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Modest Gains On Weakness in Germany

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against most leading currencies yesterday, after weak economic data from Germany encouraged traders to move out of mark-based assets.
But the gains were moderate, and many currency dealers were happy to stay on the sidelines until Washington releases price and sales reports today and tomorrow. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7410 German marks, from 1.7343 on Monday.
 
Gold Higher in New York
 Gold rose on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, gaining $3, to $388.70 an ounce.
The German Federal Statistics Office said that western Germany's economy in 1993 showed the sharpest decline since World War II, with gross national product down 2.3 percent. Although growth stabilized in the fourth quarter, some economists are predicting another decline in the first quarter of 1994.
"Today's figures do not exclude the possibility of a double-dip recession," Nick Parsons of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in London said yesterday.
The British pound, which has been rising against the mark because Britain's economic prospects are robust compared with Germany's, also surged against the mark, eclipsing its 1993 peak of 2.5950 marks.
The Japanese yen posted gains against the mark as well, limiting the dollar's headway against Japan's currency. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 112.47 yen, up from 112.27 on Monday.
While the dollar attracted investors all yesterday, dealers said few were willing to buy aggressively before the this week's American data were released.
Dealers were hoping that today's report on December producer prices and tomorrow's data on last month's consumer prices would offer clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and that tomorrow's retail sales numbers for December would disclose the strength of the consumer-led recovery.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4895, down from $1.4930 late on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.4775 Swiss francs, up from 1.4725; 1.3222 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3170.

HEADLINE: From One Island, a Savory Blend of Three Cultures

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
PUERTO RICAN food is not just cuchifritos, those fried bits of pork that are sold at luncheonettes. Although the pig is king in Puerto Rican cooking, there are hundreds of dishes in this hybrid cuisine, which is partly Spanish (pork and rice), African (plantains) and Taino Indian (beans and guava).
It is spicy and savory, sometimes sweet and seldom bland. It is also intact and in flux throughout New York City, where chefs like Michael Rodriguez, 38, a caterer in Queens who graduated from the Culinary Institute of America, are reducing the amount of salt in traditional dishes and using olive oil instead of lard. 
 These chefs have an eager audience. "From 1983 to 1990, only Spanish-speaking people bought Puerto Rican cookbooks," said Nach Waxman, owner of Kitchen Arts and Letters, a Manhattan bookstore specializing in cookbooks. "In the last two years, for the first time, there are non-Puerto Ricans buying Puerto Rican cookbooks."
In November, "Puerto Rican Cuisine in America: Nuyorican and Bodega Recipes" by Oswald Rivera (Four Walls Eight Windows, 1993) was published. E. P. Dutton plans to release "A Taste of Puerto Rico" by Yvonne Ortiz next year.
According to the 1990 census, there are 897,000 Puerto Ricans in New York City, making them the largest ethnic group -- four times larger, for instance, than the number of Chinese. They are scattered throughout the boroughs, with the largest concentration, 350,000, in the Bronx.
Puerto Rican restaurants are simple places, with a counter, stools, a half-dozen tables and chairs. Napkins are paper, coffee is strong and service is friendly.
"Puerto Ricans have never been a restaurant people," said Dr. Sidney W. Mintz, a professor of anthropology at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, who has studied Puerto Rican culture. "Partly it's economic. People ate at home because they couldn't afford to eat out."
Even in New York City, Puerto Rican restaurants with tablecloths, a barometer of fanciness, are few.
"People see it as home cooking, so it remains in the neighborhoods, as mom and pop types of restaurants," said Ms. Ortiz, who is also the food service manager at Su Casa, a nonprofit drug rehabilitation program on the Lower East Side.
Typical mom and pop places are La Taza de Oro on Eighth Avenue in the Chelsea section in Manhattan, Pepe's on Eighth Street in Greenwich Village or El Bohio in the South Bronx. But many Puerto Ricans also hire caterers for family gatherings at home.
Three dishes, essential to the culture, reflect its hybrid roots. Rice and beans, an amalgam of the Indian and Spanish cultures, is the everyday dish. Roast whole pig is the celebratory dish, eaten at Christmas and at baptisms. And pasteles are meat wrapped in plantain leaves. They were invented by African women in Puerto Rico, and they look like tamales, but aren't. Within the leaves are spicy chicken or pork and a yellow silky paste often made from grated plantains.
"The pastel in the plantain leaf is the cathedral of Puerto Rican cooking," said Soledad Romero, a lecturer in the Romance language department at Queens College of the City University of New York, in Flushing. "The cultural miscegenation is in that dish." The plantain is African, the achiote (the yellow coloring) is Indian and the pork is Spanish.
Chicken is the most frequently eaten animal but not the most coveted.
"A pig is the best possible animal for a poor man to raise on a patch of land the size of a handkerchief," Dr. Mintz said.
For savory dishes, Puerto Ricans saute onion, garlic, cilantro, bell pepper and tomatoes in olive oil to make sofrito, the base of all stewed dishes. For roasted meats, they make an adobo -- a paste of salt, black peppercorns, onion and garlic -- and rub it into slits in the flesh.
There is also achiote, the poor man's version of saffron, which is made by cooking annatto seeds in oil until the oil turns orange-red.
"The Indians used achiote to color their bodies and to give color to food," Ms. Romero said. Achiote, which has a faint musky, smoky flavor, is what makes white rice yellow.
At La Taza de Oro, Alejandro Vargas, 67, and his wife, Elizabeth, 59, live a floor above the restaurant, which is open six days a week from 6 A.M. to 11 P.M. Although the Vargases offer 22 savory dishes, from codfish salad to tripe soup, the rice and beans sell best, at $3.25 an order.
Rice and beans may slide together as one dish, but they are served separately. Customers drizzle hot sauce over them as they choose, and some add fried golden yellow plantains or pig's knuckles.
The pork addict goes to a lechonera, a restaurant where the pig -- el lechon -- is roasted whole. At El Bohio in the Bronx, the exterior, like that of La Taza de Oro, is plain. But the pig is not.
A forceful bite crunches through the golden, slightly salty blistered skin and into the succulent meat flavored by the adobo. Achiote gives the skin its rich hue.
On a Saturday night in winter, the tiny restaurant is packed. Everyone is eating pork. With it, customers usually order plantains. Unpeeled, a green plantain looks inedible. A ripe plantain looks spoiled, with black spots obliterating the yellow skin.
But plantains are as versatile as they are homely. Ripe ones, when fried, are sweet and chewy. Green ones, when sliced and fried, are called tostones and have the same compelling quality as french fries. The slices, soaked in salted water, are fried once, drained, slapped flat with the palm of the hand and refried until crisp and golden.
When a green plantain is grated with pumpkin, potatoes and manioc, it becomes masa, or paste, for a pastel. Making a pastel, Ms. Romero said, "is folklore." Women make pastels and sell them, for around $1.50 apiece, from their homes as part of an underground economy.
Some cooks emerge from the underground to become caterers, which is a way to maintain their culinary roots. Fledgling caterers learn the trade pork chop by pork chop.
For instance, at El Barrio Popular Education, a nonprofit community organization at 218 East 106th Street, there are classes in catering, literacy and computers. For the last two years, Monday through Thursday, 13 women have been cooking under the supervision of Catalina Parra, a counselor, and selling their food to the other 70 students and staff members.
On a recent Thursday, Virginia Diaz was frying tostones and slapping them flat between sheets of aluminum foil. Aida Ayala made two savory rice dishes -- one with pink beans, the other with pigeon peas. And the roast pork? "I cooked it too long," Altagracia Vargas said.
"Each woman will make around $20 a day," said Klaudia Rivera, the executive director of the organization. If $100 is earned, $10 is reinvested in equipment, another $10 in ingredients and the remainder is divided among the four cooks who worked that day. Ms. Vargas and Ms. Diaz, who are on welfare, said they could imagine cooking their way to financial independence some day, just like Frances Lopez.
When Ms. Lopez was divorced in 1980, she had three children, ages 10 to 14. "Catering was the only way to be with them," Ms. Lopez said. "I refused to be a parent on the poverty level."
She asked her aunt, Marcelina Anaya, to teach her how to cook, and asked her children to help her make alcapurrias. To create them, Ms. Lopez grated manioc, made a masa and filled it with ground spiced beef. Her children shaped the mixture into three-inch footballs, which were then fried.
Ms. Lopez's company, Fiesta Caribe in the Bronx, is now 12 years old. She prepares dishes like rice with chicken -- similar to a paella without the shellfish -- and quivering flan for clients like Banco Popular, which pay about $9 a person for such a meal.
When Jose Olmo was growing up in San Juan, P.R., the first dish he learned to make was cazuela, a pudding made from sweet potato, pumpkin and taro. Seasoned with ginger, cinnamon, star anise, cloves, sugar and coconut, it is baked and served warm and melts in the mouth.
By day, Mr. Olmo teaches English at the Wildcat Service Corporation, a nonprofit organization in Manhattan that trains unemployed people to re-enter the work force. At night, he caters from his Manhattan apartment, charging $20 a person for a dinner of cream of taro soup, beef smothered in onions, rice and beans and cazuela.
No matter how sophisticated Puerto Ricans' palates may be, they don't like to be separated from rice and beans. In 1986, after Michael Rodriguez graduated from the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., he worked at the Caribe Hilton International Hotel in San Juan and then the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan. In 1990, he started working on his own. One of his specialties is piononos, golden circles of fried plantain wrapped around spicy chopped beef and drizzled with beaten egg. He charges about $15 for a meal of pasteles, piononos, rice and beans and a salad.
Recently, after cooking pasteles and piononos, he said he had to be off, for a visit to La Taza de Oro.
And why?
"For rice and beans," he said.
 
Puerto Rican Dishes, From the Spicy to the Sweet
 
Cazuela
(Adapted from Jose Olmo)
Total time: 2 hours, 15 minutes
 
 oil for greasing pan
 1 knob ginger root, about 1-inch long, peeled and sliced
 1 large cinnamon stick, split lengthwise
 1 teaspoon star anise pods, broken into pieces
 10 cloves
 2 pounds sweet potatoes, peeled and cut in 2-inch chunks
 1 1/2 pounds taro root, peeled and cut in 2-inch chunks
 2 pounds Caribbean pumpkin, peeled and cut in 2-inch chunks
 1 can Asian-style coconut milk, unsweetened
 3 large eggs
 2 cups sugar
 1 teaspoon salt
 4 tablespoons flour.
1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Line the bottom and sides of a 9 1/2-inch springform pan with greased waxed paper or parchment paper.
2. In a small pot, combine 3/4 cup water, ginger, cinnamon, star anise and cloves. Boil for 5 minutes, strain and reserve liquid. Discard spices.
3. In a large saucepan, bring three quarts of water to a boil. Add sweet potatoes and boil for 10 minutes. Add taro and boil for 5 minutes, then add pumpkin and boil for 20 minutes. Drain and press through a food mill.
4. Using an electric mixer, beat together coconut milk, eggs, sugar, salt, flour and reserved liquid. Combine with pureed vegetables and mix well by hand. Pour into pan and bake for 1 1/2 hours. Cool for 20 minutes in pan. Serve warm.
Yield: 16 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 260 calories, 5 grams fat, 40 milligrams cholesterol, 160 milligrams sodium, 3 grams protein, 55 grams carbohydrate.
 
Stewed Green Peas
With Sausage
(Adapted from "Puerto Rican Cuisine in America," by Oswald Rivera.)
Total time: 50 minutes, plus overnight soaking
 
 1 pound dried whole green peas
 1 teaspoon salt
 1/2 cup olive oil
 3 chorizo sausages, sliced into 1/4-inch rounds
 2 tablespoons sofrito (see recipe)
 1/4 cup tomato sauce
 1 teaspoon dried oregano
 1/2 pound peeled and seeded pumpkin, cut into bite-size pieces.
1. Soak peas overnight in a bowl with water to cover.
2. Drain and rinse under cold running water. Place in heavy kettle or Dutch oven with 3 cups fresh water and salt. Boil, covered, over moderate-high heat for 20 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, heat olive oil in a skillet. Add sausages and stir-fry over moderate heat for 5 minutes. Add sofrito, tomato sauce and oregano. Saute another 5 minutes. Add to green peas.
4. Add pumpkin to green peas. Stir, cover and cook for 20 minutes or until sauce has thickened. Serve with rice.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 620 calories, 50 grams fat, 70 milligrams cholesterol, 1460 milligrams sodium, 20 grams protein, 25 grams carbohydrate.
 
Sofrito
Total time: 10 minutes
 
 8 leafy stems cilantro
 1 medium green bell pepper
 1 clove garlic, crushed
 1 medium onion, coarsely chopped
 1/4 pound aji dulce, halved with inner seeds removed (see note)
 6 whole leaves recao, chopped (see note)
 1 tablespoon vegetable or olive oil.
Combine all ingredients in a food processor and puree until smooth.
Yield: 1 1/3 cups.
NOTE: Aji dulce are small, sweet chili peppers. Recao is a green herb with a long oval leaf. Both may be found in bodegas and Asian markets.
 
Coconut Custard
(Adapted from "Puerto Rican Cuisine in America," by Oswald Rivera.)
Total time: about 1 hour
 
 2 large ripe coconuts
 1/2 cup cornstarch
 2/3 cup sugar
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
 Ground nutmeg
 Ground cinnamon.
1. Using a hammer and a carpenter's nail, pierce the eyes of the coconuts and make holes about 2 inches deep. Drain liquid and reserve.
2. Using a hammer, split coconuts and remove meat from shell. Peel the brown skin from the coconut meat. Break meat into pieces, rinse and grate finely.
3. Add enough water to reserved coconut liquid so that it measures 3 1/2 cups. Bring liquid to a boil and add grated coconut. Drain coconut into a strainer, pressing to extract the liquid into a bowl.
4. Bring 1 cup of water to a boil and add to the coconut in the colander, again pressing to extract the liquid. Discard the coconut.
5. In a medium saucepan, combine cornstarch, sugar, salt and vanilla. Whisk in coconut milk and blend well. Cook on moderate heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon until mixture thickens. Reduce heat to low and stir until mixture bubbles.
6. Remove from heat and pour into 8 slightly wet 2-ounce molds or a 2 1/2- to 3-cup pan or mold. Refrigerate until cooled and set. Invert onto a serving dish. Sprinkle with nutmeg and cinnamon and serve.
Yield: 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 245 calories, 14 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 145 milligrams sodium, 1 gram protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.

Rice With Rosemary
(Adapted from Soledad Romero)
Total time: 25 minutes
 
 1 bay leaf
 1 tablespoon dried rosemary
 2 cups converted rice
 1 small beef bouillon cube
 1 tablespoon vegetable or olive oil
 Salt to taste.
1. In a medium saucepan combine two cups of water, the bay leaf and rosemary and bring to a boil. Add rice, bouillon cube, oil and salt. Return to a boil and reduce heat to low. Simmer, covered, for 10 minutes.
2. Stir rice with a fork. Simmer, covered, for another 10 minutes or until liquid is absorbed.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 250 calories, 3 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 145 milligrams sodium (before salting), 4 grams protein, 50 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: OFF THE MENU

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

The Party's Over, for Now
The party has ended on West 44th Street, at least for the time being, as the owners have shut the doors of Mamma Leone's, the huge, rollicking restaurant that has been a New York institution for decades.
"The cost of operating the restaurant in that location had become prohibitive," said Nick Valenti, the chief executive of Restaurant Associates, which owns Mamma Leone's. The restaurant, which first opened in 1906 in the 14th Street area, has been on 44th Street in the Milford Plaza Hotel since 1988. Mr. Valenti said the company negotiated unsuccessfully with Milstein Properties, the owner of the Milford Plaza Hotel, to try to get a better deal. "We are looking at new locations in New York, Orlando and Las Vegas," Mr. Valenti said. 
 The restaurant, a mecca for tourists, had been grossing about $8 million a year. But Mr. Valenti said it had been affected by the economy.
Its leaf-bedecked grottos and plaster statues of nymphs and satyrs would hardly raise an eyebrow in Orlando or Las Vegas. "We are considering one of those cities regardless of what happens in New York," Mr. Valenti said. "I don't like to see New York lose any of its institutions, but right now I'm also thinking about how nice and warm it is in those places."
 
Oops! Not Kosher

Something is not quite kosher about the 1994 Zagat Survey of New York City Restaurants. Trastevere 83, to be exact. The restaurant, listed as kosher in the guidebook, does not serve kosher food, as a number of people who follow the guidebook, shall we say, religiously, have found out. About 300,000 books were printed with the mistake indicating the restaurant has "reliably good kosher-Italian food" and listing it as kosher in the index.
So we all make mistakes. How did this one slip through? "Some of the 300 or so surveyors who mentioned it said it was kosher," explained Tim Zagat, the president of the company. "I always thought it was kosher myself so I didn't question it. Then we started getting complaints."
It was not the worst mistake, Mr. Zagat said, explaining: "That was a few years ago when we gave the address of the Four Seasons restaurant as East 49th Street, not 52nd Street. We got an angry letter from a woman saying her 85-year-old grandmother was coming to a party at the Four Seasons one night in the pouring rain and got out of the cab at the 49th Street address we gave. 'It's a miracle she's still alive,' the woman said."
 
Caviar to Go
 Caviarteria, the delicacy shop at 29 East 60th Street, is moving to 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, the former location of Reginette, and opening a retail shop and tasting cafe. The cafe, due to open in April, will feature caviar, smoked fish and foie gras, as well as champagne. Bruce Sobol, one of the owners, said they plan to serve these foods for the same prices that are charged at the retail counter.
 
Park Avenue Cafe Chain?

Will Park Avenue Cafe become a name to be reckoned with in cities that don't even have a Park Avenue? The New York Restaurant Group, which owns the Park Avenue Cafe here, where David Burke is chef, hopes to clone the restaurant in 20 cities. It is currently negotiating with a hotel chain that it wouldn't identify. "We've been looking to do something like this for years," said Alan Stillman, a partner in the company. "We hope to have a signed deal by the end of the month."
If the deal does go through, it will be one more sign that hotels have decided that leasing their restaurant space to outsiders is preferable to running the operations themselves. These days, a fancy restaurant that loses money is not something the companies that own hotels are eager to subsidize.
 
New Tastes at Le Cirque
 This week and next, some regional Italian dishes are being added to the lunch menu at Le Cirque, 58 East 65th Street. Franca Franceschini, the chef of the restaurant Romano in the Tuscan seaside resort Viareggio, will be preparing fresh linquine, baby calamari, spiny lobster and slices of miniature zucchini in the lightest olive oil and seafood broth. Next week, Bruna Santini and her son Antonio, from Dal Pescatore in Canneto Sull'Oglio, near Mantua, will prepare a dish from Lombardy. The dishes are available on the regular $29 prix-fixe luncheon.

HEADLINE: Begging and Giving

 BODY:
Begging. Most people, especially in New York, are conflicted about begging. Panhandlers can be annoying, menacing or pitiable. They remind the rest of us of matters we'd rather ignore, from poverty and deprivation to mental illness and drug addiction. What to do when approached by beggars -- give them some loose change to help them, or withhold money to discourage them? And what of the desire of the rest of us to go about our lives free of hassle and guilt?
Transit Authority officials have asked that question and they have offered up an answer: a crackdown. Don't give to beggars, they're telling straphangers; arrest panhandlers caught begging repeatedly, they're telling transit police. 
 As most New Yorkers are about begging, we are conflicted about this latest T.A. policy. Subway panhandling is indeed an intrusion. Subway riders are temporary captives. There's nowhere for them to escape until they get to their stop -- other than into the next car. They have a right to breathing space and peace. So yes, the Transit Authority police should discourage begging on the subways, even to the point of arrest.
But should government be telling people not to exercise compassion at a time when poverty is at its most visible since the Depression? The increase in panhandling in New York and elsewhere is partly a reflection of the country's economic condition. Some beggars are, as a college student put it in an interview with The Times, "begging because they need to." They are down on their luck, out of work, poor. Of course, some are alcoholics or drug addicts, or the mentally ill. But they, too, can be needy. Surely our municipal soul is not so pinched that we cannot spare a dime for those less fortunate than we, even those who made the miserable, and frigid, beds in which they lie.
To its credit, the Transit Authority says it will refer the beggars to social service agencies that can help them. But is it also government's job to say don't help with loose change if you feel so moved? That may make sense in the subways, where it is against the law to panhandle and one is trying to drive the panhandlers away. But the tone of the official response suggests a hardening of attitudes that could harm helpless members of society throughout the city, not just in the subways.
As the T.A. -- and the new Giuliani administration -- embrace tougher measures, officials from the Mayor on down have to avoid demonizing the disadvantaged and mistaking discipline for long-term solutions. Getting tough with panhandlers on the subways really amounts to stirring a damaged and resourceless population. They won't go away. They will go above ground, more visible reminders that the city's deeper afflictions need curing.
Panhandlers, especially those in enclosed spaces like subways, and many of the squeegee-wielders on street intersections can indeed be threatening, even dangerous. The public has a right to its peace of mind. But people also have a right to show compassion. So yes, T.A. police, discourage the panhandlers. But New Yorkers have every right to exercise their charitable instincts.
It is cold out there.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
