HEADLINE: Disarming Diplomacy in Ukraine

 BODY:
In a victory for its nuclear diplomacy, the Clinton Administration has persuaded Ukraine's leader to get rid of the nuclear arsenal he inherited from the Soviet Union. In agreeing to the deal, President Leonid Kravchuk recognized that Ukraine's nuclear legacy may be worth more converted into fuel than as arms. The chief concern now is that nationalists in the Ukrainian Parliament will find a way to block the pact.
If instituted, the agreement would remove a threat from Ukrainian missiles still programmed to hit American targets, reduce the risk that the warheads will fall into reckless hands and keep tensions in the former Soviet Union from escalating to nuclear war. 
 The U.S. put together an offer Ukrainians shouldn't refuse. In return for disarming, Ukraine will receive U.S. help in dismantling the arms, making its Chernobyl-type reactors safer and cleaning up its environment. The nuclear material extracted from its warheads will be turned into fuel for its power plants.
In an effort to satisfy the demands of Ukrainian nationalists, Russia will cancel a portion of Ukraine's debt as reimbursement for warheads already handed over for dismantling. It will refrain from economic coercion. And Russia, along with the U.S. and Britain, will guarantee Ukraine's borders.
The deal requires Ukraine to dismantle its entire nuclear arsenal -- 1,240 nuclear warheads mounted on its SS-19 and SS-24 missiles and 564 more on cruise missiles carried on long-range bombers. The warheads are a wasting asset. Even though they sit on Ukrainian soil, they remain under Russian operational control. For Ukrainians to pick their electronic locks and gain control over them would take time. To re-target them by reprogramming their on-board computers would take still more time. Meanwhile, the warheads are decaying and the missile fuel is becoming dangerously unstable, making the arms a menace to their possessors, not just their foes.
Nevertheless some nationalists see Ukraine's nuclear arms as a symbol of its newborn nationhood. Others want to wave the warheads at Russians who are not yet reconciled to an independent Ukraine.
But the arms are a distraction from the real threat to Ukraine's independence: the gross mismanagement of its economy and the social unrest it is kindling.
Instead of instituting economic reforms, Kiev is financing factories that produce nothing worthwhile. Ukraine's currency, which once traded on a par with Russia's ruble, now has no buying power abroad, and hyperinflation has begun to rip Ukraine apart.
Ethnic Russians in western Ukraine who voted for independence in the belief that life would be better than in Russia now have their doubts. And political disarray could pave the way for nationalists to win parliamentary elections in March.
Under these circumstances, the Clinton Administration was wise not to wait for Kiev to live up to its pledge to join the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which Parliament would have to ratify. Instead, Washington persuaded Kiev to deactivate the warheads on missiles aimed at the U.S., the sooner the better. And the U.S. will pay Russia to ship nuclear fuel to Ukraine in advance of extracting more from Ukraine's warheads.
The Administration deserves credit for brokering this deal. And Ukraine's leaders are right to reject nuclear symbolism for economic substance.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mozambique Working Hard to Build Its Future

 BODY:
To the Editors:
I just came back from six months as a development aid volunteer in Mozambique, rebuilding two abandoned schools with local residents. Mozambique is said to be the poorest country in the world, a former Portuguese colony that gained independence just 18 years ago. It has suffered a decade of civil war, financed by South Africa, China and others. 
 Virtually no infrastructure is left. A devastating drought coincided with the last two years of war. Internal strife in South Africa and the cold war's windup ended foreign involvement in the war in Mozambique, leaving the two sides ready to settle for peace. Last year the United Nations went in to try and monitor a peace accord. That put Mozambique on a list with Cambodia, Angola, Liberia, Somalia and Bosnia.
Instead of finding desperation in Mozambique, I found peace and potential. My Mozambican co-workers are rebuilding houses and schools and moving back to the countryside, a war zone for so long. The rains came back last year after the drought. Mozambique is extremely fertile, and drought is not common.
Mozambique's war was not ethnic warfare like Bosnia's. Despite the number of ethnic groups in the country, there is less hostility between north and south in Mozambique than in the United States. Mozambique's return to stability will allow landlocked neighbors like Zimbabwe, Zambia and Malawi access once again to Mozambique's ports, which will stimulate the region's economic growth. Most important, the peace accord has held more than a year.
The United Nations still has a lot to do before next October's elections. But I think Mozambique is going to make it. Mozambicans have chosen peace and are working hard to build a decent future.
 
BETSEY CHACE
 Weston, Mass., Jan. 3, 1994

HEADLINE: Consumer, Beware of Banking 'Reform'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Unfinished Bank Reform" (editorial, Dec. 29): Banking "reform" to date has not saved taxpayers any money, it has only placed a straitjacket of unnecessary regulation around banks, making it difficult for them to lend, serve their communities and fuel the economy. 
 Congress did not pour money into a nearly empty deposit insurance fund. You are confusing the banking industry with savings and loan associations -- the two are very different. Banks and the Bank Insurance Fund have not cost the taxpayers a nickel. The banking industry supports the insurance fund entirely and has nearly recapitalized it singlehandedly.
You state that further reform to permit interstate branching is needed, but that small banks have blocked it, fearing competition. The benefits interstate branching will bring to small business and consumers are illusory. Allowing large banks to monopolize local banking will reduce service to local customers. One large bank told a Congressional panel this year that it found making loans of less than $500,000 cost-prohibitive. Very few of the truly small businesses that sustain our communities look for loans of this size, amd their organizations oppose interstate branching.
Consumers are unlikely to get higher interest rates on deposits. You point to California's example. But a 1991 study showed that in California, a highly concentrated market where four banks controlled more than 60 percent of the deposits in 1991, interest paid on transactions accounts was significantly lower -- and interest charged on loans significantly higher -- than the national average and average rates paid in out-of-state urban areas. That's not good for consumers, and most consumer organizations strongly oppose interstate branching.
We also seriously doubt that "small bankers have the same easy access to international outlets for their money" as large banks. A $100 million community bank in a small town does not have this access, or want it. Its mission is to help its community thrive by lending to local citizens and businesses.
 
KENNETH A. GUENTHER
Executive V.P., Independent
Bankers Association of America
Washington, Jan. 3, 1994

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Humbled Spanish Banker Responds

BYLINE: By ANA WESTLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The ousted chairman of Spain's third-largest bank, Mario Conde, defended his management today and argued that intervention by the nation's central bank late last month had been unnecessary.
On Dec. 28, the central bank took over Banco Espanol de Credito, or Banesto, as it is commonly known here, and replaced Mr. Conde and the board of directors. 
 Today, Mr. Conde broke his silence since his ouster and acknowledged at a news conference that Banesto "had problems," but he argued that they had been greatly overestimated by the central bank and could have been resolved this year if his own rescue plan, which he said had the backing of J. P. Morgan & Company, had been given a chance.
Mr. Conde insisted that Banesto's liquidity, solvency and stability in no way warranted the decision by the central bank, the Bank of Spain, to seize it. He also took issue with the central bank's accounting criteria.
 
Mild Legal Step
 Unusually subdued, Mr. Conde disputed every figure that the central bank had used as a justification for its takeover but ruled out a legal confrontation, filing only an affidavit rejecting the Bank of Spain report. Mr. Conde said he was discarding other legal options to protect the image of Spain's financial institutions.
For more than two hours in a Madrid hotel lounge, he defended his management of Banesto.
J. P. Morgan had picked Banesto as its first high-risk, high-return investment for its Corsair Fund, which had an 8.17 percent equity stake in the troubled Spanish bank. A Morgan vice chairman, Roberto Mendoza, was a Banesto board member.
Mr. Conde said he had Morgan's support days before the central bank takeover. A Morgan spokesman in New York was quoted by the Spanish news agency EFE as saying the bank would not sign Mr. Conde's appeal.
 
Figures Roundly Disputed
 When the central bank took over Banesto two weeks ago, it asserted that the entire Spanish financial system was threatened. The central bank governor, Luis Angel Rojo, told Parliament that Banesto had a deficit of about 500 billion pesetas, which is equivalent to $3.46 billion.
Mr. Conde, however, said this had been overestimated by 400 billion pesetas. But the bank's new managers fear that the shortage could be higher than the central bank's figure.
The Bank of Spain had rejected Mr. Conde's restructuring plan as insufficient and unrealistic, and described his accounting methods with words like "inventions" or "tricky."
The usually flamboyant Mr. Conde, 45, had come to represent the get-rich-quick schemes of the late 1980's and was an idol to many young Spaniards. Today, humbled, he admitted that he had made "some mistakes" but attributed Banesto's problems to the broad Spanish recession.
Speaking for shareholders -- and for his own 5 percent stake in the bank -- he argued that a capital reduction had been unnecessary.
 
Efforts by New Managers
 According to a top member of the bank's new management team, the new chairman, Alfredo Saenz, is negotiating a salvage plan that will try to protect investors' equity from the common "accordion operation," in which capital is slashed or wiped out.
Mr. Conde said he had not decided whether to appear at the next shareholders meeting, which will be asked to approve the rescue plan. His appearance stirred apparent relief in Spanish financial circles. The Madrid stock index soared above its September 1989 record of 328 to a high of 333.
"The impression we have is that he is not looking for combat," Emilio Ontiveros, a financial analyst said, "although he tried to save face."
Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, in Brussels for a meeting of NATO leaders, said new audits would clarify the situation. Finance Minister Pedro Solbes insisted that the "correct interpretation is that of the central bank."

HEADLINE: Clinton Looks Homeward

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Behind all foreign policy there lurks, or ought to lurk, careful political calculation. What the folks at home will not support, the traveling potentate cannot afford to promise.
So it has been with President Clinton this week, on his maiden voyage to Europe as the leader of the Atlantic alliance. Having seen how quickly American opinion turned sour when the body of an American serviceman was dragged through the streets of Mogadishu, to be duly photographed, he is reluctant to make small commitments -- witness the turning back of an American troopship bound for Haiti -- let alone big dangerous ones.
 
No Bold Moves
 Mr. Clinton therefore made no bold move on Bosnia. He issued no ultimatum to the combatants -- do this or we will do that. Instead he and the allies temporized. 
 They threatened yet again, as they did to no great effect last August, to use air strikes at Sarajevo, but only under certain conditions and not very soon at that. They added Tuzla and Srebrenica to the list of possible targets, but only pending yet another study of feasibility and suitability.
Mr. Clinton resisted, likewise, pressures from the East Europeans for full membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, obliging them to accept instead the Partnership for Peace, a little-brother status that they did not much like.
 
Russia Has Higher Priority
 One reason is the sensitivity of the Russians. For the moment, at least, Mr. Clinton has given a much higher priority to avoiding offense to the frail forces of reform in Moscow than to strengthening ties to the once-oppressed peoples of the former satellite states that once occupied such a special place in Washington's heart. That reflects the influence of Strobe Talbott, the expert on Russia who has come to dominate this Administration's strategic thinking on Europe.
But another reason is what membership in NATO means. It is, at bottom, a military alliance, and its members agree to come to the aid of each other if attacked. Expansion would mean the United States was prepared to commit troops to defend Poland or the Czech Republic (and possibly more recent membership applicants, like Lithuania or Romania) if they were attacked.
Britain's empty guarantees to Poland on the eve of World War II may have been on the mind of Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, when he asked the pivotal question last month: "Are the United States Congress, the House of Commons, the French Assembly, the German Bundestag solemnly ready to guarantee with the lives of their citizens the frontiers of, say, Slovakia? If not, or not yet, then it would be a deceit to pretend otherwise."
President Clinton does not think so, at least not now, and the mood of the country and the Senate would seem to bear him out. He was elected by a country eager to focus on its own problems, not those of the rest of the world, and he has done little to urge it to look abroad, except in terms of economic self-interest.
Even if the will were there, the means are not. The 100,000 American troops Mr. Clinton promised this week to leave in Europe, no matter what, would certainly not suffice to halt any serious manifestation of Russian expansionism. Dollars are scarce and getting scarcer for the Pentagon.
"The most effective thing for us," an American official said, "is to try to protect Eastern Europe by encouraging anti-imperialist, democratic tendencies in Russia. The problem is that the United States, or any other outside power, has only very limited influence over events in Russia."
But this is a President who likes to have things both ways. So having denied them what they sought, he met in Prague with four Eastern European leaders, led by Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and Lech Walesa of Poland, and came close -- much closer than some of his Western European partners would like -- to telling them, "Just be patient, and you'll get what you want."
 
Waiting on NATO
 On Tuesday Jiri Dienstbier, the former Czech Foreign Minister, said in an interview in Rude Pravo, a leftist daily in Prague, "We must not permit the partnership to remain a sedative or a waiting room in which to await how things turn out in Russia."
As if in direct reply, Mr. Clinton said after his round of meetings today: "While the partnership is not NATO membership, neither is it a permanent holding room. The question is no longer whether NATO will take on new members, but when and how."
But when will the right moment come?
If the American people are not ready to defend Eastern Europe with their sons' and daughters' lives now, when will they be? Surely not until Mr. Clinton or some other President makes a much stronger case than he has so far that the vital interests of the United States are at stake in the independence if these small states.
If Russia is not to be provoked at any cost, then membership for the Czechs and the others will have to be delayed until Russia has become so stable that even if angered, it would pose no threat to its neighbors. Russian history does not encourage the hope that will happen any day soon.
 
Contemplating a Darker Past
 As Mr. Clinton conceded, "There is always the chance that the darker past might be re-created."
In a way, it already has been, in Bosnia. The failure of the alliance to prevent or even to halt the genocidal war there, in another East European country to which NATO guarantees do not apply, cannot be encouraging to Poland and Hungary and the Czech Republic as they contemplate what would happen if they found themselves trapped once more in their tragic geography between East and West.
After a notably confident performance, Mr. Clinton won plaudits from his Western European colleagues this week, and his own staff seemed feverishly eager to portray him as reasserting American leadership abroad. Along with the usual spin-masters like David Gergen, Secretary of State Warren Christopher joined in the buildup effort, telling reporters he could almost feel America taking charge once again in the Brussels meeting rooms.
But for all that, there is still no definitive answer to the basic question as to when, where and at what cost the United States will commit its military forces. The Administration has not given its answer, and neither has the public. Until they have spoken, Europe will remain unsettled.

HEADLINE: Warning on Clinton Health Proposal From Idea's Originator

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
A Stanford University economist who invented the concept of managed competition in the health care industry said today that President Clinton's health plan would not work and should be completely rewritten.
"I conclude that the Clinton plan puts the Federal budget at enormous risk and will result in huge tax increases," said the economist, Alain C. Enthoven. He addressed a conference of the American Insurance Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan and later elaborated on his comments in a telephone interview. 
 Mr. Enthoven, a professor of management at the Graduate School of Business at Stanford, said workers might have to pay new taxes to cover the costs of Mr. Clinton's proposal.
Professor Enthoven seeks to combine market forces with a limited amount of Government regulation, to stimulate doctors and hospitals to compete on the basis of price and quality. This idea inspired many proposals Mr. Clinton advanced in his 1992 campaign for President.
 
Flaw in 'Controls
 But Professor Enthoven said a critical flaw of the plan was its effort to restrict prices. At the conference, he said Mr. Clinton's plan would set "extremely unrealistic" goals for health care cost increases.
Richard Kronick, a Clinton Administration adviser on health policy, disputed Mr. Enthoven's views in an interview with the Reuters news agency.
He said that the proposed ceilings on insurance premiums were not price controls and that the Clinton plan was intended to increase competition in the health care industry.
Limits on health insurance premiums "are different from what most people think of as price controls," Mr. Kronick said.
Professor Enthoven said he preferred a more modest proposal offered by Representatives Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, and Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa.

HEADLINE: Mexico Orders Cease-Fire and Offers Rebels Amnesty

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Responding to growing political pressure to end the violence in southern Mexico and negotiate peace with a new rebel group, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari today declared a cease-fire, ordered the Mexican Army not to pursue fleeing guerrillas and offered amnesty to rebels who stop fighting.
Under the new orders, the army will return fire only if fired upon, or if civilians are threatened by the rebels, Mr. Salinas said. 
 The unilateral cease-fire is the latest of several steps Mr. Salinas has taken in the last few days to soften the Government's military response to the peasant rebellion. The Mexican military's strafing of civilians and bombing of rebel holdouts have been denounced by many Mexicans and by human rights organizations.
Since Monday, Mr. Salinas has moved toward a negotiated settlement to Mexico's first significant uprising in 20 years. But opposition party leaders still questioned whether Mr. Salinas was trying to gain peace or save face.
"We just hope that they fulfill it," said Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leader of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, referring to the Government's pledge to negotiate.
Manuel Camacho Soliz, the man appointed by Mr. Salinas on Monday to find peace, arrived in Chiapas, the southern state where the fighting took place, and headed to Ocosingo, one of several cities that had been taken by rebels of the Zapatista National Liberation Army when they began their rebellion on Jan. 1. The city has since been retaken by the army.
Mr. Camacho said at a news conference that he had not yet had any direct contact with the rebels but was sure they had heard of the Government's willingness to stop fighting and talk.
In an effort to win the confidence of local Indians, and presumably the rebels with whom he would negotiate, Mr. Camacho appeared in Ocosingo with Bishop Samuel Ruiz, a Roman Catholic Church leader who has been a strong defender of Indian rights in Chiapas for more than 30 years.
 
Rebellion Coincides With Nafta
 The Chiapas rebellion, which started the same day the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, has been seen as an embarrassing renunciation of Mr. Salinas's economic development programs over the last five years. Mr. Salinas is under pressure from members of his own Institutional Revolutionary Party, as well as international observers, to end the violence quickly.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who opposed the free trade agreement, said that because of the events in Chiapas he intended to hold hearings before the end of the six-month period in which the pact will be reviewed and a vote taken on whether to adopt it permanently.
"We're going to make clear to the Salinas Administration what kind of political reforms are expected and required before that happens," he said.
Only sporadic shooting has been reported in Chiapas in the past few days. Journalists reported hearing explosions in the valleys around the town of Guadalupe Tepeyac on Tuesday afternoon, but most observers have been kept from the battle zone by army roadblocks.
The Mexico City daily La Jornada reported today that the rebels staged another attack on Tuesday on the army barracks in Rancho Nuevo, about six miles from San Cristobal de las Casas, and that a group of journalists trying to get to Guadalupe Tepeyac were shot at by an army helicopter.
 
Officials Say Firing Stopped
 Government officials said that as of this morning, all shooting and bombing had stopped. But journalists in the area said they heard some rocket or artillery fire along the road to Guadalupe-Tepeyac hours after the cease-fire.
So far there has been no response from the rebels to Mr. Salinas's declaration, but on Monday they said in a note that was published in El Tiempo, a newspaper in San Cristobal, that they would be willing to negotiate with the Government if the army stopped bombing, withdrew its soldiers and recognized the guerrilla movement.
Army officials reported this morning that with the exception of Guadalupe Tepeyac, all the towns taken by the rebels have been recaptured and that 12,000 to 15,000 Government troops had secured the region.
The army said that its push toward Guadalupe Tepeyac, just north of the Guatemalan border, had been prolonged because the principal roads leading there had been heavily damaged. Rebels reportedly have dug deep ditches across the mountain roads and blocked them with downed trees.
Journalists in the area reported seeing a convoy of some 40 trucks and 15 armored vehicles advancing slowly yesterday toward the small community of a few hundred residents.
On Monday Mr. Salinas, acknowledging in a televised speech that parts of his Government were not working as they should have, made several changes in his cabinet. He named named Mr. Camacho, who had been Foreign Minister, as commissioner of peace and reconciliation in Chiapas. Mr. Camacho is known as a skilled negotiator and had been a top candidate to run for president in next August's presidential elections.
While Mr. Salinas has said from the beginning of the crisis that his Government is willing to negotiate, his original offer of reconciliation was more restrictive than later ones. Last week the Government offered to talk to the rebels only after they had surrendered their arms, released hostages and identify their leaders. Now there are no conditions.
Mexico was startled in the first few hours of the new year as armed insurgents marched into several cities in Chiapas, declaring war on the Government and vowing to fight for a long list of demands including Indian rights and honest elections.
At first the Mexican Army did not respond. But after the rebels attacked a military camp, the army counterattacked. The fighting spread for several days until a large number of the rebels had disappeared into the deep jungle.
Over the weekend, violence apparently related to the uprising spread to Mexico City and other parts of the country where car bombs exploded and attempts were made to blow up electrical towers.

HEADLINE: Koppell Wants Lilco to Cut, Not Freeze, Rates

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 12

 BODY:
The State Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell, said today that the Long Island Lighting Company should cut its rates, rather than freeze them for two years, as the company has proposed.
Appearing at a news conference here with three State Assemblymen from Long Island, Mr. Koppell called on the State Public Service Commission to conduct "a full investigative hearing" on Lilco's rate proposals, which include a rate freeze in 1995 and 1996, followed by a 4 percent increase in 1997. 
 Mr. Koppell said he was concerned that Lilco and the commission might be trying to work out a private agreement on the company's rate requests. While he provided no details on how Lilco might reduce rates, he pointed to declining fuel costs as one indication that the company could do more to save consumers money.
"What we want to avoid here is facing a fait accompli -- Lilco and the P.S.C. making a deal," said Mr. Koppell, a former State Assemblyman who became Attorney General earlier this month. "We feel that it's time to review their rates, and hope to convince the P.S.C. the rates should be lowered."
Lilco officials denied that there had been any private negotiations on the proposal. Spokesmen for both the company and the commission said that plans for hearings on Lilco's rate requests were already in the works.
Suzanne Halpin, a spokeswoman for Lilco, defended the company's plans, arguing that the freeze would save electric customers $250 million.
 
A Two-Year Hold on Rates
 Last month Lilco announced that it would seek the freeze on rates, an action that surprised many Long Islanders, who had been expecting the company to continue to raise rates for the next several years as a result of costs associated with its agreement with the state to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant.
In explaining the two-year hold on rates, company officials said a number of favorable economic conditions, including lower interest rates and oil costs and the ability to buy more cheap power from outside Long Island, had made the freeze possible.
Two state agencies, the Consumer Protection Board and the Long Island Power Authority, which have long challenged Lilco's rate proposals, have filed an alternative plan for Lilco rates with the commission. That proposal also called for a two-year freeze, followed by a rate cut of one-half of 1 percent in 1997.
Richard Kessel, executive director of the consumer board and the chairman of the power authority, said Lilco's plan is not a true rate freeze.
He said that carry-over charges for fuel and other costs from previous years would allow Lilco to raise rates.
But Ms. Halpin said Mr. Kessel was trying to "muddy the waters" by suggesting that adjustments in fuel costs -- which are always made outside the rates set by the commission -- invalidate the rate freeze. "The commitment to freeze base electric rates is firm," she said.

HEADLINE: Caspian Sea Oil Search To Honor Bird and Beast

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
It is where 90 percent of the world's sturgeon breed. More than 300 species of birds migrate and nest there. A flourishing population of seals lives there.
It is the part of the North Caspian Sea controlled by Kazakhstan, a former Soviet republic, and it is where there are an estimated 36 billion barrels of oil, more than was discovered in Prudhoe Bay off Alaska. 
 Despite a great temptation to prove that the oil is down there, exploratory drilling has been banned since the area was declared a nature preserve in the 1970's.
That is about to change. A group of Western oil companies is eager to begin exploration, and the Kazakh Government has made agreements that could allow drilling to begin within three years if questions about the effects of exploration and drilling on the environment can be answered.
Sviatoslav A. Medvedev, Kazakhstan's Minister of Ecology and Bioresources, who has been touring oilfields in the Gulf of Mexico for the last few weeks, said at a press briefing today in Washington that exploration would eventually be allowed because the revenue from the oil and natural gas there was vital to restructure and improve the country's faltering economy.
"We need to develop our economy to produce the oil and gas for the stable development of our country," Mr. Medvedev said through an interpreter.
Yet he is also determined that the consortium of seven oil companies explore for the oil safely. It is an area where about 600,000 seals make their home, as do half a million birds, including one of the largest concentrations of flamingos in the world. And the sturgeon that produce the country's caviar, a vital industry, spawn there.
 
Field Inspection
 So he and his staff went to see for themselves how this could be done, touring the offshore oil and gas fields and platforms of the Mobil Corporation in Mobile Bay in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Medvedev said yesterday that he was encouraged by what he saw there.
This week he also met with officials of the Clinton Administration, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Interior Department to line up money, advice and expertise. The Administration, he said, promised to raise about $25 million through agencies like the World Bank.
He said the money would allow his department, which was created five years ago, to carry out scientific studies of the sea, help train staff members and put together laws and regulations to oversee the exploration.
He said the oil companies -- Mobil, AGIP S.p.A. of Italy, British Gas P.L.C., a partnership of Statoil of Norway and British Petroleum, Shell Exploration and Production B.V. of the Netherlands, and Total of France -- would spend the next two years taking seismic readings and that exploratory drilling would probably not begin for three years.
"This gives us a breathing space," he said. "We will be ready by then."
 
Earlier Wells Now Under Water
 The area already faces a major problem from 1,400 oil wells that had been drilled onshore about 30 years ago that are now covered by water because of an unexplained rise in the level of the Caspian Sea.
So far, he said, there have been no major oil leaks. Still, he said he intends to seek help from Western oil companies to find a way to cap the wells.
J. C. Hildrew, manager of environmental services for Mobil, said drilling in the North Caspian Sea would be a challenge because ice forms in the winter, toxic hydrogen sulfide gas is expected to be encountered in the drilling, and the sea is self-contained. In case of a spill, the oil would not be dispersed by water currents, as it would be in the ocean.
Mobil, he said, was supporting a gradual approach, adding, "We're not the kind of company that jumps in impetuously."
Kristin Suokko, a senior research specialist at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, said any drilling in the region would have to be done very carefully.
"It is a very vital area," she said, and drilling will be "tricky."

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Bigger Security Council Will Make U.N. More Effective

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Opening consultations here on its decision to support Germany and Japan as permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, the Clinton Administration said today that it believed a larger Council would have greater moral authority in the world and make the United Nations more effective.
The American Representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, broke off her tour of Eastern Europe and the Balkans to explain to Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and other officials that while the United States wanted permanent seats for Germany and Japan it thought that this would be difficult to achieve without giving some form of permanent membership to populous developing countries as well. 
 Enlarging the Security Council was one of the most hotly debated issues last year at the General Assembly, which set up a working group to report back on the issue later this year.
 
Complaints by Many

Developing countries and many smaller industrial nations complained that the Council's present composition -- with the five World War II victors, Britain, France, the United States, Russia and China, enjoying permanent membership and a veto on decisions -- is anachronistic and no longer corresponds to present-day realities.
But there was little agreement on how to alter its membership with some countries wanting to abolish permanent seats and vetoes altogether while others wanted to add them.
In his election campaign, President Clinton said he thought Germany and Japan should be given permanent Security Council seats in recognition of their economic strength and the contribution they make to the United Nations budget, which is bigger than those of Britain, France and China.
 
Standing by View
 Subsequently, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Representative Albright have said the Administration stands by that view.
While the admission of Germany and Japan as permanent members will dilute America's influence and that of the four other permanent members, bringing on new countries will increase the Council's prestige as well as the likelihood that the United Nations gets the resources it needs for its work.
Conversely, the Clinton Administration believes that failing to enlarge the Council means its legitimacy will gradually be eroded as the rest of the world grows stronger and feels that its interests are no longer represented.
 
No View on Veto
 At the moment, the United States has no view on such questions as whether Germany and Japan should or should not be given the same veto on decisions that the present five members enjoy.
The United States will also not insist that Germany and Japan revise their constitutions to allow their military to participate in distant peacekeeping operations. "Germany can help with logistical and medical support which won't affect its constitutional restrictions," Ms. Albright told a news conference here today. And the Administration does not think agreement on enlargement is likely until 1995.
As a practical matter, the senior official said, "it is hard to see Germany and Japan joining" without some additional representation being given to the developing world at the same time.

HEADLINE: A Potential New Loss for Westchester

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
If I.B.M. vacates its headquarters complex in nearby Armonk, the move would further wound the Westchester County economy, already hurt by the loss of thousands of jobs and a growing office vacancy rate.
But it also would be another blow to Westchester's 30-year image as a suburban mecca for corporate America, the headquarters not only of the International Business Machines Corporation but of brand-name companies including Pepsico, General Foods, Reader's Digest, and Texaco. 
 In the most recent data available, the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a real estate firm that conducts surveys of the Westchester office market, said last July that the county's vacancy rate was 27.1 percent, up almost five percentage points from the previous six months. The report attributed much of the increase to I.B.M.'s decision to vacate hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space in White Plains, Purchase and Tarrytown. An exodus of I.B.M. from Armonk would open up another 400,000 square feet of space.
 
40,000 Jobs Lost
 More important, the county has had a loss of 40,000 jobs, many of them white-collar, since the 1987 stock market crash. The decline has taken the bloom off what seemed like a never-ending cycle of growth.
Starting in the 1950's, the arrival of large corporations transformed the sleepy downtown of the county seat, White Plains, into a warren of gleaming office towers. White Plains, just off Interstate 287 and five miles from I-95, became the quintessential "edge city," demonstrating how arterial highways could disperse business out of large cities like New York. But now, fewer workers emerge from the downtown buildings for lunch or errands, giving the complex of towers an empty feeling.
After I.B.M. moved into its Armonk headquarters in 1963, the village became one of Westchester's most prosperous communities. The arrival of I.B.M. brought new country clubs, fashionable restaurants and boutiques to the surrounding area. With an I.B.M. exodus, the future of some of these amenities would be in doubt.

HEADLINE: Economic Collapse Leaves Ukraine With Little to Trade but Its Weapons

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Jan. 12

 BODY:
As the second largest of the former Soviet republics, a country endowed with natural resources and a well-educated work force, Ukraine was once viewed by Western economists as having an excellent shot at becoming a prosperous market economy.
But two years after gaining independence, the earlier hopeful assessments have turned sour as Ukraine sinks deeper into economic crisis. 
 Its energy production has collapsed, its inflation is 70 to 100 percent a month, its currency reserves are perilously low and many large factories are idle or operating at less than 30 percent capacity.
It is the virtual bankruptcy of Ukraine, a country the size of France with a population of 52 million, that aides to President Clinton apparently felt could persuade the Ukrainian President, Leonid Kravchuk, to give up the nuclear weapons he inherited from Russia. More than anything else, Ukraine needs a quick infusion of economic assistance and the only thing it had to bargain with was its nuclear arsenal.
 
Difficult Prospect for Pact
 Mr. Clinton arrived in Kiev today, saying again that he felt confident that Ukraine would carry out the accord announced on Monday in Brussels eliminating its nuclear arsenal over the next seven years, even though members of Ukraine's Parliament say ratification of the deal will be difficult.
Under the accord, many details of which remain to be worked out, Ukraine would gain billions of dollars in proceeds from uranium sales and from American assistance for dismantling the world's third largest nuclear arsenal.
Mr. Clinton's visit here, the first by an American President to independent Ukraine, was seen by many as dramatizing the country's economic collapse.
While less attention has been paid to Ukraine than Russia by the West, its shattered economy almost makes Russia's look like an International Monetary Fund model.
 
Little Privatization
 Mr. Kravchuk, who used to head the Communist Party's ideology department, has clung to the old ways, shunning the sale of state-run enterprises to private owners even on the modest scale carried out in Moscow.
Russia's monthly inflation rate fell to 12 percent in December. Ukraine's was close to 100 percent. While Russians enjoy warm apartments, many Ukrainian cities are suffering from brownouts this winter and electricity is strictly rationed in many places. Although it was the bread basket of the former Soviet Union, Ukraine now imports grain.
Even though the Government ordered a 50 percent cut in industrial energy use to save what was left for domestic consumption, heating in apartment buildings in cities outside the capital, Kiev, is tightly rationed.
Amid this chaos, daily existence for Ukrainians is a grind of making ends meet, coping with a system in which poorly paid doctors seek bribes, indigent factory workers steal the products they help make for barter, and oil workers siphon off precious fuel to sell at the roadside.
 
Few Customers in Shops
 Earlier this month, on the day before the Orthodox Christmas, there were few customers in the major shops.
"Business is horrible," said Sergei Reznik, grimacing as he stood at his butcher's counter in the central market yesterday with slabs of meat hanging at his back but no takers on Christmas Eve. A few potential customers ventured forward, asked the price and then turned away.
The chaos in the economy is particularly worrisome, reform-minded Ukrainians and Western officials say, because of the size of the country and its possession of nuclear weapons. Fanning the nuclear issue is the fierce nationalism of Ukraine's Parliament, where many members see the weapons as vital to Ukrainian security.
 
Fear of Russian Power
 The economic and nuclear issues are intricately tied up with Ukraine's relations with Russia. Russia, as much as the United States, would like the nuclear warheads dismantled since some Ukrainian legislators talk of using the missiles as a deterrent against Russia.
Ukraine's economy was facing difficulties well before independence. About 30 percent of the gross domestic product came from the military industry, the country was dependent on Russian energy and one of its most reliable exports, coal, was becoming less desirable on world markets. Almost the entire industrial base was dependent on raw materials or components from other parts of the Soviet Union.
Since Ukraine severed its political ties with Moscow, its weaknesses have grown. Ukraine cannot afford to pay for the imports it needs from former Soviet republics. Exports of the products it does have to offer -- coal and steel -- have been strangled by the heavy Communist-style state regulations that include complicated licensing and foreign currency controls.
Ukraine's onetime steady strength, its agricultural sector, has also weakened. Once the provider of 25 percent of the Soviet Union's wheat harvest, Ukraine now imports grain..
The serious energy crunch is largely due to Ukraine's inability to afford the new, world-market-level prices that Moscow, its chief supplier, is demanding for its oil. And Ukraine's inability to pay is largely caused by its collapse of exports and currency reserves.
 
Russia Supplies Energy
 Ukraine imports half its energy needs from Russia. And the 50 percent that it produces domestically is unreliable -- coal that is affected by miners' strikes and atomic power stations that rely on Russian nuclear material.
"You have to realize you are in a country where there is not a normal economy," said Yuri I. Ehanurov, a Deputy Minister of Economics and a critic of his Government's policies. "By issuing many regulations and decrees, the Government thinks it is creating order in the economy but it is forcing more and more of the economy into the gray area."
Other critics say that too many Ukrainian leaders profit from its poor economic situation. For example, many members of Parliament are also directors of the country's large state factories and thus unwilling to sell them off to the private sector.
 
Credits From Central Bank
 The state enterprises, ranging from decrepit steel mills to failing coal mines, have been gobbling up huge credits from the Central Bank in order to avoid laying anyone off. The uncontrolled credits are said by economists to be a major cause of inflation.
"This is not just mismanagement," said a Western diplomat. "This is destruction of an economy in order to get rich. There is a mentality here on the part of the political class that we are due this privileged life and will just take it."
President Kravchuk has admitted some mistakes but his New Year's Eve address was upbeat.
"The outgoing year witnessed many blunders and errors, but Ukraine is not on the brink of an abyss," he said. "National income and production declines were not as great as the previous year. The most important thing is to maintain peace and calm in our common front and feel confident in our future."
But the World Bank, disputing Mr. Kravchuk's optimistic conclusion on production, instead estimated that the gross national product declined 25 percent in 1993, following an 18 percent decline in 1992.
The Parliament continued to ignore appeals to cut back on credits. In its last session on December 24, it urged the National Bank to appeal a ban placed earlier in the month on credits to unprofitable industries.
 
Corruption Among Officials
 A certain amount of corruption among members of Parliament is an accepted way of life, in large part because of their dual role as executives in the state enterprises. Last month, the acting Prime Minister, Efrem Ziviligsky, pleaded to a gathering of barons of the state industries to help the country out and stop demanding loans from the central bank.
"Come on, I know you all have $1,000 in your pockets," he joked.
As an example of the Government's destructive economic policies, Mr. Ehanurov cited a recent decree that requires businesses that earn dollars to exchange half the dollar earnings into the Ukrainian currency at an artificially low rate set by the Government.
The Government said the move was needed to capture revenues to pay for Russian oil. But Mr. Ehanurov said the decree simply encouraged Ukrainians who earn foreign currency to park it illegally in accounts abroad. He estimated that $12 billion in such accounts existed outside the country.
As for the lagging agriculture sector, farmers on the outskirts of Kiev are relatively well off because of the nearby city market, but they are beginning to feel the effects of the shrinking purchasing power of the city residents.
 
Greenhouses Dismantled
 The Sovki state farm, for example, dismantled its greenhouse complex last month because it could not afford the heating bills to grow the tomatoes and cucumbers it sold to Kiev. Smashed glass and broken heating pipes littered the bare earth. Fifty of the 400 employees on the farm were sent home on unpaid leave, many of them young people who went back to the more remote countryside to live with their families.
How Ukraine can get out of its economic mess is unclear.
Some Ukrainians pin their hopes on the scheduled election of a new Parliament in March. But even the optimists concede that result will probably be a Parliament similarly inclined to block economic change, because the election laws give state enterprises a head start over the neophyte political parties in nominating candidates.
Western experts say they see the pattern of Russia repeating itself here, with candidates opposed to austerity steps doing well.

HEADLINE: U.S. Slightly Eases Conditions for Aid to Moscow

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told Russian leaders today that the United States is prepared to help speed up delivery of Western aid, but only after credible signs that Russia is restructuring its budget to phase out money-losing industries, to lower inflation and to better assist the unemployed.
The mantra for President Clinton's visit, Treasury officials say, is: more Russian reform in return for more Western money more quickly. 
 That approach is in marked contrast with the initial Administration reaction to the Dec. 12 elections in Russia, when both Vice President Al Gore and the Russian-affairs coordinator, Strobe Talbott, suggested easing Western conditions for reform to defuse opposition to President Boris N. Yeltsin. That view was strongly opposed by the Treasury Department and seems to have been firmly quashed.
Mr. Bentsen, who arrived in Moscow for economic talks ahead of President Clinton, told reporters afterward that the Russians had made progress in taming inflation and spawning many new private businesses. Inflation is running about 15 percent a month, about one-tenth the rate of a year ago.
But the next few days and weeks, he said, would be critical in determining whether President Yeltsin and the newly elected Parliament can carry out the sustainable structural changes necessary to receive more aid.
Mr. Yeltsin is still putting together his new Government, and Parliament is just getting organized. It is not clear yet whether advocates of reform will be assigned leading roles in the new cabinet and, even more important, whether the Parliament will be ready to authorize a sweeping budget reorganization.
The basic position articulated by Mr. Bentsen, relayed by a senior Treasury official and echoed at a news conference in Paris today by Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, is this: the West is ready to supply aid that has been promised and not yet delivered if Moscow offers "viable plans and clear and credible statements of intent" to realign its budget.
 
$23 Billion to Come
 What is new is that Washington will not insist on a waiting period to test implementation before money is delivered. Of the $28 billion in assistance promised to Russia last year by the Group of 7 industrial nations, only about $5 billion has been delivered.
That means, Mr. Bentsen said, that Moscow has to reduce inflation further. The only way to do that is to stop printing money to cover the budget deficit. And the only way to do that is to halt the broad subsidies to huge state industries like coal mining, tank factories and state farms; these subsidies account for much of the deficit.
After cutting the deficit in this way, Washigton wants Moscow to use the rest of the savings to help retrain and relocate workers who would lose their jobs and to pay pensions and unemployment insurance to cushion the political fallout.
Treasury officials say that just cushioning the workers without ending subsidies will only produce more inflation, and just cutting subsidies without cushioning the unemployed will only produce more Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky's, the nationalist leader whose allies made a strong showing in the elections.
Reaching Washington's goals, however, will require a wholesale revamping of this year's budget, which has not even been drafted.
"I think they are making some progress, but they have much more to do in so far as the social net and the reallocation of resources," Mr. Bentsen said. "The hard budget choice is going to be taking away some of the subsidies from these major industries. That is an enormous budgetary change and it will take a great deal of courage."
But if Russia can do that, he said, Washington's job would be "to see that the amount of money follows the progress that is being made in support of reform."

HEADLINE: Casinos Putting Tribes at Odds

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARICOPA, Ariz.

 BODY:
In a tiny museum on the Ak-Chin Indian reservation here, near displays of prehistoric pottery and stone tools, is a vision of the future -- a drawing of a glittering $28 million casino that will soon be built and managed for the tribe by the Harrah's division of Promus Companies Inc.
"When I saw the drawings it was like going to downtown Vegas or Reno and walking down the strip," said Martin Antone Sr., the tribe's chairman. "I could smell the money." 
 But that scent is proving elusive for the Gila River Indian Community, which hoped to build a $55 million casino and resort 15 miles away from here near the same desert road. The plan was dropped amid allegations of insider dealings by the tribe's governor -- claims that he vehemently denied. Now, in a bid to compete for this area's gambling bounty with the Ak-Chin, Gila (pronounced HE la) River officials plan to operate a temporary gambling hall in a vacant industrial building to help raise the money to build a casino.
More than 150 Indian tribes, or about one-half of those in the continental United States, have jumped into the gambling business on reservations or are poised to do so. But many tribes are discovering an unexpected source of competition -- each other. There is also a growing tension over who will reap the bulk of profits from Indian gaming: the tribes themselves or publicly traded gaming companies and others that are increasingly circling reservations eager to cash in on the bonanza.
"Everyone understands that competition is here," Mr. Antone said. "All the tribes are looking at each other, and they know they are in a footrace."
Some tribes have already seen large profits evaporate after opening casino doors. Recently, the Lower-Sioux tribe signed a consulting agreement with Harrah's Casino to develop new marketing strategies for its casino near Morton, Minn. The problem: an expansion of another tribe's casino closer to Minneapolis, a major source of customers.
"Two years ago, you could put up a few slot machines, and people would stand in line, but now the bar has been raised substantially," said Thomas Carr, the senior vice president of the Indian gaming division of Promus Companies, Memphis.
 
Federal Act Paved Way
 Although a few Indian tribes ran high-stakes bingo halls in the late 1970's, it was the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988 that opened the doors to Las Vegas-style casinos. Since then, at least 74 tribes in 18 states have signed agreements known as compacts to open reservation casinos, according to the National Indian Gaming Commission. Dozens more are likely to do so.
While Indian casinos generate only 5 percent of the gaming industry's total profit in the United States, or $900 million annually, that money is significant to hard-pressed tribes. The Gila River Community, which is 30 miles south of Phoenix, has an unemployment rate of 38 percent. And because of the economic benefits, other poor tribes like the Navajo, the nation's largest Indian group, have overturned laws barring casinos despite fears about gambling's social problems.
"Many of our people were concerned that those on welfare would run over to a casino with their government checks to win the big payout and end up going hungry," Duane Beyal, a Navajo spokesman, said.
To be sure, many tribes, like the Mashantucket Pequot, which operates Foxwoods' casino in Leynard, Conn., have reaped a bonanza from gambling. Even before a recent expansion of the casino, bettors were putting down as much as $3 million on a busy weekend day. Some groups have dispened profits directly to tribal members or plowed them into services like housing and education.
 
Gaming Companies Involved
 Even the giant gaming companies that light up Atlantic City and Las Vegas, once opposed to Indian gaming, now see opportunities. Many have signed or sought agreements with dozens of tribes over the past year. They have flown Indian leaders to Las Vegas, extended loans of as much as $75 million to build casino complexes on reservations and offered links with powerful industry names like Harrah's, Caesars World and Showboat Casino.
Yet some Indian groups have rejected alliances with gaming companies, viewing them as carpetbaggers.
"We don't need a lot of high-flouting millionaires that come in here and rip you off," said Theodore Smith Sr., the chairman of the Yavapai-Apache tribe in Camp Verde, Ariz.
For example, the Wisconsin Winnebago tribe fell into near-bankruptcy during the 20 months that its casinos were managed by a corrupt businessman who pleaded guilty in June to Federal charges of bribing tribal officials to retain a lucrative contract and is now in prison.
 
Opportunity or Exploitation?
 "Gambling offers Indian nations the best promise for a good life since before Columbus came," said William Thompson, a professor of public administration at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. "Yet it could easily turn into just another opportunity for exploitation by outsiders."
Some Indian leaders, in fact, have joined forces with publicly traded companies in hope of protecting themselves against fraud while winning financially, too. Earlier this year, for instance, the St. Regis Mohawk, whose reservation is in Horgansburg, N.Y., about 200 miles from Montreal, Toronto and Quebec City, found themselves courted by a number of management companies including President Riverboat Casino Inc. and Showboat Casinos, John S. Loran, a tribal chief, said.
In a bidding war for the site, President Riverboat agreed to pay $1 million for the right to build a $13 million casino and to a seven-year contract under which its take would be only 30 percent of the profits for five years and 20 percent during the remaining two years, Mr. Loran said.
Under Federal rules that regulate contracts between management companies and Indian tribes, a company that invests substantially in a reservation casino can receive up to 40 percent of its profits for seven years.
"We like to think that we are pretty good businessmen up here in Mohawk country," Mr. Loran said.
 
Latecomers in Arizona
 The Ak-Chin and Gila River are both latecomers. In the Phoenix area, the Fort McDowell tribe operates a large casino. At least 10 of Arizona's 21 tribes have signed gambling compacts with state officials to permit reservation gaming, and more tribes are preparing to do so.
With little time to spare, Mr. Antone said the Ak-Chin, a small tribe of 500 who have eked out a living growing cotton, decided to join forces with Harrah's, the only large casino company that expressed interest. Neither Mr. Antone nor Harrah's officials would disclose the terms of the deal, which is subject to approval by Federal regulators, a process that could take months. Then, Mr. Antone said he hoped Harrah's could build the casino in only six months.
While corporate executives had proposed calling the Moorish-style structure "The Oasis of the Desert," Mr. Antone said he preferred "Harrah's of Ak-Chin."
"I think the name alone will bring people in," he said.
But just down the road, the Gila River, a tribe of 11,000, has found itself in the uncomfortable role of playing catch-up after dropping a plan for Mirage Resorts Inc. to build a far larger casino with hotel rooms, a golf course and bowling alleys.
 
Gila River Conflict
 The decision followed a heated conflict between Thomas R. White, the tribe's former governor and former manager of economic development, Ammar Halloum, whom Mr. White dismissed last January. Mr. Halloum accused Mr. White of pushing the Mirage plan because he would personally benefit from it. He also claimed in a recent interview that Mr. White had offered him $30,000 to back the Mirage plan, which he thought was unfavorable to the tribe, because the casino's costs would be recouped from the tribe's profits.
Both Mirage officials and Mr. White vehemently deny any wrongdoing. And Mr. White said he dismissed Mr. Halloum for problems unrelated to the Mirage plan. He also said that Mr. Halloum had independently sought deals with management companies and had offered to make kickbacks to Mr. White if he were made the casino's purchasing manager.
"He said he would make me comfortable for the rest of my life," Mr. White said. Mr. Halloum, who sued Mr. White and the tribe in November contending he was wrongfully dismissed, denied the allegation.
Whatever occurred, the Gila River's tribal council decided this summer to forgo the Mirage plan, which the company projected would generate an annual payroll of $39 million and net revenues of $85.5 million before depreciation and interest cost related to construction.
"People got scared that Mirage would just swallow us up," Mary V. Thomas, the tribe's governor, said.
 
Avoiding Outside Investors
 Instead, the tribe will open an interim gambling hall in a vacant building in a reservation industrial park and get training in running it from Little Six Inc., a consulting company owned by the Shakopee Mdewakanton Dakota Community, which runs the highly successful Mystic Lake Casino in Prior Lake, Minn.
Ms. Thomas said she hoped that construction of Gila River's permanent $30 million casino would be completed by December. Some gaming consultants believe that the tribe, if successful, will be far better off than groups like the Ak-Chin that split their earnings with outsiders.
Both Ak-Chin and Gila River leaders said they expected their competition to be friendly and hope there will be enough customers to go around. But as she pondered her neighbors, Ms. Thomas remained worried that her tribe's dissension had cost it valuable time.
"We are losing money every day," she said.

HEADLINE: Winter Pulls Up a Chair and Stays;
Yesterday's Snow Adds to the Burden on Municipal Budgets

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY

 BODY:
Months from now, when hearts are light with spring and this awful, icy mess of winter is just a vague memory, the imprint of the weather of 1994 will still be visible on the bottom line.
Governments across the region, charged with making life livable despite the elements, are reporting that the two storms of January are putting a strain on their snow-removal budgets. 
 New York City has already spent more than the $10 million it budgeted for the current year, and yesterday it began hiring hundreds of temporary workers to shovel out storm drains at street corners so that the ice and snow does not lead to flooding.
"In these tough budgetary times it's always a problem, but these are the dictates of nature." said Anne Canty, assistant commissioner of the City Department of Sanitation.
More snow fell yesterday and forecasters said the region could see additional flurries tomorrow. Just to keep things interesting, an arctic front from Canada is headed toward the northwest Great Lakes region and is expected to reach the New York area on Friday night, promising a weekend of temperatures in the single digits.
With yesterday's snowfall, a total of 12 inches of snow has been recorded in Central Park this winter, about 4 inches more than average for this time, said Lee Grenci, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. Last year at this time, less than an inch of snow had fallen, though by the end of the season, 24.6 inches had fallen, including 10 inches during the blizzard in March. The average annual snowfall for New York City is 25 inches, he said.
Beyond the financial effects on hard-pressed local governments, yesterday's snow meant another round of disruptions for commuters and other travelers.
La Guardia Airport was closed for about three and a half hours yesterday afternoon, delaying or canceling more than 100 flights, said John Kempfe, a Port Authority spokesman. The airport reopened at 6 P.M.
The Westchester Airport closed shortly after 4 P.M. and reopened at 9, according to the airport manager, Joel Russell.
"It was pretty intense at one point in the day," Mr. Kempfe said, referring to the four inches of snow at the airport. "They were getting one inch an hour and that was too much for them to keep up with."
 
Minor Delays for Commuters
 Most commuters heading home on buses from the Port Authority Bus Terminal experienced only minor delays, though officials said some buses to northwestern New Jersey encountered longer holdups because accumulations there were greater.
The weather caused other interruptions. Mail was not delivered to houses at which sidewalks were too icy, said Thomas E. Gaynor, a spokesman for the Postal Service in New York City. He said between 5 and 10 percent of homes did not receive mail for that reason. "We know what the motto is, and we're out there making every attempt to deliver the mail, but safety is a priority and if it's unsafe we tell the carriers to use their judgment," he said.
On Long Island, Jay Rawley, a physician's assistant in the emergency room at Hudson Valley Hospital Center in Peekskill, said there have been more broken bones, sprains and bruises as a result of "a ton of car accidents and falling-type injuries from people walking on ice."
For all the beauty of the flakes and the annoyance caused by the conditions, the most lasting effect of the weather is likely to be financial.
 
Nassau's Expensive Month
 Nassau County spent one-third of its $650,000 snow-removal budget during the first 12 days of the year, said a county spokesman, Dave Vieser. The county overspent its snow budget last year and is likely to again this year, he said. "Snow removal is an absolutely essential service for the safety of residents and no matter what the situation is with the budget, we will continue to clear the roads," Mr. Vieser said.
In Connecticut, Louis Malerba, the assistant director of maintenance for the Connecticut Department of Transportation, said half of the state's $17 million snow-removal budget for the year is already spent. "It's costing us more than we expected," Mr. Malerba said.
"We had a rough week last week," he said.
The New Jersey Department of Transportation has spent $6.2 million of the $10 million it expected to spend on snow-removal this year keeping state roads clear. Rick Remington, a spokesman, said the department does not set a budget figure for snow-removal costs. "You really can't budget snow, because each winter is so different from the next winter," Mr. Remington said. "It's really like predicting the weather."
Predicting the snow budget can be even more difficult.
In New York City, for example, the budget is set by taking an average of the snow-removal expenditures for the last five years. But that calculation excludes the year in which the budget is being prepared, because that budget year is not over when the next year's budget is being set.
Therefore, this year's $10.1 million snow-removal budget is based on the amount spent in fiscal years 1988 through 1992, all years that were unusually mild with light snowfall.
"All those mild winters when we didn't spend our entire budgets are coming home to roost," said Ms. Canty of the Sanitation Department.
Last year, with $11 million budgeted for snow removal, the city ended up spending $23 million, mostly as a result of the March blizzard. So far this year, the city has already spent $11 million, about $1 million more than budgeted.
The current round of snow and ice has brought out all the Department of Sanitation has to offer: 173,000 tons of salt at $36.03 a ton, 350 salt and sand spreaders and more than 1,000 trucks with plows.
Since last Friday, the city has spent $1.5 million in overtime keeping sanitation crews working virtually around the clock to remove the snow and ice and to try to catch up on garbage collection, which was delayed by snow removal.
Yesterday, the city hired 560 day laborers to clear storm drains, fire hydrants and bus stops.
James Robbins, 27, who was working yesterday on Lenox Avenue in Harlem, said he had been unemployed for two years. He said he was happy to have the work. "I was looking for a job anyway," he said. "I wish we could do it for longer."
Beyond governments, the costs of the snow to businesses in lost time and lost customers is difficult to calculate.
"There is a real cost, but it isn't one we ever end up counting," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "You end up operating, but with a little strain. It becomes part of the cost of doing business in the winter."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Reflecting a dive in the oil market, prices at the producer level edged down one-tenth of a percent in December while inflation for all of 1993 came close to the vanishing point, Government figures showed today.
The bond market rallied strongly on the report, pushing long-term interest rates down to 6.18 percent, the lowest in five weeks, as many credit market analysts concluded that the economy was growing at a slower-than-expected pace. [Page D16.] 
 Still, many economists concluded upon close scrutiny of the inflation report that it was as unnerving in some of its detail as it was reassuring on the surface.
 
Some Find Inflation
 "There was a certain glow," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities in New York. "But when you penetrate the oil slick, what you find is that there is some inflation."
Not counting a 3.5 percent drop in the price of energy last month -- gasoline prices alone were down 10.4 percent -- prices received by producers for finished goods climbed five-tenths of a percent for the second straight month. Energy accounts for just under 14 percent of the Producer Price Index.
Analysts also pointed to sizable jumps in the prices of various goods at earlier stages of production, including copper and other metals sensitive to a pickup in demand, and a 2.4 percent surge in raw materials other than food and energy.
"Price pressures are starting to appear in a variety of clusters," said Robert F. Dieli, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "These can be the forerunners of inflation."
But even as they suggested the report was not as good as it first appeared, analysts said the Federal Reserve remained unlikely to raise interest rates soon as a pre-emptive strike against revived inflation, a step it is thought to favor.
"This kind of report would forestall Fed tightening," said Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. He and others believe that although the economy turned in a strong fourth quarter, the Fed lacks the pretext for tightening in the face of favorable inflation headlines and repeated contentions by the Clinton Administration and Congressional Democrats that there is no need for higher interest rates.
The finished-goods index has now advanced in only one of the latest eight months, a two-tenths of a percent rise in September.
Today's report also showed that the so-called core inflation rate -- excluding food and energy -- rose just four-tenths of a percent for the full year, the smallest increase since it was first formally calculated in 1974. The core, which rose two-tenths of a percent last month, has now also declined for two consecutive quarters, an unprecedented development.
 
Food Prices Climb
 Partly offsetting the drop in energy prices last month was an acceleration in the price of food, which surged 1.1 percent after an eight-tenths of a percent jump in November.
Much of this reflected a 40 percent leap for fresh vegetables that including a more than tripling in the price of spinach and increases of more than 50 percent for tomatoes and sweet corn. Fresh fruit also rose faster than in November but beef and veal, processed fruits and vegetables and bakery products turned down, while milled products rose less than 6 percent after increases of more than 20 percent in October and November.
Makers of passenger cars, with new-found pricing power, enjoyed a six-tenths of a percent gain last month while a 1.7 percent increase was little consolation for tobacco producers who saw prices for the full year shrink by 22.4 percent.
Goods at the intermediate level of production, like a bolt of cloth or sack of flour, eased two-tenths of a percent last month but rose by that amount when food and energy are excluded.
Analysts fretted particularly about a 1.1 percent burst, the biggest since February, in the price of durable materials, like metals, used in manufacturing. After declining in November, prices turned up for hot rolled steel bars, sheet and strip; copper cathode, aluminum mill shapes and primary aluminum.
On the other hand, chemicals and other nondurables used in manufacturing fell five-tenths of a percent last month, weaker than November's three-tenths of a percent drop.
Crude, or raw material, prices dropped 2.2 percent over all last month but this was heavily affected by energy, down 8.9 percent for the month and 13.7 percent for the year.
Raw materials other than food and energy -- about one-fifth of the index -- jumped 2.4 percent after rising 1.7 percent in November and nine-tenths of a percent in October.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vons Opens Store in City Torn by Riots

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COMPTON, Calif., Jan. 12

 BODY:
Making good on a promise to invest in riot-torn neighborhoods in the Los Angeles area, the Vons Companies, the largest supermarket operator in Southern California, opened the first of 12 new low-income area stores today in this city known for violent crime and "gangsta" rappers.
The Compton Vons -- which has a First Interstate Bank branch, pharmacy, dry cleaners, delicatessen and bakery -- is the first full-service supermarket to open in an area 20 miles south of Los Angeles that was ravaged by riots in 1992. During the riots, the Compton Renaissance Plaza shopping center, where the new Vons is situated, had to be protected by dozens of police officers as angry mobs attempted to loot and burn it. 
 Since the riots, hundreds of companies, including Vons, have pledged their support to help revitalize inner-city areas through job training programs, donations of equipment and personnel, and construction of new businesses.
Vons, based in Arcadia, Calif., plans to spend more than $100 million to build 12 stores in low-income areas of Los Angeles. The company is expanding into the inner city at a time when its sales are slipping, hurt by an economic downturn and stiff price-cutting by competitors and wholesale grocery clubs.
Gary Giblen, an analyst for Paine Webber, said, "The inner-city strategy makes sense because Vons is going into underserved markets. It will work because people in poor areas like nice stores just like everyone else."
 
A Third-Quarter Loss
 Vons operates 350 stores under the Vons, Pavillions, Tianguis, Williams Bros. and Expo names, most of them in the suburbs. It reported a loss of $20.9 million in the third quarter ended Oct. 10. The results included a restructuring charge of $56.9 million. Sales were down in the quarter, to $1.5 billion, from $1.6 billion in the comparable period a year ago.
In November, Vons announced a cost-cutting plan, including laying off 250 workers and closing 11 unprofitable stores. The company also said it would eliminate executives' company cars and freeze administrative salaries.
But company officials said the inner city had great potential because it was grossly underserved. As many as 1.2 million people in South Central Los Angeles do not have access to a supermarket, Vons said.
"Inner-city residents don't want just another rundown Boys Market," Mr. Giblen of Paine Webber said, referring to a rival supermarket. "They want a first-class store."
Analysts said the foray by Vons into the inner city was fraught with risks, mainly the potential for crime and vandalism that could drive away customers. Still, the analysts said Vons had a good chance of succeeding because there was less competition.
Julie Reynolds, a spokeswoman for Vons, said the company had reduced the risks of operating in a high-crime area like Compton by hiring workers from the community and making sure the store had enough security.
