HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fixing air traffic control with a new corporate management.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT'S 5 P.M. on Thursday, and you are sardined into a sleek jet capable of whisking you from Miami to New York in time for "Seinfeld." But with air controllers lacking up-to-date equipment already straining to keep track of the hundreds of planes aloft, it will be another hour before take-off. And you aren't the only frustrated traveler this night or many others. And your frustration represents big bucks to the airlines: between 1988 and 1992, the number of hours flown daily by the average airliner actually fell by one-fifth.
Is this any way to run an air traffic control system? Not if the White House has anything to say about it. Acting surprisingly swiftly on a recommendation from the National Commission to Ensure a Strong Competitive Airline Industry (who names these things?), the Clinton Administration proposed last week to create a Government-owned corporation to manage the system. 
 The proposal has been cautiously seconded by almost everyone except those who stand to lose authority in the shuffle. Clifford Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution, is merely more outspoken than most when he describes the F.A.A.'s record as "the best-kept secret of mismanagement in Government." Still, getting from here to there will be not be a breeze.
The Administration is committed to presenting a plan for corporatizing the F.A.A.'s air traffic control responsibilities by April. While no details have been offered, the best guess now is that the corporation would be financed entirely with user fees and run by an independent board with only limited oversight by Congress. But no one is contemplating a self-policing air safety system: The F.A.A., notes Daniel Kasper, a consultant at Harbridge House in Boston who was a member of the airline commission, would almost certainly retain power to enforce standards for planes, pilots and controllers.
What would be gained? Robert Poole, the head of the libertarian Reason Foundation in Los Angeles, argues that at minimum, the system would be freed from the constraints on capital spending, imposed by Washington as part of its continuing effort to cut the muscle rather than the fat from the Federal budget. In many years, he notes, the F.A.A. spending authority has been far less than the sum collected in ticket taxes.
Corporatization would also loosen the Civil Service straightjacket that now makes it almost impossible to keep the right people in the right jobs. The idea would be to match supply and demand, paying air controllers at a high-pressure post like O'Hare whatever it takes to recruit the best.
Not least, corporatization would break the grip of procurement rules that prevent timely purchases of new technology: current air traffic modernization plans are three to five years behind schedule, and counting. "The F.A.A. has more vacuum tubes than any other Federal agency," jokes Alfred Kahn, the former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.
What could go awry? Clark Onstad, the F.A.A.'s chief counsel in the Carter Administration, worries that a casually managed divorce between the agency and air traffic control would do more harm than good. In particular, he is concerned that the corporation and agency would fail to coordinate critical decisions in training and technology. Worse, perhaps, he fears that Congress would retain sufficient power to micro-manage the corporation without being accountable for the system's failings. "The issue is control," he says.
This may be putting the cart before the horse. The first task is lining up sufficient support -- or at least dividing the opposition sufficiently -- to get a favorable judgment on corporatization from Capitol Hill. The airlines are apparently solidly behind the proposal, as are good government types: academics, policy wonks and former regulators who do most of the thinking about aviation policy. But the Administration will have to devise a strategy for placating other interests.
One potential obstacle is the powerful general aviation lobby, nonairline users of the system, in particular, owners of small aircraft. They would not easily make way for new managers who see their primary job as serving airlines and airline passengers.
Mr. Kasper suggests that single-engine aircraft owners could be pacified with the formal promise they would be asked to pay for air traffic control only when they use it -- and then only for the extra cost of accommodating them. This could be rationalized as good economics as well as good politics, he argues, since small planes are a minor burden on traffic control. By the same token, Mr. Kasper wonders whether the F.A.A. bureaucracy and its allies in Congress could not be bought off with more secure financing for the agency's remaining duties.
Corporatization won't turn lead to gold. Indeed, Mr. Kahn wonders whether in the best of worlds "it might be worth going all the way to privatization," transforming the system into Federal Express rather than the Post Office. In this world, however, Mr. Kahn and others concede, corporatization may be the only way to dig the air traffic control system out of its rut.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation Report Buoys Long Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
With another sign that inflation remains under control, investors rushed to buy the Treasury's 30-year bond yesterday. Prices of the long end of the market outperformed the shorter maturities.
The release of wholesale price data for December, the first of this month's inflation reports, were particularly well received by the long end of the market, where the price of the 30-year bond increased much more than short-term and intermediate-term securities. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of a percent over all and rose two-tenths of a percent in the core inflation rate, which excludes the more volatile food and energy components. Analysts said the numbers were what many market participants had expected.
 
Pressure Off Fed
 The numbers helped to further reduce investor fears that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates anytime soon since the economy is growing but at a pace that is slower than the market had expected. 
 The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.18 percent, its lowest level since Dec. 9, when it was 6.15 percent. By late in the day, the long bond was trading at a price of 1011/32 , up 26/32 .
But while the producer price numbers were in line with general expectations, the report was actually a mixed bag of news.
It also reinforced the message sent last week through a modest rise in December nonfarm payrolls, that the economy appears to be growing at a steady pace.
The energy component, which came down more than anticipated, 3.5 percent, led the improvement in prices. But it does leave the market wondering how much longer energy can carry the ball.
"There were people who accumulated cash and speculators who were growing increasingly negative on the bond market," said John P. Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at CS First Boston. "But on Friday the psychology was short-circuited with a moderate December jobs number."
"Given the information we've gotten so far," he continued, "we feel the market has probably overreacted to these numbers because of the pent-up demand for Treasuries, which is reaching levels hard to sustain without further evidence of a weakening economy."
Today's economic numbers include the second leg of this month's inflation news -- the Consumer Price Index. The consensus of economists calls for an increase of two-tenths of a percent.
While the producer price data and lower commodity prices no doubt contributed to yesterday's rally, analysts at MMS International say these reasons cannot be seen as the primary factors behind the market's strength.
"The P.P.I. has been well contained for months," the firm said. "In fact, the market's resiliency shows there is strong conviction that noninflationary economic growth can continue."
 
Municipal Bonds Gain
 Activity in the municipal market was described by Michael S. Appelbaum, a first vice president and municipal bond specialist at Merrill Lynch, as lagging behind the government market, but with strong investor demand because of lower inflation. "However, the real focus of the muni market is in supply, which will be less with fewer refundings this year than last," Mr. Appelbaum said. "Higher taxes this year over last make the outlook for municipals very attractive."
Municipal issues were up about 1/4 point in price in firm trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Report on Producer Prices Sends the Dollar Tumbling

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against most leading currencies yesterday after a Government report suggested that inflation was too low to encourage the Federal Reserve to tighten credit.
Sharp declines in energy prices helped push American producer prices down one-tenth of a percent in December. Excluding the volatile food and energy components, prices rose just two-tenths of a percent. 
 The benign price data dampened lingering speculation that the Federal Reserve soon would raise interest rates to keep the economy from heating up too quickly. Lower interest rates in the United States tend to make dollar-denominated assets less attractive.
"Now everybody's figuring the Fed will hold off at least until the end of the first quarter," said Paul Alley, foreign exchange dealer at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan in New York.
Prices of Treasury securities surged after the report on producer prices was released, depressing interest rates and encouraging dollar sales.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 112.25 Japanese yen, from 112.47 on Tuesday. It also fell to 1.7335 German marks from 1.7410.
Gold, an inflation hedge, also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, lost $1.80 to settle at $386.90 an ounce.
Many currency dealers said, however, that they still thought the dollar was on an upward trend because of expectations that American economic growth would outpace that of other countries, particularly Germany. And even if American interest rates fail to rise, German rates are almost certain to fall more, they said.
Persistent reports that European central banks were selling dollars for marks helped keep the dollar in check, dealers said. While most believed the banks were buying marks to shore up reserves and not to depress the dollar, they said the end effect was the same. Once these sales dry up, the dollar could resume its upward trend, they said.
A surprisingly large fall in the British unemployment rate in December encouraged purchases of the British pound, which already had been rising steadily against the battered mark. The pound closed in New York at $1.5040, much higher than late Tuesday's $1.4895.

HEADLINE: U.S. Can Help Stop the Land-Mine Slaughter;
Deadly Legacy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The banning of antipersonnel mines throughout the world is a worthy long-run goal. 
 In the Western Hemisphere, years of armed struggle in Central America have left this deadly legacy, not only in countries where war was waged, but also in neighboring ones. The Organization of American States is engaged in extensive mine removal in Nicaragua, where demining platoons trained by us are working to clear 112,000 mines over two years. The project will be expanded to Honduras this year and then to Costa Rica, at the request of their governments.
The Organization of American States General Assembly established a special fund in 1992 to channel contributions for technical assistance in Central American mine removal projects. The United States has made important financial contributions and has helped with equipment and training. Support for this humanitarian effort has come in financial contributions and medical supplies from France, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, the Russian Federation, Spain and Sweden, all holding permanent observer status in the organization.
More than 100 Nicaraguan soldiers, trained, supervised and supported by military personnel from Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Guatemala, Honduras, Peru, the United States and Uruguay, are using the latest methods to remove unmarked mines from some of Nicaraguan's most fertile lands, which have gone untilled for years in fear of these deadly remnants of the civil war that ended in 1990.
The Organization of American States, with the technical support of the Inter-American Defense Board, is coordinating this activity, which is vital to the peace, stability and economic recovery of the region as a whole.
 
JORGE BARBOSA
Director, Dept. of Public Information
Organization of American States
Washington, Jan. 5, 1994

HEADLINE: Ukrainian Agrees to Dismantle A-Arms

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Jan. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton extended his hand here tonight to a Ukrainian President he had shunned, and Leonid Kravchuk returned the gesture with his first public endorsement of a three-way accord requiring Ukraine to surrender its nuclear weapons.
A joint appearance by the Presidents after an airport meeting tonight appeared to put to rest the last doubts about whether the agreement would indeed be signed on Friday in Moscow, as Russia and the United States announced with considerable hullabaloo at the beginning of the week. 
 But there remain enormous doubts whether President Kravchuk can win sufficient support for the accord from the new Ukrainian parliament, to be elected in March, and from his own cabinet.
 
The Fuzziness That Remains
 Administration officials insist the agreement was never in peril, despite assertions by Ukrainian officials on Tuesday that details remained incomplete. But it took a special stopover by President Clinton on his journey from Prague to Moscow to win President Kravchuk's commitment.
At a joint news conference in the hangar-like Borispol Airport terminal after the two men had talked for 100 minutes, Mr. Kravchuk never quite said that he would sign the agreement. Nor did he pledge unequivocally to rid Ukraine of its entire arsenal of 1,800 warheads.
But he spoke of "the wish of the three states" that the agreement be carried out and said, "Ukraine will be a state which will not stand in the way of disarmament."
Barring any last-minute breakdown, the deal will now be formally approved when the two leaders join President Boris N. Yeltsin on Friday.
[President Clinton arrived in Moscow early Thursday for two days of meetings with Mr. Yeltsin. He was greeted in a light snow at the airport by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin before heading to his hotel.]
 
Support for 'Partnership'
 Earlier today in Prague, Mr. Clinton won a warm if not wholehearted embrace from four Eastern European heads of state for his plan to forge a loose partnership between their countries and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. President Lech Walesa of Poland, who had been a stern critic of the arrangement, not only relented but asked Mr. Clinton to visit Poland this summer. Mr. Clinton accepted.
While some reiterated their aspirations for more formal association, the leaders of the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia all indicated that they would enlist in the plan, which Washington calls a Partnership for Peace. Mr. Clinton said he was convinced the region would take its place "at the heart of a new Europe, an integrated Europe, prosperous, secure and free."
Tonight, in Kiev, Mr. Clinton reaffirmed that Ukraine would also be eligible to join the partnership. He also said his meeting with Mr. Kravchuk would open "a new era in our relations," and invited him to visit Washington in March.
 
Gist of the Agreement
 As outlined by United States officials, the arms accord calls for Ukraine to get rid of its 176 long-range missiles and all the nuclear warheads, most of which are aimed at the United States, within seven years. The arms are a hold-over from the days when much of the Soviet strategic force was stationed in Ukraine.
Under the accord, Ukraine would ship the warheads to Russia, where the uranium would be extracted and sold for nuclear reactors around the world.
The proceeds, estimated at $12 billion over 20 years, would be returned to Russia, which would share them with Ukraine and two other former Soviet republics, Belarus and Kazakhstan, that have also given up their nuclear weapons. Ukraine would receive an estimated $1 billion, in the form of fuel rods for its nuclear-energy program.
As part of the deal, the United States has promised Ukraine $176 million in aid to dismantle the weapons and $155 million in financial aid, which could be doubled this year if Kiev commits itself to economic reform.
 
A Little Help From His Friend
 Until tonight, Mr. Kravchuk had not spoken about the accord in public, and some of Ukraine's main newspapers made no mention of it even today.
In adding a Ukrainian visit to Mr. Clinton's itinerary, Administration officials said, they had recognized that Mr. Kravchuk needed the show of support that only Mr. Clinton could deliver. Mr. Clinton sought to give that support by saying repeatedly that the United States stood ready to increase substantially its economic support and encourage other Western countries to do so.
But when asked what security commitments the United States would offer to Ukraine in return for its surrender of nuclear weapons, he did little more than repeat the blanket assurances provided to all countries that sign the Nuclear Nonproliferation Agreement.
 
The Early Word
 President Clinton's decision to announce the deal on Monday had somewhat complicated Mr. Kravchuk's task of winning support at home.
Administration officials said they had hoped to give President Kravchuk until today before all three leaders made the accord public, a delay intended to allow the Ukrainian leader time to overcome reservations within his Government. But they said Mr. Clinton's hand had been forced by a Russian declaration earlier on Monday.
"What Kravchuk needed was Clinton's presence to reaffirm Ukraine's status as a full partner in this deal," an Administration official said. But other officials acknowledged that Mr. Clinton's announcement of a follow-up visit to Washington and his mention of the prospect of increased financial aid were intended as sweeteners.
 
'Sometimes Small Is Beautiful'
 In Prague, President Clinton was told by President Vaclav Havel that the Czech Republic, for one, would continue to seek full membership in NATO as security against the threat of a revanchist Russia.
But none of the four East European leaders expressed open dissatisfaction with the more modest offer by Washington, and President Walesa, who has been one of the most forceful critics of the partial association, said today, "Sometimes small is beautiful."
More than 50 years after the great powers' meeting in Yalta in 1943, a meeting that has come to symbolize the division of Europe, President Havel said he hoped the talks in Prague would one day be seen as an emblem of Europe's coming together in alliance.
 
Inching Toward Alliance
 While President Clinton did not single out any candidates or provide a timetable on when others might join the alliance, he was more explicit than NATO has been in describing the "partnership" as a way station.
"While the partnership is not NATO membership, neither is it a permanent holding room," Mr. Clinton said after he and the four leaders emerged from their luncheon in the United States Ambassador's residence. "It changes the entire NATO dialogue, so that now the question is no longer whether NATO will take on new members, but when and how."
The leaders who met with Mr. Clinton today included Mr. Havel, Mr. Walesa and the Presidents of Hungary and Slovakia, Arpad Goncz and Michal Kovac. Only Mr. Clinton, Mr. Havel and Mr. Walesa spoke at the afternoon news conference.
But each of the four has said his country would join the partnership, and Mr. Clinton said none had pressed him directly for stronger immediate security guarantees.
 
Visit to a Cemetery
 Before their talks, Mr. Clinton paid a somber visit to memorials to Prague's nearly extinct Jewish communities, including the Pinkas Synagogue. There, the names of the 77,297 Jews from the Czech lands of Bohemia and Moravia who were killed in the Holocaust are again being inscribed on the wall after being erased by Czechoslovak Government when it broke relations with Israel after the 1967 War.
Wearing a gray yarmulke, the President was also guided through the Old Jewish Cemetery, where 90,000 bodies are buried under headstones erected between 1389 and 1787 and in graves that in places lie 12 deep.
Surrounded by bare-limbed trees, Mr. Clinton said little during his half-hour stay, but Richard Schifter, a National Security Council official whose parents were killed in the Holocaust, said the President had been moved by the scene.

HEADLINE: Whitman Rejects Plan to Land Sixers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman today offered early proof of her promise to be frugal with the taxpayers' money by rejecting a plan to move the faltering Philadelphia 76ers professional basketball franchise to the Camden waterfront.
The costs of building a new 530,000-square-foot arena, as calculated by the project's sponsor, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, were too imprecise and unsettled, Mrs. Whitman said. The project's backers also shifted their ground on important questions of land ownership and the share of development costs to be paid by Camden County, she said. Ultimately, Mrs. Whitman said, taxpayers could end up responsible for $100 million in underperforming construction bonds and state income guarantees to the Sixers. 
 "I have a certain standard, and whether it is a little more risk-averse than others remains to be seen," Mrs. Whitman said at the announcement of her decision at her transition offices here today. "But I have certain levels of satisfaction with the data that I require, and they just weren't met."
She said she would apply similarly stringent financial tests to another major sports franchise that is making feelers about moving to New Jersey: the New York Yankees.
"I understand that risks have to be taken, and I am perfectly prepared to take risks," she said to the prospect of luring the Yankees from the Bronx. "I'm just not going to take fliers with my eyes closed."
 
Florio Reacts With DismayXxx
 Gov. Jim Florio, who leaves office on Tuesday, helped put together the proposed Sixers deal as a boon to the South Jersey cradle of his political career, and he reacted to Mrs. Whitman's decision with dismay, calling it "a mistake." The deal requires action by the Legislature, whose Republican majority leaders would not act without the agreement of their new Governor and fellow Republican.
Harold Katz, who owns the team, faces a Feb. 1 lease expiration at the 76ers' present arena, the Spectrum in Philadelphia. He has been dickering with Philadelphia to build a new arena for years, and critics of the move to Camden have accused him of having used Camden's hunger for new development amid the ruins of a faded industrial past as a lever against Philadelphia's reluctance to build a site for his team.
"Naturally I do not agree with this decision and believe strongly that it is not in the best interests of the State of New Jersey, the City of Camden, or Camden County," Mr. Katz said in a statement released a few hours after Mrs. Whitman's announcement.
And Camden's Mayor, Arnold W. Webster, who lamented the collapse of the plan today, has said he would continue to seek a way to settle the basketball team in his city.
Mrs. Whitman did not rule out changing her mind on a Camden arena if a better plan, with less risk to taxpayer dollars, is developed. Mr. Katz made it plain that he would persist with the plan, which was first raised during the administration of Thomas H. Kean in the 1980's.
Mr. Katz argued that if the plan had the approval of both Gov. Florio and former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who started talks on a 76ers' move to this state, it should be good enough for Mrs. Whitman, and he accused her of refusing to negotiate seriously and give him a chance to respond to her concerns.
 
Estimate of Guarantee
 Mrs. Whitman has said ever since the prospect of a new Camden arena became her responsibility last month that she would not approve the state's guaranteeing construction bonds for a new arena, through the Sports and Exposition Authority, unless she were satisfied that the building would generate enough money to cover its operating costs and debt amortization.
The details of the proposed arena and its surrounding improvements have not been made public, but published reports, along with consultants hired by the ownership of the Spectrum, who oppose the deal, say that the state and Camden County would have to guarantee a total of $144 million in land acquisition, improvement and construction bonds, as well as guarantee a minimum $7 million annual income to the 76ers.
Throughout Mrs. Whitman's deliberations on the arena project, Mr. Katz and Mr. Florio have portrayed it as an investment that would pay for itself, if only in added tourism and related expenses in South Jersey.
But Robert Bodde, a professor of economics at Lake Forest University and an expert in the economics of sports franchises, said that sports teams do not usually cover the costs of their publicly financed stadiums, and that what spending they do draw is usually taken from some other area of the economy.
"There is almost no instance where stadiums pay for themselves," he said. "The rationale that cities use to build them anyway is the economic spillover that occurs -- people staying in hotels, eating in restaurants and buying gas and so on. They treat sports spending is if it were all new spending coming in, and it's not. Sports spending often substitutes for spending that people would quite probably engage in anyway, if that sports team were not in town."
 
Accountant and Rock Star
 Mrs. Whitman displayed the eclectic learning pattern that has been a hallmark of her transition to reach her decision. She turned to Arthur Anderson & Company, the accounting firm, for income projections, and to a backstage chat with her friend and supporter Jon Bon Jovi, the New Jersey rock star, for testimony that a new Camden arena would compete with the group's Philadelphia venues.
Mrs. Whitman also complained that the terms of the plan shifted several times during her review, giving the impression that the project's backers were themselves unsettled.
For example, she said she was told on Dec. 19 that of $40 million in land and improvement costs, $15 million would come from the Delaware River Port Authority and the Sports Authority. But those sources of funds recently vanished and, Mrs. Whitman said, nearly all the cost would be borne by Camden County.
In addition, outside experts consulted by Mrs. Whitman disputed the $85 million construction cost presented by the Sports Authority, saying the cost would be closer to $90 million.
"To the extent the cost of construction exceeds the projection, taxpayer dollars are at risk," she said in a prepared part of today's conference.
Dr. Bodde, the sports economist, said today that while voters often rejected referendums on bonds to build stadiums -- as New Jerseyans did over a baseball stadium proposal in 1987 -- it was unusual for an elected official to stand in the way of raiding another state for a team.
"Getting a new team is is something that elected officials generally are excited about," he said. "A lot of them have bought into the idea that you aren't major league until you have major league sports. Cities with teams are assumed to be cities on the rise instead of cities on decline."

HEADLINE: Police in Oregon Make Arrests In Assault on Olympic Skater

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Tonya Harding's bodyguard and another man were arrested tonight by the Multnomah County Sheriff's Department in connection with the attack on the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan.
Shawn Eric Eckardt, 26, a 350-pound bodyguard with a past criminal history, and Derrick B. Smith, a 29-year-old unemployed resident of Phoenix, were each charged with one count of conspiracy to commit assault, a felony. They were held on $20,000 bail each. 
 More arrests were expected, but officials said there were no immediate plans to arrest or charge Miss Harding, a longtime skating rival of Miss Kerrigan.
 
Kerrigan Granted Spot on Team
 Miss Kerrigan was clubbed on the knee after a practice session at the United States Figure Skating Championships in Detroit and was unable to compete but was granted a place on the United States team for the Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway, next month. In Miss Kerrigan's absence, Miss Harding won the championship and with it a spot on the team.
The United States Olympic Committee said that if Miss Harding was not implicated in the alleged conspiracy she would be given every opportunity to compete.
Earlier today, the police in Detroit said the weapon used in the attack, a telescoping metal baton, had been found in a trash can behind the arena.
No one answered the door at Miss Harding's home in Portland today. But The Oregonian newspaper quoted her former husband, Jeff Gillooly, as acknowledging that he was under investigation, but he denied involvement in the attack. Mr. Gillooly was divorced from Miss Harding last August, but they remain close after three years of a stormy marriage. Court records here show that Miss Harding and Mr. Gillooly were evicted from their residence in October for failing to pay their rent.
Conspiracy charges are often preferred by prosecutors for two reasons: They can be easier to prove, and the rules of evidence, particularly about hearsay, are different for conspiracy cases and favor the Government over the defendant.
In conspiracy cases, prosecutors must merely prove that the defendant agreed with others to participate in an illegal act. The Government need not prove anything beyond the agreement, such as that the defendant actually bought a crowbar or drove a getaway car.
 
'Darling of Prosecutors'
 Because the Government has an easier case when such charges are brought, conspiracy is commonly known among lawyers as the "darling of prosecutors."
It may also be the case that conspiracy is being used as a charge so that Portland has jurisdiction to hear the case instead of Detroit, where Miss Kerrigan was struck.
In Detroit, Deputy Police Chief Benny Napoleon said an out-of-state woman had called last Saturday and insisted on speaking with him. "She indicated to me that she heard a conversation regarding the planned assault on Nancy Kerrigan" several months ago, Mr. Napoleon said. "She put it off as somebody talking. Once the assault occurred, she became frightened. She wanted to make sure the people responsible were apprehended."
 
Information About Eckardt
 Mr. Napoleon said the woman identified about four people, and he passed the names along to the F.B.I.
"I am not going to indicate who she implicated to me," Mr. Napoleon said. He said Miss Harding was not implicated in his conversation with the woman.
The police and Federal agents here have been sorting through a story told them by Mr. Eckardt and several people close to him. He said that he runs a bodyguard business, that he recently became Miss Harding's bodyguard and that he lives with his parents.
Although the motive for the assault, according to police sources, was to assure that Miss Kerrigan was taken out of competition, Mr. Napoleon said in Detroit, "To my knowledge, there has been nothing to implicate Miss Harding in this case."
In 1991, Miss Harding won the United States figure skating championship and Miss Kerrigan finished third. This year, Miss Kerrigan was the favorite but couldn't skate after the attack last week.
 
Never Fit the Mold
 In the fairy tale world of women's figure skating, where long hours in cold arenas are fueled by dreams of lucrative endorsement contracts and a chance to become "America's sweetheart," the unfolding story here has been greeted by disbelief, even by those were told earlier this week, first hand, of what happened.
Miss Harding has never fit the mold of the typical skater; she is an asthmatic who smokes cigarettes, a hunter who killed her first deer at age 13, a woman whose mother was so poor she collected bottles to finance her daughter's skating costumes. She drove a pickup truck and boasted that she knew how to overhaul a transmission.
The story unraveled on Monday when one of the people close to Miss Harding starting to tell others about what he knew; they, in turn, went to the F.B.I. -- giving police their most concrete leads.
One of those who first went to the F.B.I. was Gary Crowe, a Portland private investigator who taught a paralegal class at Pioneer Pacific College in nearby Wilsonville. Mr. Eckardt, a longtime resident of Portland, was one of the students, as was Eugene Saunders, a 24-year-old Portland minister. Mr. Crowe said Mr. Saunders had heard a tape recording that detailed a plan to attack Miss Kerrigan.
 
No Comment About Tape
 After Mr. Saunders contacted Mr. Crowe, they went to the F.B.I. Federal agents would not discuss what they had talked about with the Portland men, nor would they comment on whether a tape exists.
Mr. Crowe described Mr. Saunders as "a devout Christian, a born-again, an absolute straight-arrow, someone who will go to his grave without telling a lie." He said Mr. Eckardt went to Mr. Saunders because he was afraid and wanted someone else to know that there was a tape.
It is unclear how long Mr. Eckardt has been a bodyguard. He said he ran a service called Worldwide Bodyguard Services in Portland. But he never told classmates that he had a client until late last year, when he bragged of working for Miss Harding.
Coaches say they never saw Mr. Eckardt at the rink near Portland where Miss Harding trained. Mr. Eckardt starting working with Miss Harding after a death threat was made against her recently in Portland. The police never found the source of the threat.
Even as she was making her mark in the records books of American figure skating, Miss Harding was encountering problems with the police and in court. Her marriage was full of violence and near-breakups, according to law enforcement records, and she herself was investigated by the police for assault.
 
Two Divorce Petitions
 Twice, she had filed for divorce, first in 1991 -- 15 months after she married Mr. Gillooly at the age of 19. "He wrenched my arm and wrist and pulled my hair and shoved me," she wrote in a 1991 petition seeking the restraining order. "I recently found out that he bought a shotgun and I am scared for my safety."
Shortly afterward, they made up. But early in 1992, the police were called to fight near the town of Clackamas, near Portland, where they reported finding Miss Harding with a baseball bat in her hand, threatening another woman. The police reports say Miss Harding pulled her pickup truck behind another motorist, who was stopped at a red light, and then became angered. She honked her horn, got out and then punched the woman, knocking her glasses off, the police said. Miss Harding later apologized and no charges were brought.
Last October, the police seized a handgun from Miss Harding after a report that a shot had been fired near the apartment she shared with her former husband. Again, no charges were filed, and Miss Harding said the gun had gone off accidentally.
But a few weeks later, she and Gillooly were forcefully evicted from their apartment. According to Clackamas County court doucments, the couple had failed to pay their rent. They did not contest the order and were evicted, records show.
This last episode came less than six weeks from the United States Figure Skating Championships, at time when Miss Harding and Gillooly had told friends they were financially desperate.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
CLINTON, IN RUSSIA, IS FIRM IN SUPPORT OF YELTSIN'S AIMS

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton came to this wintry capital today and embraced President Boris N. Yeltsin almost without qualification, despite the surprisingly strong nationalist, anti-Yeltsin revolt evident in the parliamentary elections on Dec. 12.
On his first visit to Russia as President, Mr. Clinton and his top aides conceded that many people here had suffered acute economic privation in the transition from Communism to a free market. They spoke of the need for a redesigned net of social services to ease the pain. But they nonetheless pressed for a sustained or, in some areas, increased pace of reform. 
 In backing the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky and other foes of the Government, one of the main American participants in today's talks said, Russian voters had not been protesting the pace of reform, as widely suggested. Rather, he said, "what we had was a vote against difficult economic conditions," and the way to ease them is more reform, not less.
 
All Parties Represented
 Tonight, at a reception at Spaso House, the residence of the United States Ambassador, Mr. Clinton hedged his bets a bit, greeting members of all the parliamentary parties, including Gennadi Zuganov, a Communist member of the lower house, and Maxim Travkin, a 25-year-old banker who is a more suave, less vociferous colleague of Mr. Zhirinovsky.
According to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Mr. Zhirinovsky himself was not asked "because his actions and his language and his statements do not make him fit to be in a meeting or invited by the President of the United States."
Mr. Clinton told the legislators and a wide variety of officials, scholars, artists and business people, "Each of you who have participated in this new democratic process have my respect, my admiration and my pledge of equal partnership."
 
Shifting the Aim
 On Friday, Administration officials said, Russia and the United States will officially announce that they have agreed to stop aiming their missiles at cities and military targets in each other's countries and in allied countries. Instead, the officials said, some will be aimed at uninhabited ocean areas.
While the agreement is largely symbolic, because the missiles could be reaimed in a few minutes, Thomas R. Pickering, the United States Ambassador, said, "it also has real value in confidence-building."
Also on Friday, the Russian and American leaders are to be joined by President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine for the signing of an agreement leading to the destruction of Ukraine's entire nuclear arsenal.
Today, Mr. Clinton met three times with Mr. Yeltsin -- at two sessions in the Kremlin this morning, with the emphasis firmly on economic policies, and tonight over dinner at a snow-dusted Government dacha outside town, where security issues were discussed. He left not the slightest doubt that the silver-haired reformer remained the Administration's main man in Russia.
"I believe that we have a clear opportunity to work together to build a new framework of security for Europe," Mr. Clinton told reporters, "based on free political systems, free economic systems and nations that respect one another. And President Yeltsin has been doing that here and deserves the support of the United States."
From the Kremlin, the President embarked on a tour of Moscow shops, dropping in on a baker, then a combined butcher and fishmonger near Red Square. He fumbled in his pocket for rubles to buy a loaf of dark bread, told inquiring Muscovites that Hillary Rodham Clinton would arrive Friday and offered assurances that things would soon get better for ordinary Russians.
"All these folks working hard need to know that in the end they will be rewarded," he said.
 
Prayers at Cathedral
 Then, wearing a gray fur hat to ward off the 17-degree cold, he went on to Kazan Cathedral, destroyed in the Stalin era and recently rebuilt. Its bells chimed as he arrived, and he prayed for his mother, Virginia Kelley, whose funeral Mr. Clinton attended in Arkansas just before leaving for Europe.
Finally, he visited the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, Aleksy II, the Partiarch of Moscow and All Russia, who is ill with bronchitis, at the Central Clinical Hospital in a parklike district of downtown Moscow.
The dacha where the dinner was held, called Novoye Ogaryovo, a half-hour southeast of Moscow, was the site of the meeting where Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a last, futile effort to hold the Soviet Union together.
An American who was there tonight said the two leaders had shared in "a candid, freewheeling exchange" in which Mr. Clinton spoke sympathetically of the "difficulties and complexities" that face reformers in the Parliament. A string quartet played as the guests arrived, but as the hour grew late Mr. Clinton, described on a Moscow radio station this morning as "the saxophone President," took up his instrument and jammed with the quartet's pianist.
 
Caviar and Lip of Moose
 On the menu were caviar, pickled mushrooms, lip of moose and suckling pig. Mr. Clinton, inevitably, started talking about razorback hogs.
United States officials described the meetings today as excellent, and one expert on Russia said that for the first time, the two sides were "no longer merely passing points across the table." He said "the quality of the discussion was fundamentally different for me as a participant" because relationships had become institutionalized in the last year.
Mr. Yeltsin assured the Americans that he would continue to back reform despite the backlash manifest in the election, but he made no commitment to the reform strategy urged upon him by the United States and international banks -- the need to end subsidies to inefficient industries, curb rampant inflation and create a more sustainable social safety net.
Nor did he offer any assurances, the officials said, that the two Deputy Prime Ministers most thoroughly committed to rapid reform, Yegor T. Gaidar and Boris G. Fyodorov, would remain in office when Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin forms his new government, which is due any day now. Mr. Chernomyrdin is considered an advocate of a slower, socially oriented approach to reform.
But the American delegation took the reappointment of Anatoly B. Chubais, head of the State Privatization Committee, today as a hopeful sign.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen praised Mr. Yeltsin for what he has accomplished so far, but he pointedly noted that Mr. Clinton had insisted -- and Mr. Yeltsin had agreed -- "that more attention has to be paid to easing some of the hardships that we've heard about." But he said no one had raised with the Russian leader the problem of endemic corruption in the Government, which is said to have contributed to popular disillusionment.
The Americans emphasized that more reform would mean the release of more aid from international banks and the Group of Seven major industrial countries. To show how much had already been done, Mr. Clinton handed his host a map showing where American dollars had gone -- mostly outside Moscow and St. Petersburg -- and what they had been used for.
With inflation at 12 percent a month and the ruble at an all-time low, Russia has yet to prepare its 1994 spending plan. More than $14 billion in long-term, low-interest loans from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are being withheld until the plan is approved.
 
'Equal Partners'
 For his part, Mr. Yeltsin seemed to be sending a none-too-subtle message to his visitors, to the effect that the thunder on his right made it important for him to stand up for his country and its place in the world.
His spokesman, Vyacheslav Kostikov, emphasized to American reporters that Mr. Yeltsin's main point was "that the U.S. and Russia are equal partners, as opposed to Russia being in a position where it has to plead for American help." Since the elections, the spokesman said, Russia has joined the ranks of the world's major constitutional democracies, and the United States now realizes it cannot solve Europe's problems without Russia.
If that seemed like a belated response to the opposition's major themes in the campaign, Mr. Clinton clearly picked it up. Tonight at the Ambassador's house, he spoke lyrically of how, "over the centuries, the Russian people have shown their greatness in many ways -- in culture, on the battlefield, in government, in space" -- and now stood poised to make their country "strong and vital and alive for hundreds of years into the future."
To further underline his respect for his host and for Russian tradition, Mr. Clinton agreed today to spend Friday night, which will be his last here, in an apartment in the Kremlin. That will make him the first American President to do so since Richard M. Nixon in 1972.

HEADLINE: Welfare Plan Places Limit on Cash Grants

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts today proposed an overhaul of the state's welfare system that would force a majority of able-bodied welfare recipients into full-time community service after 60 days.
Joining a growing number of other governors who are also pushing new welfare rules, Mr. Weld said in his State of the State address tonight that his plan would put 50,000 welfare recipients -- about half the state's total -- to work. The state would continue to provide health insurance and food stamps, as well as day care. 
 "I don't believe we can continue a welfare program that rewards illegitimacy and long-term dependency," Mr. Weld said in his State of the State address. "Those monthly cash grants succeed most in keeping people out of the work force, and poor. Most children who grow up in this system merely repeat its dismal failures. It is time to rewrite government's exhausted prescription for poverty and dependency."
 
Some Exempt From Plan
 The chief architect for the Governor's plan, Charles Baker, who is the State Secretary of Health and Human Services, said there were plenty of jobs available for able-bodied people. Those who cannot find jobs after 60 days would have to do community service or forfeit their cash benefits.
The benefits received by those doing community service jobs, like working in a neighborhood school or hospital, would amount to less than the minimum wage. The maximum grant for a mother with two children is $539 a month.
A welfare recipient who refuses to work would not receive day care or child care or a cash grant, but would remain eligible for food stamps and Medicaid.
The Governor's plan would exempt teen-age mothers -- who will be required to graduate from high school, and live at home -- women in the third trimester of pregnancy or who have recently given birth, legal guardians, disabled people and those caring for disabled children.
For a Republican Governor with national aspirations, the announcement is a way to leap to the forefront of an issue that many other politicians have only flirted with. A cornerstone of Bill Clinton's campaign for President was his pledge to end welfare "as we know it," but the Clinton Administration is apparently putting welfare on a back burner as it wrestles with health care.
With a record 5 million families in America on welfare -- slightly more than 14 million people -- many elected officials have been talking about getting tough on welfare recipients. In his recent State of the State address, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York advocated increasing a program to detect welfare fraud by fingerprinting state recipients.
Oregon has a proposal awaiting Federal approval that would take all the money now spent on welfare, food stamps and a few other small social service programs and roll it into a work program. Instead of welfare, applicants would get a subsidized job.
 
Approval for Wisconsin
 Colorado won Federal approval on Wednesday to remove welfare recipients from the rolls after two years if they refuse to take a job or training. Wisconsin won approval in November for its plan to cut off people's welfare checks after two years if they do not work or look for jobs.
Last year Governor Weld proposed a less ambitious plan to overhaul welfare, but the legislation did not pass the Legislature. Therese Murray, a Democratic State Senator who is the chairman of the Human Services and Elderly Committee, said that her committee was considering its own welfare overhaul proposal this year.
If Governor Weld's plan wins Federal and state approval, then all new welfare recipients would be required to find jobs within 60 days. Those who are already on the roles would have more time -- closer to a year -- to find employment. The state welfare department estimated that close to 30,000 welfare recipients would find jobs by the end of the first year.
There is considerable debate about how many jobs, and what kind of jobs, are out there. Mr. Baker said that one way the state would help people find jobs was by giving them access to the Department of Employment and Training's job listings.
Wallace Graham, the public information director for that department, said there were 13,000 listings, which are primarily aimed at unemployed people seeking to re-enter the work force. "Those jobs are not aimed at welfare people," Mr. Graham said. "We still place people from welfare, but that's not the point of this agency." A quarter of the 13,000 listings are for part-time jobs, Mr. Graham said.
Unemployment in the state is at 6.3 percent. There were 200,000 unemployed people in the state last month, according to the latest figures.
 
'Where Are the Jobs?'
 Deborah Harris, a lawyer for the Massachusetts Law Reform Institute, a legal services group, said in response to the Governor's plan: "Where are the jobs? Everyone knows that the jobs are simply not available."
But Mr. Baker said that only a small number of welfare recipients would end up without jobs -- and in community service.
Mark Greenberg, a senior staff lawyer for the Center for Law and Social Policy in Washington, said that in the past community service programs had been ineffective. "They're administratively difficult," he said. "They cost money, and there doesn't seem to be evidence that they raise employment rates or reduce welfare costs."
But Douglas Besharov, a resident scholar with the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, praised Mr. Weld's plan. "This is a serious attempt to replace welfare with work," he said. "The object of welfare policy should be to move people off welfare. You might view this as a more realistic version of the Clinton plan. It's the wave of the future."
Still, Mr. Besharov raised questions about how many jobs were available. "The question is are there enough jobs for all the people on welfare," he said. "That's the $64 question."

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits declined by 1,000 last week to the lowest level since Christmas, the Government said yesterday. The Labor Department said the number of newly laid-off workers filing for jobless benefits dropped to 354,000 for the week ended Jan. 8, compared with 355,000 in the previous week. The change was much less dramatic than the past two weeks, when claims had soared 62,000 after having fallen by 37,000 in the previous week. Economists had expected a much bigger drop, but layoffs in the textile and apparel industries helped to make the decline more moderate. The job market has been unpredictable in recent weeks.

The Economy
 Inflation last year was held to the smallest increase in seven years, the Government reported. The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of a percent last month, for an annual rate of 2.7 percent. Amid the low inflation, the economy continued to show signs of a modest recovery. In a separate report, retail sales climbed a strong eight-tenths of a percent last month. The reports encouraged most economists to agree with the Clinton Administration in predicting there would be little pressure to increase interest rates. [Page D1.]
More than 80 percent of bank customers falsely believe that the Government protects the mutual funds they buy at banks against loss, a survey found. Regulators and Congress are debating how to provide adequate protection for the growing number of consumers who buy securities at local banks. [D2.]
 
Companies

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose 2.7% in 1993

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
The smallest annual rise in the cost of medical care since 1973 helped hold the overall inflation rate to 2.7 percent last year, the smallest increase in seven years, Government figures showed today.
The Consumer Price Index has now risen less than 3 percent for two consecutive years, the first time this has happened since the 1960's. 
 With a rise of just two-tenths of 1 percent in December, consumer inflation remains mild despite a rapid acceleration in the economy that began in late summer. Today's data encouraged most private economists to agree with the Clinton Administration in predicting there would be little pressure to increase the low interest rates that have helped fuel economic expansion.
 
Easing Some Fears
 Although there were some warning signs flashing in the Government's year-end report today, it put an end for now to fears that arose last summer in Washington and on Wall Street that the economic recovery would cause inflation to spurt and the Federal Reserve to stunt the growth by raising short-term interest rates. For now, Wall Street, where record highs have been set in the stock market recently, is euphoric as the economy generally seems to be growing nicely with inflation in check and interest rates at historic lows.
Confirming the rebound in the economy, shoppers spent at a surprisingly brisk pace last month, according to a separate report today, with the main beneficiaries being sellers of autos and other big-ticket items rather than the more traditional holiday presents of clothing and toys.
Retail sales climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said, putting sales for the month 6.9 percent ahead of the December 1992 level and further raising expectations for overall fourth-quarter growth.
The bond market took the news on inflation in stride but began a selloff after the retail sales figures were much stronger than had been expected. The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 13/32 , while its yield -- which moves in the opposite direction -- rose to 6.26 percent, up from 6.18 percent on Wednesday. [Page D12.]
Widespread holiday discounting helped limit the overall monthly price index to a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent, the same as its gain in November. And while medical costs for the full year rose 5.4 percent, or twice the inflation rate as a whole, the yearlong trend was clearly downward.
During the second half of 1993, medical inflation fell to a 4.4 percent rate from 6.3 percent in the first six months as the cost of services like doctors' fees dropped sharply while the price of commodities rose moderately. The rise in the cost of health care, as with oil prices in the 1970's, is now shown to have limits, even without legislation.
"The consumer is just saying no to higher prices," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Chemical Bank, referring to high prices of all kinds.
This was especially evident in clothing prices, which fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, with men's and boys' apparel among the weakest.
 
Costly Goods Sell Well
 The retail sales results were once again dominated by durable goods, which are costly items like cars and appliances intended to last at least three years. Their sales jumped 1.7 percent, to $77.14 billion, with all three major categories posting sizable gains.
Auto dealers raised sales 1.2 percent even after a sharp upward revision for November that transformed what had been initially tallied as a small decline into a 1.8 percent gain.
Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes increased receipts 2.7 percent last month while those selling furniture and other equipment for the home took in 1.8 percent more.
This strength, driven largely by low interest rates, could push the economy's fourth-quarter expansion even higher than the 4.5 to 5 percent pace that most analysts expect to see when the data come out on Jan. 28.
On the other hand, cautioned Laurence H. Meyer, an economic consultant in St. Louis, the durable-goods sectors will "likely play a diminished role" in 1994, suggesting that an expected slowing in business activity could be substantial.
Sales of nondurables last month posted a slight gain of three-tenths of 1 percent, to $141.12 billion, the Commerce Department report showed.
There were increases of 1.1 percent at restaurants and bars, five-tenths of 1 percent at food stores and three-tenths at drug and proprietary stores. But sales fell nine-tenths of 1 percent at stores selling apparel and accessories and three-tenths at department stores and others selling general merchandise.
Gasoline service stations showed no change in sales last month, holding their own despite what the inflation report showed as a 2.2 percent decline in the price of fuel.
Total sales for 1993 were $2.08 trillion, up 6.2 percent from 1992. Roughly half the rise reflected higher volumes, the other half higher prices.
The Labor Department's report on December inflation, which had few surprises, showed accelerating rises for food and shelter that were partly offset by lower prices for clothing and energy. The report did, however, have some disquieting notes.
For example, dividing the index into two broad categories shows that services climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the highest since August. Services account for nearly 56 percent of the Consumer Price Index and are generally considered a greater threat to price stability than are commodity prices, which edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
The so-called core inflation rate -- excluding the often-gyrating food and energy components -- posted its third straight rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in December, a result considered neither particularly good nor ground for immediate concern.
 
Moderating Influences
 For the full year, however, core inflation was 3.2 percent, the lowest since Government price controls in 1972. This reflected, among other things, a record 5.9 percent drop in tobacco prices and moderation in medical care inflation, which has been nearly cut in half since 1990, according to C. J. Lawrence, a New York investment house.
Most of December's rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in food prices resulted from a 5.2 percent surge for fresh fruits and vegetables. But prices also rose for poultry, cereal and bakery products and dairy products, the report showed.
Higher rents and costs of home ownership helped push the heavily weighted housing component up three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the highest since August.
Transportation costs, on the other hand, eased two-tenths of 1 percent as lower gasoline prices and a 1 percent drop in automobile finance charges countered another sharp jump in air fares, up 2.9 percent for the month and 17 percent for all of 1993.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Recovery Bandwagon Passes Figgie

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Harry E. Figgie Jr. and Gerald Swanson made the best-seller lists last year with "Bankruptcy 1995: The Coming Collapse of America and How to Stop It," an apocalyptic view of the nation's economic future that focused on rising Government debts. But Mr. Figgie's credibility on Wall Street has collapsed even faster.
Losses at Figgie International Inc., the $1 billion conglomerate of which the 70-year-old Mr. Figgie is chairman and chief executive, have piled up while companies around him have ridden the wave of economic recovery. 
 "The environment is not that bad," said Sidney Heller, who follows conglomerates for Lehman Brothers. "They have a lot of businesses that could be good but nothing that's performing particularly well. At this point, I have no confidence in any of their projections."
Figgie, based outside Cleveland in Willoughby, Ohio, owns Rawlings sporting equipment, Fred Perry sportswear, a wide range of fire equipment and security companies, packaging and materials handling companies, insurance and leasing operations and an oil and gas company.
 
 
Attracting Bottom Fishers
 Through the 1980's, it was one of the nation's better-performing conglomerates and the stock rose smartly despite Wall Street's dismay at strong anti-takeover measures it adopted to preserve the Figgie family's control. But these days, Figgie is strictly an investment for bottom fishers.
Analysts and portfolio managers say the company fell from favor quickly after earnings peaked in 1989 at $3.04 a share. Since then, investors have been punished every time they crept back into the stock expecting a turnaround.
Figgie surprised investors in November when it reported a third-quarter loss, which was accompanied by a cut in the dividend to 6 cents a share, from 12.5 cents. But it stunned them last week when it warned there would be another loss when fourth-quarter results are released next month, leading to a full-year loss for the first time in its 30-year history.
Figgie's B shares, which carry most of the voting power and are 18 percent owned by the family, peaked at $35.50 in 1990. They finished yesterday at $15 in Nasdaq trading. The A shares, which are more liquid and typically trade at a 10 to 25 percent discount, finished yesterday at $13.
Figgie has plenty of explanations for its troubles. Flooding at three factories in Kansas, for example, had a lot to do with last year's $14.4 million third-quarter loss. Commercial real estate, an important market for several Figgie companies, has not yet joined the economic recovery. And the company has been investing at a staggering rate in consolidating and modernizing manufacturing in an effort to make itself a world leader in making products, like industrial fire-protection systems, that are produced intermittently in relatively small numbers.
Figgie cites as benchmarks of its restructuring success a cut in the 3,400 machine tools it used to 250 flexible systems, the shuttering of more than 50 factories and a reduction in employment from 13,000 to 9,300. For all that, the few analysts who follow the company regularly believe that the economic recovery should have shown up in profits and now wonder whether Figgie is bungling its modernization drive.
Figgie's reputation will not be helped by a lawsuit filed on behalf of shareholders last fall in an Ohio court. It says that Figgie manipulated its balance sheet to look healthier than it was by overstating the value of property it is developing near Richmond, overvaluing inventories and failing to recognize bad loans in its insurance operations.
The suit also says that equipment deals between Figgie companies and the Clark-Reliance Corporation, a separate company owned by the Figgie family that Mr. Figgie has described as "the proving ground" for modernization efforts, were structured to strengthen Clark-Reliance at Figgie's expense. Finally, the suit says that the Figgies have used corporate aircraft and other assets for personal purposes.
Figgie will not comment on the accusations, which it is fighting, and Wall Street clearly does not believe the suit's contention that the company is "in imminent danger of irreversible business decline." But the suit does reinforce Wall Street's qualms about the depth of the company's management and the wisdom of giving senior management positions to Harry Figgie 3d and Matthew Figgie, two of the founder's sons. Harry Figgie 3d is the vice chairman and chief architect of the modernization drive. Matthew, 27, was named head of mergers and acquisitions, currency trading and investments in November.
"There's a real restructuring story here," said T. Edward O'Neil, whose recent report on Figgie for the S. W. Ryan Company, a stockbroker in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., recommended that speculative investors buy Figgie. "But it would help if they brought in a strong outside manager."
Mr. O'Neil said Figgie was the only conglomerate he followed that was trading below the book value of its tangible assets, which he put at $16 a share. Most other conglomerates, a group that historically trails the rest of the stock market when prices are rising, have already risen substantially from last year's low, making Figgie cheap by comparison.
Some portfolio managers who specialize in undervalued companies say Figgie should begin a strong profit rebound by the second half of this year. They note that Figgie says that most of its investment in modernization is behind it and that the company has retained investment bankers to help it sell noncore assets. Wall Street's preferred targets include consumer products, particularly sportswear, financial services and natural resources.
"This company is under-followed, it's unwanted and the outlook is uncertain," said David Katz, chief investment officer at Matrix Asset Advisors Inc., a New York money management firm that has been a long-term investor. "That creates an investment opportunity, but it's a matter of timing. You don't have to work hard at all to see the stock in the 20's once it's perceived as a turnaround."
Asset sales would be used to reduce the relatively high debt load, a goal Mr. Figgie has set and then let slide in the past while pursuing longer-term opportunities. Mr. Katz said significant asset sales would be a clear sign that Mr. Figgie has become more concerned about the views of outside investors.
"Harry Figgie always had an attitude that this was his company and he would run it for the long haul," Mr. Katz said. "His ego has been working against us for the past few years. Now it's going to be working for us."

HEADLINE: The Battle for Macy;
Against Long Odds, Retailer Fights To Remain Independent and Intact

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Myron E. Ullman 3d, the chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, has vowed to keep the department store company independent in the face of an attempted takeover by its longtime nemesis, Federated Department Stores, but most analysts and retail watchers say that could be difficult.
He might find a white knight with a packet of cash, or scotch Federated's overtures by finding another suitor. Or he could pay off Federated entirely; a creditor paid off in a plan of reorganization has no further say in the bankruptcy process. 
 But the forces arrayed against him are impressive. Federated has at least two cards in its favor. Any retailer with an interest in Macy can make a strong economic case for combining operations and reducing redundancies.
And before last September, Diane Baker, Macy's chief financial officer, alienated many creditors by not returning telephone calls and berating them for questions she considered illogical or ignorant.
Although James P. Kenny, senior vice president for corporate planning, stepped in as Macy's liaison with the creditors in September, relations with the banks, mutual funds, investment groups and bondholders who are its creditors are not as solid as they might be.
"Macy stands a chance of remaining independent and has a fair number of weapons available to it, but Federated has perhaps more will and more wherewithal," said Jack Hersch, an analyst at M. J. Whitman L. P., which specializes in trading distressed securities.
Mr. Ullman's biggest trump card is Judge Burton R. Lifland, who is minding the Macy bankruptcy in court. Bankruptcy experts and analysts said Judge Lifland, who has a history of allowing debtors like Macy to dictate the course of their bankruptcy, would almost certainly extend the company's exclusive right to submit a plan of reorganization, which expires on March 15. He has extended it three times previously, by three or six months.
Harvey R. Miller, the wily lawyer for Weil, Gotshal & Manges who is representing Macy, is likely to argue that the company cannot possibly cobble together a reorganization without its No. 2 executive, Roger N. Farah, who, because of Federated, his former employer, cannot start his new job until July 1.
Judge Lifland has gone along with Mr. Miller and his clients in several other cases, including the bankruptcy of Eastern Airlines, which dragged on so long that the company ultimately was forced to liquidate. The judge might well have Eastern and other drawn-out cases on his mind as Macy enters its third year of bankruptcy. Mr. Ullman can also call on considerable financial resources. His roommate at the University of Cincinnati, Peter Woo, is the chairman of Wheelock International, a Hong Kong conglomerate with investments in hotels, retail and real estate with an interest in United States retailing.
Macy's board is also packed with potential investors like Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman and chief executive of CBS and the Loews Corporation. But Macy will have trouble convincing its creditors that a financial investor would be better than a strategic one. A retailer combining operations with Macy could offer them the same value plus a premium from any savings.
 
Suitor Rebuffed
 To be sure, Mr. Ullman could seek a partnership with another retailer. But Mr. Ullman has repeatedly rebuffed advances from one interested party, Dillard Department Stores, as recently as a week ago.
Analysts said a merger might save the new Federated-Macy from $100 million to $200 million, although Peter N. Schaeffer, an analyst who used to work for Bloomingdale's, said: "Both companies are really bare-boned already. I think it will end up being a wash."
Federated, however, has gained the upper hand in previous deals with Macy. In 1988, when Mr. Ullman joined Macy, the company was lagging behind competitors in computerization, and hired the Sabre Group, a division of Federated, to catch up. Macy pays Sabre the cost of the services plus 20 percent, giving Sabre little incentive to contain costs.
Federated may have also gotten the better of Macy in its public dispute over Mr. Farah, the head of its merchandising office, who was hired by Macy last summer. To settle the dispute, Macy agreed to pay Mr. Farah's salary and benefits, potentially as much as $835,185, through the duration of his contract with Federated, which expires on June 30. But Mr. Farah was prohibited from working for Macy until July 1.
In hindsight, Federated deprived Macy of a chief merchant until next summer, forcing it to request more time in bankruptcy so Mr. Farah could shore up its merchandising.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Strong Retail Sales Hurt Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Conflicting signals in recent economic data and a forecast of strong economic growth from a Federal Reserve governor prompted a selloff in the bond market yesterday.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 13/32 , while its yield -- which moves in the opposite direction -- jumped to 6.26 percent, from 6.18 percent on Wednesday. Bond prices had soared nearly 3 points in the previous five trading days amid optimism that economic growth was moderate and not likely to fuel inflation. 
 Yesterday's losses reversed gains on Wednesday that came after the release of producer price data that showed inflation under control in December. The Labor Department affirmed the low inflation outlook yesterday, reporting that consumer prices rose a lower-than-expected two-tenths of a percent in December. At the same time, however, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose a strong eight-tenths of a percent in December. Economists had expected a rise of just three-tenths of a percent.
 
Retail Sales the Key
 Thomas J. Runkel, a portfolio manager at the Franklin/Templeton Group of Funds in San Mateo, Calif., said the Consumer Price Index was about what was expected, but it was the higher-than-expected retail sales report that started the market's downward movement.
"People were taken by surprise by the strong retail numbers," he said. Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist for CS First Boston, said that even though December's retail numbers were higher, there was a large downward revision in November's figures, excluding autos, "which neutralized some of the impact of today's numbers."
A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, told a business gathering in Boston that he expected growth in the fourth quarter of last year to be around 5 percent and growth in the first quarter this year to be 3 to 4 percent. Mr. LaWare said he expected the gross domestic product to rise 3 to 3.5 percent in 1994.
Mr. Runkel described the Fed official's comments on interest rates as confusing, saying they could be taken two ways: "One, that the central bank is taking a neutral position, or two, that it is taking a negative bias."
 
Lower Estimate in Market
 Mr. LaWare's projection of 3 to 4 percent growth in the first quarter contributed to the selloff, because the market had been expecting growth of 2.5 to 3 percent.
"The combination of his unclear statement and first-quarter growth was an overall negative for the bond market," Mr. Runkel said. "It's a nervous market that has gone from fear of tightening to no tightening at all."
Some traders viewed the selloff of bonds as healthy, since they believe the market had gotten ahead of itself over the last few days. '
An analyst at MMS International said the firm's Fed policy outlook remained unchanged after yesterday's data, with the Fed keeping a steady policy for now. But the firm expects a slight upward nudge on interest rates late in the first quarter or early second quarter.
In municipal bond market matters, the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, in testimony to the New York State Assembly Ways and Means Committee, announced that he would develop a plan to use the competitive bidding process in the sale of New York City bonds and increase the opportunity for underwriting firms owned by minorities or women.
He said the city should use competitive bond sales when they were cost effective, depending on market conditions, with the aim of having a broadly agreed-upon standard to encourage competitive bidding.

HEADLINE: Retreat of Blue Chips Continues on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell on another bout of profit taking yesterday after their recent run to record levels, but Nasdaq stocks, which had been lagging, edged into record ground.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.20 points to close at 3,842.43, marking its third consecutive losing session since hitting a record high of 3,865.51 on Monday. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,142 to 936, on moderate volume of 278 million shares.
The Nasdaq composite, helped by a late rally, rose 0.94 point, to 787.81, enough to surpass its record close of 787.42 on Oct. 15. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 1.70, to 472.47. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.19 point, to 480.06.
A jump in credit market interest rates dampened the buying enthusiasm for stocks, analysts said. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 6.26 percent, from 6.18 percent on Wednesday.
The rise was linked to news that retail sales in December had posted a ninth consecutive month of gains, making 1993 the best sales year in four years and providing new evidence that the economy was gaining.
But analysts said they were encouraged by the stock market's relative strength in the face of higher interest rates. They also noted a restrained rise in the Consumer Price Index, up just two-tenths of 1 percent last month, as a bullish sign for stocks and an indication that rates would stay low.
There were no clear trends in the market yesterday, analysts said. Automotive, bank and brokerage firm stocks found buyers, while drug and technology shares were mostly lower.
"It's a day where people are low on conviction so they're trying to look for things that are cheap," said Ron Hill, an investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman.
 Peter Canelo, the chief investment strategist at NatWest Securities, said he was fielding calls from investors who were worried that the recent decline might be a sign that the stock market was headed for a sharp correction.
But he took the investors' concern as a bullish indicator. "Nobody's worried about the upside; everybody's worried about the correction," Mr. Canelo said. "That's usually a sign you're in the middle of a good move and it's going to go a lot further."
The Dow index, he said, could approach 4,000 before the rally ends.
Among the big movers, Quaker Oats tumbled 3 3/8, to 66, after saying its earnings for the fiscal second quarter would fall 15 percent to 20 percent below those in the comparable period a year ago, noting the weak European economy.
The GTE Corporation said it would cut 17,000 jobs in its telephone operations over the next three years and take a $1.8 billion pretax restructuring charge in the fourth quarter. Its stock slipped 1/4, to 34 5/8.
Procter & Gamble lost 1 1/2, to 57, on news that it will close four plants and shut down production lines at six other sites in the United States and Canada as part of a previously announced restructuring.
Bear Stearns gained 3/4, to 23 7/8, after reporting record quarterly earnings.
The stocks of other brokerage firms also rose, with Morgan Stanley up 1 3/4, to 74 3/4, and Paine Webber up 1/4, to 27 1/4.
J. P. Morgan added 3/4, to 70 3/8, after reporting strong fourth-quarter earnings, including record trading revenues of $606 million. Citicorp rose 2 1/8, to 40 3/4, on an upbeat earnings forecast.
