HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A 2-Year Peak for the Dollar Against the German Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar reached its highest level against the German mark in more than two years yesterday after United States Government data showed an unexpectedly strong rise in retail sales last month.
The dollar was also higher against other leading currencies except the Japanese yen. 
 Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery jumped $3.70 to close at $390.60 an ounce.
The dollar, which has been trading in a narrow range against the mark, jumped up to close in New York at 1.7505 marks, compared with 1.7335 on Wednesday. The dollar was trading at its highest level against the mark since September 1991, traders said.
Some traders said the market decided to test whether it could push the mark above 1.7500 without stirring a reaction from the Bundesbank. The German central bank has been quietly buying marks in recent weeks, bolstering the currency against the dollar, traders said.
The dollar's move came as the Commerce Department in Washington reported a higher-than-expected rise in retail sales last month, of eight-tenths of a percent. The figure provided still more evidence of an economic recovery, which has caused the dollar's recent rise.
But the dollar fell against the Japanese yen as Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown joined a chorus of Clinton Administration criticism of Japan for not doing more to reduce its trade surplus. Mr. Brown told reporters that progress in talks with Japan had been "disappointing."
"Comments like that are giving people at least concern over the dollar-yen going higher," said Jack Griffin, a vice president at the New York branch of Fuji Bank Ltd.
In New York, the dollar slipped to 111.77 yen, from 112.25 yen on Wednesday.
Mr. Griffin said investors sold marks and bought yen, believing the Japanese currency would remain strong because of trade tensions. The mark-yen trading magnified the dollar's move against the currencies, traders said.
Investors believe that American officials favor a strong yen so that the trade gap will not widen. A strong yen makes Japanese exports more expensive in the United States, and American imports to Japan cheaper.
The British pound ended at $1.4977 in New York, down from $1.5035 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Data Highway Accelerating In Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Southern New England Telephone, the local phone company in Connecticut, announced plans today for upgrading its service that could make the state the first to be fully tied into the nation's developing fiber-optic telecommunications network.
Nearly 40 percent of the state will be connected within three years, and every home and business will follow by the year 2009, executives of the independent telephone company said. They predicted that the project will give Connecticut a strong advantage in competing with other regions for businesses and jobs in an age of computer and video communication. 
 Connecticut's commissioner of economic development, Joseph McGee, expressed delight with the project. "This is one of the most significant business announcements made here in the last 10 years," he said.
 
Plans by the Regional Bells
 Regional Bell companies across the country have announced ambitious plans to upgrade their networks. More than a year ago, New Jersey Bell became the first telephone company to commit itself to link every customer within one state to a fiber-optic system, by the year 2010.
In New York, Nynex has not announced a schedule, pending changes it is seeking in the state's regulatory system that would free it to compete with rivals like MCI on a more equal basis. But spending $1.25 billion a year to modernize lines, Nynex has already installed 530,000 miles of fiber optic wire in New York and replaced nearly all of the crucial trunk lines that form the foundation of the emerging telecommunications systems.
Southern New England Telephone, known across Connecticut as SNET, is small by comparison, with just 2,500 miles of fiber optic wires installed. It will need no more than 50,000 miles to serve its 1.3 million customers.
The SNET system will use fiber optic wire to connect every switching station in the state with nodes serving up to 500 customers. Coaxial cables, like those used by cable television, will then connect the nodes to each home or business, providing "dial tones" not only for audio communication, but also for video and data transmission. Though coaxial cable cannot match the carrying capacity of fiber optics, it will more than suffice for the range of services a single home or business is likely to require, telecommunications experts say.
The eventual cost of the new network is estimated at $4.5 billion, or $300 million a year, though that figure incorporates the more than $200 million a year the company already spends on modernization.
According to SNET's chief executive, Daniel J. Miglio, within three years, 500,000 homes and businesses in the Hartford and New Haven areas and in Fairfield County will have full access to the interactive capabilities of what enthusiasts call the information superhighway.
SNET intends to accomplish this without raising telephone rates, he said. Instead it will increase productivity, cut costs and introduce profitable new services.
 
SNET Keeps Pace
 Mr. Miglio said that SNET is keeping pace with New Jersey Bell and other national leaders, not only in moving toward providing the new network to all customers, but also in rapidly putting it to practical use.
SNET has already installed a new system that combines fiber optics and coaxial cables in a part of West Hartford to test the market for video on demand. That pilot project, just getting under way, allows people to do things like order movies to watch at their convenience on their television sets. That test will be expanded this year throughout the Hartford suburb, in neighboring towns and in Fairfield County.
As the technological ability is extended, said Ron Serrano, vice president for corporate development, SNET will be testing what residents and businesses want to use it for, introducing new products and services every few months.
In announcing their plans today, SNET executives laid out their strategy for competing in a once-staid marketplace based on local telephone service that now is roiling with change. The change has already been painful for SNET's 10,000 employees, who this month began receiving the first of 2,500 termination notices expected under a company reorganization during the next two years.
While the new fiber optic network will be installed by SNET employees, Mr. Miglio said it would not itself provide new jobs. But as the network's abilities provide a growing array of services, from video conferencing to movie programming, interactive college courses and video games that can be played with friends across the country, entire new businesses would be established and employment should rise, he said.
 
Local Competition
 The new telecommunications services, if SNET is successful, should make up for revenue being lost to new national competitors within Connecticut, where last year regulators began allowing A.T.& T., MCI and other long-distance companies to compete with SNET for in-state toll calls.
Those long-distance rivals are also developing ways to avoid the costly fees that local providers like SNET charge for access to their networks as the final link in a long distance call. This month, for example, MCI announced plans to invest $2 billion in its own local-service networks in the nation's 20 largest cities.
But one necessity for SNET, as for Nynex, is to win changes in their regulation as monopoly utilities that would allow them to keep pace with MCI and other competitors, which they say can pick and choose their markets, while they are still required to provide universal telephone service at reasonable cost.
In both Connecticut and New York, regulators are considering moving away from the traditional practice of setting a fixed rate of return for telephone companies. The idea is to encourage the companies themselves to make the immense investment demanded by the new telecommunications network by giving them the freedom to cut costs and set prices, within limits set by the states. The companies would have the incentive of a higher return if they succeed.
 
Incentives Needed
 Without those incentives, said Bob Varettoni, a spokesman for Nynex, the telephone companies have great difficulty investing more than their already substantial annual budgets for upgrading lines.
"We believe that we have a network that's second to none already in place," he said, "but other states are rapidly catching up and could pass us in the next few years because they're under incentive regulation. We're struggling to maintain the same level of investment."
As of Jan. 1, Nynex was required by New York's Public Service Commission to cut its residential rates.
"Certainly investment in telecommunications does help a region retain and create jobs," Mr. Varettoni said. "We are in competition with other states, and we feel that any delay in initiatives toward incentive regulation does a disservice to the state."

HEADLINE: Value of New York City Real Estate Still Falling

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The value of real estate in New York City has fallen for the fourth year in a row, and though the rate of decline has slowed, the figures indicate that the city's economy is only fitfully climbing out of the depths of recession, the city's Department of Finance said yesterday.
The decline in market values means a decline in the assessed value on which the city bases its tax bills, compounding the difficulties facing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as he tries to close a gap in next year's budget that his aides estimate has now grown to $2.3 billion. 
 Mr. Giuliani has declined to specify what steps he will take to balance the budget for the fiscal year that begins in July, though he has promised to try to avoid tax increases by concentrating first on wasteful spending. His budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, has already asked the city's agencies to cut 1 percent of their budgets immediately and to plan for deeper cuts.
Yesterday Mr. Giuliani asked City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi to use his authority to review spending by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, whose current budget of $3 billion has fallen out of balance by as much as $160 million, according to fiscal monitors.
At the same time, Mr. Lackman ordered the corporation, which operates the city's 11 municipal hospitals as well as health clinics, not to consider any new spending or sign new contracts unless there was a health emergency until the budget shortfall was resolved.
"The city cannot afford to be a deep pocket for H.H.C.," Mr. Lackman wrote in a letter to the corporation's chairman, Luis A. Miranda Jr., and its outgoing president, Dr. Billy E. Jones.
The drop in the taxable value of the city's real estate -- particularly of cooperative apartments, condominiums and apartment buildings and of commercial and industrial properties -- is expected to cost the city at least $100 million in revenues for the 1995 fiscal year, which begins in July, officials said.
The administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins had actually predicted that those revenues would increase about $100 million. That change, coupled with another $100 million that officials expect to lose through challenges to the tax assessments, means the budget gap Mr. Giuliani faces has grown $300 million since late last year. The increase confirmed the direst forecast by Mr. Lackman last month.
"The good news -- if one wants to call this good news -- is that it doesn't come as a surprise to the administration," said Marc V. Shaw, the Finance Commissioner, who announced the annual property assessments at a news conference yesterday.
 
A Slower Decline
 The total market value in 1993 of all real estate in New York City -- about 1 million properties -- is now estimated by the city at nearly $296 billion, a 17 percent decline from the peak of $358 million in 1989. The total fell 1.5 percent from 1992, a slower decline than in previous years.
The biggest decline came in properties known as Class II, including co-ops, condominiums and apartment buildings, which declined 3.8 percent in value citywide. The decline was steepest in the Bronx, where values fell 6 percent, and Brooklyn, where they fell 5 percent.
Commercial property values continued to fall, though at 2.4 percent the decline was considerably less than the 6.1 percent drop last year. According to the Department of Finance, the decline reflected the lingering glut in office space, almost entirely in Manhattan. Commercial values on Staten Island, by contrast, improved slightly, in part because of expansion of the Staten Island Mall.
The market value of homes -- from one-family to three -- appears to have stabilized, but the amount of the assessed value of those that is taxable increased 2 percent because previous increases are still being phased in.
The taxable value of properties -- derived from the market value under a complex rate schedule -- amounted to $77.2 billion for the fiscal year that begins in July, down from $78.2 for the current fiscal year. The billable assessments tend to lag behind changes in the market value.
"There's some light at the end of the tunnel," Mr. Shaw said.
Still, the decline in revenues from property taxes -- which generate roughly a quarter of the city's nearly $32 billion budget, the largest single source of money -- complicates Mr. Giuliani's efforts to balance his first budget without tax increases or painful cuts in services.
The drop in revenues could be offset in part by increases in revenues from other taxes, including those on sales, income and corporate profits. The amount the city can expect from those taxes will be made available later this month.
While not identifying specific ways he hopes to close the budget gap, Mr. Giuliani has indicated that he will try to employ a variety of tactics, including cuts in agency spending and help from the state.
In the case of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which operates a budget independently of the city's, Mr. Giuliani appeared intent to exert more control over spending right away.
Under a new financial restructuring agreement, the city contributed $278 million to the corporation in this year's budget. With its costs rising, however, the corporation asked for $50 million more, though fiscal monitors estimated its shortfall to be $160 million, Mr. Lackman said.
In a statement, the corporation's chairman, Mr. Miranda, who was appointed to the post by Mr. Giuliani, said he was "as worried as Mayor Giuliani" about the "difficult financial situation."

HEADLINE: Innovation In Sending Donations To Neediest

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
During a season when many longtime contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have been forced to send less because of economic hardship, hundreds of others have instead seen the difficulties as a challenge.
In letters with their contributions, they describe how they have taken up the cudgels of innovation to try to meet the challenge, collecting money from their fellow employees or neighbors, holding auctions, sending along windfalls or even raising money from recycling to help those in need. 
 The second-grade class at Public School 81 in the Bronx, for example, decided in early December to hold a bake sale in the school's lunch room to add to the coins they usually collected to help the Neediest Cases Fund.
"Parents not only donated beautiful baked goods but their time and effort in helping organize, set up, count change and a million other details," the students wrote, sending along a check for $369.24. "The 2d graders beamed as their goods were sold and could not have been more pleased as our dollar amounts increased. We hope the contribution helps bring a bit of the holiday to others in our New York neighborhood."
Gregg and Diane Deger of Sag Harbor, L.I., encouraged their friends to give to the fund by letting them know, in a not-so-subtle way, that the Degers had already contributed $200 in their honor.
Their tactic was to include a small printed note with all their Christmas cards announcing: "In the spirit of holiday giving, we have made a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in the names of our families and friends."
"We know that they will share in the happiness we have in making this small gift so it will help make a merrier Christmas for a family that is truly in need of assistance," the Degers wrote.
Others seized on a happy occasion to persuade their colleagues to dig into their pockets. For Steve Innerfield, a controller at Admaster Inc., a marketing and communications company in Manhattan, the occasion was a particularly auspicious communication between two people in his office last year.
"What happened was that Andrew Corn, our president, decided to propose to another employee who worked in the computer graphics department," Mr. Innerfield said. "And the result was that Andy and Lisa were married Dec. 12."
The best wedding present for his boss, Mr. Innerfield decided, would be to help those in the city who really needed it. "It just seemed like a natural," he said yesterday. "So we passed the hat and everybody kicked in a couple of bucks." Five days after the wedding, the employees sent a check for $101.
Collective efforts to help have included those of tenants of apartment buildings, such as the Edgewater on East 72d Street, which collected checks totaling $910. Employees at a branch of Dean Witter Reynolds, in Wayne, N.J., raised $115 by recycling soda cans.
Because The Times pays the expenses of the campaign, which in its 82d year, contributions like these are sent directly to seven social-service agencies to help provide a wide range of assistance to New Yorkers who are poor, hungry, disabled or abused.
The appeal, which will end Feb. 28., continues to need gifts of any size to help charities whose resources are stretched thin. At this time last year, the fund had collected $3,540,061.08. This year, collections stand at $3,454,457.77, or a negative difference of more than $85,000.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

A Little Whorehouse Carries On
It appears there will be enough new musicals for a full complement of Tony nominees after all. The long-rumored arrival of "The Best Little Whorehouse Goes Public" was confirmed this week by the producer, Stevie Phillips, and Larry L. King, who, with Peter Masterson, wrote the book. The show is a follow-up (though not really a sequel, Mr. King said) to "The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas," the musical about a small-town brothel called the Chicken Ranch that opened on Broadway in 1978 and ran for nearly four years. It is scheduled to open on May 10, the day before the Tony deadline, at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, whose owners, the Nederlander Organization and Stanley Stahl, have agreed to spend $1 million to renovate.
The show is to have a cast of 39, including Dee Hoty as the brothel keeper, Miss Mona, and a full pit orchestra (the original made do with a country-western band). The creative team that put on the first show -- the composer and lyricist Carol Hall; Tommy Tune as co-director (with Mr. Masterson) and choreographer -- is back. (Jeff Calhoun will share the choreography with Mr. Tune.) And once again, Universal Pictures is putting up all the money. Ms. Phillips wouldn't say how much, calling it "unladylike" to speak about such things, but another person close to the show -- definitely not a lady -- said, "Seven million would be a good guess, but you didn't get that from me." 
 Mr. King, a playwright and novelist, based the first show on an article he wrote for Playboy magazine about the closing of the Chicken Ranch, and this one was inspired by real events, too.
"About four years ago," Mr. King said in his gravelly drawl, "the I.R.S. seized a brothel in Nevada for back taxes, and then they tried to run it, and even considered taking it public. Nothin' much come of it, but we immediately saw a great opportunity to have a lot of fun with the I.R.S., the Government, Wall Street and so forth. The next thing we knew we were out in Nevada interviewing the bankruptcy referee who'd been brought in to see, if they went public, if the Federal Government could recoup its money. And then Pete Masterson and I even visited a few brothels out there, to get the conversational lay of the land, so to speak."
"The show kind of moves back and forth from Las Vegas to Texas to New York to D.C., changing times and places, kind of like jump cutting a movie or channel surfing on TV," Mr. King said. "It makes a lot of use of state-of-the-art electronics, stuff that's gonna cost a ton. But in addition to the razzmatazz, it's got a good story."
Ms. Phillips said that the paltry Tony field (the only other eligible new musicals this season are "Cyrano," and two that haven't opened yet, "Beauty and the Beast" and "Passion") was certainly part of the decision to open before the deadline. So, evidently, was the Nederlanders' willingness to spruce up the Lunt-Fontanne, the shoebox-shaped auditorium that seats 1,492 and has been occupied sparingly of late. (Last year, it housed, briefly, "Ain't Broadway Grand.")
The renovation, Ms. Phillips said, was "absolutely mandatory."
"We could not go into that theater and be comfortable the way it was. They'll be pulling out the whole front of the house, reconfiguring aisles, pouring a new cement floor to regrade it, putting in all new seats." In addition, she said, the clouds and cherubim on the ceiling would be removed, and the theater would be repainted and recarpeted in a color scheme complementary to the show's set, though what the colors were she declined, in ladylike fashion, to say.
 
Bon Voyage for 'Oleanna'
 "Oleanna," David Mamet's two-character campus drama about harassment, sexual and otherwise, is to close on Sunday after a remarkable Off Broadway run -- 15 months, 513 performances and 15 previews -- at the Orpheum Theater in the East Village.
The play, which is still sending audiences out onto Second Avenue and into the local bars seething and trembling, was capitalized at $325,000 and, in the words of one of its producers, Fred Zollo, "It's made a bucket of money." The return has been estimated by another producer, Peggy Hill Rosenkranz, at $1 million.
That is far from the end of it, however. Three regional productions of the show are now running, with four others having already completed limited engagements. Seven other American productions, including a tour, are scheduled for 1994.
English-language "Oleannas" are on stage now in London and Johannesburg; in German, the play is now touring Germany, Austria and Switzerland; it's touring in Italy, as well, in Italian, naturally.
Further, beginning with a Swedish production, opening in Stockholm tomorrow, foreign-language versions are scheduled for 1994 in the following countries: Japan, Canada, Israel, Spain, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Brazil, Portugal, Greece, Hungary and France. Before the play opened, Mr. Mamet and his producers considered opening it on Broadway, but chose the less expensive route. (It would have cost about $750,000 to open "Oleanna" at, say the John Golden, Mr. Zollo said.) With so many plays having opened and died on the Broadway boards since then, it seems, in retrospect, to have been a wise decision.
Nonetheless, one wonders whether the spotlight of the Broadway stage, in addition to the controversy the play generated all by itself, would have attracted an even larger audience to it, whether "Oleanna" is the kind of "event" play, like "Angels in America," that would have a chance in the Broadway environment that now seems so hostile to nonmusicals.
"None whatsoever," Mr. Zollo said, asked if he'd had second thoughts about eschewing Broadway. "It felt right in the Orpheum space, that perfectly square stage, like a boxing ring."
He added: "I could've seen it at the Golden. But it would've had a limited run. We didn't have famous actors and the chances of awards to pump up your volume was slim, because of the presence of 'Angels', " which, incidentally, Mr. Zollo also helped produce.
At the Orpheum, a 299-seat house with a potential weekly gross of more than $80,000, the show cost not much more than $30,000 a week to run.
"It was a nice economic situation," he said. "We had four or five sellout months, and then it fell into a pleasant valley where, because it costs X instead of Y, it could run in that pleasant valley."
Mr. Zollo, who will happily deliver some of the more colorful ravings against the dwindling audience for drama, is nonetheless producing, with Gregory Mosher, Mr. Mamet's next play, a three-character drama called "The Cryptogram," which New Yorkers may well see this spring, perhaps even on Broadway.
"Should we go to the Golden?" he said. "We're thinking about this."
 
Footlights
 *"Unfinished Stories" by Sybille Pearson, a contemporary drama set on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is next up at the New York Theater Workshop. The play, which begins performances on Feb. 4 for an official opening on Feb. 16, focuses on a Jewish family -- a newly remarried middle-aged man, his ex-wife, his father, who is dying of cancer, and his son -- stars Laurence Luckinbill, Christopher Collet, Delphi Harrington and Joseph Wiseman. It is being directed by Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where the play was developed and first produced the season before last. Mr. Davidson is, of course, a transplanted New Yorker and a frequent visitor back (recently as a co-producer of "Angels in America" and "The Kentucky Cycle"), but he hasn't directed a play here since "The Lady and the Clarinet" in 1983.
*A merry-go-roundish change in the schedule at the Manhattan Theater Club: The world premiere of Terrence McNally's play "Love! Valour! Compassion!," which had been scheduled for the mainstage this spring, will now open the fall season instead; the hope is that at that time Jerry Zaks will be available to direct. In its place, "Kindertransport" by Diane Samuels, which had been scheduled for Stage II, now moves to the mainstage, for an April 26 opening. The title refers to the German-Jewish children who were evacuated to England during the war, and the play focuses on the life of one girl as she grows up and confronts her heritage. Moving into the vacant slot on Stage II is "The Arabian Nights," a contemorary adaptation by Mary Zimmerman, imported from the Lookingglass Theater in Chicago.
*Attention, Gilligan! Tina Louise, who appeared on Broadway in "Li'l Abner" (1956) and "Fade Out, Fade In," (1964) before being marooned on a desert island, makes her Off-Broadway debut in "Good as New" by Peter Hedges ("What's Eating Gilbert Grape?"), one of four one-acts being presented by the Manhattan Class Company at 120 West 28th Street. Performances begin Feb. 13.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Not Heat, but Humidity
Frank Lloyd Wright took his time designing and building the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (17 years from start to finish). So complex was his design that the only builder he could find to execute his drawings economically was a man whose expertise was constructing concrete parking garages and freeways. Now the Guggenheim is taking its time again, but the issue is how best to solve some of the longstanding problems (a few left over from Wright's design) that weren't fixed by the museum's $45 million restoration and expansion in 1992. Again, museum officials say, lack of money is part of the problem.
This winter's harsh weather hasn't helped. While it may not be noticeable to the average visitor, the museum is grappling with condensation problems. Everyone connected with the museum -- from conservationists to architects -- says that when it is particularly cold outside, moisture from skylights and windows that have not been sufficiently insulated drips down some interior walls. 
 In Wright's grand spiraled rotunda, the trouble spots are particularly noticeable on the third and sixth ramps. Portions of what the museum calls its "little rotunda," a small atrium at the north end of the building, are having similar problems. Long stuffed tubes of absorbent material, giant sponges that resemble blue sausages (museum officials call them socks), line the perimeters of the floors to absorb the moisture that condenses on the windows. These same sausages are discreetly tucked behind paintings in the large rotunda; the art there has been hung on brackets away from the walls.
"As far as I know there has never been any damage to the paintings," said Paul Schwartzbaum, the Guggenheim's chief conservator. "The museum has always had these problems; in fact, before the restoration they were much worse. Now they seem more noticeable because we're much more in the public eye."
Portions of the building that for years were closed off to visitors are now part of the museum again. The "little rotunda," for instance, which now houses the Thannhauser Collection and the Thannhauser Galleries, were office space before the recent refurbishing; the top gallery section of the spiral ramp in the central rotunda was used for storage.
Some of the worst condensation problems were solved when insulated glass was substituted in the large skylight of the main building, Mr. Schwartzbaum said. Before the restoration, the dome had leaked; now, not only is it airtight, but also condensation is avoided with a system that diverts water to the outside of the building through weep holes. These tiny holes have also been made in the bottom of the window frames in the skylights that wrap around the main rotunda, but because the original uninsulated glass remains in these skylights, condensation is still a problem.
"When Wright built the museum, technology was a very naive discipline," said the New York architect Charles Gwathmey, who with his partner, Robert Siegel, refurbished Wright's building and designed the new, 10-story limestone addition. "It's a whole new sophisticated world now."
In the restoration, sophisticated air, electric and humidity systems were installed and hidden so as not to disturb Wright's design. Plans for the re-stuccoing of the building's exterior and the addition of an elastic coating, or vapor barrier, to the outside, as well as replacement of the remaining skylights and window frames -- what Mr. Gwathmey calls Phase 2 of the project -- have been approved by the Landmarks Commission. Mr. Gwathmey, who estimates the cost of these renovations at under $1 million, is waiting for a green light from the Guggenheim to proceed.
Both Mr. Schwartzbaum and Michael Govan, the museum's deputy director, say money isn't the only factor that has delayed Phase 2. While everyone agrees on what work should be done, museum officials say they want more time to study the problem. "Any restoration has a life of its own, and certain things get priority," said Mr. Schwartzbaum. "There wasn't time to do the proper studies and raise the money to meet the schedule for the reopening. The museum felt it was more important to be diligent about studying the problems and finding the right solutions."
On Thursday, Mr. Schwartzbaum said, two prototype thermal-resistant large-paned windows will be installed in the little rotunda.
"It's hard to come up with the right technical solutions while at the same time respecting the Wright landmark," he said. "You don't want to turn a Chihuahua into a cocker spaniel."
 
Dia Director to Leave
 Just as the Dia Center for the Arts in Manhattan is beginning to move away from its status as a small alternative space and into the mainstream of the museum world, it is losing its director, Charles Wright, who has resigned from his post, effective June 1, giving family obligations as his reason. Mr. Wright will remain on Dia's board. Ashton Hawkins, the chairman of Dia's board as well as the executive vice president and counsel to the trustees at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said Dia was just beginning to search for a successor.
Among the projects Mr. Wright has overseen, all of which are nearing completion, is the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, which is scheduled to open in May. The museum has been a collaborative effort involving Dia, the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh and the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts in New York. Another is the Cy Twombly Museum, a collaboration by Dia, Mr. Twombly and the Menil Foundation that is to open next year in Houston. And a new space for Dia's permanent collection of art from the 1960's to the 1980's is to open next year in a newly renovated building at 535 West 22d Street, in Chelsea.
"It's a great time for someone to come in and shape Dia's future," Mr. Wright said this week. "In the next 20 years it will be known as the next major museum in the city, the one that has shown artists like Warhol, Beuys, Flavin, Judd, who changed the ground rules mid-century. It's an ideal time to be leaving."
 
New Head for Dealer Group
 The Private Art Dealer's Association, a four-year-old nonprofit organization that represents about 60 dealers who run nonpublic galleries in North America, has elected Robert Dance to be its new president.
Mr. Dance, a Manhattan-based dealer in Old Masters and drawings who specializes in Italian paintings and drawings, replaces Jill Newhouse, a Manhattan dealer who has served as president since the organization's inception.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
In Belarus, Memorials Define a Nation

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINSK, Belarus, Jan. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to lay a wreath in the Kuropaty Forest, just off the highway from the airport, as he arrives in Minsk has ignited a debate that tells much about Belarus's fragile sovereignty and Soviet-style politics.
The fuss threatens to overshadow Mr. Clinton's six-hour visit here on Saturday, a quick thank-you to the former Soviet republic for agreeing to give up all 81 of its SS-25 nuclear missiles, an accord that was reached without any of the haggling needed to produce a similar pledge by Ukraine. 
 Kuropaty, an ice-covered clearing in the forest marked by a crude wooden cross embellished with a circle of barbed wire, is not one of the plentiful memorials in this blood-soaked country to the victims of Nazi Germany. It is the site of a mass grave of those executed by Stalin's secret police from 1937 to 1941, and it is thought to contain up to 200,000 corpses.
 
Symbol of a Nation
 The current Government looks at Kuropaty with extreme ambivalence.
When excavation at the site began in 1988, Kuropaty took on symbolic importance for nationalists. The archeologist who discovered it, Zyanon Paznyak, a leader of the political opposition, regards Prime Minister Vyacheslav F. Kebich as a traitor, accusing him of "conducting a pro-imperial, pro-Russian policy."
So the wreath-laying will serve to highlight Mr. Clinton's support for faster political and economic change in this nation of 10.7 million, including early elections to a Parliament that has been in place since 1990, before independence.
Mr. Kebich said in an interview that the legislature had decided to ask the White House to schedule Mr. Clinton's visit to Kuropaty last, as he departs -- and not before paying his respects at the official Soviet-built monument to the victims of Nazism in downtown Victory Square.
 
Legacy of Bloody Wars
 But for Mr. Paznyak, such a schedule change would be an outrage.
"The old Communist Party and Supreme Soviet are still in place in Belarus," he said. "Kuropaty is a crime committed by their predecessors, and they hate that Mr. Clinton will pay respects to this horrible place, this factory of death. It is a symbol of Stalin's genocide and the massacre of our nation."
A senior Western diplomat said it was unlikely that Mr. Clinton's schedule would change.
Like Ukraine, to the south, Belarus has seen centuries of bloodshed and has been chewed up by many larger neighbors. An estimated 1.3 million Belarusians died during the Nazi occupation in World War II -- including virtually every Jew and half the population of Minsk.
Up to 2 million died in Stalin's purges.
And Belarus, like Ukraine, is trying to build an independent state, but on weaker foundations, with little left of ancient Belarusian culture. Except for the Nazi occupation and a few months of independence after the Russian Revolution, the area has been under the control of Russia since 1772, and of Poland and Lithuania before that. Few people even speak Belarusian.
"Not so long ago, on a tram car, if I heard someone speaking Belarusian, I knew who it was without even turning around," said Ihar Germyanchuk, an opposition deputy and editor of Svaboda, or Liberty, a small nationalist newspaper.
So Kuropaty is also important in the search for symbols of Belarusian nationality. Minsk's vast main street, for instance, once named for Lenin, is now named for Frantsisk Skaryna, born about 1490. He was Belarusian all right, but he is honored for having printed the first Bible in what was then Lithuania, and he spent most of his life in Cracow and Prague.
 
'Think of Survival First'
 Stanislav S. Shushkevich, the embattled centrist democrat who is Chairman of the Supreme Soviet, says Belarusians have learned humility from their history, which helps to explain the paucity of reform and the willingness to kowtow, if necessary, to Russia.
"We've been beaten so many times and put in such difficult situations, we always think of survival first," said Mr. Shushkevich, a nuclear physicist.
Mr. Shushkevich has been kept in power by Mr. Paznyak and the opposition, but he tries to steer a course between them and the old Communist officials around Mr. Kebich, who now promises elections this year, after rejecting a petition to hold them earlier.
"I don't sense the building of an independent state," Mr. Shushkevich said. He finds the Government to be reactive and wavering, first promoting a Belarusian currency and then, as inflation worsened, promoting an ill-defined economic union with Russia.
 
In the Bear's Embrace
 Many workers see the embrace of Moscow and its ruble as a sort of salvation. One said, "I can't think of sovereignty and independence when I can't feed or clothe my son."
Mr. Kebich denies that economic union, which is by no means fully negotiated, would diminish sovereignty -- despite the need to coordinate Minsk's currency, budget and financial policies with Moscow.
"We're realists," he said. All oil and gas pipelines come from Russia and 75 percent of Belarusian industry depends on Russian products and markets.
But when asked if he is worried about Russia's putting economic pressure on Belarus, he replied: "Of course we're worried. That's why we should behave ourselves! That's why we must behave very quietly!"

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Politics of Nativism

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
When California political consultants talk with their focus groups these days about such issues as crime, schools or jobs, they find an underlying concern about something else: immigration. There is a strain of ferocious anti-immigrant feeling in the state.
Fear of immigrants is not new in California. As long ago as 1848 an outcry against Peruvian miners led to a Foreign Miners Tax, and there has been periodic anti-immigrant fever since. 
 The present agitation focuses on illegal immigration. Of California's population of 31 million, about 1 million are estimated to be undocumented aliens, most of them from Mexico and other Latin American countries. But the hostility really seems to extend to all immigrants, legally admitted or not.
The anti-immigrant mood is plainly connected to California's current economic distress. It is said that immigrants take jobs away from citizens and put a costly burden on schools, hospitals and other public facilities.
In fact, most economists believe that immigrants benefit, not burden, the economy. Julian L. Simon of the University of Maryland, writing in The Wall Street Journal last year, showed that immigrants do not reduce others' jobs and that the average immigrant family pays $2,500 more in taxes annually than it receives in public services. (But most of the tax money goes to the Federal Government rather than the localities that pay for such things as schools.)
"Some people genuinely worry about the problem of too many immigrants in a stagnant economy," Prof. Bill O. Hing, an immigration expert at the Stanford Law School, says. "But for most, economics is a diversion. Underneath it is race."
People say that immigrants are clannish, live by themselves, don't speak English. All of those things were said 100 years ago about Jews and Italians and others whom nativists denounced as "undesirable immigrants." Much of what is going on in California today is old-fashioned nativism or xenophobia.
A frequent claim, for example, is that today's immigrants do not assimilate as readily as those in the past. But English-language courses have long waiting lists.
The historic American pattern of striving immigrants building the economy also continues. Here in San Jose, the big city of Silicon Valley, Vietnamese are about 10 percent of the population. Vietnamese businesses are thriving, and many a high school valedictorian is of Vietnamese origin.
But facts are being overwhelmed by the emotions of fear and hatred. And politicians are running with those feelings much the same way they used to with anti-Communism.
Gov. Pete Wilson has staked out the low ground on the issue. Last summer he published an open letter to President Clinton demanding sweeping measures against illegal immigrants.
Mr. Wilson called for a constitutional amendment to repeal the 14th Amendment's provision that everyone born in the United States is a citizen. American-born children of illegal immigrants should not be citizens, he said -- and should be denied the right to attend public schools.
The Supreme Court held in 1982 that denying education to illegal aliens was unconstitutional. Even the dissenters, in an opinion by then Chief Justice Warren Burger, said that as a matter of social policy it would be "senseless for an enlightened society to deprive any children . . . of an elementary education."
The Governor sought advice from the Federation for American Immigration Reform (FAIR), an anti-immigration group, which urged him to seek exclusion of undocumented aliens from public hospitals and schools. FAIR gets support from a New York foundation, the Pioneer Fund, that also subsidizes researchers seeking to prove that blacks and Latinos are inherently inferior.
Democratic politicians have tried to jump on the anti-immigrant bandwagon. Senators Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer have proposed fierce new measures to tighten the border. But one political observer, paraphrasing the saying about a segregationist Senator in the old South, said: "Nobody's going to out-immigrate Pete Wilson."

HEADLINE: Anti-Zionists Do the Work of Anti-Semites

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"U.S. Jews Don't Clamor for Spy's Release" (letter, Dec. 30) by Alan V. Stone, president of the American Council for Judaism, is an unfortunate example of the way serious, controversial issues can be exploited to advance a private agenda. 
 For Mr. Stone, the Jonathan J. Pollard case provides a convenient vehicle to promote the standard propaganda line of his 50-year-old anti-Zionist organization.
It opposed the United Nations partition of Palestine in 1947, opposed the creation of Israel in 1948 and consistently took an anti-Israel position in the decades that followed. In that same period, the Arab states waged wars and economic boycotts against Israel while forcing international isolation of Israel.
By ignoring the centuries of longing and love for Zion by Jews in the diaspora, the Amercan Council for Judaism has made a fetish of emphasizing Israel's "foreignness."
It is ironic that, out of their own fear and defensiveness, Mr. Stone and his colleagues are raising the same specter of false and sinister "dual loyalty" against American Jews that anti-Semites have conjured up for so long.
 
MELVIN SALBERG
Chairman, Anti-Defamation League
New York, Jan. 3, 1994

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International 3-6
 
ONWARD, CLINTON TELLS RUSSIANS
Plunging into a nationally televised "town meeting" in Moscow, President Clinton urged Russians to stay the course toward a free market and democracy and to find a "new definition of Russia's greatness." 1
Reporter's Notebook: Fielding questions and dispensing sympathy. 6
News analysis: Mr. Clinton made it across a tricky tightrope. 6

HEADLINE: Cuomo Declares an Election-Year War on Crime

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Escalating an election-year war of posturing over crime, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo took the unusual step today of ordering the Legislature to meet on Monday to consider legislation aimed at curbing gun violence.
Last month, the Democratic Governor asked the Legislature to convene for a special session on Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday, an invitation rejected by the Republican leadership of the State Senate. 
 Only four days ago he suggested that it might be a waste of taxpayers' money to force the senators to come to work on Monday, a state holiday, particularly when they can begin work as early as Tuesday on a variety of crime bills.
But Mr. Cuomo said today that he thought the special session would be useful to focus attention on the issue of crime even if it produces no action. The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, responded by saying his members would comply with the edict. But he fired off a news release characterizing the Governor's tactic as "a cynical attempt to camouflage his opposition to the death penalty and his failure to stop the growth of criminal violence during his 11 years in office."
Both the Governor and the Senate Republicans have declared their support for several crime bills, including legislation to restrict the possession and use of assault weapons. But they have spent the last month jockeying for political advantage with a succession of tactical maneuvers intended to underscore their commitment to fighting crime.
When Mr. Cuomo asked both houses of the Legislature to meet in Albany on Jan. 17, the Democratic-majority Assembly, which passed an assault weapon ban last year, quickly assented. But the Senate Republicans, wary of letting Mr. Cuomo take control of the anti-crime agenda, said they would not attend. They vowed to act before the Jan. 17 session on their own anti-crime bills.
But that has not happened. Today Mr. Cuomo changed his request that the Legislature return into an order, a power granted him by the State Constitution.
 
Seeking 4th Term
 Mr. Cuomo is running for re-election to a fourth term this year and the Republicans plan to make major issues of his handling of crime and the economy. The fear generated by last year's fatal shootings on the Long Island Rail Road and the bombing of the World Trade Center have made crime a particularly potent political issue.
Of course, the Governor cannot force the Senate to vote on his bills. He has often remarked, most recently on Monday, that attempts to force the Legislature to act can be counterproductive.
Mr. Cuomo has used his authority to call an "extraordinary session" only three other times in his 11 years as Governor, always in December after the Legislature had recessed for the year. A 1985 extraordinary session to deal with medical malpractice legislation was considered an extraordinary failure.
"The worst way in the world to try to get things done is to order people to agree," Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference on Monday, when he was asked whether he would order the Senate to return. "You cannot order people to agree. And that's why I have not done it since, what, 1984 or '85, when it was a fiasco. All it did was waste people's money.
"I don't like pounding myself on the chest saying, 'You must come and do this.' They won't. They'll come and they won't do it and they'll waste your money."
But Mr. Cuomo said today that the lack of action by the Republicans compelled him to force their return.
"There is no power, constitutional or otherwise, that can force legislators to act, although it is possible to force them to be present," he said in a statement. "By calling an Extraordinary Session beginning on Jan. 17 I can assure that the issue of gun violence becomes the central focus of our attention.
"Also, the unusual use of this special executive power properly emphasizes the great importance I attach to this issue, an issue that involves nothing less than the lives, the safety and the peace of mind of the people who have chosen us to govern."
 
Not a Costly Day
 Mr. Cuomo said in an interview today that next Monday's session would not, in fact, cost much. Because the Legislature technically has been in session since Jan. 5, the only expenses will be the $89 paid each working day to lawmakers and any holiday pay earned by legislative employees paid by the hour.
The Governor's order for the Legislature to return came one day after Senate Republican leaders proposed a crime package of their own. It includes tougher penalties for several crimes and a ban on about 20 brands of assault weapons. The assault weapon ban would be paired in the same bill with reinstatement of the death penalty, a measure that Mr. Cuomo has vetoed each year of his tenure.
Because the Republicans know that Mr. Cuomo would veto the death penalty again, and the assault weapon ban along with it, the Governor blasted the plan as a "cynical political game" intended to highlight his opposition to the death penalty.
"It would be to take the assault weapons bill, tie it to a giant boulder, and throw it into the middle of the Atlantic Ocean," he said on Thursday.
 
Bills Held Hostage
 In his statement today, Mr. Cuomo urged the Senate "not to hold hostage effective measures against crime in their campaign to keep the death penalty alive as a political issue."
Mr. Marino responded that "Governor Cuomo is the only obstacle to achieving both the death penalty and a ban on assault weapons."
Several Democratic legislators said they did know whether Mr. Cuomo's move today ultimately would accelerate negotiations on crime legislation toward an agreement or prolong them through partisan bickering.
The Governor said he was not trying to pick a fight and said he did not think his order would prove counterproductive.
"I don't think it will antagonize them at all," he said. "How could they have expected anything else? We all said it was urgent. You said you would do it before Jan. 17. You failed to do it before Jan. 17. What would you say to the victims?"

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
For Clinton in Russia, TV and Empathy

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Just as he has on "Donahue" and MTV, and at town hall meetings in scores of American cities, President Clinton perched himself in a studio audience here this afternoon, opened himself to inquiries from far and wide, and assured the uneasy that he could sense their pain.
"Let's go to Nizhni Novgorod," the President commanded at one point in the broadcast, which was carried live throughout much of the former Soviet Union on Government television. As Russian producers cut to a hookup from that industrial capital, Mr. Clinton looked into the wide screen and asked: "Did I say it right?" 
 On the American campaign trial in 1988, Mr. Clinton gamely fielded questions from all comers, including a self-described pagan witch. And in what amounted to a 100-minute "Bill Clinton Show" today, he applied to diplomacy his well-honed skills of empathy.
 
Praise of Words
 Asked by one questioner whether there might be something the United States could learn from Russia, as well as the other way around, the President responded with praise. "If Boris Yeltsin came to the United States and did what I'm doing here, very few of the students could stand up and speak to him in Russian, as you're doing in English," he said.
And when one woman asked the President what he thought of astrological predictions that Russia "will soon become the center of everything," Mr. Clinton readily agreed that "there's a great energy here, I think." He later shook the hand of a well-spoken 13-year-old boy, Aleksandr Fyodorov, who he said might well become President of Russia, just as Mr. Clinton moved into the White House three decades after shaking the hand of John F. Kennedy.
With so many Russians left uneasy by the country's state of turmoil, Mr. Clinton had already made efforts at reassurance a centerpiece of his conversations here with everyone from President Yeltsin to a bakery clerk. But the White House effort to extend its message to millions more people brought to the country's television a most unusual display.
Mr. Clinton spoke at the Ostankino television center, where Russian troops battled with anti-Government forces only three months ago. He was introduced by Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, the former aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who earlier admonished an invited crowd of 800 students, teachers, journalists and professionals not to "engage in a polemic with the President."
 
A Call to Action
 Standing in front of a backdrop that showed American and Russian flags draped together over a globe, and flanked by two risers stacked five-high with listeners, Mr. Clinton began with an address to the Russian people, in which he said the nation's future was "still yours to make, yours to write, yours to shape."
But once finished with his set piece, he shed all pretense of formality, leaving his podium behind to walk down a ramp and onto a platform that extended into the crowd. Wearing a dark suit, white shirt and bold purple tie, he assumed the demeanor of a sympathetic talk show host.
"I'll take one from the right, one from the left, I'll do the screen and come back, O.K.?" he asked at the outset, while the audience nodded in agreement. Asked mostly for his views about Russia and the world, Mr. Clinton once used the word "partner" four times in a sentence.
He even claimed to envy the power given to Russia's President under the country's new Constitution. But he also spoke repeatedly of the difficulties still at hand here.
 
In Search of Wisdom
 Asked with whom he would speak if he could choose only one person in Russia to tell him about how things stood, Mr. Clinton said he would "speak to the wisest person I could find in a medium-sized city in Russia that was having a difficult time with those economic changes."
He said such a person, rather than someone in Moscow, could best tell him how ordinary Russians "were viewing what was going on now."
Many in the crowd later spoke with admiration of Mr. Clinton's performance and said they had been impressed by his candor and his knowledge. "It is a great difference from our President," said Yuri Zinchenko, a psychology faculty member at Moscow State University, describing Mr. Clinton as "very open."
But others said they remained skeptical of Mr. Clinton's motives in reaching out. "He is a very informed man on Russian problems," said Mariya Leontyeva, a 19-year-old college student. "But we're a big power, so he needs to be concerned."
 
Common Interests
 Hillary Rodham Clinton was also in the audience. She arrived in Moscow today with the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea, to join Mr. Clinton for the final weekend of his trip, which will end on Sunday in Geneva.
Mrs. Clinton spent the morning visiting a pediatric ward and a birthing clinic in a Moscow hospital with Mr. Yeltsin's wife, Naina, who shares Mrs. Clinton's interest in health care. The two women shared the head table with their husbands at tonight's state dinner in the Kremlin.
Chelsea Clinton, who is 13 and is making her first visit to Russia, passed up both the talk and the pomp. Along with Mr. Yeltsin's two grandchildren, White House officials said, she spent the evening at Moscow's famous circus.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Naina Yeltsin watching a snowfall in Moscow yesterday through the window of the American Ambassador's house. The wives of the American and Russian Presidents visited a Moscow hospital, then joined their husbands at a state dinner. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

The Economy
Evidence mounted that the economy grew at a rate exeeding 5 percent in the final quarter of 1993, faster than many economists had expected. Industrial output jumped in December and the operating rate of factories, mines and utilities reached its busiest pace in four and a half years. Economists are now raising their sights for this year, particularly for the first quarter. [Page 1.] 
 The Administration said it would end a contract providing low-cost wood from the nation's last largely intact rain forest. [8.]
 
Companies
Ripples from Metallgesellschaft's financial crisis have reached Castle Energy. The oil company said a failure by banks to approve a restructuring package for the German conglomerate would have "severe adverse ramifications" and could impair its ability to finance its operations. [37.]
William I. Koch compares the challenge of restoring order to Kendall Square Research to the 18-month campaign he mounted to pursue and win the 1992 America's Cup yacht race. [37.]
The head of Coopers & Lybrand told his partners that responses to a poll he had circulated persuaded him not to seek a second term as the accounting firm's chairman and chief executive. [37.]
Dow Corning said it would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $415 million, reflecting the company's estimate of liability from lawsuits involving silicone breast implants. [39.]
Wal-Mart will move into Canada for the first time, agreeing to buy 120 Woolco discount stores in Canada from Woolworth. Analysts say the move is likely to invigorate Canadian retailing. [39.]
A Curtiss-Wright unit, Target Rock, agreed to pay $17.5 million to settle charges that it fraudulently overcharged the Navy. [39.]
BPI, which publishes Billboard and The Hollywood Reporter, has been acquired by VNU, a Dutch media conglomerate. [39.]
 
International
President Clinton plunged into a nationally televised "town meeting" to urge Russians to stay the free-market course. [1.]
The U.S. warned Japan that it was being inflexible in talks to open its market to foreign goods. Still, Nissan said its largest Japanese dealer would sell cars made by Ford. [37.]
Toyota's chairman has been tapped to become the next leader of Japan's most powerful business organization. [39.]
 The African National Congress's plan to end apartheid calls for redistributing land and breaking up white-run conglomerates. [3.]
 
Markets
 Stock prices surged across the board, pushing several indicators to records. The Dow industrials rose 24.77 to a new record close of 3,867.20. The Dow gained 46.43 for the week. [38.]
Treasury securities prices fell and yields rose in response to strong economic data, closing a week of seesaw trading. [46.]
Heating oil prices soared about 5 percent as cold weather hovered over much of the nation. [48.]
 The dollar slipped after rising to a two-year high against the German mark. It also lost ground against the yen. [48.]
 
Your Money
Many first-time home buyers have found that anything unusual can stymie a mortgage application. Lenders' requirements have changed substantially since the free-wheeling 1980's. [35.]
Big gains for foreign stocks and mutual funds have energized the market for American depository receipts. Investing. [35.]
People who make estimated tax payments have an extra 72 hours to pay their final installment this year. Strategies. [35.]
The new year brings an onslaught of credit card offers, but it is important to read the fine print. Caveat Emptor. [35.]
Gay men and lesbians are looking to revocable living trusts as a way to efficiently pass assets to their partners. Trusts. [36.]

HEADLINE: U.S. to Cancel a Timber Deal in Alaska

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
Reversing decades of preferential treatment for a timber company in Alaska, the Clinton Administration said yesterday that it intended to end a 50-year contract providing low-cost wood from the nation's last largely intact rain forest, the Tongass National Forest.
The National Forest Service told the Alaska Pulp Corporation, one of two timber companies that have long-term contracts to harvest trees in the lush forests in Alaska's southeastern panhandle, that the company had breached the contract by shutting down a pulp mill at Sitka last year. 
 The contracts, guaranteeing high volumes of old-growth timber at low prices for another decade, have been criticized by conservation groups for years.
Alaska Pulp, a Japanese-owned company, was given 30 days to demonstrate to the Government that the contract should not be terminated, something that it could theoretically do by taking the unlikely step of reopening the mill, which had 400 workers.
Officials at Alaska Pulp said they were working on a plan to convert the plant to make fiberboard, a process that pollutes less and could earn more revenue.
 
Company Seeks Resolution
 "We are confident that information provided to the Forest Service earlier this week will resolve differences on the matter," said Frank Roppel, the company's executive vice president.
But the bluntly worded letter from Michael Barton, the Forest Service's regional contracting officer, left no doubt as to the Government's intentions to end the contract as quickly as possible.
Under terms of the contract, the Government would be required to tell the company by mid-February where logging would be permitted for the next three years. In total, the Government was to identify a supply of timber probably amounting to more than 100 million board feet annually.
Spanning 17 million acres on the rocky shores and numerous islands, the Tongass is the biggest of the national forests, once described by the naturalist John Muir as "an endless rhythm and beauty."
But in recent years, scientists and forest managers at the agency have identified serious declines in wildlife and in the general condition of areas that are being logged, and conservationists have warned that unless forestry practices were significantly changed, the damage could become grave and irreversible.
The long-term contracts for the Alaskan forest were signed in the 1950's to try to create jobs in Alaska, chiefly by providing raw materials for a product called dissolving pulp, which is used for cellophane and other industrial products.
But there is a worldwide glut of those products, and the timber companies have used much of the wood for more profitable sawmill operations, which provide far fewer jobs.
The other company with a long-term contract, the Ketchikan Pulp Company, is also under pressure from the Government, which is reviewing the latest big timber sale to Ketchikan Pulp from the Tongass.
 
Urged to Cancel Contracts
 In a letter to the Administration last week, six members of Congress called for both companies' contracts to be canceled. Although Ketchikan Pulp, a subsidiary of Louisiana-Pacific, is operating its pulp mill intermittently and thus might not be technically in breach of contract, the letter said that the company had hardly been a model corporate citizen and that it is facing Federal Clean Water Act complaints.
Even without the long-term contracts, the companies would be able to cut timber in the forest but only in the competitive bidding procedures used elsewhere in the national forest system.
Their preferential contracts guaranteed them a continuous supply of timber in quantities unparalleled in other forests and at prices that were unusually low. They received further Government help in the form of roads and other services. The Forest Service loses millions of dollars every year, because the revenue from timber sales does not offset the cost of these services.
Opponents of the logging practices under the contracts have argued, using studies done by the Forest Service, that by the time the contracts expire the forest would be severely damaged, leading to an inevitable decline in logging at that point.
Although the forest is vast, much of it is mountainous glacier, peat, scrub timber and the like. Only about one-third of the area is considered suitable for commercial cutting, and only 4 percent contains the high-volume stands that are used by the timber companies, according to a study by the Association of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics, a conservation group.
 
Conservationists Offer Plan
 Conservation groups have argued that the forest could be better managed by letting small-scale loggers work there, while preserving much of the oldest growth to shelter species like Sitka deer and salmon, which provide for an economic base built on tourism, fishing and other activities.
The conservation groups hailed yesterday's development as a clear indication that the Clinton Administration is taking a fundamentally new direction in the management of the nation's forests.
"This is a very significant action," said Charles M. Clusen, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private conservation group. "I would put it right their with passage of the Tongass Timber Reform Act in 1990."
That law directed important changes in how the forest is managed, but Congress decided at the time not to terminate the contracts outright, and critics of the Forest Service have complained that some of the act's other provisions have not been carried out.
Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, praised the decision.
"This egregious contract has long been the driving force in mismanagement of the Tongass National Forest," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Clinton Administration said yesterday that it would end a long-term contract with the Alaska Pulp Corporation that provided low-cost wood from the Tongass National Forest in Alaska. HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Japanese Over Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The United States warned Japan today that it was being inflexible in talks to open up its market to foreign goods, although American efforts to sell more cars in Japan have begun to register some success.
In both Tokyo and Washington, American officials warned that tensions could mount before Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, visits Washington on Feb. 11, unless there was progress in talks aimed at increasing Japanese purchases of foreign cars, auto parts, medical equipment and telecommunications equipment.
 
 
Nissan Dealer to Sell Fords
 There was some good news for the Americans today. The Nissan Motor Company said its largest dealer, Tokyo Nissan, was planning to sell cars made by the Ford Motor Company. 
 It is believed that other Nissan dealers are also negotiating to begin carrying Ford vehicles, although spokesmen for both companies would not comment. A central goal for the United States in its talks with Tokyo is to get more Japanese dealers to carry American cars.
Expressing the American view of the talks, a senior Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said in an interview: "Less than a month before that visit, we haven't had a serious engagement with the Japanese in these negotiations. What the political leaders in Japan may not know is how focused the Administration is on these talks and how united the American Government is on them."
At a news conference today in Tokyo, Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, sent out the same message, saying that after a week of talks, "The fact is, we haven't moved an inch."
 
 
Toughest Stance in Months
 Today's stern message is the toughest stance the Administration has taken toward Japan in months, and, some officials say, could signal the end of the honeymoon between President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa. At the same time, this message appears to be part of the normal jawboning of international negotiations.
Responding to the American criticisms, Masafumi Ishii, first secretary of the Japanese Embassy in Washington, said: "Japanese officials are as eager to reach an agreement as United States officials are. We are making our utmost efforts."
The two countries are seeking to flesh out a so-called framework agreement signed in July after a summit meeting in Japan at which Tokyo said it would liberalize its Government rules to allow for increased imports of telecommunications and medical equipment. Japan also promised to take steps to allow foreign insurance companies to sell more policies in Japan.
Although the Clinton Administration recognizes that Prime Minister Hosokawa is sitting atop a fragile political coalition -- one that could be weakened by making concessions to Washington -- officials say they are intent on pushing his Government to make good on an agreement signed by his predecessor, Kiichi Miyazawa.
"One of the sources of frustration is so much of what the U.S. is asking for is consistent with the direction Hosokawa promised of increasing consumer choice and improving life style," an Administration official said. "What we're asking would reduce prices and give consumers a wider choice of goods."
 
Difficult to Pin Down
 After Joan Spero, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, returned from Tokyo this week, she told other officials that it was difficult to pin down the Japanese because there are so many parties in Mr. Hosokawa's coalition and because Japan's powerful bureaucracy has an uneasy relationship with the Hosokawa Government.
One dispute is over the quantitative indicators that the framework agreement says should be set up to monitor progress in improving market access in Japan. American officials maintain that the Japanese have rejected every quantitative indicator suggested by the United States.
Tokyo insists that it will not agree to setting numerical targets for such things as purchases of foreign auto parts by Japanese companies, because that would violate the rules of free trade. Washington asserts that it is not asking for simple targets, such as achieving a certain market share in a given year. But it is asking for goals that are more vague -- like increasing the number of dealerships selling American cars. The Japanese insist that these are, in effect, targets.
Mr. Garten said that in autos, "there is not even agreement on the nature of the problem."
Washington contends that foreign auto sales in Japan are low because Japanese business practices, like close links between Japanese manufacturers and dealers, exclude foreign cars. But Tokyo says the problem is that Detroit's cars do not suit the Japanese market.

HEADLINE: Russia's New Parliament Chooses Ally of the Communists as Speaker

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
As President Boris N. Yeltsin gave President Clinton general assurances that economic change would proceed in Russia, its newly elected lower house of Parliament chose an anti-reform Communist stalwart as its Speaker today.
The vote was another graphic reminder of the political realities facing Mr. Yeltsin once Mr. Clinton goes home. The victorious candidate, Ivan P. Rybkin, had the support of the Communist Party and its allies, and of the far-right nationalist party headed by Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky. 
 The lower house rejected pro-reform candidates for speaker in its first round of voting on Thursday and chose today between Mr. Rybkin and a nationalist independent, Yuri P. Vlasov.
 
Led Old Communist Faction
 After Mr. Vlasov announced that he would vote for Mr. Rybkin in order "not to split the nationalist forces," the legislature elected Mr. Rybkin, 47, a leader of the Communist faction in the old Parliament, which Mr. Yeltsin dissolved in October.
Mr. Rybkin, now a member of the pro-Communist Agrarian Party, won the bare majority needed in the 444-member lower house, 223 votes, after the pro-Government Russia's Choice faction, the largest, chose to abstain. There were 111 votes against him, including members of the second-largest reform faction, headed by Grigory A. Yavlinsky. In a separate ballot, Mr. Vlasov, a famous weight lifter who has expressed strong anti-Western and anti-Zionist views, received 23 votes.
Mr. Rybkin, an engineer from Volgograd, was supported by the Communists, the Agrarians -- who are allied with the Communists but say they represent collective farmers -- and the nationalist Liberal Democrats led by Mr. Zhirinovsky.
By conceding in favor of Mr. Rybkin, Mr. Vlasov demonstrated the potential of any nationalist-Communist alliance. Such a bloc seems unlikely to solidify but could come together often on specific issues.
But the Communists and their Agrarian allies have shown strength and superior organization in the last two days of maneuvering in the lower house. They worked to set a quorum of half of the 444 registered members, making it impossible for any one faction, like the reformist Russia's Choice, to block the legislature. Russia's Choice favored a two-thirds quorum.
The Communists and nationalists also insured that Mr. Rybkin, as the new Speaker, would maintain the power to prepare the lower house's agenda, and pushed the threshold for achieving official status as a parliamentary faction, qualifying a group of lawmakers for important privileges, to 35. Russia's Choice wanted the number to be 20, to dilute the power of the opposition.
 
Reformers Not Very United
 By contrast, the reformers, mustering just under 200 votes, have not had enough strength to push through their own agenda, and they have not been very united in Parliament's first few days.
Officially, Russia's Choice is listed as the largest faction, with 76 seats, followed by Mr. Zhirinovsky's Liberal Democrats with 63; the Agrarians with 55; the Communists with 45; the reformist Russian Party of Unity and Accord, 30; the reformist Yavlinsky-Boldyrev-Lukin bloc, 25; Women of Russia, 23, and the centrist Democratic Party, 15. That leaves 112 members officially classified as independent -- a huge swing vote.
But no matter which side prevails in Parliament, it will have only a limited ability to block or change the policies of the Yeltsin Government. Under the new Constitution, a bill that passes the lower house becomes law if the upper house approves it or takes no action in 14 days. If the upper house rejects it, the lower house may override with a two-thirds vote. If the President vetoes a bill, a two-thirds vote in both houses is required to override the veto. Moreover, presidential decrees automatically become law unless judged unconstitutional by the courts or blocked by new legislation, which must survive possible presidential veto. So it is difficult for the legislature to force laws on Mr. Yeltsin, though its powers over the budget, which it must approve, remain important and untested.
 
Promises Fairness to All
 Mr. Rybkin promised to work with all factions fairly. He also said he supported political amnesty for all those who had taken part, without criminal activity, in the failed coups of August 1991 and last October, and he emphasized a need to make some corrections in economic policy.
One of the failed candidates for Speaker was Mr. Zhirinovsky, who angrily withdrew his candidacy on Thursday, shouting, "Every candidate for Speaker must be sent to a psychiatric hospital!" Today, he was punched in the face in Parliament's cafeteria. An independent member from St. Petersburg, Mark L. Goryachev, was waiting in the buffet line and apparently resented Mr. Zhirinovsky's loud demand for immediate service when he entered with aides.
As waitresses rushed to Mr. Zhirinovsky, Mr. Goryachev complained that he and other legislators had been waiting for some time. Witnesses told the Interfax news agency that Mr. Zhirinovsky then rushed to Mr. Goryachev, telling him to "shut up" and that Mr. Goryachev then punched him. Mr. Zhirinovsky was quoted as commanding Mr. Goryachev to "get out of here while you're still in one piece" and called for the police.
Mr. Zhirinovsky later denied that any such incident had happened.
 
Yeltsin Praises Lawmakers
 At a news conference today with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Yeltsin said he could work with the new Parliament, which he said was "cleverer and more intellectual and has more experience" than its predecessor. On Thursday the upper house of Parliament, made up largely of local officials and bureaucrats, elected a Yeltsin ally, First Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir F. Shumeiko, as its Speaker.
Mr. Yeltsin will provide the first real indication of any possible policy shifts when he announces a Cabinet shuffle, perhaps as early as Monday, in which some key economic reformers may be demoted.
Today, Mr. Clinton referred genially to Mr. Yeltsin's looming troubles with Parliament. "It's nice to be in a place where some other president is having trouble with his Parliament instead of me," he said.
But he suggested that lawmakers learn how to work within a more democratic spirit of give-and-take than Russia is used to.

Lukyanov, a former Speaker of the Soviet Parliament who is accused of being a leader of the August 1991 coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev. (Reuters) (pg. 5)
