HEADLINE: German Giant's Ills Endanger a U.S. Oil Company

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Ripples from the financial crisis confronting Germany's Metallgesellschaft A.G. have spread across the Atlantic to the Radnor, Pa., home of a small oil company.
On the eve of last-ditch talks between the Frankfurt-based conglomerate and its creditor banks, the Castle Energy Corporation said yesterday that the banks' failure to approve a $1.95 billion restructuring package could impair Castle's ability to finance its operations. That is because Castle, whose stock is owned in part by the metal conglomerate and its senior executives, relies on Metallgesellschaft for much of its revenue.
 
Revamping Could Be Affected
 The paradox is that Metallgesellschaft's relations with and commitment to Castle may be a major impediment to its restructuring. 
 "If I were a banker I would have serious questions about Metallgesellschaft's ability to continue without a substantial change in all its contracts with Castle," said Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Metallgesellschaft has said all 120 of its creditor banks must accept the restructuring plan in its entirety for the rescue to go ahead. If not, it has said, it will file for bankruptcy.
Metallgesellschaft, Germany's 15th-largest company, is on the brink of ruin mainly because of huge losses in oil futures trading at the MG Corporation, its American subsidiary, in the last three months of 1993.
Metallgesellschaft's relationship with Castle began in 1989, when it gave Castle much-needed financial support and entered into the first of two agreements to buy 100 percent of the oil refined by Castle at fixed profit margins that are extremely lucrative for Castle, ranging from $2 to as much as $4 a barrel above margins currently earned by most refiners.
In an unpublished analysis of the Metallgesellschaft crisis, Mr. Verleger put the combined value to Castle of these two contracts, which extend to the end of the century, at around $310 million a year.
"In this market, it was a very, very rich processing fee," he said. "People at the major oil companies would love to be paid that much."
Until the end of September 1993 Metallgesellschaft and its executives held 49.3 percent of Castle Energy stock. That changed in late November when Castle sold 2.8 million shares in a secondary offering. The German company now owns 40 percent of Castle shares, and three of its executives own an additional 3.9 percent. As shareholders, they benefit from the lucrative contracts.
A good chunk of the $42 million raised in the stock offering was used to pay down debt owed to Metallgesellschaft.
Perhaps coincidentally, Castle's stock offering was priced less than 24 hours before Metallgesellschaft announced it had taken a quarterly loss and eliminated its dividend.
Joseph L. Castle 2d, Castle Energy's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview yesterday he had no idea of Metallgesellschaft's problems when the stock deal was priced.
"I found out on Dec. 6 that they had problems," when the company admitted the losses it was facing were bigger than initially reported, he said.
Officials at MG, the New York-based subsidiary, did not return telephone calls for comment.
In the prospectus detailing the stock offering, Castle disclosed that three top MG executives were board members and big shareholders. The three were Siegfried K. Hodapp, MG's president and chief operating officer, a senior vice president of the parent company and Castle's chairman since May 1992; W. Arthur Benson, a senior vice president at MG and a well-known oil futures trader, and Joseph M. Rinaldi, another MG senior vice president.
 
Dismissed in December
 Mr. Hodapp was dismissed by Metallgesellschaft in December after the huge oil futures losses. Mr. Rinaldi and Mr. Benson remain.
Castle's stock, priced at $24 a share on Nov. 23, has slid steadily since. It closed yesterday on Nasdaq at $10.125, down 37.5 cents.
In addition to its equity stake in Castle and its refining arrangements, MG also holds about $30 million in Castle debt and separately provides Castle with credit lines that according to the prospectus appear to exceed $300 million.
In the telephone interview, Mr. Castle said his company, which made $67.8 million in the 12 months ended Sept. 30, would have lost money in 1993 but for the MG arrangements.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE: A Russian Tightrope;
The President Does Not Fall Down, But He Does Wobble Now and Then

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
American Presidents used to come here to treat with monolithic governments. On his arrival here this week, Bill Clinton found no real government at all, but rather two inchoate groups, one composed of reformers, the other a mix of "go slow" pragmatists and counter-reformers, all struggling for power, staggering into an unfathomable future.
That put the young, inexperienced President on something of a diplomatic tightrope, fighting to keep his balance. He did not fall off, but he did not make it across without a few wobbles this way and that. 
 "I thought the tone was excellent," said a senior European diplomat who had never seen Mr. Clinton in action before. "He never condescended to them. He told them how great their country is, which they need to hear, especially from the mighty Americans. He said their country was not the only one with problems, and he talked about his own difficulties in pushing health-care reform through Congress. He also told them, as they have learned to their cost, that the free market doesn't have all the answers."
 
Four Meetings With Yeltsin
 The President and his senior aides chose to spend most of their time with the leader of the first group, President Boris N. Yeltsin. Only at a reception Thursday night at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, did he briefly encounter the second group, mingling with and praising members of all parties in the new Parliament. His national security adviser, Anthony Lake, spent most of his time there with the leader of the semi-reformed Communist Party, with whom the Americans may want to do business.
Upping his bet on Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton chose not to visit the Parliament, not to speak at length to its members, not to hold substantive meetings with its leaders, at least partly because the parliamentary hierarchy has not yet solidified. He held four long meetings with Mr. Yeltsin.
"There is a 'with us or against us' mentality in this country, which Clinton has chosen to accept," said a Briton long a resident in Moscow. "He chose not to stress the importance of Parliament because Parliament is obviously Yeltsin's adversary. He opened not an inch of space between himself and Yeltsin, although Yeltsin is in decline, arguably terminal decline."
 
Some Object
 Other people noticed, too, and some objected, as have critics in Washington, to what looked like excessive identification with one man.
"Mr. President," a man in Red Square said to Mr. Clinton during his televised town meeting, "we're getting an impression you're supporting not so much the reforms in Russia but the personality of Mr. Yeltsin."
Mr. Clinton, who had answered a similar question a few moments before, replied: "I'm the President of the United States. I should be open to meeting with and listening to all the democratic voices in Russia. But in the end, I still have to work with your President."
 
Excellent Chemistry
 Mr. Yeltsin spoke, for all the danger that awaits the Russian politician who overidentifies with the United States, of "my friend Bill Clinton." It was said, as it has been ritually said at every summit meeting for decades, regardless of who was involved, that there was excellent chemistry between the two.
Beyond that, the conference produced or expedited important achievments -- an agreement not to aim missiles at one another, a three-way agreement under which Ukraine's President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, pledged to scrap his country's nuclear arsenal, an agreement to open the American market to Russian uranium -- even if it yielded no magic elixir for Russia's ills.
Yet it is Parliament, elected only a month ago, that most vividly reflects the grass-roots fury of this vast and turbulent nation -- and in particular the mounting anti-Americanism. However much they love their Cokes and Levis, however much they may privately admire American wealth and success, many Russians blame the United States for their country's loss of empire and superpower status, for the poverty and privation in which many workers find themsleves and for the crudity of nascent capitalism here, with its sleazy products, crooked politicians, swindlers, racketeers and profiteers.
 
Parliament Is Safety Valve
 Mr. Yeltsin has the constitutional powers to sidestep Parliament, but it is still the Parliament that can provide the safety valve for the steam of wounded pride, the Parliament where new political coalitions will have to be built and consensus on grand strategy, if any, achieved, and the Parliament that will serve as the forcing ground for the young politicians who will have to provide the answer to the question, After Yeltsin, who is there?
Mr. Clinton and his advisers believe passionately that a slower pace of reform, as advocated by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, whose star is in the ascendancy here, will only delay the dawn of recovery and prolong the pain. Viewing him as the only viable counterforce to the gradualists, the Americans extracted from Mr. Yeltsin a pledge to press on, undaunted, with his relatively radical reform program, and they warned as bluntly as good manners permitted that international aid would be forthcoming only if he did.
"It's reassuring," said Secretary of State Warren Christopher, "to be back here in the presence of the Russian leaders and find them undeterred by any events, indeed redoubling their efforts to move forward on reform."
 
Whistling in the Dark?
 His Cabinet colleague, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, added: "What you're seeing is a country that's stabilizing." That sounded like whistling in the dark to many Russians, who have seen the ruble slide to an all-time low this week and who still, despite considerable progress, still suffer inflation of 12 percent month. Indeed, Mr. Bentsen seemed to contradict himself when he said things would have to get a lot better before foreign investment would soar.
Mr. Yeltsin's ability to deliver may be limited, not least by his own sense of what is politically wise. To appease the nationalist and Communist foes of reform, who won about 45 percent of the party preference votes in the Dec. 12 election, Mr. Chernomyrdin is expected to demote or jettison one or more of the chief architects of Mr. Yeltsin's reform policies when he forms his new Cabinet next week.
In an effort to outflank the nationalists, Mr. Yeltsin has begun to picture Russia, however fancifully, as an actor on the world stage with a role fully equal to that of the United States. According to his spokesman, he told Mr. Clinton that new security arrangements with Europe could not be reached without Russia's assent -- in effect claiming a veto over American policy in the region that President Clinton has heatedly denied giving him.
 
U.S. Can Do Little
 But that kind of muscle-flexing, which did not disturb the Americans very much, won't provide the social services, including health care and education and pension plans, that Russia so desperately needs as an analgesic for the pain of economic transition, and Mr. Clinton readily acknowledged that the United States can do little to help beyond providing technical advice.
Each in his own way, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton tried at the closing news conference this morning to dispel any suggestion that Russia was dancing to an American tune, as some of Mr. Yeltsin's critics have asserted.
Eager to avoid any appearance of begging or dependence, and conscious of the budgetary strictures in Washington, Mr. Yeltsin asserted, "We don't need direct social aid because such aid is also needed by the American people."
Mr. Clinton drove the point home: "The implication that we have somehow tried to direct the course of policy is just not accurate and not true. We have our problems at home, too -- every country does. The United States has no interest in charting Russia's future; that's for Russia to do."
Now he will have to go home and wait to see what happens.

HEADLINE: New York State Reports Surplus of $300 Million

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 14

 BODY:
State will end its fiscal year on March 31 with a $300 million surplus, the result of a slowdown in Medicaid inflation, a moderate increase in tax revenues and tighter spending policies, state officials said today.
State officials welcomed the projection as new evidence of an improving regional economy. The surplus in the $32 billion budget will be the second in a row for the state, which laid off thousands of workers and cut services to close budget gaps at the height of the recession. 
 But the New York officials warned that some areas of business, particularly in manufacturing, remain weak and could face additional layoffs this year. And they noted that the state, even in a strengthening economy, faces a $2 billion gap between projected spending and revenues for the coming fiscal year.
"What these two surpluses in a row tell us is that we have brought the ship through those rough waters," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who announced the surplus on a statewide talk show on public television Thursday night. But, he added, "The surplus is not huge."
The stage is now set for the annual battle of the budget. Mr. Cuomo will introduce his spending plan for the next fiscal year on Tuesday, and he is expected to call for modest spending growth for education, new prison cells and youth programs, as well as cuts in some Medicaid services. He will also call for laying off 160 state workers, down sharply from the 2,495 layoffs Mr. Cuomo proposed in last year's budget.
 
Budget Fight Looms
 The surplus from the previous year is traditionally one of the first skirmishes of the new budget fight, with the Legislature demanding that the money be used for expanded services and Mr. Cuomo arguing that it should be used to close budget shortfalls.
This year, the Republicans who control the state Senate have predicted that the surplus will be $500 million. The Senate may raise its estimate and demand that the money be used to increase aid to the suburban school districts they represent, Senate Republican aides said.
In the strongest indication that the state's economy has turned, revenues from a range of state taxes are up from last year. Leading the way have been Wall Street financial firms and banks, whose end-of-the-year bonuses have translated into increased income tax revenues.
As of November, income taxes were up 8.8 percent, banking taxes were up 15.4 percent, estate taxes were up 21 percent and sales taxes were up 3.8 percent from the same period a year before. Sales tax revenues were particularly strong in New York City, Long Island and Westchester, where tax revenues have grown faster than inflation for three consecutive quarters.
This year's surplus is also the fruit of several consecutive seasons of state layoffs. Since 1991, the state work force has shrunk by about 25,000 positions.
 
Medicaid Growth Slows
 Also underlying the surplus has been a slight slowdown in the growth of Medicaid spending, which represents about 16 percent of the state's general fund budget. Aides to Mr. Cuomo said the Medicaid growth rate might dip into the single digits for the first time in several years, largely due to a leveling off of health care costs across the region.
The projected surplus would have been larger if Mr. Cuomo had not decided to use about $120 million of it for a Medicaid payment that was delayed last year to help eliminate a gap in that year's budget. Though the bill could have been paid out of next year's budget, his aides said Mr. Cuomo decided to retire it sooner in an effort to appease Wall Street, whose credit-rating agencies have given the state the second-lowest bond rating among the 50 states.
It has long been the hope of Cuomo aides that the state's bond rating would be raised this year, when Mr. Cuomo is seeking his fourth term as Governor.
For the coming budget year, the state faces a shortfall of about $3.3 billion, aides to Mr. Cuomo estimated. However, about $1.1 billion of that gap comes from scheduled reductions in personal income and hospital taxes, and the Legislature is likely to delay both rollbacks.
In his budget message to the Legislature on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo is expected to repeat his call for a state takeover of local Medicaid costs in exchange for a share of local tax revenues, something New York City has long sought. Under Mr. Cuomo's multiyear plan, the state would assume no local Medicaid costs this year, about $120 million the second year and an increasing amount in successive years.
But facing a $2.3 billion gap in next year's budget, New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani joined last week with the Republican county executives from Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland and Westchester Counties in imploring Mr. Cuomo to begin assuming local costs this year.
Though Mr. Cuomo's budget will not include the $120 million needed to do that, his aides said the Governor will call on Legislative leaders to discuss the idea -- in effect challenging Senate Republicans to help the city's new Republican Mayor.

HEADLINE: NEW SET OF DATA BOLSTERS OUTLOOK FOR THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that the economy grew at a rate exceeding 5 percent in the final quarter of 1993 as car and truck production powered an unexpectedly big jump in December industrial output. The operating rate of American factories, mines and utilities also climbed last month, reaching its busiest pace in four and a half years.
Many economists, who until recently had estimated economic growth in the final months of last year at about 4.5 to 5 percent, are beginning to raise their sights for this year, particularly for the year's first quarter. 
 "What is crystal clear is that the economy is showing even stronger demand" than most people had expected, said John Lipsky, an economist at Salomon Brothers.
 
Consumer Confidence Soars
 Prospects for a continuation of the rapid expansion were bolstered by the University of Michigan, which reported that its indexes of consumer confidence surged early this month.
The figures appeared to undermine a longstanding consensus among economists that business activity would repeat the pattern of a year ago in which holiday-season vigor was followed by a sharp slowdown early in the new year.
Salomon Brothers told its clients today that this time the economy was still gathering steam as the year ended. The momentum, it said, "probably will prove sufficient to sustain growth in a 3.5 to 4 percent range" in the early months of 1994.
 
Source of Optimism
 Mr. Lipsky said there was now little chance of a flip-flop in gross domestic product like the one that occurred when a 5.7 percent pace of expansion in the fourth quarter of 1992 was followed by expansion of just eight-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1993.
A major contributor to the current optimism that higher taxes and weak export prospects will not sink the recovery is the fact that interest rates, which have worked their magic on housing and cars, are still relatively low. The fact that rates were low a year ago did not forestall some softening in the beginning of last year, but proved a prime factor eventually in the acceleration of economic growth.
Although still lacking some data, particularly on international trade, Merrill Lynch now predicts that the Government will report in two weeks that the economy expanded at a 6 percent annual rate during the fourth quarter. This would be a pace comparable to the boom-like year of 1984, when total output of goods and services spurted 6.2 percent for the full year.
Between early December and early January, before this week's barrage of good news, the consensus fourth-quarter growth prediction of 50 forecasters in the Blue Chip survey had risen to 4.2 percent from 3.8 percent. Early this month, the 10 most optimistic economists had put the quarter's growth rate at 4.8 percent.
Analysts noted, however, that the fourth quarter would benefit from spending related to the continued efforts to recover from the summer's floods and drought.
While today's figures -- a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in industrial production and a jump in consumer sentiment to 95.8 from 88.2 -- sent interest rates up somewhat, many analysts expressed little alarm.
Indeed, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said today at a conference of mortgage bankers in New York that he expected inflation to remain in a 2.5 to 3 percent range this year, a level that would represent little or no acceleration from the 2.7 percent pace recorded for 1993. Interest rates, though they generally lag in affecting the economy, tend to track the inflation rate closely.
Robert Rubin, a senior economic adviser to President Clinton, said he saw no pressures to drive prices up at a time when there is global overcapacity in manufacturing and many economies remain sluggish. His comments could be seen as at least partly an effort to tell the Federal Reserve that the Administration wants it to avoid trying to head off the possibility of revived inflation with actions that might be premature now.
And though high operating rates in industry have traditionally been seen as harbingers of inflation, many analysts said today that the climb of recent months, which took capacity utilization to 83.5 percent in December, was probably benign.
 
Mitigating Factors
 They contend that actual capacity is substantially greater than the Federal Reserve's figures assume, reflecting a recent boom in capital spending.
"This investment has not been fully captured," said Mickey D. Levy, chief financial economist at Nationsbank in New York.
Analysts also cited improvements in productivity, estimated by Merrill Lynch to be growing more than 5 percent a year, that allow companies to produce more goods with fewer workers and other resources.
"Few bottlenecks are likely to develop in the coming year," said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist for Merrill Lynch.
The economy's resurgence since about Labor Day has bypassed some parts of the country. But even in California, which has been battered by military cutbacks, there are signs that the nationwide strength is bringing some stability. The state's unemployment rate, which stood at 9.8 percent as recently as October, has fallen more than a percentage point.
 
Revisions for Earlier Months
 Today's production report showed not only a seventh straight rise, but also presented revised data showing that the gains in October, November and December were each at least twice as large as those in any of the preceding four months.
Output at factories, which advanced seven-tenths of 1 percent, was concentrated in durable goods. Production of motor vehicles and parts jumped 4.9 percent in December.
In contrast to durable goods, which rose by 1.3 percent over all, nondurables like clothing, paper products and fuels fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month after rising six-tenths of 1 percent in November.
The operating rate for factories was put at 82.7 percent last month, with primary processing at 86 percent and advanced processing at 81.4 percent, the Fed report showed.
Output from mines, which includes oil wells, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after a November skid, while utility output posted another solid gain, 1 percent.
The University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment raced to 95.8 at its preliminary January reading from 88.2 in December, according to subscribers to the survey. This was the highest since September 1989.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 24.77 to Record In a Broad-Based Climb

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Stock prices surged across the board yesterday, pushing several key market indicators to record highs, as evidence of strong economic growth and higher corporate profits offset a rise in interest rates.
Technology and semiconductor stocks rose, led by Motorola, which reported strong earnings on Thursday. Electrical equipment, chemical, auto and entertainment stocks also gained. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.77 points, to 3,867.20, topping Monday's record of 3,865.51, and bringing its gain for the week to 46.43 points.
 
Reports Raise Confidence
 The stock market is "focusing on the strong economic numbers rather than the typical negative reaction in the bond market," where investors are wary of more inflation, said Philip Smyth, analyst at Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn.
A rash of reports raised confidence in the economic recovery. The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index surged to 95.8 in January from 88.2 in December, the highest reading in more than four years. Industrial production surged seven-tenths of a percent last month to the highest level since the middle of 1989.
Among broader market indicators, the Nasdaq combined composite index climbed 4.50 points, to 792.31, setting its second straight high, and the Dow Jones transportation average reached a record 1,834.81, up 10.73 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 2.44, to 474.91, near its Monday record of 475.27, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.17, to 262.90, which was just above Monday's record of 262.76.
Volume remained heavy on the New York Stock Exchange, where 304.9 million shares changed hands, up from 278 million Thursday.
 
An Upbeat Outlook
 "Investors are interpreting the environment as the best of all possible worlds," with "low interest rates, low inflation and solid corporate profits," said Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Sherwood Securities.
The outlook for stocks is bright as long as interest rates stay low, fueling the recovery and making stocks more attractive investments relative to fixed-income securities, investors said.
Stocks rallied even as long-term interest rates moved up yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond at 6.29 percent, up from 6.26 percent on Thursday.
"Something terrific's happening," said Cummins Catherwood, managing director at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood Inc. in Philadelphia. "We've got momentum, let's face it."
Shares of Motorola surged yesterday after it reported earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations.
"Any time a stock like Motorola reports better-than-expected earnings, the stock's going to go up," said Jack Baker, head of equity trading at Furman Selz Inc. "I don't see any selling pressure in the market."
 
Motorola Up 1
 Motorola, up 1 at 99, said late Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit rose to $1.15 a share from 64 cents. Analysts had forecast earnings of $1.03.
Among other technology stocks, Wellfleet Communications gained 2 3/8, to 70 1/8. It also posted stronger-than-expected earnings.
Bank stocks rose amid optimism about quarterly profits. Citicorp gained for a second day, rising 1 1/4, to 42, after it said on Thursday that it would post strong earnings and that it was getting rid of its money-losing Quotron business. J. P. Morgan rose 1 1/8, to 71 1/2, a day after it said fourth-quarter net income rose 77 percent. And Wells Fargo added 2 3/8, to 133 7/8, after setting a 52-week high of 134 1/8.
L.M. Ericsson Telephone's American depository receipts rose 3 3/8, to 45 1/2. A unit of the Swedish telecommunications company won a cellular telephone contract in South Africa.
But Excel Industries dropped 1/2, to 17 7/8. Ford Motor plans to sell its 24 percent stake in the maker of automotive window systems. Ford gained 3/8, to 68 1/4.
Castle Energy fell 3/8, to 10 1/8. The oil refiner said it might be hurt by problems at Metallgesellschaft, a troubled German company that is Castle's largest shareholder.
 
National Media Gains
 National Media rallied 2, to 10 1/4. Valuevision International, which owns 9.8 percent of National Media's stock, made a takeover proposal for the entire company. Valuevision fell 3/8, to 14 1/2.
The Medstat Group fell 2 1/4, to 13 3/4. The marketer of software to analyze medical claims was lowered to "sell" from long-term "attractive" at Equitable Securities.
In Tokyo yesterday, Japanese stocks staged a late-afternoon rally, pushing the Nikkei index of 225 issues up 396.44 points, or 2.13 percent, to end at 18,973.70.

HEADLINE: Beauty Beyond the Turnpike;
Jokes Aside, New Jersey Tries to Shed Inferiority Complex

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Here's a classic New Jersey story, offered instructively as Christine Todd Whitman prepares to govern a state with probably more diversity than it knows what to do with.
Two business travelers on a plane strike up a conversation. Both are from New Jersey but don't know it. 
 "Where are you from?"
"New York."
"You live in Manhattan?"
"No, I live outside."
"Brooklyn?"
"Actually, I live across the river. In New Jersey. Montclair."
"Gee, that's a terrific town. Why didn't you say so?"
"Well, if I say that, people will make cracks about New Jersey. If I say I'm from New York, everybody accepts that I'm an O.K. guy."
 
<SC0>Beauty Beyond the Exit Ramps
 The storyteller, Gordon A. MacInnes Jr., a Morristown Democrat who recently won a State Senate seat, is encouraged that such encounters with closet New Jerseyans seem to be decreasing. It is a sure sign of progress in the battle to separate the words New Jersey from Turnpike and to make America and Jay Leno understand that, yes, there is beauty beyond the exit ramps.
For Mrs. Whitman, who takes figurative command of the state's 567 fiercely independent municipalities and 21 counties on Tuesday, the challenge will be to forge and burnish a cohesive image of a state whose residents sometimes seem to have only their differences in common.
Do its commuters identify with New York, Philadelphia or the town where they sleep and eat? Can those who live "down the Shore" understand those in the Highlands or the Pine Barrens? Can gentrified suburbanites shed a tear (or a tax dollar) for the poor of Camden or Newark?
All these people, and more, live in New Jersey, but do they recognize their New Jerseyness? Can they be persuaded to? Increasingly, pollsters and pundits say, they do and they can.
Most armchair sociologists date this image transformation to the "era of good feeling" under the popular Gov. Thomas H. Kean ("New Juhsey and you. Puhfect togethah," 1981-1989). It continued for four years under his successor, the unpopular Gov. Jim Florio, who despite rough political and economic times, kept the nation focused on his battles over taxes, gun control and welfare reform -- and away from questions like, "Is Jimmy Hoffa really buried in the end zone at Giants Stadium?"
And now, with recessionary forces abating, Mrs. Whitman is poised to inherit this small (46th in area) powerhouse of a state that exhibits more contradictions than Edward J. Rollins Jr. and over the years has had an image problem nearly as large as his. Lots of work remains to do on that, but even New Jersey catches a break once in a while. After all, it is not Long Island.
New Jersey's essential enigma (its identity crisis) is a big one, though, and it was crystallized in a song, "I'm From New Jersey," that has haunted the halls of the State House in Trenton for more than 35 years. Its author, Red Mascara of Phillipsburg, has unsuccessfully lobbied all this time to adopt these words as the official state song:
I'm from New Jersey and I'm proud about it, I love the Garden State.
I'm from New Jersey and I want to shout it, I think it's simply great.
Immortal phrases? Perhaps not. But Mr. Mascara's ardent chauvinism exposes the core of the problem. To proclaim I'm from New Jersey is to prompt another question: So what does that mean?
 
Blueberries and Cranberries
 Well, it means its citizens live in the nation's most densely populated state -- the only one with more than 1,000 inhabitants per square mile -- yet almost 60 percent of its land is forest or farm. It has 127 miles of Atlantic beachfront and 1,400 miles of trout streams, ranks second in production of cultivated blueberries and third in cranberries.
It leads in pharmaceuticals and telecommunications, and its tourism industry -- the beaches, Atlantic City, ocean and stream fishing -- contributes almost 10 percent of the state's gross product.
As the first all-suburban state, New Jersey has no major city. Its six largest contain less than 10 percent of the population, most of it poor. It has more horses and more scientists per capita than any other state. Parts of its northern and western counties resemble Vermont (though no one has ever said that Vermont resembles New Jersey) and nearly a quarter of the state is the wild and pristine Pine Barrens in the south. If the Mason-Dixon Line had been extended, a fractionof New Jersey would have been in the Old South.
And while it strives to market the New Jersey name -- "Jersey Fresh," New Jersey Transit, NJN (the state-run cable television network), "New Jersey and You" -- it is the only state that does not lend its name to the state university system. In fact, for too many years, too many high school graduates sought their college degrees beyond its borders.
 
Now, About the Turnpike
 One New Jersey name needs no introduction: the turnpike, with its notorious vistas of gas and oil tank farms at the northern exits. It's a tough picture to paper over, so it's easy to forget that New Jersey was home to the first incandescent lamp (Menlo Park, 1879), the first condensed soup (Camden, 1897) and the first solid-body electric guitar (Les Paul, Mahwah, 1940).
Easier to remember is that this quaint colony of George III later nurtured the corrupt political machine of Frank Hague in Jersey City, provided the setting for the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby and toxic-waste dumps and produced Henry Krajewski, a Secaucus pig farmer who ran for President.
And one day, about a century ago, probably on a vaudeville stage in Manhattan, a baggy-pants comic searching for a sure-fire insult came up with a line about Joisey. There simply aren't enough dignified antidotes to invoke -- not Princeton University, not Woodrow Wilson, not William J. Brennan, the former United States Supreme Court Justice -- to overcome one well-timed Joisey jape.
Like its cousins -- Brooklyn, Peoria, Cleveland and Oshkosh -- New Jersey at the turn of the century was meant to be funny simply because it wasn't New York, wasn't big time, wasn't sophisticated. It was flat, it was farms, it was hayseeds at large. It was, in fact, exactly what Benjamin Franklin said: a "keg tapped at both ends," a stepchild of two political bullies, Philadelphia and New York City. Through the 1940's, it was also the grimy industrial state where more than half the jobs were in manufacturing -- those that weren't on the piers.
 
From a Lemon, Lemonade
 What can you do with a state like that? You learn to turn liabilities into assets. You learn that with maturity often comes sophistication. You gain the wisdom to accept what you can't change -- you can't pretend the turnpike doesn't exist.
So last fall, confronting the What exit do you live near? refrain, the State Division of Tourism issued a guidebook with maps of all major roads, their exits and brief descriptions of notable sites within 10 miles of the off-ramps. It is called the Road Scholar program.

With the inauguration of Christine Todd Whitman set for Tuesday, workers are scurrying to reflect the change. Jill Metzier of the Department of Banking removed the departing Gov. Jim Florio's name from her lobby wall in Trenton. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Justices to Decide on a Right Of Review of a Jury's Award

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the right to judicial review of a jury's award of damages is constitutionally required to protect defendants against excessive judgments.
The case is a challenge to an Oregon rule that makes the size of jury awards unreviewable either by the state trial judge or by an appellate court. The Supreme Court appeal was brought by the Honda Motor Company, which an Oregon jury ordered to pay $735,000 in compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages to a man who was injured when a three-wheel all-terrain vehicle made by Honda flipped over on him. 
 While the case concerns damages in general, the Court's focus will almost certainly be on the punitive damages aspect. Five times in recent years the Court has tried and failed to articulate a constitutional theory for limiting the multimillion-dollar punitive awards that have been a growing concern to the business community.
A majority of the Court appears to share this concern, but has been unable to agree on an approach. Just last June, for example, the Court upheld a $10 million punitive damages award for a $19,000 economic injury. The 6-to-3 ruling in that case, TXO Production Corporation v. Alliance Resources Corporation, was not supported by a single majority opinion, and the predominant tone in the plurality opinion was one of discomfort with the outcome.
 
Effect Could Be Narrow
 Two years before that, the Court suggested that some punitive damages awards can be so "extreme" as to violate the constitutional requirement of due process of law. But that decision, Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company v. Haslip, which upheld a punitive damage award of $840,000 in a $3,800 insurance fraud, stopped well short of specifying when that point might be reached.
The case the Court accepted today, Honda Motor Company v. Oberg, No. 93-644, will not necessarily lead to a more definitive result. The Court's ruling could be narrow, with little significance outside Oregon, the only state that bars judicial review of the size of a jury's damage award. Even if the Court agrees with Honda that the absence of any review procedure at all violates due process, the decision would not necessarily illuminate the more general punitive damages questions.
On the other hand, if the Justices viewed the case only as a challenge to an anomalous law of a single state, they would not necessarily have agreed to review it. The case offers a vehicle for a broader ruling on whether the Constitution's due process guarantee places limits on other states' procedures for handling punitive damage awards.
Under Oregon law, judges may review jury damage awards to determine whether there was sufficient evidence to support the verdict. But the size of the award itself is insulated from judicial review by a provision of the state constitution that the Oregon Supreme Court has interpreted as barring judges from reconsidering a jury's factual determinations. The Oregon Supreme Court rejected Honda's constitutional challenge to this rule in a decision last May.
Honda is basing its appeal to the United States Supreme Court in part on a long tradition in English and American law of providing judicial review for the size of jury verdicts. Juries' decisions on damages are "fraught with the risk of injustice," the appeal asserts, particularly when the defendant is a big out-of-state corporation. "The risk of aberrational results is simply too high" to go unreviewed, Honda told the Court.
The plaintiff in the case, Karl L. Oberg, suffered head injuries when his all-terrain vehicle flipped over on him as he tried to drive it up a steep embankment. The jury found that he was 20 percent at fault in the accident, with the manufacturer bearing 80 percent of the fault. The trial court permitted his lawyers to introduce statistics compiled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission on the large number of injuries associated with these three-wheel vehicles.
 
Accountant Rule to Be Heard
 In another case, the Court agreed to hear a Florida lawyer's constitutional challenge to a state rule that bars lawyers who are also certified public accountants or certified financial planners from using those designations on their business cards, letterheads or listings in the yellow pages.
The rule, enforced by the Florida Board of Accountancy, was challenged unsuccessfully in the state courts by Silvia S. Ibanez, a lawyer who also holds a state license as an accountant and represents clients in Internal Revenue Service proceedings. Her listing in the yellow pages, which an anonymous sender mailed to the accountancy board, included her C.P.A. designation. The board reprimanded her on the ground that the listing was "inherently misleading" because she was not conducting an accounting practice.
Her Supreme Court appeal, Ibanez v. Florida, No. 93-639, argues that the state rule infringes her First Amendment right of commercial speech. The Justices have been sympathetic to similar arguments. Last year they struck down the same state board's limit on the right of accountants to solicit clients.

HEADLINE: Messages for Neediest Cases: Someone Cares

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
For many regular contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, sending a donation is a way to show gratitude for business success, to remember a loved one, to celebrate an anniversary or simply to feel they have done their civic duty. The checks arrive with a small note attached or sometimes with only a few words jotted next to a signature.
But there are scores of other donors who feel it is not enough just to contribute. In a city where friendliness can seem in short supply and where it is easy to become inured to suffering, these donors see the Neediest Cases Fund as a way to let their fellow New Yorkers know that they are still affected by the poverty they see around them every day. 
 "This is really a beautiful season," wrote Liv Hempel of Manhattan, who gave $250. "But it's also one of the saddest times of the year. You are constantly confronted with the terrible discrepancy of haves and have-nots. It's time for those of us who have something to be thankful for to share some of it with those so much less fortunate."
Jed A. Levine sent $50 along with a letter describing his family's mourning at the death of his grandmother, Lillie Levine, who was 96. "Sadly, this year has also been a difficult one for the city that we love," he added. "The streets are filled with ever-increasing numbers of homeless men, women and children. Violence has become so commonplace that we are in danger of becoming complacent about the random deaths of innocent citizens. Many of this city's children go to bed at night hungry and hurting. It is our hope that this contribution will help."
 
'Where Are Our Priorities?'
 Some letters convey a rising sense of frustration. "The amount of suffering and deprivation seen on the streets of New York grows worse and less tolerable every year," wrote Bernice K. Leader of Wayne, N.J., who sent $50. "Where are our priorities? How can we ignore the plight of fellow human beings? Why isn't enough being done to eliminate the problems of homelessness, hunger and poverty? I feel more helpless and hopeless every year."
Others, like Irene and Albert Libchaber of Princeton, N.J., hold out cautious optimism. "We have hope this year will improve the economic state of the homeless," they wrote in a letter accompanying their $400 donation. "Recovery has not yet arrived and I know our check is a drop in a well of desperation. But we have to be thankful and share as much as we can."
The Times pays all overhead costs for the campaign, which is in its 82d year, allowing donations to be sent directly to seven charities to assist the homeless, the hungry, the abused and the mentally ill. The campaign continues until Feb. 28.
Many of the donors' letters say they hope their contributions set an example to encourage others to give. "I'm sending more than usual this year," wrote B. J. Goodspeed of Fairfield, Conn., who enclosed a check for $300. "The need is so great and I feel so fortunate that everyone in my family is healthy and happy. Sometimes I wonder how I got so lucky."

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Securities Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices fell yesterday, closing a week of seesaw trading. Stronger-than-expected economic data released yesterday continued to rattle bond traders who were already worried about economic growth, the potential for rising inflation and possible moves by the Federal Reserve to tighten credit.
By late in the day yesterday, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond declined 1/2 point, to 9917/32 , to yield 6.29 percent, up from 6.26 percent on Thursday. The rate on shorter maturities rose slightly, with three-month and six-month bills up 2 basis points, to 2.96 percent and 3.14 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 After some early strength, strong numbers on industrial production in December, up seven-tenths of 1 percent, and capacity utilization, reported at 83.5 percent in December, helped depress prices of Government securities. The production gain was higher than the four-tenths of a percent that had been expected, and capacity utilization was in line with expectations.
 
G.D.P. Growth Expected
 In addition, November business inventories were up six-tenths of a percent, compared with a revised figure for October of three-tenths of a percent. Analysts said the unexpected surge following a sharp upward revision could bolster the market's forecast for fourth-quarter growth in the real gross domestic product.
And the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey for January showed solid gains.
Such signs of economic strength worry bond traders because a growing economy has a tendency to generate inflationary pressures, which erode the value of fixed-income investments.
Traders said the market was likely to waffle through the next couple of weeks as it waits for January statistics and starts to shift some of its focus toward supply.
Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company, Chicago, said that yesterday's trading was an extension of Thursday's, with losses from strong economic data providing an impetus for selling.
 
Brooding Over the Fed
 "Basically there has been a shift from last week to this week, with the market first believing the Fed will tighten in the second half and then back to thinking it will happen late in the first quarter," Mr. Dederick said. "And unless there is good news for the market, the brooding over some Fed action will begin soon.
"The market is also thinking increasingly of supply again, with the Treasury announcing next week the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions and upcoming February quarterly refunding."
Because the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday will be observed on Monday, the Government securities market will be closed, although other financial markets will be open. The Treasury will hold its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills on Tuesday.
 
Pressure on Rates
 Most of the market is aware that the Fed will eventually have to nudge short-term rates higher. With the first-quarter data a crucial variable for the Fed in deciding when and how much to act, the market is concerned that the strength seen in the late fourth-quarter figures, and now the early reading of consumer sentiment in January, will push up the Fed's timetable.
Analysts at MMS International continue to believe that the Fed will not act before it gets more hard evidence that the economic growth will be sustained in the first quarter. Thus, it will wait for at least a couple of months of data before deciding on a course of action, traders say.
Meanwhile, "prices will back up further and possibly the market will digest all the data, Mr. Dederick said. "But until something new comes along, prices will slither down a bit," he added.
At a briefing for foreign journalists in New York, Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of the National Economic Council, estimated that the economy would grow about 3 percent this year and said he saw no new inflationary pressures.

HEADLINE: Democrats Offer a Plan For Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Seeking to move ahead of New York's new Republican Mayor on tax cuts, the two most powerful Democrats on the City Council offered a plan yesterday to reduce taxes on commercial rents, hotel rooms and cooperative apartments and condominiums.
Later Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani endorsed the principle of cutting taxes on city businesses. He said that he would present a budget on Feb. 2 that included some cuts in the hotel tax and the commercial occupancy tax but that he believed that a reduction in the property tax on co-ops and condominiums was unlikely this year. 
 "There's no question that one of the things that we have to do is to show some reduction in taxes as an economic incentive," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference at City Hall yesterday afternoon. "The question becomes, 'How far can we go in that direction when we have $2.3 billion deficit?' "
In announcing their plan, the Democratic leaders -- the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, and the chairman of the Finance Committee, Herbert E. Berman -- proposed cuts that would cost the city $72 million in lost revenue. They said, however, that the cuts would bolster the city's economy by easing the burdens that taxes have imposed on businesses, tourists and homeowners.
 
Opening Bids
 The proposals amounted to the opening bids in the complex, sometimes wrenching negotiations between the Mayor and the City Council over the budget, which is for the fiscal year that begins in July.
Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman said the cuts were feasible, despite the looming deficit, because of higher-than-anticipated increases in revenue from taxes on personal income, banks and corporations.
Those increases, which their aides estimate could total $170 million by the end of the year, appear to reflect the tentative improvements in the city's economy, a day after the Department of Finance reported that the value of the city's real estate continued to decline. Breaking with the Democrats' call for protecting city services whenever possible, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman said they felt that it was now more important to reduce the city's most regressive taxes -- even if it meant Mr. Giuliani had to cut some services.
"While we agree that the budget difficulties facing the city are a serious concern, we remain committed to a strategy for tax reform that will send a message that New York City is a good place to live and do business," Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman wrote in a letter to Mr. Giuliani.
 
Jostling for Voter Support
 By moving to propose cuts ahead of the Mayor, Mr. Vallone, the city government's ranking Democrat, has tried to become the first to offer tax relief to merchants and homeowners, as the Democrats seek to recapture the support of the frustrated middle-class voters who helped elect Mr. Giuliani.
For his part, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he was glad the Democrats "had joined him" in seeking tax cuts for businesses, particularly small businesses.
Under the plan outlined by Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman, the city would increase the number of businesses exempted from the 6-percent tax on rents for commercial space. The tax is now levied against businesses that pay more than $11,000 in rent each year in Manhattan below 96th Street or more than $15,715 elsewhere. The city has already approved raising the exemptions to $21,000 and $30,000, but the new proposal would raise them to $28,000 and $40,000. The change would exempt 12,000 businesses of the roughly 90,000 that now pay the tax.
The tax, first imposed in 1964 and unique among municipal taxes in the nation, has long been criticized by merchants and business leaders.
The change would cost the city about $20 million next year.
Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman also proposed reducing the city's tax on hotel rooms to 5 percent from 6 percent over the next two years. Last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a gradual reduction in the state's 5 percent tax on hotel rooms.
 
An Appeal to Cuomo
 Mr. Giuliani has appealed to the Governor to reduce the state's share of the tax on hotel rooms, which totals 19.25 percent. Also, New York City assesses a flat $2 fee on rooms costing more than $100. Yesterday, he said he would also propose reducing the city's share, as Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman proposed.
While the tax raises $120 million a year for the city, many argue that it has hurt tourism, particularly through a boycott by the Professional Convention Management Association.
The other proposed cut would reduce the taxes on co-ops, condominiums and apartment buildings, which are taxed at a higher rate than homes for one, two or three families. For example, the owner of a single-family home worth $255,000 pays $1,950 a year in property tax, while the owner of a comparably valued co-op pays $3,900, according to City Council financial advisers.
Mr. Vallone and Mr. Berman proposed phasing in a reduction of the tax on those properties over the next decade. While the reduction would cost $44 million in the next year alone, Mr. Berman argued that it would allow more people, especially young people, to afford homes and that it could spark "a real estate boom."
At a news conference, Mr. Giuliani played down the possibility of the cut in property taxes but said he would keep an open mind as his aides prepare a preliminary budget.
Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson praised the spirit of the proposed tax cuts, saying it was important that the Mayor and the Council work to improve the city's image among the business leaders. "A few small cuts will say to them, 'It's not getting any worse,' " Mr. Dyson said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips After Reaching 2-Year High Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped after rising to a two-year high against the German mark yesterday, as traders sold it to lock in their profits ahead of the weekend.
The dollar also lost ground against the Japanese yen. 
 Gold prices fell in New York after finishing mostly higher overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery slipped 50 cents, to $390.10 an ounce.
The dollar rose in early trading yesterday against European currencies after the Federal Reserve reported a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in production at United States factories, mines and utilities in December.
 
Consumer Confidence Helps
 Also pushing up the dollar was an increase in the University of Michigan's survey of consumer confidence, to 95.8 percent in the first part of January from 88.2 percent in December. The data were further evidence that the United States economy was pulling away from the European and Japanese economies.
The dollar, which hit a two-year closing record of 1.7505 German marks on Thursday, traded as high as 1.7565 marks yesterday before turning around as investors cashed in. It ended the day in New York at 1.7495 marks.
"Market participants used the industrial production numbers and market sentiment numbers as a way to essentially take profits on their gains," said David De Rosa, a director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
 
Decline Against Yen
 The dollar continued to decline against the Japanese yen as foreign investors piled into the Tokyo stock market. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 110.98 yen, down from 111.77 yen on Thursday.
The dollar was also hurt by trader fears that Washington would start to "talk up" the value of the yen, Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said.
"The market is looking at the lack of progress in trade talks between the U.S. and Japan," he said.
Clinton Administration officials expressed concern recently when the yen softened. A weaker yen could cause America's trade deficit to expand, since it can make Japanese exports cheaper.
Meanwhile, the British pound fell in New York to $1.4934, from $1.4977 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Weather Gives Heating Oil Biggest Day's Gain in a Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Heating oil prices soared about 5 percent yesterday, the biggest one-day gain in more than a year, as the longest sustained cold spell since the mid-1980's settled over much of the continental United States.
Rises for copper and heating oil lifted the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities to a three-year high. The index, a gauge of inflation, rose about a point to settle at 228.86. 
 Weather forecasters have predicted weekend temperatures of around 0 degrees Fahrenheit in both Chicago and New York. The weather in the Northeastern states has been colder than normal since Christmas and no let-up is expected this month.
Jerry Samuels, managing director with Arb Oil in Los Angeles, said that "it's a heating-oil-dominated market" and that prices could move higher "as long as that cold weather continues."
Light sweet crude oil for February delivery gained 27 cents, to $14.78 a barrel, while heating oil jumped 2.35 cents, to 51.26 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline gained 0.66 cent, to 42.56 cents a gallon.
Natural gas prices soared 3 percent as well, to a five-week high. Gas has soared 23 percent since Dec. 21, and heating oil has leaped 16 percent since Dec. 28.
Even with the sharp rise in home heating fuels, prices remain depressed, Mr. Samuels said. A year ago, heating oil sold for about 60 cents a gallon, he said, "so there's room to go up."
 
Copper Hits 4-Month High
 In the copper market, traders bet that strong American economic growth would stimulate demand, sending future prices surging to a four-month high. Copper is used in many industrial applications and demand is thought to rise when economic activity increases.
"It's strictly speculative," said Robert Lesemann, an analyst with Resource Strategies Inc. in Exton, Pa. "Granted, the economic outlook in the U.S. is good, and demand here has been very good." Even so, he added: "It's very myopic to look at the copper market and draw conclusions based on the U.S. Demand from Japan is still very poor."
Copper for March delivery jumped 1.55 cent, to 84.50 cents, a pound on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Stockpiles have not fallen enough for the supply-demand balance to improve, Mr. Lesemann said, with world stockpiles still 600,000 tons above normal.

HEADLINE: When Devilish Details Block a Mortgage

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
Dr. Daniel Fass, a radiation oncologist with a private practice in Greenwich, Conn., and his wife, Jessica, expected to breeze through the mortgage process for their first home. After all, he had the money for a down payment, a squeaky clean credit history and a rock-solid career.
The lender sized up the situation far differently. Dr. Fass was rejected because he could not show that his practice had been profitable for at least two years, the customary requirement for someone self-employed. "It was a real Catch-22," he said, explaining that his office had been open only a year. 
 Like many first-time home buyers, the Fasses learned that anything unusual can stymie a mortgage application and that lenders have changed since the free-wheeling 80's. "The screws have definitely been tightened," said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage tracking company in Butler, N.J. He cited as reasons the increases in both delinquency and default rates during the recession and the regulatory pressure on lenders.
First-time buyers get particular scrutiny, Mr. Havemann said, because they are notorious for fudging the facts out of fear of being rejected. And many of the people flooding into the housing market, where sales rose to a seven-and-a-half-year high in November, are first-timers, as low rates and low prices combine to make housing more affordable. This week, the average fixed rate on 30-year mortgages fell below 7 percent.
For the millions of Americans considering a home purchase this year, self-employment is just one of the potential stumbling blocks. Problems may arise over an incorrect or a tarnished credit report. Even a history of paying bills on time may be insufficient. Sometimes lenders balk at multiple credit cards, which expose the potential for future debt.
With some persistence, such obstacles can generally be surmounted. The Fasses, for example, ultimately triumphed with the help of a mortgage broker who found a more accommodating lender.
The hassle, though, could be costly. If your mortgage application is delayed, someone else may step in to buy the house you so desire. Or interest rates may rise while you smooth out problems. And if the lenders with the best rates completely reject you, you will wind up paying more.
A few simple steps can help make the most of your situation.
Among the easiest problems to detect is an error on a credit report. Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services of Manhattan, advises people to contact the three big reporting agencies -- TRW, Equifax Inc. and the Trans Union Corporation -- before they even apply for a loan. A mortgage broker can also screen your record through available data bases.
If you find an erroneous entry, you will probably have to send a letter of explanation to the bureau, which will contact the source of the problem. If a legitimate debt appears on your report, say a long-forgotten unpaid account at a department store in another city, you may want to contact the lender and set up a payment plan.
Mortgage brokers, real estate brokers and lawyers can all provide advice on how to deal with a credit problem. A credit advocate or counseling agency might be able to help. Be cautious, though; fraud has been a problem in this unregulated business. Make sure the credit counselor will do more than charge $100 for copies of your credit reports, available for no more than a nominal fee.
Steven Berman, president of Credit Advocates of Manhattan, said he would negotiate with creditors for a settlement of overdue debts, urging them to accept partial payment, at an average cost to the client of $400. To finish the job, he gets creditors to submit a clearance letter to remove the blot from credit reports.
Any delinquency on a credit report or unusual gap in employment history should be explained in a letter accompanying a mortgage application. For example, if bills fell overdue because of an illness, divorce or layoff, inform the lender and explain that payments have otherwise been timely. The same applies to a break in work because of a death in the family or some other crisis.
Of course, mortgage makers may still balk, even at apparently good credit records. Cathy Huskins and her husband, Dennis, stumbled over a problem last fall. Because they had paid a mortgage in the past and owned some property outright, they considered their record stellar.
"We owed no money," said Mrs. Huskins, who lives in Fairfield County, Conn. "We had no car loans, no debt." Yet the couple had a total of $150,000 in credit lines on about a dozen credit cards, none of which they were using. They had to cancel all but two of those cards before they could borrow $100,000.
Geri Detweiler, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer education group in Herndon, Va., said lenders used to look only at the amount of debt outstanding, but now delve deeper. "You could run up bills on all those card tomorrow," she explained, "and not be able to pay your mortgage."
Because home lenders still consider an applicant's total debt, it may be wise to postpone major purchases, like a new car, until after buying a house. In any case, home buyers will want to pay off credit cards and other debt where possible, to keep the total, including mortgage payments, under the lender's benchmark of 36 percent of gross monthly income.
A lender may be unwilling to approve a loan if it appraises a house for less than the selling price, a particular problem in the Northeast. Alternatives include renegotiating with the sellers, challenging the appraisal by showing similar valuations in the market and asking the sellers to finance the difference.
The simplest solution might be to try another lender, since appraisals vary, as well as down payments. Some lenders permit a 5 to 10 percent down payment instead of the usual 20 percent. Countrywide Funding of Pasadena, Calif., for example, makes low-down-payment loans with geographic and income restrictions, and most government-backed loan programs have relaxed requirements.
Scanning the market can be time-consuming, whether looking for a lender who will be flexible or simply finding the best rate. One way to simplify the process is to hire a mortgage broker, who receives a commission from the lender and should not add to the borrower's cost.
For Dr. Fass, Vicky Papson, a mortgage broker in Stamford, Conn., found Pawling Savings Bank in Pawling, N.Y., a small lender that specializes in helping physicians. To obtain a mortgage on a four-bedroom house from the bank, Dr. Fass reluctantly agreed to pay 25 percent in cash, instead of 20 percent. As he found, a bigger down payment may persuade lenders to overlook certain imperfections in an application.
TRW can be reached at (800) 392-1122; Equifax at (800) 879-4094 and Trans Union at (800) 851-2674. The cost of each credit report should not exceed $8. For $24, Credco Inc. will supply a comprehensive report and can be reached at (800) 443-9342.

HEADLINE: CAVEAT EMPTOR;
Low Interest Rates in Credit Card Offers Are Often Just Teasers

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
The new year brings an onslaught of credit card offers -- some very enticing to consumers laden with holiday bills.
If the offers look too good to be true, make sure you read the fine print. A popular ploy is a teaser rate, a very low initial rate that may rise markedly after a short period. 
 A New York woman recently received a letter from a unit of the Banc One Corporation offering a pre-approved Visa card at an annual rate of just 5.9 percent. Only by studying the fine print on a small enclosed card did she discover that this rate would soar after her August billing period to the prime rate, now 6 percent, plus 9.9 percentage points, for a total of 15.9 percent, slightly above the national average.
"This is very confusing for consumers," said Gerri E. Detweiler, executive director of the Bankcard Holders of America. "It is one of those cases where consumers have to read every word."
John W. Fisher, Banc One's marketing manager, defended the practice. "We say in several locations in the letter that it is a low introductory rate," he said.
Federal law requires all applications and solicitations for credit cards to state somewhere what the annual percentage rate is, whether it is variable and how it is determined. Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, introduced a bill last April to require additional disclosure. "I'd like to see the actual interest rate be clear as a bell to the consumer," he said.
Consolidating holiday bills on a low-rate card could make sense, especially if consumers pay off the balance before the rate rises. Issuers, of course, expect few people to cut up their cards. "I don't think any credit card issuer wants a short-term relationship," said Mr. Fisher of Banc One.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Junk Bond Group May Have Some Life Left

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
The junk bond market bottomed out in late 1989 and 1990, and then took off like a rocket, resulting in 20 percent-plus annual gains for many of the top junk funds over the last three years.
Those big returns are not likely to continue, analysts say. Still, the category may have some life left. 
 For one thing, junk bonds are less sensitive to interest rates than long-term Government issues. Therefore, any rise in rates would be less painful for junk-bond holders. Also, junk bonds stand to benefit from any improvement in the economy. That's because the issuers of the bonds would grow more creditworthy.
But don't overlook the risks, said Erik Laughlin, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the mutual fund rating company in Chicago. The American economy might slip back into recession, he said, or the bond market might correct.
Low interest rates may also have lured smaller issuers to the junk bond market -- with riskier issues. Finally, "there's been such a huge issuance that if demand dries up, there can be an oversupply and a drop in price," Mr. Laughlin said.

HEADLINE: Jim Florio's Good Governance

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio did the right thing, and that is why his time is up. Christine Todd Whitman succeeds him as New Jersey's chief executive on Tuesday, in large part because of the huge hike in taxes enacted in his first 100 days. It was a necessary move, but many voters regarded it as a betrayal. It set off a tax revolt that propelled the Republicans in 1992 to control of the Legislature, and now Mrs. Whitman to the governor's mansion.
If Jim Florio failed on that count, he succeeded on gun control. In the same burst of activity that saw reluctant Democratic legislators approve his tax bill, he put through a ban on semiautomatic assault weapons. New Jersey was first to do so; Governor Florio dared take on the powerful lobbyists of the National Rifle Association. Indeed, he beat them twice, on the original legislation in 1991 and again last year when he stood down the now-Republican Legislature's attempt at repeal. 
 In the battle over guns, he had the public on his side; in the battle over taxes, just the opposite. Campaigning in 1989 against a no-new-taxes Republican, he implied a pledge of his own -- "I see no need to raise taxes." On taking office, the need was all too clear -- to close a yawning budget gap, to ease the burden of property taxes and to comply with a court order to increase aid for urban schools. But when he moved to raise income and sales taxes by $2.8 billion, virtually without warning, and without building a consensus, public reaction was angry and demonstrative.
In the fall of 1990 Mrs. Whitman nearly unseated Senator Bill Bradley by hounding him for taking no stand on the Florio taxes, and a year later the voters installed veto-proof Republican majorities in both houses of the Legislature. Mr. Florio, chastened, became less daring.
Nonetheless, he built a record of using government constructively. He attacked pollution on the state's long oceanfront beaches, vital for attracting vacationers and for New Jersey's economy. He overhauled the automobile insurance system, which had been a key issue in his election campaign. He put more money into helping people on welfare with job training, education and day care, but cracked down on women who bore more children while collecting welfare payments.
Jim Florio entered public service as a State Assemblyman in 1969. He went to Washington with the Watergate class of 1974, and spent 15 years in the House. His election as Governor in 1989 was a landslide, his defeat last year a 26,000-vote squeaker. In those 25 years, he earned the respect of his state and the nation as a politician with backbone.

HEADLINE: Helping Russia -- and Ourselves

 BODY:
Why should the United States spend $3 billion this year to help revive Russia's crumbling economy? The answer: Containing the fractious, militaristic Russia that might emerge from total economic collapse could cost 10 times that much every year. With Russia stabilized and tranquil, America could substantially reduce the defense budget and plow the savings into reclaiming our cities, revitalizing our failed education system and preparing for the challenges of the next century.
Only now is Bill Clinton wresting the problem from the International Monetary Fund and speeding the aid the U.S. has already pledged. By taking the initiative, he shows he understands how much Americans have to lose from further delay. 
 Mr. Clinton needs to sell Americans on the dividend that will flow from the Russian rescue, and suggest how that dividend will be spent. At the same time he needs to acknowledge that it may already be too late to save Russian reform but that, even so, he has no choice but to proceed.
America has pledged its share of aid to Russia, but it has yet to deliver many dollars. It cannot let the opportunity slip away once more. The aid must be delivered even before Russia tightens its budget by shrinking subsidies to unproductive factories. Russia's reformers face a real dilemma. To bring the budget under control they have to put people out of work -- and worse.
The factory for most Russians means more than a job; it is their social safety net. It feeds and houses them. And it keeps paying them even if they aren't producing anything -- a form of unemployment insurance. The recent election results signal a resurgence of nationalism. But even scarier forces could be unleashed by closing down the factories and leaving millions destitute.
That's why Russia needs a new social safety net not tied to the factory. To get one started, it needs outside help.
Mr. Clinton and other Western leaders need to make good on their aid pledges now. And they need to persuade taxpayers to put up money for Russia's unemployed when their own people are experiencing many times Russia's unemployment rate.
Mr. Clinton himself summoned up the reasons in a town hall meeting in Moscow yesterday.
"It is in our interest," he told the Russians, "to be able to spend less on defense and to invest more in our own people, in the education and health and welfare and technology that will help to carry us into a better time in the 21st century. It is in our interest to curb the spread of weapons of mass destruction and to cooperate with you in reducing threats to peace all around the world. It is in our interest to develop new trade ties and new customers. And each of these developments is more likely if we have a genuine equal partnership with a strong and free Russia."
Now Mr. Clinton needs to say that to Americans. It takes the courage to change, as he once put it. That's true, and not only for Russians.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Smoke Bomb

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
Thirty years ago this week, the first Surgeon General's report linking cigarette smoking to cancer was released in Washington. The press conference was held on a Saturday, lest the news cause a panic on Wall Street.
Ever since, the relationship between commerce, health and cigarettes has been a touchy and a two-faced one. On the one hand the government facilitates the sale and use of tobacco through farm programs and trade negotiations. On the other it decries its use through scientific papers and public education. 
 Under current Food and Drug Administration regulations, cigarettes would not be accepted for marketing if they were introduced today. But cigarettes have never been classified as either food or drug, which would require them to be safe and effective; they're classified as a "device of pleasure." Tobacco has always had friends in high places.
Yet despite the best efforts of elected officials amply compensated in campaign contributions and well-connected lobbyists amply compensated in fees, the tobacco industry has not succeeded in maintaining its standing in the United States. Where about 42 percent of all Americans smoked at the time of the Surgeon General's first report, now the number is down to about 25 percent. Once Americans got wise to the health consequences of smoking, there was only one thing left for the industry to do: Kill 'em abroad.
Philip Morris has acquired a controlling interest in what was once the state-owned Czech tobacco company. In Russia, it is building a factory in St. Petersburg and has agreed to assume a 49 percent stake and eventually the majority interest in a plant in Krasnodar, south of Moscow. In that factory, the company hopes to double cigarette production within three years.
This summer Philip Morris announced that it had reached an agreement with the China National Tobacco Corporation to produce and sell Marlboros and other brands in China. American trade negotiations in recent years have also made it possible for American tobacco companies to compete with home-grown competitors in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea.
An oncologist in Tokyo said several years ago that he was constantly asked the same question: "Why are Americans trying to encourage Japanese to smoke?"
For the money, of course. The social and moral responsibilities of big business make for interesting debate, but any such discussion comes to naught with tobacco companies, who still deny the health risks of the product and insist they are merely playing suppliers to consumers' demand.
The truth is that tobacco companies have always created new demand for cigarettes by targeted advertising and sponsorship of sports and concert events. In China, for example, more than half of all men smoke but few women do. And if you believe disclaimers by the cigarette companies that they will not target those women, I've got a couple of Virginia Slims ads you can hang on your bulletin board.
In many of the same nations in which America provides aid or expertise to improve health care, American tobacco companies are moving in to, in essence, increase mortality. "The transnational tobacco companies exploit our countries' desperate need for immediate economic investment," public health officials from former Soviet bloc nations wrote to President Clinton. "But in so doing they damage our health and ruin our longer-term economic well-being."
For years they've been doing the same here: create jobs, kill workers. For three decades, the tobacco interests have had to hone their rationales, first here, now abroad. When you are pursuing the moral equivalent of selling asbestos handkerchiefs to foreign neighbors, you have to have a slick rap to go with it. Or not so slick. When he was questioned by lawyers in a class action suit last year, Bennett S. Le Bow, a New York investor whose holdings include the Liggett Group, a tobacco company, said he neither knew nor cared to know whether cigarettes cause cancer. "I'm a businessman," he said.
The truth about tobacco came out 30 years ago, in a State Department auditorium in Washington D.C. The cold war was still in full flower. Certainly no one could have imagined that the way we would find to eliminate the Russians and the Chinese would be, three decades later, to sell them cigarettes. And all in the name of progress. Cancer and capitalism -- what a pair.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
