HEADLINE: New York City's Taxes Drive the Tourists Away

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The New York tourist industry is keeping its fingers crossed that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo makes good on his promise to cut the special occupancy tax on hotel rooms that cost more than $100.
New York has a 21.25 percent total levy on hotel rooms, the highest in the country. Our tax tacks $23.75 onto the average New York City hotel room, compared with $11.36 in Chicago and $10.48 in Washington. 
 But the hotel and convention trades hardly suffer alone. Travelers also ride subways, eat in restaurants, shop in stores and go to the theater. According to the New York City Comptroller, the surtax drains $1.5 billion a year from the local economy.
Clearly, the plan to reel in new visitors has backfired big time, with the state losing, rather than gaining from the tax.
Last year the tax generated $64 million for the state, but lost $94.4 million in other tax revenues because tourists stayed away, according to the Hotel Association of New York City and the New York State Hospitality and Tourism Association.
By 1996, they predict, the tax will lose the state nearly $1 billion -- twice as much as it will generate.
We are completing a $5 million conversion from apartment building to hotel that began with the faith that New York still wants visitors from all around the globe. Thus, the Governor needs to seize the opportunity to show Albany -- and the world -- that New York means business. Otherwise, the city in particular will continue to pay the price of being far and away the most heavily taxed destination in the country.
 
JOSEPH KAMINSKI
General Manager, Delmonico's
New York, Jan. 4, 1994

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Your Share Is $500

 BODY:
What good is that trade agreement signed by 117 nations in Geneva last month? According to Gary Hufbauer and Kimberly Elliott of the Institute for International Economics, it will save the typical American family $500 a year.
The two researchers estimated that existing tariffs and other barriers to foreign-made goods jack up prices in the United States by about $1,000 for the typical family. The trade agreement, when instituted, will cut that cost in half by opening up markets to low-cost imports. Even better, the poorest American families will reap the biggest dividends; the prices of goods they buy the most -- clothing, dairy products and other foods -- will tumble the furthest. 
Whatever benefit actually emerges, there will be a downside. Most consumer benefits come from imports of clothing and other low-priced goods that will displace about 200,000 American jobs over 10 years -- a period during which 20 million other American workers are also expected to lose work temporarily. But because the workers in apparel and the other vulnerable industries are low-paid, they are not likely to suffer large wage losses when they find new jobs. The nation's task is now to make certain the workers dislocated by imports get plenty of help so that they too can win.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
On Russian TV, Clinton Backs Reforms

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton plunged into a nationally televised "town meeting" today to urge Russians to stay the course toward a free market and democracy and to find a "new definition of Russia's greatness."
Clearly stimulated by candid and provoking questions from a live, youthful audience at the Ostankino television center in Moscow and similar groups linked by television from other cities, Mr. Clinton was alternatively professor, politician and preacher as he counseled Russians to "choose the future." 
 "I come here as a friend and supporter of the democratic changes going on in this nation," he said. "I hope that my nation and I can make a positive contribution, in the spirit of genuine and equal partnership. In the end, you will have to decide your own future. I do not presume to do that."
 
Supporting Yeltsin
 The telecast was the first such extemporaneous appearance by an American President in Moscow, and it offered Mr. Clinton a nationwide audience for the central theme of his visit -- to declare America's support for Russia's embattled reforms and struggling President, Boris N. Yeltsin. President Reagan, during a trip to Moscow in 1988, also got considerable attention from a speech to students and faculty at Moscow State University.
If any reminders of the Russian struggle were needed, the opening days of the new Parliament provided a constant drumbeat. Today, while the Presidents were meeting in the grand halls of the Kremlin, the new lower house of Parliament elected a devoted Communist as its Speaker, while the demagogic nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky was the center of another furor, this time when he was punched in the face by another deputy, who resented Mr. Zhirinovsky's demanding and being given preferential treatment at the Parliament canteen.
 
Accord With Ukraine
 The main agreements that emerged from the summit meeting dealt largely with the troublesome arsenals left over from the cold war.
The major bonus of Mr. Clinton's journey was realized at the start of the day when President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine joined Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin to sign a statement in which Ukraine agreed to turn its strategic nuclear warheads over to Russia for dismantling in exchange for security assurances and compensation in the form of nuclear fuel.
All three Presidents hailed the "trilateral statement" as a break in what a senior Administration official described as Ukraine's "stall mode."
 
Parliament Dragged Its Feet
 Though Mr. Kravchuk has signed agreements at least twice in the past to surrender the weapons, which are blocking the carrying out of major disarmament treaties between the United States and Russia, the Ukrainian Parliament has dragged its feet on ratifying the pacts, convinced that without the missiles Ukraine would become irrelevant to the West and vulnerable to Russia.
There was still no certainty that the Ukrainian Parliament would be any less stubborn than in the past. But parliamentary elections are scheduled for March 27, and Mr. Kravchuk may have calculated that new deputies might be more amenable to approving the agreements, especially after so public an endorsement.
The statement specifically called on Ukraine to turn over the warheads on its most modern and deadly weapons -- 46 SS-24 missiles, each with 10 warheads -- within 10 months. In exchange, Ukraine would receive immediate compensation in the form of nuclear fuel for its nuclear power plants.
In a related agreement, the United States agreed to buy 500 tons of highly enriched uranium extracted from former Soviet missiles over the next 20 years. At current prices, 500 tons is worth about $12 billion and amounts to the world demand for three years. A Russian official said it represents about 20,000 warheads.
 
No Mutual Targeting
 A third agreement dealing with the leftover arsenal of the cold war was a pledge by the American and Russian Presidents that by May 30 none of their strategic nuclear weapons would be targeted at each other, or for that matter at any other country.
Officials agreed that the measure was more symbolic than practical, since it carried no verification procedures, and since most missiles can be rapidly retargeted in any case.
Before today's agreement, Mr. Yeltsin had declared that no Russian missiles were targeted at American cities. But following his statement Russian arms control specialists said that there had been no change in Russian targeting and that missiles were still aimed at a variety of United States targets.
A central political issue of the summit meeting was the clamor by some East European and Baltic states to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, an idea that riles Russia. Mr. Clinton's solution has been to invite allEast European and former Soviet nations to join in a vague "Partnership for Peace." Mr. Yeltsin heartily embraced the proposal.
"I think that the initiative of President Bill Clinton and also of some Europeans not to accept countries into NATO on a case-by-case basis, but to proclaim all of them to be partners in maintaining peace and security is a good formula," he said at a joint news conference, "because drawing one more line, dividing all into white and black anew, no, this won't do."
In contrast to past summit meetings, this one was not about aid. The only new assistance Mr. Clinton spoke of, in addition to what he had promised at the Vancouver summit meeting last April, was a request for $900 million in additional aid in the 1995 budget.
Mr. Yeltsin had no complaints about the American stance. "We believe that, unlike in the case of Vancouver, we will not count on the humanitarian sphere and direct social assistance," he said. "This is our business."
Americans, he said, needed social support themselves. "It would be absurd to help resolve the unemployment problem in Russia while neglecting the employment situation in one's own country," Mr. Yeltsin said.
Mr. Yeltsin was more critical of the Group of Seven, the major industrial countries, which pledged $2.5 billion in aid in April. "A decision has been passed and its implementation has been minimal," he said.
 
No Retreat on Reform
 As for Russia's own course, Mr. Yeltsin declared that there would be no retreat from economic reform. "As regards reforms," he said, "we will be resolute and radical."
Though Mr. Zhirinovsky was never mentioned directly by either President, his large showing in the December election cast a constant shadow over the summit meeting.
"It's nice to be in a place where some other president is having trouble with his Parliament instead of me," Mr. Clinton quipped.
But he continued with some stern words of advice to the new Russian deputies: "You are the product of the first genuinely democratic and constitutionally provided Parliament in the history of your country, and you ought to be willing to listen and learn and grow and deal with the issues."
Several other agreements announced during the summit meeting included joint statements on controlling the spread of nuclear weapons, on human rights and on the Middle East.
Mr. Yeltsin acknowledged some differences in discussions, evidently on the question of Russian troop withdrawal from Estonia and Latvia, and over policy toward Bosnia.
But with Russia in political and economic turmoil, this was not a summit meeting for major foreign-policy or disarmament initiatives. It was to show that the United States still stood firmly behind Mr. Yeltsin and reform.
"Throughout our discussions, I reaffirmed the strong support of the United States for Russia's commitment to democracy and transition to a market economy," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference.
Later, at the "town meeting," the American President was asked whether he did not identify Russian reform too closely with the person of Mr. Yeltsin."Do I intend to work with President Yeltsin as long as he embodies Russian democracy and as long as he is the choice of the majority of the people of Russia to be the President?" Mr. Clinton replied. "Of course."
 
'No Other President'
 "There is no other President," he continued. "There may be some people in Russia who wish someone else was President of the United States, but I am the only U.S. President you have right now. That's not the same thing as saying that I'm all there is to American democracy. I am not."
Students sat transfixed as Mr. Clinton wandered among them, picking questioners himself, bantering with them and introducing his wife, Hillary, who arrived in Moscow on Friday.
The session was televised live at 3:30 P.M. Moscow time. It was to be repeated Saturday afternoon, and parts of it were shown on evening news programs.
The format was a familiar one for Mr. Clinton, and one in which he clearly felt at ease, especially after a few questions in English.
 
Only One Saxophone Play
 What would he like historians to say of him? ("I would like them to say I restored a sense of hope and optimism to my country.") Would he play the saxophone? ("No, I played for President Yeltsin last night. I have a quota, one saxophone play per country.") Would he change places with Mr. Yeltsin? ("No, I like the job I have.")
A 13-year-old boy, Aleksandr Fyodorov, recalling a picture of Mr. Clinton shaking hands with President Kennedy, asked how old Mr. Clinton was when he "got the idea to become the President of the United States."
Mr. Clinton called the boy to him: "Come up here. Come shake hands with me, and maybe you'll be President of Russia someday."
But the core of Mr. Clinton's message was an earnest plea to the Russians not to lose faith.
"Let me say that I think this has been in some ways the most difficult period of all for you because you have taken a lot of risks, you have made a lot of changes already, and yet the changes have not been felt tangibly in the lives of most ordinary citizens in the country," he said.
"But I can say that just as an outside observer, it seems to me that it is likely that you will begin to see those changes. People will come to see that there is a light at the end of this long tunnel."
Mr. Clinton's day ended with an official dinner of caviar, salmon and cabbage soup in the Kremlin. The Clintons will then spend the night in the Kremlin, a tribute extended only to one other American President, Richard M. Nixon.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 25, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 15 about the scene as President Clinton appeared on Russian television during his visit to Moscow, adjoining the main article about the day's events, misstated the year of his Presidential campaign. It was 1992, not 1988.

HEADLINE: Fixing America

BYLINE: By David E. Rosenbaum; David E. Rosenbaum is a Washington correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

FACING UP
How to Rescue the Economy From Crushing Debt
and Restore the American Dream.
By Peter G. Peterson.
Foreword by Warren B. Rudman and Paul E. Tsongas.
Illustrated. 411 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $22. 
PETER G. PETERSON, who was Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration and is now an investment banker on Wall Street, argues that the country is sinking in a sea of red ink formed over many years in which the Government spent too much and collected too little in taxes. Unless a rescue operation is mounted, he maintains, little will be left for the next generations and the American dream will be lost.
If the argument of "Facing Up" sounds familiar, that's because it is. So much has been written about the Federal budget deficit -- including much by Mr. Peterson -- that the prospect of reading still more on the subject may seem no more enticing than reading the multiplication tables.
But don't fall asleep yet. This book is worth reading, studying even, because in remarkably clear prose Mr. Peterson takes the decidedly unfamiliar step of describing just how painful rescue would be. It is the political equivalent of saying the emperor has no clothes.
In fact, with this treatise Mr. Peterson has set a bench mark against which the debate over lowering the Federal budget deficit will be measured for years to come. No longer will it be sufficient to suggest, as politicians and commentators have done for years, that the budget can be balanced by eliminating waste, fraud and abuse, or by approving a constitutional amendment, or by placing higher taxes only on the rich, or by setting a cap on Government benefits, or by cracking down on welfare cheats, or by taking any other short cut that avoids the potholes of specifics.
"Facing Up" does not mince words:
"Most Americans -- emphatically including the middle class -- will have to give something up," Mr. Peterson writes in what amounts to the book's topic sentence.
"If one group (the nonpoor elderly) bears a somewhat disproportionate share of the sacrifice in my plan, it's because they now receive a vastly disproportionate share of our public largess," he writes at another point.
"In the end, there will be no way around the 'R' word -- rationing," he asserts. "As much as we like to think that health care is somehow different, here, just as in every other area of our lives, trade-offs are inevitable."
He would subject Federal benefits, including Social Security, to an "affluence test." The higher one's income, the more benefits would be slashed. Only retirees with incomes below $35,000 would be spared. He would also raise the Social Security retirement age to 68 from 65, substantially increase the out-of-pocket share of medical expenses the elderly pay under Medicare and require income taxes to be paid on a portion of Medicare benefits. Otherwise, his health care proposals follow more or less along the lines President Clinton has recommended, but Mr. Peterson would also place an absolute ceiling on how much the Government could spend each year on health programs.
Mr. Peterson does not shy away from steep new taxes. He would impose a 50-cents-a-gallon increase in the tax on gasoline and a 5 percent national tax on retail sales, and limit the tax deductibility of mortgage interest and employer-paid health insurance premiums.
He reports what all this would cost the average family -- read voters -- in various income categories in terms of lower benefits and higher taxes: $231 a year for families with incomes between $10,000 and $20,000; $1,817 for those with incomes between $30,000 and $40,000; $5,608 for those with incomes between $100,000 and $200,000; $23,294 for the average family with an income over $200,000.
The author believes the country and its political representatives are ready for such bitter medicine. Nothing that has happened so far suggests he is right about that. After all, President Clinton's budget barely passed Congress last year, and he avoided the sacred cows Mr. Peterson wants to slay.
Maybe Mr. Peterson is also wrong, although he makes a persuasive case, in his belief that only balancing the budget will enable today's children to match their parents' living standard. Or maybe it does not matter how the children fare. But he is definitely right about this: If politicians persist in saying that controlling the deficit is important, then they must cease practicing what he calls "the politics of denial."
The "have-it-all hubris" that has dominated politics for a generation, Mr. Peterson correctly holds, has left Americans "boxed into a corner from which there are no pleasant exits."
From now on, everyone proposing a solution to the budget problem will be subject to this test: If you don't like one aspect or another of the Peterson plan, then what particular spending cut or tax increase do you suggest in its place?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Prettification Patrol

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
Let's say you're trying to peddle some fake flowers. Do you call yourself a fake-flower peddler? Of course not; you're a floral marketer, artificial-flower division.
Now you look at your product -- sometimes quite beautiful, petals made of silk or whatever -- and you ask yourself, "Why artificial?" That's a word that turns buyers off. You brood about that, and come up with a fresh-as-a-daisy answer: you'll create a market for permanent flowers. That not only lends longevity to your produce, but it also knocks the noxious weeds turned out in hothouses and pesticide-ridden, inorganic, fertilizer-driven gardens as temporary flowers. 
 That's the art, or racket, of euphemism, from the Greek eu-, "good," and pheme, "speech." And it's been gaining speed ever since environmentalists were able to transform the damn jungle into the glorious rain forest (where you can get wetlands fever).
Some objects of green wrath, lumbermen and fishermen, counterattacked with euphemisms of their own. "The timber industry speaks of harvesting trees on public lands, the fishing industry of harvesting fish from the ocean," grumps Ray Sawhill of New York. "My understanding is that in order to harvest you have to have first reaped." Maybe he means sown; at any rate, if you have planted the trees, or raised the fish from caviar, you could then harvest them, although "harvest" is not a term that goes well outside the vegetable world. Thus, I would not use the headline, as The New York Times did last summer, "Giant Maw for Fish Harvesting."
No newspaper can be held responsible, however, for the prose prettification in its advertising. If you're appealing to a snooty clientele, you hate to use the word sale; nice stores don't have sales. (In France, sale is a dirty word.) If it's cheap but it hasn't been marked down yet, call it a special purchase. Or, if you're the Artium Gallery on Fifth Avenue, "Join us for our current anniversary exhibition of master jewelers and receive a 10 percent accommodation." Hotels provide accommodations; what will they now call a lowering of rates on rooms?
Even the most innocent words, when they take on a taint, are quickly euphemized. The Miss America contest, eager to shed any hint of royalism, now forbids the use of reign to denote the period in which here-she-comes holds the title; her once-reign is now "a year of service."
No longer need Shakespeare's Edmund, in "King Lear," cry, "Now, gods, stand up for bastards!" As Ben J. Wattenberg has written of those born on the wrong side of the blanket: "It was once called bastardy. Then illegitimacy. Then out-of-wedlock birth. And now, frequently, wholly sanitized, nonmarital birth." (He left out love child.)
"Do you do euphemisms?" writes Ben Bradlee, The Washington Post's vice president at-large. (In my view, the hyphen makes the words mean "not confined to a specific assignment"; without the hyphen, it would mean "sought after by the police.") He cited a broadcast by Peter Jennings of ABC when Yasir Arafat's plane was missing: "if something has befallen him in a terminal way. . . ."
Because the word lying is off-putting to some, we have seen some prettification under oath. Oliver North denied lying to Congress, but admitted he had "provided input which differed radically from the truth." And Roger Le Locataire notes from Ponders End, London, that British officials caught telling half-truths or otherwise deceiving the court admit they have been economical with the truth.
In the general derogation of politically correct terms, some euphemism has been parodied: nobody seriously uses vertically challenged for "short," or holds that a bad speller is orthographically impaired; Clyde Haberman of The New York Times was writing tongue-in-cheek when he described a rotund Turkish political figure as kilogramically endowed. But some writers have rejected prostitute for the less pejorative "sexual worker," and the person in charge of waste disposal (formerly garbage) for the township of Montclair, N.J., refers to herself as "Senior Sanitarian."
In politics, the Clinton Administration has made it linguistic policy to refer to the taxes necessitated by its health plan as premiums, which most people associate with insurance policies. Others say that if the payment is mandatory, it's a tax, which has become a political dirty word.
Almost as dirty as guns. When Richard Nixon came out with "Guns are an abomination," advocates for unrestricted sale of the things that shoot bullets searched for a euphemism. A reader of a Minneapolis city magazine, Mpls. St. Paul, wrote to the editor to assert that "thousands have saved themselves, contrary to the myth of the danger of a home-protection weapon." Jason Zweig of Forbes magazine objects to this euphemism: "I don't think it can transform a gun into a mom-and-apple-pie product. You can call a bullet a criminal-impairment projectile, but that will never blind the mind's eye to the ferocious furrowing of metal through flesh and bone." (Mr. Zweig, an old-school Hyphen Harry, agrees, however, with the letter-writer's use of the hyphen in home-protection weapon.)
We cannot leave today's subject without a look at dysphemism, defined in the Random House Unabridged, revised second edition, as "the substitution of a harsh, disparaging or unpleasant expression for a more neutral one." It turns euphemism on its head.
When Dick Gregory titled a book "Nigger," he bit down hard on a painful slur, turning it to his advantage. In the same way, the word queer -- like queen and fairy, long used as a derogation -- is being stolen by homosexuals for their own use.
"The vivid representation of identity," Edmund White said in a speech to the Center for Lesbian and Gay Studies in New York, "is especially important for the queer community." As reprinted in The New York Times, the word seemed shocking until Mr. White repeated it: "Until recently, there were few openly queer films or publications."
Is gay passe? If queer is now acceptable, its etymology deserves a look: Hugh Rawson's "Devious Derivations" tracks Queer Street, a condition of financial impecunity, to the 1811 edition of Grose's Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue, meaning "Wrong. Improper." Before that, the word queer -- perhaps rooted in the Greek for "oblique, off-center" -- was used by pickpockets and con men to mean "out of order," as in "queer as Dick's hatband." Until recently, bent was the term many homosexuals preferred as the antonym to straight, but the new usage has queered it.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); FRANCE (52%);

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
At 70, an Enfant Terrible As Elder . . . Statesman?

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: NANTUCKET, Mass.

 BODY:
AS STATESMEN, THE ELDERS OF American composition have proved an uneven lot in recent decades, often showing little care for social grace and tact. Although William Schuman was a suave administrator and diplomat, and Aaron Copland projected a sweet public persona, Virgil Thomson, Leonard Bernstein and John Cage could be brash and unruly. And David Diamond remains as waspish as Elliott Carter and Milton Babbitt are amiable.
Now Ned Rorem, the once and future enfant terrible of American music, has turned 70. He does not act it, and certainly does not look it, his ruddy, boyish face still uncreased. Nor, he insists, does he see himself as a grand old man. But he has mellowed with age. He gently boasts that after decades of flaunted philandering and conspicuous indulgence, he has lived monogamously with James Holmes, an organist and choir director in New York, for 27 years; that he has not touched cigarettes or alcohol for 23 years; that he never uses "naughty words" (well, hardly ever). 
 "I don't have much of a social life," Mr. Rorem said a few days ago, after helping Mr. Holmes serve a holiday dinner to five guests here at his second home. "This is about the extent of it. I hate parties." Yet he refers to "the bad Ned" of yore with obvious affection, and like Edith Piaf, he professes to regret nothing.
"One thing about being 70," he said, "whatever I am now, there it is, for better or worse. I have made a statement. I feel that I've earned the right to do what I've always done anyway. I feel I'm due a certain respect." But as ever with Mr. Rorem, vulnerability lurks close beneath the bold surface. "That comes from an inferiority complex," he added, "and I feel very guilty for saying it."
Another thing about turning 70, it is a wonderful excuse for a party . . . er, celebration. The perennial flurry of Rorem performances intensified shortly before the landmark birthday, last October, and has yet to subside. On Wednesday, Mr. Rorem, as pianist, will accompany the soprano Angelina Reaux in his song cycle "Women's Voices" and in the New York premiere of his seven-minute opera "Anna la Bonne" at the Kaye Playhouse on the Upper East Side. Next Sunday, the New York Festival of Song presents a Rorem tribute at the Greenwich House Music School in lower Manhattan. And on Jan. 27, the New York Philharmonic will give the premiere of his English-Horn Concerto, with Thomas Stacy as soloist and Kurt Masur conducting.
As usual, Mr. Rorem's songs, considered by many the cream of his output if not of recent American song as a whole, get the most attention. But his choral works are being presented weekly through the spring at St. Thomas Church in Manhattan, and Robert Shaw, the dean of American choral specialists, intends to offer an overview of Mr. Rorem's choral music next season in Atlanta. "He's about the most significant American song writer of the last half-century," Mr. Shaw said, "and the most significant choral writer, too."
Mr. Rorem has always been more than a composer, notably an essayist of uncommon wit, style and candor, and the anniversary finds him immersed in reminiscence and introspection. While still composing at full tilt (six sizable projects are in the works), he recently completed his memoirs, "Knowing When to Stop," scheduled for publication next fall by Simon & Schuster. The 735-page typescript, parts of which have already been printed and a copy of which was supplied by the publisher, awaits editing and trimming; with characteristic self-mockery, Mr. Rorem frets that the title, full of personal meanings, may be turned against the very thickness of the tome.
The memoirs draw freely on Mr. Rorem's copious earlier writings, both published and unpublished, especially his extensive diaries, infamous for their telling of tales out of bed and closet. His conversation, in turn, draws heavily on the memoirs. Familiar themes from Rorem lore come couched in familiar phrases, seemingly -- often demonstrably -- honed long ago. Whether in a professional or in a social setting, Mr. Rorem speaks carefully, closely weighing the effect of his words.
Effect, he argues, is everything. In a recent public forum, he said that although he has written a lot of "Goddy music," as he puts it, he does not believe in God; he believes in belief. "I said that largely for effect," he now explained. "But it also happens to be true. I say something for effect, but I also believe it.
"Music is for effect, too. Anyone can express himself. The important thing is whittling it down. The mere fact of whittling is for effect. Everything is for effect." Effect, in his world view, is French, perhaps, while plodding truth and conviction are German.
"I very early understood that the universe is divided between two esthetics: French and German," he begins his memoirs, elaborating on a recurrent theme in his writing and conversation. "Everything -- is either French or German. . . . Cats are French, dogs are German. Night is French, day is German. Women are French, men are German. . . . Gay is French, straight is German (unless it's the other way around). Schubert is French, Berlioz is German. Generalities are French, specifics are German."
Is it necessary to add that Mr. Rorem himself is French? "Contrary to what everyone says," he insisted, "I was Frenchified before I went to France." No matter that he was born in Richmond, Ind., and raised in Chicago. His father, C. Rufus Rorem, was an economist who helped found Blue Cross and Blue Shield. He died in 1988, at 93, shortly after the death of his wife, Gladys.
"I look in the mirror and see my father," Mr. Rorem said. "I have the same genes," he added, seeming to invoke longevity while explaining his own youthful appearance.
Both parents converted to the Quaker faith. Mr. Rorem, who lives with Mr. Holmes in an apartment near Lincoln Center, now attends only an occasional meeting of the Society of Friends, he said, but he calls himself "a good Quaker" and espouses pacifism. He has devoted several works to that theme, including "Swords and Plowshares," written for the Boston Symphony in 1990. (Having promised to play a tape of the Boston performance for a visitor, Mr. Rorem reneged, with typical self-deprecation: "I'm afraid it would be too painful for me to sit here watching you hate the piece.") He argues repeatedly, in conversation and in the memoirs, that gay-rights groups should seek to abolish the military, not to achieve fuller representation in it.
Mr. Rorem's musical talents developed precociously, somewhat in spite of stolid instruction, in Chicago, at Northwestern University, at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia and at the Juilliard School. But his good looks (he was often called "pretty" in those years) and personal charm were no less crucial in thrusting him, in his 20's, into heady artistic company, hobnobbing with the likes of Thomson, Copland, Bernstein, Samuel Barber, Gian Carlo Menotti, Paul Bowles and Marc Blitzstein, to list only composers.
He settled in Paris in 1952, developed formative relationships with Francis Poulenc and Jean Cocteau and spent periods in Morocco. In 1958, he returned to New York, where he has mostly lived since. He bought the home in Nantucket 18 years ago.
FROM HIS YOUTH, MR. ROREM composed in a refined, lyrical style, following his own Romantic bent even as tonality dropped out of fashion after World War II. As a composer, he was anything but an enfant terrible, and the real enfant terrible, Pierre Boulez, remains a symbol to him of an international musical establishment that treated him with malign neglect. "Boulez is a very intelligent person and a very imperious bastard," Mr. Rorem said. "I could have been a 12-tone composer, but I wasn't interested. It was poignant to see Copland and Stravinsky trying to please Boulez."
Despite -- or because of -- his independence, Mr. Rorem has always found performers eager to take on his music, and he has made his living almost entirely as a composer and writer, with little help from teaching stints. (He teaches at Curtis now and will begin at the Manhattan School of Music next fall.)
In the mid-60's the literary Rorem came loudly to the fore, with publication of the diaries from Paris and New York. Written with an incisive flair, these revealing and provocative volumes sent shock waves through the wide circle of Mr. Rorem's acquaintances and beyond.
Mr. Rorem says that the "Paris Diary," the first to appear, in 1966, was published at the insistence of the Braziller publishing house, "in spite of me."
"I don't like to hurt anyone's feelings, ever," he insisted. "I'm not a bitch. I'm not mean." And all of this seemed plausible as he spoke in his endearing manner. But how could anyone so conscious of effect not have known what pain his diaries might cause? As friends point out, Mr. Rorem likes to play the innocent, relying on his endless charm to get him out of scrapes, trusting that everyone will forgive him in the end; it usually works.
"I started writing more responsible prose when I knew strangers would read it," Mr. Rorem said. Yet even now, he pulls no punches. Consider this grand declaration from the memoirs:
"I can't sleep with famous people. Or for that matter with rich people, or people in power, used to being the center of attention. I have been in bed with four Time covers -- Lenny Bernstein, Tennessee Williams, Noel Coward and John Cheever (included among 3,000 proportionately anonymous souls, including one woman) -- and I performed out of a combination of duress and politeness. However, I grow uncomfortable when in other people's memoirs I read this sort of thing (maybe this will be excised when the time comes), especially when embellished by the writer's smug sense of charisma, boasting how he wouldn't put out for some star."
No, nothing will be excised when the time comes: effect, remember? Mr. Rorem's tally of sexual partners, murmured modestly in parentheses, falls far short of Wilt Chamberlain's but exceeds Don Giovanni's. Most of these dalliances took place before AIDS found its way into this country -- and before Mr. Rorem turned 45. How did he find time to compose so much?
Compose he did, following his own conservative path: symphonies and tone poems, piano and chamber works, songs and choral music. The songs drew the most attention, partly for their sheer excellence, partly because talented singers routinely sought out songs at the time, and few Americans were producing them. Supply has since outstripped declining demand.
"I used to be called America's No. 1 song composer because I was the only song composer," Mr. Rorem said with needless modesty. "Now nobody has commissioned me to write songs since Phyllis Bryn-Julson did in 1979. I don't want this to sound bitter. I should say wistful, not bitter."
Meanwhile, Mr. Rorem's star has risen in other areas of repertory, with the resurgence of Romanticism and tonality in American composition. As atonalists retrenched around him, Mr. Rorem quietly moved ahead, suddenly finding himself back in the mainstream. Sounding wistful again, he refers to himself as "the prodigal son's brother," unnoticed for having been in the right place all the time.
"He has always trod the kind of tonal path he began on as a kind of test of moral character," said David Del Tredici, one of the actual prodigal sons. Mr. Del Tredici cited Mr. Rorem as a model particularly for gay composers like himself: "He showed how to make an art of your gayness, using texts of Whitman and the like."
Again, Mr. Rorem takes a less exalted view of his accomplishment. "When I was out of fashion, it was like those cases in which parents are told by a psychiatrist that they molested their child," he said. "I thought maybe I was wrong, but the feeling was never strong enough that I wanted to give up. I'm an honest composer not because I'm a model human being but because I'm too lazy to be a whore, to jump on every bandwagon."
Lazy? Between the early diaries and the memoirs, along with his usual heavy regimen of composition, Mr. Rorem produced another 10 volumes of essays and other writings, as remarkable for their craft and prolificity as the music. "He is one of the best writers about music that I have ever read," said Stephen Sondheim, "and that is no easy thing to do."
THE MAGNITUDE OF MR. Rorem's output has at least become a bit more comprehensible now that he has shed some of the distractions. "My life was messy for a long time, but I've become very orderly about my work," he said. "I have a proprietary feeling." He spends most of his time at home, composing and writing, dealing with the outside world largely by telephone and letter. (In his current mania for order, he has filed 30,000 items of correspondence.)
Mr. Rorem has said, in fact, that he is working all the time, mentally plotting out a composition or polishing a phrase, whatever else he may seem to be doing, during every waking hour. And there are a lot of them.
"I haven't had a good night's sleep in 30 years," he said. "I lie awake wondering: When am I going to die? When is Jim going to die? How will the laundry get done?"
Though he does not dwell on his age -- seems hardly to believe it -- Mr. Rorem thinks about dying all the time, he said. "I'm not afraid of death. It's now a reality: I'm probably going to die. I don't want to die in a painful way, and I don't want to be a burden on my friends. I don't want to kill myself, because when you're dead, you're dead. Out of millions of galaxies and trillions of light years, our little romance on earth is all we've got."
He desperately wants to be remembered for his music. "No newspaper article can be me," he said. "My diaries have nothing to do with me. They do, but they don't. My music may be me." But he is pessimistic on the score of posterity (as on most others). "I'm a part of history," he said. "That's not a fantasy. But it's amazing how the important become more important with time and vice versa."
It is impossible to know, of course, what the future holds, but one detached observer finds cause for optimism. H. Wiley Hitchcock, a prominent historian of American music and no particular fan of Mr. Rorem's work, speaks of a Rorem renaissance and welcomes it. "It has let us experience more of his instrumental music, some of which is very well done," he said. Comparing Mr. Rorem to other American composer-authors like Virgil Thomson and Henry Cowell, Mr. Hitchcock seemed surprised at his own conclusion: "I wonder if Ned won't have more lasting worth as a composer."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Taking Steps On Safety Issue

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
FACED with mounting anxiety about crime against travelers, particularly in Florida, associations representing the major segments of the United States travel industry met recently in Washington to look for potential solutions. Representative Jim Bacchus of Florida, who represents a central portion of Florida's east coast and part of Orlando, speaking to the 80 travel officials and reporters at the Jan. 5 session, defined the gravity of the problem. In tourism, he said: "When Florida sneezes, the industry gets a cold. And Florida has pneumonia."
The safety of a destination ranks as travelers' top concern, according to a survey made in August and September for the marketing company Robinson Yesawich & Pepperdine of Orlando, Fla., by the market-survey organization Yankelovich Partners of Westport, which interviewed 850 representative United States households. More than 80 percent ranked safety concerns at the top. This was the second survey by those two companies, but safety of destination was not listed as an important attribute the year before, so comparison is not possible. 
 As there are no simple resolutions to the problems of violence and crime, the safety meeting saw no way to devise quick formulas to deal with root causes, or to get tourism out of the line of fire. Research into problem areas, education of travelers on the theme "travel smart" and anti-crime legislation were all endorsed.
On education, the last two years have seen a surge in folders and leaflets counseling travelers on how to avoid danger or scams, and the organizations at the meeting -- representing hotels, airlines, car-rental companies, cruise lines and travel agencies -- agreed to press ahead with that kind of education. But they decided against consolidating their tips into what one official called a fat little encyclopedia, concluding that information was most serviceable at the time it applied -- that hotel tips were most useful to people entering their rooms, for example.
In probably its most important decision, the meeting did agree to gather statistics to measure the problem travelers face: the percentage of hotel or motel guests who suffer assaults, rapes or thefts, how many renters of cars lose their belongings to thieves or are attacked at highway rest stops, and other data to put the effect of crime on travel into context. Paul M. Ruden, senior vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents, which convened the meeting, said: "There will be no more bald assertions by me that you are more likely to drown in the bathtub than to be shot while traveling. We will get the data together to prove it."
Cooperation and Legislation
At the conference, the Travel Industry Association, a trade group of 2,000 members that includes hotel chains, the National Park Service, the state tourism bureaus, theme parks, airlines, cruise lines and others, announced completion of a link to Crime Stoppers International providing rewards for anonymous tips that lead to solving crimes that cause severe injury to or the death of a traveler. Crime Stoppers, a coalition of local organizations affiliated with police departments and other law groups, interviews tipsters who call "800" phone numbers and sets up systems for them to collect rewards when suspects are arrested and indicted.
Bob Dickinson of Carnival Cruise Lines, chairman of the Travel Industry Association, announced the program, explaining that a traveler would be defined as someone 100 miles from home who plans to return but is not part of a plane or other operating crew and is not a student going to or from school. The rewards, to be provided by the T.I.A., will range from $500 to $1,000, depending on the information. The Crime Stoppers number is (800) 474-8477.
Also on the legal-legislative front, Representative Bacchus discussed a travelers' safety bill that he introduced last fall with Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii and James L. Oberstar of Minnesota, all Democrats. That bill would allow Federal law officials to be called in if a traveler from another country, or another state, is a victim of a crime of violence. David Gergen, President Clinton's counselor, spoke on behalf of the Administration's omnibus crime bill, saying that the freedom to travel, in addition to its economic value, was part of the American spirit, needed if the country is to remain "a beacon of freedom."
Releasing Crime Statistics
The conference brought together executive officers and security experts from the travel agents' group, from the Air Transport Association, the American Hotel and Motel Association, the International Council of Cruise Lines and the American Car Rental Association.
The plan to divulge crime statistics is remarkable, because in 1991, when a trial stemming from a rape at a motel in Dallas brought a $10 million settlement that became a focus of media attention, no one in the hotel-motel industry would divulge any figures, saying either that such figures did not exist or that they represented information the hotel chains chose to keep to themselves. Now, Kenneth F. Hine, president of the American Hotel and Motel Association, said: "The knee-jerk session is over. We have indications that systems and companies will release information to contribute to a pool of data."
In Florida, the rental-car companies have already formed a security council to meet with law-enforcement groups and other organizations to enhance safety. Steps have been taken there, including the creation of a detailed Dade County route map that Miami car-rental companies are required to give to customers. New lighting and signs around the airport have also been installed and a special police precinct has been created covering the rental-car-return area.
Travelers, Prepare!
Although many of the safety leaflets published in the last year rely on common sense, sophisticated precautions are evolving; for instance, it is now considered safe practice that your registration at the hotel or the folder with your key not list your room number along with your name. It is also urged that if a hotel clerk says, "Room 31, Ms. Traveler," you request a new room immediately.
A copy of those leaflets may be obtained by sending a stamped self-addressed envelope to the organization at the address given. The American Automobile Association's "Playing It Safe, Taking Care of Yourself and Your Stuff When You Become a Tourist" is available at many A.A.A. offices, or from "Playing It Safe," Mail Stop 700, 1000 AAA Drive, Heathrow, Fla. 32746.
The Hotel and Motel Association's pamphlet of 10 safety tips, 10 million copies of which have been distributed in hotel and motel rooms since it was published in March 1993, may be obtained from the association by sending a request and a stamped self-addressed business-size envelope to 1201 New York Avenue N. W., Washington, D.C. 20005.
"Stay Safe and Sound" by Loews Hotels may be obtained by writing to Loews Hotels, Corporate Security Department, 1 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016.
"A Consumer's Guide to Renting a Car," published by Alamo and the National Association of Consumer Agency Administrators, has a sheet of safety tips. Send a stamped self-addressed envelope to McCool Communications, Post Office Box 13005, Atlanta, Ga. 30324.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 10; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Rush to Build for the County's Aging Population

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
IN recent years, the 27-year-old White Plains Hotel attracted few guests. But a developer now hopes it will appeal to a growing market as a residence for the elderly who need some help with daily chores.
In Rye, a nursing home built in 1908 is about to be transformed into an apartment building for the aged who wish to live independently, but in a structured environment. 
 Such projects, as well as total-care nursing homes, are now being planned all over the county to accommodate an increasingly aging population.
Perhaps the most popular type of housing is called "assisted living apartments," where the elderly rent units, and meals, housekeeping and other services are provided.
"There's a real market out there for assisted-living apartments," said Solomon T. Scharf, who last month bought the 105-room White Plains Hotel on South Broadway and Lyons Place, which had been foreclosed in October 1992 by The Bank of New York.
Mr. Scharf, who is president of Lloyd Equities, a development company in Manhattan, plans to convert the hotel into 284 apartments, which he said he could do by making mostly cosmetic changes, such as installing new furniture, carpeting and wallpaper.
"This hotel, like many others, has rooms with connecting doors," Mr. Scharf explained. "You can create apartments simply by opening the doors."
There will be studio, one- and two-bedroom units, all with kitchenettes, that will rent for $2,500 to $3,000 a month. The price will include three meals a day in a central dining area, housekeeping, recreation and local transportation. Amenities will include a card room, library, exercise room, an arts and crafts center and a chapel.
The plan still requires the approval of the White Plains Common Council, but there has been little opposition, Mr. Scharf said.
He said he expected to begin the renovation in the spring and phase in assisted-living residents while continuing to operate the building as a hotel. The phasing in, he said, could take as much as four years.
Mr. Scharf owns and operates the Esplanade Hotel, a 181-unit assisted-living accommodation at West End Avenue and West 74th Street in Manhattan. "With life expectancy continuing to go up, there will continue to be a need for this kind of housing in the future," he said.
That opinion is echoed by Stephen Lopez, Planning Commissioner for the town of Greenburgh, where a 160-bed nursing home is now being planned.
"There's such a variety of living arrangements for seniors now," Mr. Lopez said. "There's still a great need for total-care facilities, but there's a greater call for more intermediate care for seniors who aren't fully capable of taking care of themselves, yet don't need to be in an institution."
One ambitious project involves the $60 million expansion of the Osborn Retirement Community, now under way between Theall and Boston Post Roads in Rye. It will involve an 84-bed skilled-nursing facility and 188 independent-living residences, including 148 one- and two-bedroom apartments in three buildings, and 20 two-family homes, each with 1,638 square feet of living space.
THE community, on a 56-acre campus, already has a 125-bed retirement residence for men women in a 186,000-square-foot Georgian building opened in 1908 for women only. The building will be converted into 65 one-bedroom independent-living rental apartments and 40 assisted-living units.
The original building, which already has dining rooms, parlors and a 200-seat theater, will also be equipped with a fitness center, and another building will be constructed to house an indoor pool and a spa.
Fees for all the various housing options have not yet been approved, according to Mark R. Zwerger, chief executive officer of the Osborn Retirement Community, who has submitted an offering plan to the New York State Attorney General.
Mr. Zwerger said a one-time refundable entrance fee would be charged in addition to a monthly service fee for the 188 new independent-living units. "Our entrance fees will be comparable to the prices of similar sized condominiums," said Mr. Zwerger. "But residents won't own their units. They will be owned by the Osborn."
When the resident dies, or if he or she moves, the entrance fee will be refunded to the estate or the individual, he explained.
Each resident will get a package designed to accommodate individual preferences, Mr. Zwerger said. "If they want, three meals a day will be provided, as will housekeeping services and recreation."
Mr. Zwerger said that market research showed that the needs of the elderly were changing. "They wanted larger personal accommodations," he said.
The other major impetus for the expansion, Mr. Zwerger said, was economic. "We needed more people living on the campus to make it economically viable. We couldn't continue to make it with the 125 people we have now," he said.
The first stage of construction, which will begin in the fall, will involve 13 of the two-family homes and the first of the three apartment buildings, the new 84-bed nursing home and the new indoor pool.
Another complex looking to expand its services is the 127-year-old Wartburg Home at East Lincoln and Bradley Avenues in Mount Vernon. The home, which now has 240 elderly people on its 35-acre campus, plans to build a new 160-bed nursing home and create 44 assisted-living units in a building that now houses 90 people. In addition, an auditorium will be transformed into an adult day-care center accommodating 100 people.
WHEN the new building opens early next year, the complex will accommodate a total of 240 nursing-home residents and an overall population of 370, said the Rev. Glenn C. Stone, spokesman for the Wartburg Home, which is affiliated with the Lutheran Church.
In the Town of Greenburgh, a 160-bed nursing home has been proposed by the Hebrew Hospital Foundation, a not-for-profit organization that now operates a 480-bed home in Co-op City, in the Bronx. The site plan for the four-wing, 85,000-square-foot home to be built on just under 60 acres on Grassland Roads at Stephens Lane is before the Town Planning Board.
At one time, the property was to be used for a one-family-home development that fell victim to the downturn in the real estate market.
Many people in town are happy that the land will now be used for a nursing home, since it will preserve more open space.
"The building itself will take up a very small percentage of the property," said Mr. Lopez, the Town Planning Commissioner. "The rest will be used for sitting areas and about half of the property is steep slopes."
Mr. Scharf, the owner of the White Plains Hotel, believes that the trend toward converting old projects and buildings into residences for the elderly will continue for some time.
He cites statistics that show that, in the next decade, the number of people 65 years of age or older nationwide will grow by 3.3 million, to 34.87 million people.
"And with good medicine, a lot of these people will be healthy and want a wide variety of housing options," he said. "Nursing homes and living with relatives are not the answer for everyone."

GRAPHIC: Photos; Plans for Osborn Retirement Community in Rye include renovating 1908 building, top, and adding 20 two-family houses, left. (Photographs by Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Altering Rules on Who May Take Over Apartments

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A MONTHLY publication called New York Landlord v Tenant is adept at boiling down the facts in lawsuits involving rent-regulated housing in New York City. With regulatory complexity steadily growing, there is no shortage of cases.
Many of them are on the issue of succession: who has the legally guaranteed right to take over an apartment when the tenant of record dies or moves? 
 "A landlord won the right to evict the ex-boyfriend of a tenant who had moved out," says one summary. "Although the boyfriend had some emotional and financial relationship with tenant, there wasn't enough proof of a committed family relationship for the ex-boyfriend to get the apartment."
And another: "Landlord sued to evict rent-controlled tenant's grandson after tenant died. The grandson was a relative who was entitled to pass-on rights simply by virtue of the blood tie and because he had lived with the tenant for two years."
These contrasting cases -- one in a rent-stabilized apartment, where there are leases of specific terms, and the other in a rent-controlled apartment, where occupancy has no limited term -- illuminate the issues that arise in succession cases, a growth area in landlord-tenant friction.
Barring the willingness of the United States Supreme Court to accept an appeal, a case decided by the State Court of Appeals last month has settled the law on succession rights. In a 6-0 decision written by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, it confirmed the right of the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal to extend to rent-stabilized housing the same succession rights for family members as in rent-controlled units.
It also confirmed the right of the agency to widen the class of protected individuals from 18 categories of family members to other categories of nonfamily members without a specific legislative mandate. In its "regulatory impact statement" the agency named four classes of occupants as needing this protection: the life partners of unmarried people, the disabled, the aged, and the poor.
Left unsettled by the lawsuit is the question of the impact of expanded succession rights on rental housing. Is the stage being set for extending to rent-stabilized housing the familiar practice of passing along rent-controlled apartments from generation to generation? Are the snooping propensities of landlords eager to establish their claim on apartments when there is a tenancy turnover being encouraged? Undoubtedly, yes. Might tenants be tempted to practice deceit in order to pass on favorably priced rent-stabilized apartments to roommates? Again, yes.
The familiar clash between the need for protections on the one hand and the potential for abuse on the other is thrown into bold relief in the succession issue. Most cases never get to court, but the law serves as a backdrop for landlord and tenant behavior.
STANDING alone, the court decision does no more than protect individuals at risk of a dire housing fate, possibly homelessness. But it comes in the absence of an effective over-all policy leading to gradual decontrol of vacated apartments. It gives additional long-term occupants of regulated apartments a housing advantage unjustified by any income test. Meanwhile, the need for it is explained on the basis of a "housing crisis" that many would say is primarily the result of state regulation itself.
Last year the State Senate made an effort to moderate the most glaring injustices of the regulatory system by removing controls from very-high-rent apartments. But by the time a compromise acceptable to the Democratic leadership was reached and a law was passed and signed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, only those earning $250,000 or more for two consecutive years, and living in an apartment renting for at least $2,000 a month on a specific date -- Oct. 1, 1993 -- were affected. Many wealthy people so disposed will no doubt escape coverage by manipulating the years in which they accept income.
In any case, there is little doubt that the intention of the state agency was to meet the immediate needs of many people whose housing plight, sometimes after tragic personal loss, would be dire without protection. In particular, lifelong companions of individuals who died of AIDS might have faced eviction. So might elderly or poverty-stricken companions of a deceased rent-stabilized tenants.
In a lawsuit involving only rent-controlled housing, Braschi v. Stahl Associates, the Court of Appeals had already upheld the right of a longtime gay companion of a person who died of AIDS to inherit an apartment. The decision placed the burden of proof on the successor to establish the claim based on an "emotional and financial commitment, and interdependence" with the former tenant. Controlled apartments are those built before World War II and continuously occupied by the same tenant, or an authorized successor, since 1971.
Specific methods of demonstrating this relationship are suggested in the Braschi decision. These are incorporated in the state's revised regulation, making them applicable in about a million stabilized apartments -- postwar or prewar units vacated and rerented after 1971. Among the evidences that demonstrate the familial relationship are intermingled finances, formalized legal obligations, and a history of having represented oneself as a family member.
"MY concern is that poor people will have trouble meeting the standards, because they often don't have the documents," said Paris R. Baldacci, associate professor at the Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, lawyer for intervenors on the state's side in the suit. "But in general the standards seem workable."
To win a succession right there is another test besides family membership or its equivalent: The successor must have lived in the apartment as his or her principal residence with the prime tenant for no less than two years (or one year in the case of people over 62 years of age or disabled). Or, if the occupancy is less than two years, the successor must have been there from the start of legal tenancy (the lease, in the case of a stabilized apartment) or the start of the relationship with the departed tenant.
Under a separate law, tenants may take in roommates, as long as landlords are informed. The route to improper succession, therefore, will be apartment-sharing leading to claims of interdependence. Smaller landlords who find it too difficult or expensive to mount lengthy lawsuits -- and even larger landlords, depending on the gap between the tenant's rent and the potential vacancy rent -- will be disposed to negotiate to keep the current occupant in place.
Sherwin Belkin, the lawyer for the Rent Stabilization Association of New York City, an owner's organization that challenged the regulations, said an attempt to appeal to the United States Supreme Court was possible. "An owner's right to determine who many possess his property is fundamental," he said. "We don't want to stand by and see that taken away by a state agency."
One Court of Appeals judge, Joseph W. Bellacosa, urged the Legislature in a separate statement to "carefully assess the sweeping power it impliedly invested in this administrative agency in the execution of a unique human sheltering mission." He predicted that "long, successive successorships" to rent-stabilized leaseholds would "bloom as perennials, becoming functionally transformed into perpetual stakeholds."
The Division of Housing and Community Renewal was represented in the suit by its chief of litigation, Cullen S. McVoy. The Small Property Owners of New York, intervening on the owners' side, was represented by Ronald D. Hariri.

HEADLINE: Battery Park City's Original Concept

 BODY:
To the Editor:
How ironic to read that the current administrators of Battery Park City are considering the introduction of subsidized housing units ("A New Neighborhood Along the Hudson," Dec. 26). 
 It was in the late 60's and throughout the 70's that the start of construction of the first housing units at the development was delayed while Battery Park City's then administrators and developers strove to produce housing at a cost that would qualify for a variety of Federal and state subsidized-housing programs.
The purpose was to insure an economically mixed development that would meet the goals of the project's fathers, the Rockefeller administration, to provide housing for all income levels, not just the wealthy. It should be noted that housing at Battery Park City came to fruition only when subsequent state administrations abandoned the mixed-housing concept and opted for housing only high-income residents.
To set the record straight also, Battery Park City, while sired by the late Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, was not an urban-renewal development, which would have had to rely on government financing for its development. Creation of the site and its infrastructure was, rather, funded in its entirety by bonds issued by the Battery Park City Authority.
Also, only 24 of the project's 92 acres resulted from excavation for the nearby World Trade Center. The bulk of the site, 68 acres, was created in the waters of the Hudson River by the Battery Park City Authority, which demolished the decaying, abandoned piers that were on the mile-long site and pumped in millions of tons of sand barged in from lower New York Harbor.
 
AVRUM HYMAN
The Bronx

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Splitting Fees;
When the Tenant With Clout Shares a Commission

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
LAST year, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company formed a subsidiary licensed to do real estate transactions in New Jersey. The company had as much intention of brokering deals as it did of building cars.
So why the license? Because A.T.& T. had named 222 Realty, a brokerage firm in Basking Ridge, as its agent for all New Jersey space searches of 75,000 square feet or less. In exchange for a lock on that business, the brokerage agreed to share its commissions with A.T.& T. And since under New Jersey and New York laws only licensed brokers can share in commissions, it was worth it to the telephone company to get certified. 
 "We got licensed purely to work out the compensation agreement," said Gary A. Decker, A.T.& T.'s real estate vice president.
Brokers don't like it, but such scenarios are increasingly dotting the real estate landscape. Barney Upton, the executive managing director of corporate services for Cushman & Wakefield, said the pace of demands to split fees had "picked up tremendously."
James S. Meiskin, a senior managing director at Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis, estimated that he had been asked to discount his commission on about 20 percent of the mid-sized transactions he handled, and about half of the deals for more than 100,000 square feet.
"With competition so fierce and long-term relationships so important, we have to agree at least half the time," Mr. Meiskin said.
From the corporate tenant's point of view, asking brokers to share commissions represents a simple quid pro quo. A growing number of companies have formed so-called strategic alliances or preferred vendor arrangements with brokerage firms in which they guarantee those firms most, or even all, of their space-search assignments.
In doing so, they are guaranteeing the firms a steady stream of business in a hotly competitive market. And they are saving the firms the marketing and sales costs involved in competing for each job separately.
"Our strategic alliances are supposed to be win/win based on total economics," said H. Bruce Russell, director of corporate real estate for Eastman Kodak. "So if the arrangement reduces the brokers' cost structure, they can get the same profit even if they pass along some of their commission."
But while brokers generally agree with that idea in theory, in practice they say the clients are expecting too much for too little. They note that since their commissions are generally calculated as a percentage of rent, the plummeting rents of the last few years have cut their incomes drastically.
Yet they increasingly are being asked to attend their clients' strategic-planning and human-resources meetings and to participate in expansion and relocation decisions. They are expected to act as financial consultants, relocation experts and brokers all rolled into one.
While the brokers say they welcome their expanded role because it can cement the relationship with the corporate client, some balk at selling themselves too cheaply.
Arthur Mirante, Cushman & Wakefield's chief executive, said he had begun to turn down requests to bid for assignments on which there was too little money to be made.
"We will no longer take an account just to get our foot in the door in the hope of making money in the future," he said.
Bruce Mosler, a Galbreath Riverbank vice chairman, is taking a closer look at the practice, too.
"We can't regularly cut fees to build a relationship anymore," he said. "We have to offer more services, and that means more costs that our revenues have to cover."
Still, not all brokers feel they have the luxury to just say no.
"Even if you know you can't make any money on a deal, you're afraid not to bid for it," said Stephen Riker, president of Abrams Benisch Riker/Colliers. "You're afraid that if you don't respond this time, you won't get a chance at the more lucrative deal next time."
Corporate executives are not deaf to such grousing. One corporate real-estate executive, who insisted on anonymity lest he offend corporate colleagues who are collecting fees, avoids the practice.
"When real-estate firms take a real burn on pricing it's tough for them to provide the quality of service we would want," he said.
OTHER executives now pay their brokers flat fees for consulting so that, even if a deal never happens, they've made some money.
"We try hard to cover costs and even some profit for any advisory or planning services we use," said Larry P. Ebert, director of real estate services for Ernst & Young, the accounting firm.
But while these companies may be finding ways to make the bitter pill of fee splitting more palatable, they are forcing the brokers to swallow the medicine nonetheless. To them, asking for a commission split is no different from expecting a raw-materials supplier to offer a volume discount.
While the philosophy may be the same, the methods are not. Companies pay their materials suppliers directly, which means volume discounts are easily negotiated. Real estate brokers, in contrast, are generally paid by landlords, so tenants must find ways to direct the discounts they negotiated back into their own coffers.
For companies with real-estate licenses, that is easy: They simply have the landlord write them a check.
The Travelers, for one, is licensed in Connecticut, the insurance company's home state, as well as in Texas, Michigan and Georgia, where it does many transactions. For large deals, it sometimes asks for as much as half of the broker's commission.
"It doesn't take all that much more work to do a 100,000-foot deal than a 20,000-foot deal," said Wayne E. Mills, Travelers' senior vice president of corporate real estate. He estimates that Travelers gets back more than $750,000 a year in real-estate commissions. "Most brokers recognize that the huge paydays of the past are simply gone," he said.
But many companies -- particularly those that have offices in many states -- don't want to go through the hassle of keeping active certifications going across the country. Instead, they tell their brokers to have the landlord plow part of their commissions back into the deal in the form of extra months of free rent, better contributions to building the space or even a lower rent.
That's the method Ernst & Young prefers.
"We don't want to worry about the tax implications of added income, or about setting up a real-estate license," Mr. Ebert said.
The International Business Machines Corporation has its own variation on that theme: It pays its strategic-alliance brokers a flat fee per square foot rented, on the proviso that they tell the landlord up front that no commission will be involved and that this saving should translate into a better deal for I.B.M.
"If we found out some company down the street got a better deal, we'd have a pretty serious talk with our strategic partner," said J. Thomas Benek, an I.B.M. director of real estate operations.
BEFORE its recent spate of layoffs, I.B.M. had salaried staff people handle its real estate negotiations without commission, so the company is used to evaluating the value of commissionless deals. But few brokers or executives think that is the optimum approach for most companies.
For one thing, it requires taking a lot of fairly illusory numbers on faith. "A company really can't know for sure that they got 50 cents off the rent because a broker took only 80 percent of his commission," conceded John F. Powers, an executive managing director at the Edward S. Gordon brokerage.
It also robs the real estate executives of a bit of corporate glory, added Mr. Upton of Cushman & Wakefield. "When you've just reduced the rent, the corporate guy can no longer say, 'Hey, here's half a million dollars I've brought back to the company's bottom line,' " he said.
Still, brokers say the approach can work well provided the idea of building the fee back into the deal doesn't come up until the very end of negotiations, when the tenant representative is certain the landlord will not budge any further on a deal.
"First I make sure I've squeezed all the juice out of the lemon," said Mr. Meiskin, the Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis executive. "Then I tell the landlord about the fee arrangement and ask for more concessions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wayne E. Mills of Travelers estimates company gets back about $750,000 a year in real-estate commissions. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)
