HEADLINE: Bill Seeks Hard-Labor Terms In Some Crimes

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
AN influential Republican state senator who says inmates are being coddled at taxpayer expense is introduceding legislation that would create a prison whose primary purpose would be to punish criminals through a regimen of intense physical labor.
That plan by the Senator, Gerald Cardinale of Demarest, calls for a "hard time facility" for violent felons that would combine backbreaking work, unbending discipline and the absence of such amenities as basketball courts, televisions and library privileges. The aim, he said, would be to make prison life so unpleasant that even the most hardened criminals would shun future illegal endeavors to avoid returning there. 
 Dr. Cardinale says his move is a response to growing public concern over crime and violence and a perception that prisons are not doing enough to rehabilitate criminals and deter recidivists.
"Prison should be punishment, not just rehabilitation," Dr. Cardinale said. "This is not meant to do anything in terms of rehabilitating prisoners. This is meant to rehabilitate their attitude toward crime."
Those who agree with him say that such drastic action is needed because prison life, with its emphasis on rehabilitation, has become an acceptable alternative to life on the streets for many career criminals.
"They're laughing at us," said Dr. Cardinale, a dentist, who was recently named the deputy majority leader in the Republican-dominated Legislature. "They're treated better in jail than they are out on the street. They have food, clothes, shelter, television, an exercise room and a library. They're essentially coddled at taxpayers' expense."
But critics include some corrections guards as well as civil liberties advocates and prisoners' rights groups. They say such an attitude toward corrections policy is likely to be counterproductive and would be unsuccessful because of the insurmountable difficulties involved in safely managing such a prison. Moreover, they say, confining inmates under such conditions would very likely be an unconstitutional violation of their rights.
"Yes, the public is frustrated with crime," said James V. Stabile, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections. "But there's a lot of 'feel-good' legislation out there that would be difficult to put into practice. If this were the magic bullet, I'm sure that everybody would be doing it."
In fact, "hard time" prisons have been tried, with mixed results, in other areas of the country. For example, a program for dealing with violent offenders at Pelican Bay State Prison in Crescent City, Calif., has been met with lawsuits from inmates.
And in upstate New York, a "super-maximum security" prison in the Southport Correctional Facility, which is used to house inmates in long-term solitary confinement, has been receiving mixed reviews.
"I consider it to be a failure," said Edward I. Koren, staff lawyer for the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union in Washington. "It's a dead end. All these places are dead ends."
Mr. Koren also acknowledged public frustration with current corrections policy.
"I'm not saying we should coddle people, put them up in Holiday Inns," he said. "But certainly Rahway and Trenton State Prison aren't Holiday Inns by any stretch of the imagination."
Mr. Koren added that Senator Cardinale's proposal is a "variation on a theme."
"We've seen this year in and year out," he said. "But this business of hard labor is something new to me. We had it up until fairly recently in the South, but a lot of correctional history has been an attempt to get away from that mindless kind of backbreaking work that is abusive."
Under the proposed legislation, any person convicted of a first offense of a violent crime like murder, manslaughter, aggravated assault, kidnapping or robbery, or of being a drug kingpin, would spend a minimum of one-fifth of the sentence in what the bill calls a "people's prison." It would be situated in a maximum-security prison in the state. Any person convicted of a subsequent offense would serve his entire sentence in such a place.
According to the legislative statement accompanying the bill, inmates serving time there would live a "highly structured and regimented daily routine" including a minimum of 10 hours a day of "rigorous discipline and physical labor." Any inmate who refuses to participate in the physical labor would be confined to his cell and could be denied parole.
 
Would Receive No Training
 The statement also indicates that there would be no educational or vocational training, and inmates would be denied the standard prison amenities of television and telephone privileges, recreational activities and furloughs.
"These people are going to cut down trees, dig holes and break rocks," said Ryan St. Michael, chairman of the Committee for People's Prison, a grass-roots organization based in Dumont that is promoting the idea of such prisons across the country. "This is going to be a hard-time place for violent criminals. It's going to be a hellhole. It's going to be the worst place in the state to be."
Mr. St. Michael, whose sister was murdered nearly 20 years ago by killers who were never captured, said the state's current method of dealing with violent crime was inadequate.
"Everybody who has been a victim is fed up," he said. "They know that their money is being spent for institutions that just aren't working."
Officials acknowledge public support for more effective methods of dealing with violent crime and a recidivism rate of nearly 70 percent.
Mr. Stabile, of the State Department of Corrections, said corrections officials would not comment on the specifics of the legislation unless and until it became law. "We have to carry out whatever the law is," he said. "But I think the first cost of this law would be defending it in court."
 
Question of Constitutionality
 Mr. Stabile was referring to a belief among corrections experts that any law that imposes such harsh punishment would face an immediate constitutional challenge.
Susan R. Silver, director of the Office of Inmate Advocacy in the State Public Defender's office, said she had "serious reservations" about the constitutionality of the proposal, both in terms of its treatment of prisoners and in denying them parole if they do not comply.
"But a more basic problem with it is that it's basically throwing people away," Ms. Silver said. "Even violent offenders and recidivists can be doing something constructive. Breaking rocks doesn't seem to serve anyone."
Ms. Silver said a more reasonable approach to corrections would be to provide inmates with skills "so that when they come out they'll be able to reintegrate in the community in a positive way."
For someone like Patricia Rybka of Wood-Ridge, teaching criminals vocational skills may not be enough.
"Hard labor never killed anyone," said Mrs. Rybka, whose husband, a Bergen County sheriff's officer, was murdered 15 years ago by a prisoner he was guarding. "Breaking rocks? Sure. Why not. Bring it back like the old times."
Mrs. Rybka, who said that the man who killed her husband had prior criminal convictions, added that the way society now deals with violent criminals obviously isn't working.
"We have to teach them a lesson," she said. "They just have to realize that if they do something wrong they're not just going to get a slap on the hand."
 
Would Be 'Counterproductive'
 But Karen A. Spinner, director of public education and policy for the New Jersey Association on Corrections in Trenton, said that "punishment for the sake of punishment" would be counterproductive.
"We're going to end up with people who are more hardened, more angry and more difficult to control when they get out," Ms. Spinner said, adding that the "economic motivation" for criminal behavior is extremely high.
"It's not that they want to go back to prison," she said. "It's because they don't have legitimate means of making a living. They use crime as their means of livelihood. And I don't think making prison a harsher place will deter anybody."
Corrections officers say that another problem with "punishment for the sake of punishment" is that prisoners with nothing left to lose are much more difficult to control.
"The more you take away, the more dangerous they become," said Edward Murphy, vice president of Local 105 of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in Trenton, the union that represents the state's 5,000 corrections officers. "When you put someone in that category, they're going to take the position that they have nothing to lose. There's no way that you can force those inmates to work. If they say they're not going to break rock, then that's it. They're not going to break rock."
And even if inmates do cooperate, he said, the scenario envisioned by supporters of the idea would create more problems in practice than in theory.
 
Security Concerns
 "The more direct contact between inmates and officers increases the potential of danger," Mr. Murphy said. "Whenever you give somebody a sledgehammer to break rocks, you're talking security concerns."
Notwithstanding the broad criticism and potential for legal challenge to his proposal, Dr. Cardinale is confident that its popular appeal will propel it through the Legislature.
"I don't think anybody is going to be against it," he said, adding that one vocal supporter, Senator Louis F. Kosko, Republican of Paramus, is chairman of the Senate Law and Public Safety Committee, where the bill will most likely be assigned.
And Mr. St. Michael, who is hoping that New Jersey's "people's prison" might be used as a model for similar prisons nationwide, said he was "100 percent sure" that the bill would ultimately become law.
"This is not a hard sell today," he said. "People are fed up. They're looking over their shoulder every time they go shopping. Nobody's safe anymore. And they want a change."

PUB-DATE: January 16, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Technology;
Virginia's Electronic Village

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: BLACKSBURG, Va.

 BODY:
WHILE others toil on and talk about national information superhighways, an unusual town-and-gown alliance is paving an electronic country lane here. The Blacksburg Electronic Village, now in the early stages, is intended to tie many of the 35,000 residents of this university town in the foothills of the Blue Ridge mountains to each other and to the world at large by means of a computer network. Just how many electronic villagers actually sign on will become clearer as the project unfolds.
Forget about visions of full-motion video and summoning "Gone With the Wind" on a whim. This bookish system will deal only in text. But it will let users send electronic mail worldwide via the Internet and give them access to thousands of bulletin boards. And through use of specialized software called Gopher, Blacksburg's electronic villagers will be able to hunt for books, documents and software scattered on thousands of computers at universities and government agencies. 
 And in a very literal application of the "electronic town meeting" concept, Blacksburgians will be able to peruse the minutes of town council sessions, keep track of various meeting schedules, communicate with local government officials and maybe even conduct referendums on key issues.
The reason that Blacksburg, rather than some other mid-size rural town, is joining the global village is simple: Virginia Tech. The Virginia Polytechnic Institute utterly dominates the town, with 8,500 of its 23,500 students living on campus and thousands of others scattered in apartments in and around town.
Add in faculty, staff and support services, and there are few people in town not involved with the university. "There is probably no one in the corporate limits of town that is not connected directly or indirectly with Virginia Tech," said Ronald A. Secrest, the town manager.
This results in a compact, relatively isolated community filled with an unusually high percentage of computer-literate people. That made it attractive to the Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Company, which is seeking to measure the public's demand for data services and the higher-capacity lines they are expected to require. C.& P. is owned by the Bell Atlantic Corporation, one of the most aggressive regional Bell companies when it comes to developing new types of information networks.
C.& P. has joined in an alliance with Virginia Tech and the town of Blacksburg to install high-speed, digital lines to apartment buildings, which largely house older students, and to public access locations, like libraries. Eventually, if demand warrants, the network may be extended to town offices, off-campus faculty homes and other locations.
"The whole Blacksburg Electronic Village is a test of when, and under what circumstances, people will demand information services," said John W. Knapp Jr., C.& P.'s director of partnership initiatives. "The town may be a precursor of the society at large."
Students who live on campus, and faculty members in their offices, already have direct computer connections to the university's local area network. Those off campus, however, have typically been forced to tap into the net through dial-up modems that send data over phone lines, a much slower procedure.
Kai Xu, a third-year electrical engineering student who lives off campus and is not yet part of the electronic village, said he regularly logs on to the university's network via modem to check for news, homework assignments, correct answers to previous assignments and messages. But "I don't download very often; with a 14.4-kilobit line it just takes too long," Mr. Xu said of his modem setup, which sends and receives data at 14,400 bits a second.
Luckier are the students who live in apartments already connected to the high-capacity optical-fiber and coaxial copper lines that C.& P. is installing in Blacksburg. "It's fiber to the basement and coaxial cables from there up," Mr. Knapp said. "We have about 700 apartment units wired up now." The lines have almost 1,000 times the data transmission capacity of Mr. Xu's modem.
The telephone company is providing high-capacity service free of charge for the rest of the current semester, which ends this spring, to see how much use people make of it and how valuable it becomes to them. "At the end of the semester, we'll ask them what they would be willing to pay for it," Mr. Knapp said. "That way we'll be able to determine whether it will be economically viable."
If demand warrants, the project's developers would proceed with plans to extend the network.
It is a function of planning, not mere chance, that the early testing is being done in student apartments filled with aspiring engineers. "We need a success with the initial group," said Irving Blythe, Virginia Tech's vice president for information services.
But everyone connected with the project knows the real test will come later, when people without technical backgrounds attempt to hook into the network. "My attitude is that I should be able to turn it on, put in the software and it works," said Kay Kriz, an administrator at the university. "Somebody said, it should be as easy to use as a toaster."
Such talk worries Andrew Cohill, the university official who is handling the technical parts of the project. He said people will have to be patient, as the bugs are worked out of the system.
"It's like the telephone was 100 years ago," he said. "You had to learn how to turn the crank to generate power to contact an operator. That's where we are now with computer networking. People will still have to get their hands dirty for the next two or three years."
One of the causes of soiled hands, Mr. Cohill said, is communications problems between remote personal computers and the Hewlett-Packard HP9000 computer on campus that controls the network. "In testing we found that it worked 80 to 90 percent of the time," Mr. Cohill said. "But we did have a lot of frustrated people. We hope that by providing telephone support we can get people over the bumps of the first week."
The good news, Mr. Cohill adds, is that once a communications link has been established, it usually does not require further attention.
THOSE who can ignore the technical details have the leisure of conjuring visions of what life will be like in an interactive town. Mr. Secrest, for example, the town manager, sees the electronic village as an economic development tool.
"It may be able to overcome our geographic isolation and attract high-technology research companies," he said. "If they are connected, they might like the quality of life in the clean air of the Blue Ridge mountains."
Mr. Secrest said he plans to install a personal computer in the main lobby of the town hall so that people who do not have their own computers can get onto the net. He expects all town departments to be connected, as well.
And at least one local retailer, although he is not yet on-line, thinks the network will change the way people shop. "We are going to design computers into stores," said Scott Wade, head of a 13-store chain of convenience stores in the Blacksburg area that bear his name.
He would like to see people send in E-mail messages ordering canned and boxed goods, and then come to the store to pick out the meats and produce to go with the other items that have already been assembled and bagged.
